Extremely underrated game.
The art style, soundtrack, voice acting, and story are all great.
The puzzles can be a bit tough, but rewarding and there are multiple ways to solve most puzzles.

https://youtu.be/kRTRIX7UH0c?si=qrhujbCOKSCO6_mC
developer_response: Thank you so much! Our game has long survived through the love of our players, and it‚Äôs a love we‚Äôve tried to repay. Hearing how much the story and themes matter is especially touching for me. Thank you. üôèüèª

author: {'steamid': '76561198023263426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 375, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1710819810}
review:
This feels like it would make for a great claymation movie.

The puzzles/solutions can feel overly obscure, but the story, voice acting, and art direction made for a worthwhile 6 hours.
developer_response:
So glad you liked it!

I think the movie adaptation (if it happens) will be painterly 3D animation; so little is claymation these days. But claymation was a huge part of my childhood -- first Gumbi when I was a little kid, then The Nightmare Before Christmas, then the game Neverhood. There's something wonderful about the tactility and gentleness of claymation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118226673', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1481814374}
review: For a point and click I was able to do most of it intuitively which is incredibly rare. Full and active world to explore with it's own history and own desolate beauty. There are a couple properly different endings as well, which is nice.
developer_response: What a beautiful review! I'm so glad to hear that the story and worldbuilding connected so much with you. Things like Humanism, the futile War of the Four Cities, and the internecine AI politics were all drawn from such important parts of my life, it feels like a personal connection with the player when the world and its characters resonate with them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037412331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1708986374}
review:
Apr√®s avoir jou√© √† toute la s√©rie des Blackwell, √† Gemini Rue, Unavowed et The excavation of Hob's Barrow... Une nouvelle fois, un tr√®s bon opus de Wadjet Eye!
Les d√©cors et les graphismes sont sublimes, les personnages attachants et complets, l'univers passionnant et bien ficel√©, le sc√©nario ma√Ætris√© d'un bout √† l'autre. Les tenants et les aboutissants, comme l'histoire des personnages, sont distill√©s au compte goutte... √ßa nous tient en haleine et nous pousse en avant. L'ensemble se d√©voile peu √† peu, on veut en savoir plus jusqu'√† voir le mot "FIN".

Le gros b√©mol pour ma part, c'est cette vilaine habitude qu'on longtemps eut les point & click, √† savoir de privil√©gier les raisonnements tordus √† la logique ou √† l'intelligence. Certaines combinaisons d'objets, ou d'actions √† encha√Æner sont tellement illogiques ou tir√©es par les cheveux au premier abord, que j'ai eu recours √† une soluce quasi d√®s le d√©but du jeu. J'ai pris plaisir malgr√© tout, parce que le jeu est vraiment superbe et bien √©crit, mais pfffff... C'est souvent pas le cerveau qui r√©sout une √©nigme, mais plut√¥t le fait d'essayer toutes les combinaisons possibles jusqu'√† trouver la bonne. Dommage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088243363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 223, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1707320284}
review:
Really cool point-and-click adventure!
The world building is really awesome, and as the story progresses and you uncover more of the history, everything feels more epic and more grand than it first looked. The voice acting is superb, the art is well done, and the design of the puzzles were pretty cool. Big shout out to the council code section because I enjoyed all the puzzles in that section a lot. Although at times there were some pixel hunting in some areas, I eventually didn't mind them because some of the other puzzles were really nice. I also like how even though some choices you make greatly affect small parts of the game, the game is short enough (around 4 to 5 hours) that you can play again and find the "best" choices to get an even better outcome.
Highly recommend! A different and fresh way of telling a cool story.
developer_response: Thank you so much! Wonderful review to read, and really appreciate also that you streamed the game! It means a lot to me to hear players who enjoy the game's story, puzzles, and world-building, and I'm grateful when folks help share it with others!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068418619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1707355830}
review:
Is it just me or the puzzles are needlessly obtuse in comparison to other games? I LOVED Gemini Rue and got into this one because I was genuinely intrigued. I sadly cannot recommend it, at all. My last straw was the  [spoiler] monocle screen puzzle, got it up to that Redlien prompt, [/spoiler] but hit a brick wall after that. I was determined to brute force it but it ended up feeling like a waste of time. Other puzzles that I ended up figuring out were also leaving a lackluster feeling, like there was no reason to make it work that specific way other than making it convoluted for the sake of it. TLDR I didn't feel proud i just felt frustrated after finishing half of the puzzles [/spoiler] (like the subway door and the "sticky" bomb.) [/spoiler]. Overall the experience got less and less fun with each step.

[spoiler]  After throwing the towel I consulted a guide and found out the word I was missing was ART, somehow that had to be deduced from the  result for "Redlien", because it was a poem and a poem is ART... Not gonna lie this royaly pissed me off, how is ART a valid prompt where before all others were capitalized and also all prompts had a very direct or clearly implied connection to what was displayed on screen. I could have kept going after reading the guide but felt cheated [/spoiler]

Besides that, general navigation felt frustrating, something that did not happen with Gemini Rue. Having to  pixel hunt the exit for a room is not what I'd call compelling design. There were also issues with a logics puzzle that I endlessly had to repeat to write down all the information needed to progress, with no option to streamline the whole process. It wasn't a bad puzzle per se, but the execution ended up being annoying and  after figuring it out I was left feeling frustrated instead of proud.

Edit for developer: I think you missed the point of the review, I love more complex point & click games, I've been playing point and click adventure games my whole life but this is the first time -even after reading a guide- the solution seemed forced or even pretentious. And again, mechanically, the game could've used a lot more polish on the UX side.

The hint system was also hit or miss, the hint were not as relevant as I would have hoped and after some time and a healthy amount of compounded frustration I started to question why it was included in the first place. Not ONCE it helped me, instead Crispin just spouted something I already knew at that point.

I REALLY wanted to like this game but sadly I cannot recommend it. I did love the art though.
developer_response: Sorry you didn't enjoy it! It's definitely less streamlined than other point-and-click adventures, and I know that for those who prefer simpler puzzles and a pure narrative focus, that can be frustrating. Appreciate that you gave it a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996690770', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1706676371}
review:
An extremely good pnc. Great art, characters, writing, music, and puzzles. World building is well done and interesting to learn more of over time. Voice acting is full, very well done and makes the game stronger.

Some of the puzzles can be a little pixel hunty, but for the most part are not. The hint system with Crispin is actually quite good at balancing between nudge and just giving you the answer. Pen and paper are helpful for some late game puzzles, especially if going for the true ending.

If you like the genre, this should be in your library
developer_response: Thank you so much! James and I spend an ungodly amount of time on that hint system, so it always warms my heart to hear that it did a player some good! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197963515074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1706250271}
review:
A wonderful point and click adventure game that leaves you thinking about it when you're not playing it. It does so much with so little, drops you right in an interesting world with beautifully written and well voiced characters. Highlights for me:
- Your buddy-bot as both a hint provider and friend.
- The limited set of interactions and non-punishment for experimenting. Sometimes even your bad ideas bring unexpected surprises with little dialogue treats.
- The pacing and changing focus of the player's story, leaving a lot to the imagination for most of the time.

My only quibbles are that some of the steps ramp up into being pretty difficult and harder to piece together as the game progresses, and sometimes I wanted a slightly less in-my-face UX for the inventory.

Strongly recommended if you want a nice, short, but fulfilling adventure. If I had more time I would have tried to complete it in a single sitting, but it probably ran in total 5 hours for me and was just the right length.
developer_response: Thank you so much! I'm very happy to say that we came up with some better UX for item usage in Strangeland, though the UIs are perhaps still overbearing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051484615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1705361650}
review:
Fun little adventure game with an interesting backstory. 

Pros:
+ Decent puzzles with a good variety. Most on the easy side
+ Interesting scifi setting
+ Decent story
+ Good voiceover work
+ Multiple endings

Cons:
- Unfortunately, this game falls into the all-too-familiar adventure game trap of "hunt the pixel". Multiple puzzles require you to notice and click on a tiny clickable area in order to advance, none of which are ever hinted at or called out by the characters. This is made even worse by the samey color palette meaning noticing these one-pixel-wide areas is extremely difficult.
- Brown/gray color palette + lack of any stunning vista-type locations means the scifi setting is wasted a little bit. There's no area in the game that looks particularly impressive or makes you say "wow"
- Story, while decent, is incredibly predictable. If you've experienced any type of scifi at all you already have figured out the entire backstory of the game within the first five minutes. This leaves the game without any real twist, which is unfortunate as the game builds it up as if one is coming but it never does
- On the short side, even for an adventure game
- Nitpicky (spoilers)- there's one puzzle that requires you to click on a specific part of the screen that does not even contain a textual indicator that its different from any other part of the scene. I'm talking about finding the battery in the junkyard. Despite almost the whole scene being described as "junk" without any additional description dialogue, you're supposed to someone intuit this one specific spot will work with your energy locator despite the lack of any textual or audio indicator that it would. This is even more egregious given that all prior junkyard items have specific descriptive text for their locations. I'd go so far as to call this a bug that should be fixed.
developer_response:
Thanks for your thoughtful review! The criticism about pixel hunting and hard-to-read art is fair; there's explanations for why it's that way, but ultimately it's frustrating for most players. I'm glad despite your issues with the graphics and predictability you enjoyed it overall!

On the specific junkpile puzzle you mention, though, I think your critique is slightly off. Unless something is bugged, there *is* an audio cue: a ping that accelerates the closer you get to the energy source -- here's an LP video at that point where you can hear the ping https://youtu.be/ZN_mnbl4fP0?list=PLzg_vZBrP9ng5q8gGWjE8oPdJ-Zk9-4oI&t=1700. (If it's bugged, we'll be sure to fix it.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198040781735', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1705379575}
review: First, a caveat: I played this almost entirely with the help of a walk-through. I'm not good at abstract thinking but I knew this game with its strong narrative, evocative art style, and lovely soundtrack was something I wanted to experience in full. So if for no other reason than not enjoying the gameplay (which is a me thing to be clear), I'd still recommend this game, just make sure you have a walk-through handy for when it gets tough!
developer_response: Thanks so much for sticking it out and for such kind words!

author: {'steamid': '76561198092127187', 'num_games_owned': 715, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1705377549}
review:
Man is gone, all that remains are robots. Starting as one of those robots named Horatio your power core is stolen which is what kicks off the game, your primary objective being to retrieve it. An intricate point-and-click adventure game follows with a compelling story and unique, engaging puzzles. While Primordia does feature the standard point-and-click puzzles(combining things in inventory, interacting with objects, using inventory items on outside things) there‚Äôs a logic to each that makes sense. The actions taken aren‚Äôt out of left field and are things someone might reasonably think of. While it is sometimes a bit obtuse in how exactly it has to go and the proper order, compared to similar games in the genre it is quite intuitive, largely avoiding the most unnecessary parts, In subsequent playthroughs you might forget a step or two, and try something but that is a result of you knowing already, a first playthrough won‚Äôt have this problem. The game features some minor choice dialogue though much of the story remains the same until the endings, these choices can affect achievements or how certain robots treat/help you.

Dealing with heavy themes, the game is interested in religion and creation and how these ideas are allowed to exist in society. Man is a stand-in here for god and is directly called god by some characters this layer of abstraction grounds the game in the real world and keeps it distinct enough to not be bogged down too much, it is respectful of each party as well. Aside from creation, the game delves into destruction, how did man die exactly is a question that the game presents. Collective vs individual need is also a theme and each side isn‚Äôt exactly going about things in the best way, the proper answer to this is ambiguous and you might have your take on it based on the endings, I‚Äôm not sure which is correct or if I did the correct thing.

This is all helped by some great writing, characters are real people with their ideals and motives, not always willing to help out especially if you can‚Äôt prove yourself. The game while heavy also has some nice comedy added in, especially from the sarcastic side-kick Crispin who is a great contrast to the more serious Horatio. Later characters can feel equally serious or comedic and in some instances perhaps not all there. A particularly interesting character speaks only in rhymes, and not always great rhymes.

Taking place in a sort of post-apocalypse and post-man world the world is quite ugly, largely brown and rust as the world is filthy and lived in, despite having pixel graphics the art style conveys this very well, most of the robots appear rugged and like their made from lose scarp and parts as opposed to the more sleek looks that are often seen with robots. Some interactable items allow you to look closely at them, giving a close-up picture for more added detail which further adds to this aesthetic.

Unfortunately, the soundtrack is rather simple and largely lacking, mainly featuring the same theme repeated it adds nothing to the world and is mostly forgettable.

It is not often that a game makes me think about my actions and if what I‚Äôm doing is correct, there is often an obvious good or evil answer but here there is seemingly none, and that adds a great deal to its story. I‚Äôll be thinking about it for some time.

[h1]‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ[/h1]
developer_response: What a wonderful review to read -- it fills me with pride to hear that the characters, story, and themes resonated with you. And it's always great to hear from a puzzle fan! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198266874695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 495, 'last_played': 1476767936}

developer_response: What a beautiful review. So glad to have haunted your memories! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198010131797', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1705095055}
review: extremely good point&click adventure game. The story is gripping, the characters are extremely well written, the world is polished and you really can feel a part of it. The puzzles are all well thought, I haven't found a single one where I was confused or the solution felt illogical or straight up dumb, and if you struggle you always can ask your flying companion for help. One of the best adventure games I played (and I played A LOT of them).
developer_response: Thank you so much! Always nice when a player finds the puzzles logical and the hint system helpful -- put a ton of time into those (the coder and I spent ages getting the hint system to work right), so it means a lot when they pan out. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198032325550', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 594, 'last_played': 1704830632}
review:
Incredible game.

Update after Dev's answer:

After Mark's (the developer) response to this linguistic rampage above, I felt ashamed of my short review. 

Primordia is a masterpiece of independent development, creative spirit and beauty. Beauty in every screen, character, and dialog. I can't believe I was able to once again get emotions similar to the dynamic between Nameless One and Morte. 

Primordia is one of those "made for you personally" games. A few people can make art that stays with you forever. I'd like to separately mention the incredible soundtrack - I've been listening to it since 2012, from time to time.

I've only just gotten through the game - I was hampered by OCD, because the default settings had an ugly filter and the game didn't look the way I wanted it to on the screen. But this is purely an engine problem. I didn't like any of the settings. 

But the most current version looks different by default - I'm happy to have enjoyed this game, after 12 years of wanting to do so.

I will definitely go through the rest of this team's games.

P.S. I wish I could have helped the sad robot. I totally agree with the premise of that scene though :)
developer_response: Many thanks -- especially from someone with the good taste for FO:NV!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018509293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 269, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1704829777}

author: {'steamid': '76561198210504620', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1704755330}
review: A fantastic point and click adventure with such an interesting and compelling story that really keeps you hooked. The main character Horatio and his hilarious and cheeky sidekick Crispin, are so engaging and really capture your heart. I first played this back in 2022, and it had been on my mind recently so I went back for a second play through this first week of 2024, and all I can say is that I've had a blast both times.  Very fun, if frustrating at times, but overall brilliant and definitely one I will keep coming back to over the years.
developer_response: Thank you so much for your beautiful words about our little game! I'm very proud of that story and those characters, and so gratified you connected with them!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970786561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1704682369}

Dennoch denke ich, dass das, was sich Spieler von der Welt vorstellen k√∂nnen, besser ist als jede Fortsetzung ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198989761658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 378, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1703652701}

author: {'steamid': '76561198111237070', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1704042462}
review:
A great game. Art style, voice acting(which surprised me because I expected none), writing, story, OST, endings - all amazing. I have to admit some puzzles were quite difficult to do and I had to look up a guide a few times, but the fault was mine for not getting in the game well enough. One thing I can complain about is the aspect ratio of the game and having to stretch the game visuals to fill in a whole modern monitor's screen.

I must replay the game. Not soon but in the future, because I couldn't immerse myself in it before the ending section. Right at the end it dawned on me - I was playing a banger of a game.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words about the game, and about each of its parts -- we really had a great team for it, and we're even more lucky to have such great fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198046202248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1704006050}
review:
Primordia is a Point & Click Adventure masterpiece that might just be too good for its own sake.
Stunning art direction, top notch writing and phenomenal voice performances and direction create a compelling package from start to finish. 
And with the duo of Logan Cunningham and Abe Goldfarb in the leading roles, you're in for a treat!

But Primordia has one, big issue: 
It is so good with its world building and lore crafting that it will inevitably leave you wanting more.
The world is so rich that, in a perfect world, it supports an entire series of games.

And i'll never give up hope, because as our friends over at the stranded space factory engineer game know:
Factor must grow ;)
developer_response: Ha! Thanks so much! I don't expect to write a sequel, but I did do a spin-off story back in the day (https://www.primordia-game.com/fallen.html) which might give you a little more to chew on. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197971069016', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1665319136}
review: Amazing game with a unique atmosphere. Recommended for all fans of adventure games.
developer_response: On behalf of the whole team, thank you so much! Was a blast to create that team with such a talented bunch of teammates!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042424905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1703805332}
review: Good story. Puzzles are on the harder side compared to the other Wadjet Eye Games I have played (e.g. Technobabylon, Gemini Rue.) Map works well, data pad is too small - so take your own notes. That said, whatever the Data pad stores is a clue in itself.
developer_response: Many thanks for the kind words! So glad you enjoyed the story -- it was fun to write! -- and that you noticed the tougher puzzles. I toned them down a bit for Strangeland, for better and worse.

author: {'steamid': '76561199275378584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1701200526}
review:
A cyberpunk point-and-click adventure game, Primordia is set in a post-apocalyptic world with the player controlling an android, Horatio Nullbuilt. Horatio is aided by his robot companion, Crispin.

The game finds the duo trying to retrieve a item stolen from them at the beginning of the game, and sees them travel through the wasteland to a nearby metropolis, which is filled with robots and governed by an A.I.

Primordia was development by Wormwood Studios and published by Wadjet Eye Games, one of my favourite publishers for this style of game. Overall it is an excellent title, which I very much enjoyed and look forward to playing through again. I recommend this to anyone who enjoys adventure games in a cyberpunk setting.
developer_response: Thank you so much! We're grateful that players continue to find and enjoy this adventure we created so many years ago! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997412327', 'num_games_owned': 375, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1703564098}

author: {'steamid': '76561198259338671', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1703561745}
review:
I want to start by saying the art is beautiful, which is a big part of why I picked up the game in the first place.

Unfortunately, the art style was a major hindrance to enjoying the game as well. Trying to figure out what I was looking at at any given time was a bit headache inducing.

The UI was fiddly, and some of the game's mechanics were very obscure. I didn't find the puzzles particularly satisfying, either - many were quite simple, and the ones that weren't were a bit too abstract for my taste.

On top of that, the plot didn't grab me even after getting all the endings. Also, I have a low tolerance for certain tropes from 1970-90s sci-fi, and this game was full of them.

Loved the premise and the art, but the game wasn't worth it for me.
developer_response: Sorry you didn't enjoy it, and all of those are very legitimate points of criticism. (How they balance for different players is unique to the individual, of course.) Feel bad we let you down, but I'm glad you gave it a go.

review: A wonderful adventure game! The atmosphere is great, it is well acted, and the puzzles were never too hard. One of my all time favorite point-and-click games. Right up there with Full Throttle, Syberia, The Dig, etc. Thanks for the wonderful game!
developer_response: Thank you so much! Those are some true classics to be compared to, and it's a great honor for our game to be listed alongside them!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009671664', 'num_games_owned': 553, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1702119653}
review:
Had this game for a while but never really truly sat down and played it.
Picked it up again recently and have been playing it non-stop, really nice game but difficult at some points for people who aren't point-and-click savvy.
developer_response: "Playing it non-stop" is always great to hear!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038332369', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1702096336}
review:
Good game. Nothing mind-blowing, but a pretty fun point and click adventure game. 

It falls victim to a few common adventure game problems such as logic that probably only makes sense to the developers, clues pointing in slightly confusing directions, or instances where the "hotbox," for important interactable items were small enough where i didnt find them without a walkthrough. Thankfully though, these are super rare so it didn't impact my enjoyment of the game much.

The voice acting is great, characters were fun, art design was great, and the overall story was pretty ok. It'll likely go into the "I'm going to forget I played this game a year from now," category, but I certainly don't regret it.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it overall -- hope it leaves more of an impression than you expect, but even if not, I appreciate that you gave it a go!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026019837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 850, 'last_played': 1508105303}
review:
Lovely art, fantastic story. Really great game.

Edit: 

To be clear this game really stuck with me, the story of our protagonist and the exploration of self and consciousness, really exploring some of the interesting ideas to come out of machine intelligence, the post apocalyptic and ancient feel to the world. I posted a review after not having played in ages because its a piece of art that really stuck with me, and I think it will always stick with me. 

So to Wormwood studios, thank you.
developer_response: Thank you so much! It means a lot to hear that players connected with our creation!

author: {'steamid': '76561198020935870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1701807216}
review: Many parts of the game surprised me. The quality of writing, voice acting, backgrounds, and worldbuilding are the stand out features, but even the usual adventure game bulls-logic was fairly tamed. When it comes to puzzles and clarity of direction, not every single moment is amazing, but the game works so smoothly and bug-free it's more than excusable. A great point-and-click game.
developer_response: Thank you so much -- I loved the world you built for Road Warden, and I'm so glad to read that you loved the world we built for Primordia! Very proud of its story, world, and characters, and of the whole team who came together to bring that to life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198339603186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1701473229}
review: Very thought-provoking. A little difficult to complete without a guide, but well worth it for the story and the voice acting.
developer_response:
Thank you -- "very thought provoking" is music to a writer's ears! The story, world, and characters are near and dear to my heart (and largely a composite of people I've loved over the years), so it means the world when they connect with a player.

(Totally agreed on the voice acting! I'm so grateful to the team of voice actors, Nathaniel composing, and Vic on the art for their roles in bringing the whole thing to life.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198053420362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1701300830}
review: This has been sitting in my library for years but if I had known what a treasure Primordia is I would've played it right off the bat after purchasing.
developer_response:
Well, depending how many years ago, you would've missed out on many enhancing patches that James and I did over the last decade (in particular, a big one about a year and a half after release), so maybe it's for the best!

I'm so glad, though, after all this time I brought you joy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989832598', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1701646906}

author: {'steamid': '76561198125076904', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1702037885}

author: {'steamid': '76561198011581104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1701124193}
review: Master crafted dystopic story telling, world building, art style, music, and voice work. This kind of future seems even more possible now than ever. Get...Primed...for the future.
developer_response: Ha! Thank you so much for the kind words about the story! I confess that when I wrote about robot lawyers and judges, I little suspected the ChatGPT shenanigans going on barely a decade later! Still, I retain hope that we will fare better than our counterparts in Primordia and hold onto more than just dreams of green. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197968589305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1703158677}
review:
Got this game as a gift and I really tried. Love the voice acting and art style but absolutely hate the puzzles. Barely even got started, reached the robot's head and that's it. Been trying for almost two hours now, scouring every single location pixel for pixel and trying to combine every single thing in my inventory since none of the logical solutions seem to work. This is precisely what killed the point-and-click adventure genre in the first place.

At this point, even if I looked up the solution online, I have reached the point where I can no find any reason to play this any further because of the sheer frustration. The idea of having a sidekick drop hints is only useful of the hints actually help; I *know* I have to block the second nostril as well, the question is *how*.
developer_response: Sorry you had such a bad experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198077186000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1673333432}

author: {'steamid': '76561198186530370', 'num_games_owned': 2631, 'num_reviews': 570, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1700052732}
review:
If the dream of humanity comes true, will there be anyone around to witness it?

Condition: Doomsday

The world ended decades ago. There seem to be no organic beings left, and even the great machines of the Primordium, the fabled golden age of creation and the reign of Man the All-Builder, are falling into rust and ruin. Our hero is Horatio Nullbuilt, v.5, a robot who has set before himself a rather ambitious task: to restore the world, no more, no less - starting with a majestic airship, the UNNIIC (pronounced ‚Äúunique‚Äù ‚Äì who needs proper spelling?) lying in the wasteland for as long as anyone remembers. And then an unexpected turn of events sends him and his friend Crispin to chase a formidable enemy across the desolation and even farther away.

The game is simply perfect. The writing has a precise rhythm, a perfect cadence brought to life by celebrated voice actors. The setting is fantastical but internally consistent, which is crucial for puzzle solving. It features high-tech tools that work on more-or-less scientific principles, so the puzzles are refreshing in their originality. For once, you will have a plasma torch and a scintillation counter instead of the usual pair of wrench and screwdriver.

Hand-painted backgrounds in the baroque railgun-gothic style highlight the stark beauty of the post-apocalyptic world, and it‚Äôs simply amazing how evocative and sympathetic pixellized characters can be. Not only they crack tech jokes and color their speech with peculiar jargon; they behave like *robots*, not humans in metal suits. Figuring out a robot‚Äôs logic, the goals and constraints of its Artificial Intelligence is just as important as keeping your plasma torch close at hand.


‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not our property or our problem.‚Äù

This quote is emblematic of the puzzles, and, indeed, the plot structure of the game. Primordia treats its characters and you, the player, with respect: you won't be doing nonsensical things or picking up random items. It is a game that rewards intelligence, creativity and logic, not lucky guessing and a mastery of web search.

And if you‚Äôre stuck, you can ask Crispin for a hint. The game does not penalize this ‚Äì why should you be discouraged from asking a friend for help? The hint system is precise and elegant; and you‚Äôll be delighted by insightful, funny and heartwarming exchanges between characters. (And, of course, the hints contain no spoilers that could have ruined the game‚Äôs intricate mysteries.)


‚ÄúOne more setting‚Ä¶‚Äù

By adjusting the graphics settings, you can make Primordia look awesome on a screen of any resolution, without stretching and artifacts. The engine supports letterboxing (5:4), pillarboxing (16:9), windowboxing with integer scaling (any) and, of course, total immersion fullscreen (16:10). It is also playable in a window if you so desire.

Primordia does not use unstable external plugins; all special effects are custom-coded by the talented developers at Wormwood Studios, so if you are able to run AGS games on your computer at all, you will be able to play this game.


‚ÄúWe are Man‚Äôs miracle, Crispin. Let‚Äôs hope that‚Äôs enough.‚Äù

The central mystery is *fair*; you can figure it out early (not "guess because you have seen/read/played something similar - it's rather unique), in which case the mystery becomes dreaded anticipation, and the plot *works*: if anything, the little "I see what you did there" details enhance the experience even further.

There's a widespread notion that a person must read/watch/otherwise experience specific artworks before he or she dies. And that notion is plain wrong. The time one spends *not having experienced* a great work of art is the time they have wasted. Buy this game now.

Primordia has devious enemies, unexpected allies, and indifferent mechanical gods. It‚Äôs a game about what it takes to pull civilization from the brink, and what it takes to make you want to push it down. It‚Äôs a game about truth and hope, law and duty, justice and vengeance. It‚Äôs a game about what it means to be human. (Who‚Äôd have thought you need robots for that?)

[no professional reviewer disclaimers here ‚Äì I paid for my copy, thankyouverymuch]
developer_response: Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032994830', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1908, 'last_played': 1699205249}
review:
Now THIS is an adventure!!!
Its one of those rare games you think about even month after finishing it. The story is just fantastic. They could have just as easily made a film out of this story. Fascinating, mysterious, sometimes disturbing.

The puzzles are well made and logical. Some puzzles are a bit harder but they are optional for a different ending so you can skip them but get rewarded if you choose to solve them.

The cast of narrators is excellent, every one of them.

The music and graphic style are awesome and fit the dystopian athmospere perfectly.

All in all this is just the perfect adventure.
developer_response:
What a great review to wake up to! I take a lot of pride in the story and puzzles -- and I know all of us (from voice actors to composer to artist) are grateful for players leaving such a kind words.

A company (Marauder Film) does have an option to make a film out of the game, but (for better and/or worse) I am confident they will reshape the story and characters to fit the needs of movies, so I don't anticipate it being my characters/dialogue/story any more (any more than Abe and Logan's voices, or Vic's visuals, or Nathaniel's musical score), but something that uses the game as a leaping off point for their own creative endeavor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005432069', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1550714747}
review:
This is the best adventure game I have ever played, the only problem I have with it is I wish there was more. 

Please come out with a sequel and sidequel to this, I would play it for sure. 

The aesthetic and subject matter is chefs kiss.
developer_response:
Thanks so much!

I did write a spin-off story ("Fallen"), and some other material that you can get at www.Primordia-Game.com for free.

I don't think there will ever be a sequel or spin-off game, both because I enjoy creating new worlds too much to retread one where I already told my best stories and created my best characters, and because the coder and I are no longer working with the artist on the project and we long ago agreed not to make a sequel without everyone's sign off.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974146135', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1699028124}
review:
Pros.:
- Nice length of the game.
- Background story and story development.
- Choice-making.
- Legit difficulty.

Cons.:
- Similar to the pros. in terms of length. The game may seem short.
- It leaves similar feeling as another game - Machinarium. You want more but there isn't.
- Music is a bit simple. Could be more matching the tragedy of the world.
developer_response:
Thanks so much! I'm really glad you enjoyed the story and design -- choices were definitely an important thing for me to include (even in a small way) since I've always loved RPGs as much as adventure games.

We definitely wanted to leave people wanting more rather overstaying our welcome! My thought was always that a map with blank spaces left players plenty of room for their own imagination to run wild. I did write a spin-off story ("Fallen"), but tried to still leave a lot of the world undefined. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198056742528', 'num_games_owned': 558, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1698630999}
review:
An interesting world with nice art and ambiance that is held back in the later parts by gameplay mechanics that I found annoying.  A generalized, spoiler-free example:

Search an area top to bottom, interact with every conceivable thing.  Leave area.  Find out you need a Thing.  This Thing (which had been there the whole time) can now be found by re-searching in the previously empty rubble if you happen to go back to that area and search that bit of rubble again.  Where was it the first time?  In another dimension, apparently.

If you don‚Äôt mind puzzles like the above, you can find something to enjoy.  For me, they sapped the fun I had been having.

Edit:
Response to the developer: You're reading something into the review that isn't there; this is the opposite of metagaming.   What I described is being frustrated that what I'm looking for is in an area I already thoroughly searched.  And it's actually a pretty easy problem to avoid from a development perspective.  If there's something that I'll need later, don't make it nonexistant until I need it; either let me pick up a currently-useless thing like the hoarder I am, or lock it away in a box I need a key or tool to open and have the character comment as such (or the lazier but serviceable last resort, the character can say something like, "I'll check back on this later", etc.).  I'm not huge into point & click adventure games but I've played others (including one also published by Wadjet Eye Games, Technobabylon) where I didn't run into this issue, so it's certainly not inherent to the genre.  In any case, don't take it too personally; a guy on the internet was disappointed by something you made, but many more people had a great time with it.  You can't please all the people all the time, and I don't think the game is terrible, I just wouldn't recommend it to someone who likes the same games as myself.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn't enjoy it!

What you describe is an interesting pickle in adventure game design.  I'm not actually sure what puzzle you're describing in Primordia (maybe the fallback way of proving your righteousness to Ever-Faithful Leobuilt?), because I'm hard pressed to think of where that happens.  But it is fair to say that there are instances where -- particularly if the player is using a walkthrough or is clever enough to use adventure-game metaknowledge -- the player might want to do X before it makes any sense for the *character* to do X, and thus the game won't let the character do X.  Since the player imputes his metaknowledge to the character, it feels totally arbitrary.  (This comes up a lot with the 187th Legionbuilt puzzle regarding the Refuge Law.)  If you let the player get ahead of the character, it can present its own set of problems, so careful design is necessary to navigate both hazards.  I certainly tried my best to strike the right route in designing Primordia, but every so often it seems not to have worked for a particular player.

So, really, all I can say is sorry that your experience wasn't better! It's possible that Strangeland (our sophomore game) would be more to your liking, but who knows?

author: {'steamid': '76561198038516866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1698422669}
review: This was a good one! Puzzles provided a challenge, but they weren't overly hard, and I never found myself being completely stuck with it - like it is with so many other games. Voices were great, story was great and the characters were good. Dialogue was entertaining, graphics decent enough, interface was ...okay...ish. All in all, a recommended adventure from Woodworm / Wadjet Eye.
developer_response:
Yeah, user interfaces were made without regard to how users actually interface -- we tried our best to squeeze usability out of the artist, but he's an aesthete! :)  I think Strangeland is a little better in that regard.

So glad you enjoyed the story, puzzles, characters, and VO -- definitely all stuff we put a lot of love into!

author: {'steamid': '76561198115190680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1697852972}
review: very fun point and click game! just wish I had known at the start that you can also rIGHT CLICK THINGS. NOT JUST LEFT CLICK. AND RIGHT CLICKING IS NEEDED TO SOLVE ONE OF THE PUZZLES LIKE HALFWAY INTO THE GAME. Other than that, really cool!
developer_response:
:D

It is amazing how many players that tripped up... we just assumed everyone knew those controls from back in the 90s.  When the issue was first reported, we added the How to Play section to the options menu and put controls on the first page.  But players still got tripped up, so we added a timer (I think 10 minutes) and if you haven't used right click when it expires, it gives you a pop up message telling you about right click to examine.  But I think a lot of players still miss it (like you did).  We learned our lesson and gave an explicit, unskippable controls tutorial in Strangeland. :)

I'm glad that despite that annoyance, you still liked the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561199498151977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1697731278}

author: {'steamid': '76561198212352023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1263, 'last_played': 1697028836}
review:
Absolute gem of a point and click. Originally played this back in 2015 (ish) and held it as my favourite video game for quite a while. Replayed it just now, wondering if it'd still hold up, and it absolutely does. I think the main thing I love is that there's SO many (idle and active) voice lines, with absolutely exquisite voice acting. Yes, the point of post-apocalyptic dystopian wasteland that's all sorts of unfriendly comes well across. But the game also feels alive and makes me want to spend time with it. 
The characters are interesting, the puzzles generally make sense (within the world at least... pretend robot tech is magic sometimes), you can ask your companions for hints if you're stuck (and you can turn automatic hints off in the settings), the art is beautiful, there's a built in notebook so you don't need to physically take notes yourself (although I find that that helps for at least one puzzle). I honestly kinda don't remember the music, but blending that well into the world that you don't notice it might be the highest compliment one can give to a soundtrack?
developer_response: Thank you so much for this lovely review! I love reading about how all the parts fit together so well for you! That hint system was nightmare for James to code (as well as from a design/writing standpoint for me), so it‚Äôs always a balm to hear it helped a player engage with the game! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970355333', 'num_games_owned': 717, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1696639375}

The visuals may seem a little crude at first, but over time they grew on me and actually helped the atmosphere. Some puzzles are hard, but the game has very neat built-in help function.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003010211', 'num_games_owned': 294, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1301, 'last_played': 1696116910}
review:
What a delightful little adventure game. Albeit short, it reminds me of the old days when LucasArts and Sierra would make masterpieces of point-and-click games, but this one manages to have its own personality.

Purchased it years ago, and just recently played it, and to me it seems like it could be made last month, because it felt dynamic and up-to-date with modern retro-games.

Charismatic and captivating characters, SUPERB voice acting and a story that packs a nice punch of valors and ideals, even if it's not revolving with plot twists. Also, the puzzles are not really that hard, but the progression tree can keep you replaying the game for some time, if you're in for the achievements.

Thank you, Wadjet, for bringing us these pearls over the last years. Played the Blackwell series recently, Gemini Rue, and now Primordia, all of them totally satisfying.

Totally recommend them all!
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words and generous review! Those characters and story came from the heart, that‚Äôs for sure, so it means the world to hear when they connect with a player. And the amazing voice acting and art helped bring them to life‚Äîgrateful to WEG for the actors, especially Abe, Sarah, Logan, and Nonie‚Ä¶ I can‚Äôt imagine hearing anyone else deliver what I wrote for Crispin, Clarity, Horatio, and Metromind. It was a privilege to work with them, and together to share the characters with our fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031554859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1696073238}
review:
Waited too long to buy and play this.
Pretty straight forward point and click but with all the good qualities from other titles.
Really good story and all the puzzles are logical.

All though i like the art style sometimes the text is kind of hard to read.
developer_response:
Thank you so much! It's always great to hear from players -- so glad you liked the story and puzzles and art!

It never ceases to amuse me when we get back-to-back reviews where one says the puzzles were totally illogical and one says they were totally logical. :D Just goes to show the trickiness of adventures!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972369732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1695511303}
review:
As much as I regret this, I can't recommend this game though I loved the look of the game, the story, the characters and the voice acting.  

My problem with the game was that the puzzles were a little too illogical for my taste.  Even with the built in hint system, I found myself too many times wondering how I would have come up with some of the solutions on my own (other than the "use every object in your inventory on every other object" strategy).

Another issue involved your sidekick and, later in the game, another character that tags along.  For a game relying on pixel hunting, having extraneous characters that tend to block your view and get in the way when you are tying to interact with things gets old fast.

My final gripe was with the left click to "interact" with objects and right click to "look" at objects.  Not sure why I couldn't get the necessary information with a single click.  This screwed me up several times.

All in all, not a horrible game and, for some, the story alone may be worth the price of admission.  For me, I wanted to be entertained by the puzzles and was not.
developer_response:
Sorry you had a mixed experience, but I really appreciate your taking the time to leave feedback! I‚Äôve not heard the companion-blocking-hotspot issue before, so that‚Äôs a good thing to throw in the hopper. 

Our second game, Strangeland, has more straightforward puzzles, stronger hints in the hint system, and no companions, so it might be more up your alley. 

But, regardless, I also am grateful for the kind words about the game‚Äôs story and other features. Just sorry it didn‚Äôt all come together for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038451933', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1695377524}

author: {'steamid': '76561198032411193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1694789108}
review:
A Phenomenal point and click adventure game! It's three strongest aspects are:
+writing, 
+art and design, 
+voice acting. (Truly excellent, I especially love Crispin's banter!)

Puzzles are mostly good, though sometimes I'm mashing everything together in my inventory. Crispin (your sidekick) is very helpful with little hints if you interact with him enough.

-the pixel hunting is not egregious here, but a button to highlight all hotspots could be a nice accessibility feature
(On a personal note, I wish I had remembered to use my map in the city to fast travel around, so here is your reminder)
 
Game length is about 4ish hours if you are moving quickly, but there is tons of fully voice acted optional dialogue which fleshes out the world, its characters and your playtime. 
I like the soundtrack a lot too, very atmospheric.

Again the English voice acting is just amazing, loved my time in Primordia!
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words! The whole team poured our hearts into it‚Äîincluding the amazing voice actors (Abe Goldfarb was Crispin, and plays like 12 roles in our second game, Strangeland). I know the story wouldn‚Äôt have had the same impact without them and the art!

author: {'steamid': '76561198161075252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1607413562}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972389049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 458, 'last_played': 1693043570}
review: I loved Strangeland, and I b'soding loved this too. Drips atmosphere, features genuinely interesting and diverse characters and has just right amount of wry jokes from your sidekick. Good mix of simple and tough but satisfying puzzles to figure out but there were a couple I didn't understand what to do or how to get started. (Didn't realise I could use Crispin after trying the wrong way) Looking up a guide for the first hint/answer in a series helped to tune into the dev's wavelength and solve it. Thematically sound with similar philosophical questions in the same vein as Soma, Planescape and Deus Ex, which I didn't expect but enjoyed. Great game guys!
developer_response:
Thank you so much -- those characters, jokes, puzzles, and themes are all near and dear to my heart (as is "b'sod," probably the wordplay that will be my epitaph)!  I don't think Crispin's jokes would've landed nearly so well, though, without the amazing work of Abe Goldfarb in the role.  A master actor, and it still boggles me that Crispin and Strangeland's Superego adversary are the same voice.

PS:T and Deus Ex are games I adored, and PS:T in particular had a huge impact on me.  (I assume its influence is apparent on Strangeland as well.)  I still haven't played Soma, but I've heard great things about it, and it's on my bucket list.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994578911', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 1057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1016, 'last_played': 1693676847}

author: {'steamid': '76561198827965854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1692137425}
review:
Primordia, a masterpiece among point-and-click games, has undoubtedly captured the essence of what makes this genre so captivating. Seamlessly merging humor, awe-inspiring storytelling, and thought-provoking themes, it stands as a testament to the heights that interactive storytelling can achieve.

For those of us who hold a special place in our hearts for the pixelated adventures of the 90s, Primordia serves as both a nostalgic throwback and a testament to the enduring quality of classic game design. It's heartwarming to see that the spirit of those beloved, retro games has been channeled into crafting a modern experience that retains the charm and creativity of its predecessors.

One of the most remarkable aspects of Primordia is its intricate narrative. The game masterfully weaves together humor, drama, and philosophical exploration, prompting players to ponder profound questions while navigating a world of wit and wonder. This seamless blend of emotions and intellectual engagement is a rare gem in the gaming world.

Even for those who might be new to the world of point-and-click adventures, Primordia stands as a shining example of what the genre can offer. Its user-friendly mechanics and intuitive puzzles make it accessible to all, while its rich storyline and captivating characters ensure that players of all backgrounds can immerse themselves fully in the experience.

In my gaming journey, Primordia has rekindled my passion for classic adventures while introducing me to a world that feels both familiar and refreshingly new. The attention to detail, the clever puzzles, and the beautifully crafted environments all come together to create an experience that is undeniably enchanting. It's more than just a game; it's an odyssey through imagination.

To all those seeking a gaming experience that seamlessly bridges the gap between nostalgia and innovation, I wholeheartedly recommend Primordia. It's a rare gem that sparkles brightly in the realm of point-and-click adventures, and its ability to evoke emotions and stir intellectual curiosity is truly commendable. Playing Primordia was an absolute delight, and I am confident that others will find themselves similarly captivated by its magic.
developer_response:
What a beautiful review -- and it means so much to read such kind words about the game's writing and narrative. It's a personal story, so when people connect with it, I feel like I've connected with them.

That said, the impact of the narrative owes a lot to the amazing voice actors delivering the lines, and the music and graphics that bring the whole scene to life. I can't imagine anyone other than Abe portraying Crispin or anyone other than Sarah portraying Clarity, two characters particularly near and dear to my heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198314667516', 'num_games_owned': 161, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1692080222}
review: absolutely wonderful game! STUNNING art, interesting story, great world/atmosphere, wonderful soundtrack that really sells the desolate world its set in, and fun characters- literally everything a point and click game could possibly hope to be. sometimes obtuse and hints are often too vague, but once i could get a hint from an outside source to get started i could usually figure things out. runs perfectly on deck + cool robots, what could be better???
developer_response: Thank you so much! Love to hear when the game connects with a player, and I‚Äôm glad James‚Äôs work porting it to Steam Deck made the experience even better!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012126754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2108, 'last_played': 1692129510}
review: I like this game but I'm giving up on all Wadjet Eye games because they keep releasing new patches that make your old saves no longer work.  What's the point of playing these games if at any moment they might release a patch that means you have to start the game over from the beginning?  Life's too short to be fiddling about with video games much anyway, let alone having to restart one because of amateur programmers who can't keep old saves compatible with a new patch.
developer_response: It has to do with the engine the games are made in. The way it saves games is with a memory dump, and if the game‚Äôs memory usage changes, the saves don‚Äôt work. I‚Äôm pretty sure you can roll back to the pre-patched version using the Steam beta features, and we can also send you saves to the new build. Ultimately not patching the game would mean no translations and substantially reduced compatibility (not to mention no bug fixes). But I realize this is a frustration for players and sorry you had to deal with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003010934', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1692061884}
review:
I don't like P&C games, but this one looked promising with such positive reviews and a great aesthetic. I should have kept my distance. Just another mashup of bizarre and obtuse puzzles that make basically no sense. In most games with puzzle, I tend to think a bit, have an epiphany, then solve it. In this game, I think about it, can't figure it out, then click all over everything, then ask for a hint, then click on everything again, then try every inventory item on everything, then realize Crispin can do stuff (thanks for not telling me that, game), then try Crispin on everything, etc. Then, when the solution occurs I'm not like 'oh wow, I should have known, duh!' like most challenging puzzle games; instead I think 'What the hell was that?' 

So, just like every other P&C game, if you're not on the same wavelength as the devs, it's basically impossible to solve. I don't have the patience for the tedium needed to push through this, despite the narrative, positive reviews, and aesthetic. Sorry.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn‚Äôt like it. I think it‚Äôs fair to say that the P&C genre largely has non-puzzle interactions or ‚Äúwavelength‚Äù issues that you describe. How else to explain why some players say Primordia has super-logical puzzles while others say nonsensical? The metaphor I usually use is language‚Äîthe developer and the player are trying to have a conversation, but often one side can‚Äôt make their meaning known to the other. That‚Äôs true even when you share a language; and when a dev that grew up ‚Äúspeaking‚Äù adventure games of the 90s is communicating with players who didn‚Äôt, it‚Äôs even harder. We did include a very robust hint system and clue tracker to help, but ultimately if the game‚Äôs puzzles feel like nonsense, and explanatory footnote (which itself may be semi-nonsensical) isn‚Äôt a fix. 

All this is to say, sorry you didn‚Äôt enjoy the game, especially since you came to it with such high hopes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091624197', 'num_games_owned': 131, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1692013435}
review: Primordia quickly became one of my favourite Point-&-Click gaming experiences! From the very beginning the art design, the music, the characters and the atmosphere drew me into an intriguing, unique (or rather ‚ÄòUNIIC‚Äô, heh) dystopian world that was hard to leave once I had entered. The dialogue, world-building and general plot excel in immersive storytelling from start to finish, and I never got the impression that I was doing anything pointless in the game ‚Äì every action just makes sense, which made it so satisfactory to play. I liked how logic-focused most of the puzzles were instead of combining objects seemingly senselessly (as it is in some other P&C games). Although I got slightly stuck on some occasions because I didn't find all observable elements of a scene, it never reached the point of frustration because Crispin, your loyal moral support robot-sidekick and pun-provider, gives you hints without breaking game immersion. I truly loved every minute, every hour spent in Primordia, and I‚Äôm really glad I found this game (...11 years too late, but the art design and story are timeless)!
developer_response: Thanks so much! Means a lot to know our game is still connecting in so many ways with players after all these years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198187248029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1688584236}
review:
I don't recall any game implicitly giving me such a good first impression. Few minutes into the game I'm thinking, why did it fly under my radar (thanks Steam recommended section). The incredible writing shines since the first sentences - Horatio & Crispin duo (Main character and his companion) have that rare kind of synergy. You're not skipping dialogues, you're [b]skipping game[/b] to hear dialogues. If you know a bit of programming and electronics, you can catch a lot of nice jokes. It's voice acted! If it alone is not a good enough reason to buy it, get it for the world design. Story is decent, but it's the world, constructed with lots of care that made me go "wow". I'm probably biased since I like non generic stories with robots, so I'll just say that it was a treat. And lastly, puzzles are demanding, but make sense. 

In my eyes, a masterpiece.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the wonderful words about Primordia's writing! I'm very proud of it, as well as everyone else's contributions to the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198051333590', 'num_games_owned': 711, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1690483252}
review:
I have this theory that no game featuring Abe Goldfarb is bad. This game is yet another example of why that might just be true, cuz b'sod this is a quality game! One of the best point and clicks I've ever played, probably the absolute best in terms of atmosphere. The only "negative" thing I can say about it really, is that I wish we got to see more of the world, but I honestly don't see how they'd make it fit into the narrative and overall experience, so that's just me being really invested in the world and wanting more rather than a flaw with the game itself. I'm very excited to play Strangeland!

Definitely check this game out if you enjoy point and click games and/or good puzzles and writing!
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words! Abe is phenomenal (and plays like a dozen characters in Strangeland)!

There is a bit more about the world on Primordia-Game.com, including the spin-off story I wrote, "Fallen."

author: {'steamid': '76561198018671613', 'num_games_owned': 1209, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1624809991}
review:
Primordia achieves a rare mix of everything that makes a good adventure game: great dialogue, captivating setting, complex plot and worldbuilding, and satisfying puzzles that fall on the hard category.

Like one of the classics, the big non-linear set piece that occupies most of the game's playtime is a masterpiece of design and interconnected narrative threads and puzzle elements.

This is one of the best adventure games of all time.
developer_response: What a wonderful review to wake up to! It's particularly gratifying to read your kind words about the puzzles and non-linear design. Poured my heart into this stuff (the whole team did in into what everyone worked on), and it means the world to hear that it connected with players.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970705717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1700782348}
review: A sublime journey through a post-apocalyptic world. Primordia's heavily distinctive visual style ably supports its deft characterisation and world building, and bickering leads Logan Cunningham and Abe Goldfarb make for one of the most amusing partnerships in adventure games. Primordia is not a large game, but is packed so full of wit and style you won't forget any of your play through.
developer_response: Thank you so much! It's always wonderful to read reviews like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031991603', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1688868404}
review:
Excellent world building and voice acting (Abe Goldfarb is a standout as always), but some plot inconsistencies and frustrating puzzles mar the experience a bit. There's a fair bit of pixel hunting and many interactive elements blend in with the earthy color palette. A tab-highlighting option would be welcome.

A good pickup for fans of modern point-and-clicks that have already played the Wadjet Eye-developed games and are looking for something similar.
developer_response: Thanks so much for your thoughtful assessment, and for giving it a shot! Always grateful for those who keep the adventure game genre alive!

author: {'steamid': '76561198088306280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1691529969}
review:
Great experience with an engaging storyline and occasionally ambiguous scenarios with multiple solutions, giving replay value. This is not the type of plot that I am normally drawn to, but I found myself really enjoying it as time went on.

I loved the less item-driven puzzles towards the end of the game, and I liked having to write things down and think about them. (I got the logic puzzle correct the first time and have no complaints about the language. I say that as a math-oriented person who likes logic riddles though, so your mileage may vary.) Puzzles involving combinations of items were trickier sometimes, but solutions always seemed reasonable to me.

At a few points, especially but not only towards the beginning, I found it hard to find exits or other points of interest. The in-built hint system was helpful in confirming that I was on the right track when I hit those points, but I had hoped for a hintless playthrough.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this kind and detailed review -- particularly glad that you liked the more complex puzzles as the game went on. I agree that interactive spots and exits could be clearer, particularly early on (the two worst offenders, I think, are the UNNIIC and the large room in the Underworks), but I'm glad that didn't get in the way of an overall satisfying experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198071421958', 'num_games_owned': 854, 'num_reviews': 340, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1686902137}
review:
This game won me over near the beginning with it's charm. A great duo with lots of unique dialogue & interactions really make this game special. The lategame pacing might be a chore with harder leaps of logic for progression -- but thankfully hints are readily available by bothering your sidekick enough. Absolutely fantastic experience from start to finish. A spin-off short story sequel is also available here as a nice bonus for unwinding from completing the game and being done with the whole adventure. https://www.primordia-game.com/fallen.html. (Links to youtube audiobook there as well).

This was a perfect game to play in bed on my steam deck, and I'm super glad I tried it out. Definitely one of those games for me where the rich atmosphere leaves a unique lingering headspace. Definitely gonna pick up their latest developed game for sure.
developer_response: Thank you so much! Writing those little interactions was simultaneously exhausting and a joy, and it‚Äôs always great to hear when players liked them! Glad you enjoyed Fallen, too! Steamdeck port is all thanks to James, the game‚Äôs coder, who has supported it without stop over the last 11 years.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982530266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 272, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1685711561}
review:
I thought the game started out very well but the experience past the first areas was marred by obnoxious code puzzles and "oops you forgot to right click this one thing" adventure game logic impasses. Maybe I'm just a dummy but having to bust out the pen and paper to figure this junk out sort of brings the whole experience to a grinding halt. Many positive reviews here will call it out for the same reasons; for me the game is a pass due to it.

I like most Wadjet Eye published releases but this one is a great environment and decent story with a bad adventure game tacked on.
developer_response: Sorry you didn‚Äôt enjoy the puzzles!

author: {'steamid': '76561198085956182', 'num_games_owned': 1520, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1685160488}
review:
Primordia's one of the best point and click adventures I've played. Strong writing and well-designed characters elevate this game above most others (and not just this genre either). It's a shame I didn't play this earlier but better late than never.

I will say that some of the puzzle segments have unintuitive solutions but other than that this game is an easy recommend.

Crispy's also one of the best b'sodding sidekicks in any game and his jokes don't miss.
developer_response:
Thank you so much! Very proud of that writing and the characters, which came to life thanks to the great VO and art, too. 

I‚Äôm glad you liked Crispin, in particular. :) I was just reading a review that was positive overall but denounced him as the ‚ÄúJar-Jar Binks of Primordia‚Äù! I‚Äôm glad more folks fall on the favorable side of the line :)
