author: {'steamid': '76561197967459119', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 153, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1684727704}
review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[u]Primordia[/u] is an Adventure Game with 2D animation and a very low pixel count. This is very similar to Monkey Island or other SCUMM based games. You click on the environment, pick up items, and use them on different items to solve puzzles. Very standard fare.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[u]Primordia[/u] is shorter than most adventure games. A lot shorter. As in there are 2 major zones you go to through the entire game. This is the equivalent of 2 Monkey Island chapters. Fortunately the quality of those zones is good, and not many of the puzzles are terribly unfair. I wouldn‚Äôt say any are especially clever but they at least give you that smug satisfaction when you figure out what to do. The weakest puzzles are the ones that use the game‚Äôs future tech. Just what exactly is a ‚ÄúSignal transducer‚Äù? These unintuitive little gadgets make solving some portions more difficult than they should be.
If you do get stuck, your traveling partner can be questioned for hints. Although the hints are less "What is my general objective?" than outright spoilers. some games will just put a walkthrough into the game's UI,  but here it‚Äôs built into the story. I have mixed feelings about this. First, it‚Äôs easy to accidentally click on your partner and have him spoil a solution. Second, when your sidekick knows how to solve all the puzzles, it detracts from the story some what. Gameplay is fine, but nothing we haven‚Äôt seen before.

[h1]Story[/h1]
From the screenshots you can tell something special is going on in [u]Primordia[/u]. The sprite based artwork is probably its most striking feature. A weird mixture between Dune and Geiger, the alien designs of the space machines and spaceports are a visual treat. The main story starts off with the simplest of premises: Someone took your ship battery and you gotta go find it. The game is best when it sticks to this simple whodunnit mystery. But this is a short game. It really can‚Äôt be spending time fleshing out a huge lore driven narrative about the Fall of Man, the Rise of the Machines, and the internal political machinations of the robot overlords that eventually turned robo-society into an autocracy. This is all a bit much to cram into so little game. There are too many major characters for a story that is better serviced by something lighter and tighter. They do the best they can with the time given, it‚Äôs just a bit more than what a game of this size should be trying to do.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
In almost every facet but one, the game is perfect. The low pixel art VGA graphics may be off putting initially, but stick with it and you will see some wonderful landscapes, ship designs, and of course, robots. The sprites are just marvelous, and there are many equally great animations. Sound design is also good. Laser guns, ship doors opening and closing, engines, etc. all work well. And the voice acting is all on par. The range of different personalities you meet ‚Äî especially given everyone‚Äôs a robot ‚Äî is surprisingly varied.
But we still have to talk about Crispin, your sidekick. Now, I‚Äôm sure some people love this little guy but right from minute one his role as the comedic relief was just not working for me. Maybe it‚Äôs his poor voice acting or bad lines, but this integral character is just grating every time he opens his mouth. I can best describe him as the Jar Jar Binks of the Primordia Universe. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u]Primordia[/u] is a pretty, fun, tight little title. It‚Äôs not especially long, but it looks great and is satisfying enough to finish. Intermediate to advanced adventure gamers should give it a try,
developer_response: So glad you liked it! Really appreciate the detailed and thoughtful review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007988289', 'num_games_owned': 685, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1682345756}
review:
With solid lore building, decent enough voice-acting and themes, and intelligent puzzle design, this feels like a quintessential Wadjet Eye Games... game. It does suffer from the standard point and click adventure trope of obscure solutions, but that is generally because they are too clever for their own good.
While the art-style and robot and environmental design is great, everything being a shade of brown and grey does make it an overall dull game to look at.
However, I would still recommend it as it's relatively short and a deep and different take on the post-apocalypse.
developer_response: Thanks so much! The lore and puzzles were a blast to create, and I know the whole team appreciates your kind words!

author: {'steamid': '76561198092067523', 'num_games_owned': 562, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1682986158}
review:
Getting the bad out of the way firs:

Primordia is an adventure game and, as such, you're not really here for the gameplay. The puzzles can be hit or miss, generally being logical and consistent, but sometimes falling into that "rub every two thing on my inventory and the screen to try and make progress". I found it a lot less obtuse than other adventure games I played, but this still happens a couple of times. However, the game is very generous with it's tips (talk to Crispin!) so it doesn't hurt as much.

What IS good in Primordia is the setting. It is fantastic. It presents a cyberpunk, post-human, dystopia wherein machines struggle to get by and find purpose. Interestingly, Humans are worshiped as gods, the first Builders, and the main characters, Horatio Nullbuilt, Version 5, is a follower of this religion. Through the game you explore the junkyards and leftovers of old humanity and old wars, and eventually reach a sprawling city where you can get closer to robot society.

Really, the setting is awesome, and the twists are satisfying (if a bit predictable).  This is a heavy recommend for anyone looking for a quick sci-fi fix.
developer_response: Thank you so much! I loved creating that lore and those characters‚Äîwe all poured a lot of ourselves into the world, which makes it really meaningful when players enjoy the brief stay there. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198030774156', 'num_games_owned': 493, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1682376602}
review: Primordia is a great classic point-and-click adventure in the vein of [i]Monkey Island[/i] and other early 90s classics. It's trying to think some big thoughts about politics, religion, and philosophy, and if it doesn't always articulate itself well it certainly earns points for trying--and some extra affection from me for referencing one of my favorite sci-fi novels, [i]A Canticle for Leibowitz[/i]. It also features the voice of Logan Cunningham before he became (semi?-)famous as Supergiant's go-to voice actor, and the pixel art is just gorgeous. [i]Primordia[/i]'s biggest flaws are a clunky UI, some obtuse puzzle logic, and an excess of pixel hunting. I wouldn't necessarily call this a flaw per se, but one should also be aware that a remarkable number of very specific actions have to be taken in order to get the game's best ending.
developer_response: Glad you liked it‚Äîreally appreciate you taking the time to leave such a thoughtful review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198132276974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 1144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1144, 'last_played': 1681663463}
review:
Primordia is the fourth game published by Wadjet Eye rather than purely developed, with the development team actually being Wormwood studios, and it is definitely still a good one. I actually played this one a long time ago back before it even had achievements and I wasn't too hot on it then, but it definitely helps having played not only more adventure games in general but specifically those that influenced this one. Cause honestly, in a lot of ways, this feels like a fan remake of Beneath a Steel Sky. It has a similar premise of a post-apocalyptic world where one man from the wasteland has to go to one of the last known hubs of civilization, which happens to be a massive metropolitan city that was previously at war with other cities and is divided into multiple levels of height based on function, and must deal with the computer that has taken over the place while uncovering details he never knew about his past, collaborating with a robot buddy that he built and a female dissenter. Thankfully, this game is a massive improvement on Steel Sky in just about every way.

Primordia is the story of Horatio Nullbuit, a robot who is holing up in and trying to fix an airship called the Uniic, when one day a mysterious robot cuts right through the hull of his airship and steals his power core. Unfortunately, he only has an emergency generator that won't last long, so he needs to find out where the robot went and recover the power source or he, and his robot buddy Crispin will die. One thing I really appreciate about this over both of the Steel Sky games is that you spend an almost equal amount of time in the Dunes searching for an alternate power source before going to Metropol. In Steel Sky, you only saw the wasteland in the opening cutscene, and in Beyond a Steel Sky, the first hour of the technically took place in the wasteland but it was right outside Union City and most of the context was still centered around getting into the city. Here in Primordia, you get to travel to various different locations, meet some people, and get context on the world and the war that came close to ending it, setting up some things about Horatio's past that pay off later. There's more intrigue which the second half of the game builds upon rather than the plot slipping into the background till the very end like in Steel Sky.

The background art in this game is superb, some of the best I've ever seen in an adventure game in fact. Some might complain about the overly brown tone of the game, but the level of detail and the variety of environments you move through more than makes up for it. The color tone of the game actually does really help with the desolate atmosphere of the apocalyptic world where everyone is holding on by a thread. Similarly, the character designs are excellently done which you can see right from the cover of the game as a lovingly rendered image of Horatio is what they're selling the game with. All of the other robots in the game are also excellent, some looking stylized and curvaceous like something out of 50s sci-fi art and others looking very blocky and 80s industrial. 

The puzzle design in this game actually isn't bad. The only reason I had so much trouble the first time is because I didn't think to examine things and I didn't ask Crispin for help enough, as he does offer up specific advice or clues whenever you're stuck. The only time I had trouble figuring something out was the Memorious puzzle as I believe the hints for figuring out the third phrase are too vague and can be interpreted in the wrong way too easily. Everything else has a fairly logical correlation for at least one of the solutions. Yes,there are multiple puzzle solutions you can do for achievements. You can even attempt to break into the final area yourself if you can figure out the code without the codebreaking robot which the game nudges you into several times. The final puzzle is especially great as there are a whole bunch of options on what you can do for alternate endings.

Primordia may not have some of the polish that later games in Wadjet Eye's catalogue do, but it is a really solid effort. It has an interesting story with some decent puzzles and the game helps you out with the most of the more obtuse things you need to do. I would recommend this to all adventure game fans, though I think the older ones will get more of a kick out of it to be honest. I'm really eager to play the spiritual successor that Wormwood made in Strangeland after replaying this.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind and thoughtful assessment. Primordia was one of the early WEG-published games, but definitely not the first‚Äîit was preceded by Gemini Rue, Resonance, and Puzzle Bots. BASS was a huge inspiration on Vic (the artist); game-wise, I was more inspired by Planescape: Torment on the writing side and Loom, Broken Sword, and Full Throttle on the design. But we were drawing on all kinds of old game influences and bouncing stuff between us (on a three-person team, everyone does a little of everything).

review:

Gameplay-wise, we are on the Wadjet style - i.e. puzzles are doable with more or less limited help (although some of them require some pixel hunting but nothing too tricky)
All in all, strong recommendation to the Point&Click/SciFi story-driven genre lover - if you only need one, I would prefer Technobabylon (more diverse in its theme)
developer_response: So glad you liked it and the melancholy tone. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198054985169', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2355, 'last_played': 1709366563}
review:
I'm honestly shocked to realize I didn't leave a Steam review yet. Maybe I posted one after a million hours on my GOG copy and mixed them up, I don't know. Well, whatever! Primordia is easily one of my top favorite games of all time, and probably one of my most replayed; it's like picking up an old comfortable favorite book or putting on a movie I've watched a hundred times at this point, popping back in to spend a casual weekend in the robot apocalypse hanging out with some wacky well-acted old friends again.

And it's a game that genuinely rewards multiple playthroughs - not just with the commentary track, which should absolutely not be enabled in your first run as it's full of spoilers, but because there is a really delightful amount of side dialogue via RNG banters and environmental/item/Crispin interactions. You're definitely not going to encounter all of that in only one run, and I love the feel of getting to know the characters and their relationships a little better every time I've come back. Similarly, there's a lot of foreshadowing and background stuff that's easily missed in a first playthrough, and I've enjoyed the characters' arcs (which aren't, Horatio slightly excepted, completely/directly spelled out for the audience as some games' dialogue tends to do) more every time I revisit them and catch something new, or put something together I didn't before. *And* some endings are incompatible with one another, though once you know when to make a backup save - I'm not spoiling! - it's fairly painless to see everything in a single replay. So while Primordia itself is technically not the longest game, you can get a lot of hours out of it if you like what it's offering!

Anything more I could say in praise of the art, music, acting, dialogue, gameplay, and the humorous but effective in-game hint system has probably been said thousands of times already and this is already running long, so I'll just say I love it and add: big thank you to the devs and cast for this one. Primordia's one of those stories that's meant a lot to me over the years, and I have a lot of affection for its characters and their struggles. Horatio is really special to me (though quite frankly they all are) and I expect I'll be having him run around in the desert grumbling about conduits and conductive putty for many more replays to come.
developer_response: Ha! I would've sworn you'd left a review, too -- I've always really appreciated your support over the years! Thanks for this lovely write-up, on top of all the rest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198288908193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1680294081}
review:
This is one of the best P&C adventure games I have ever played by far.  I accept nothing less from Wadjet Eye and Wormwood, at this point - all of their games are fantastic.

I think my favorite aspects of this game are both the intentionally-vague background lore that the player can try to piece together with their own interpretations and the phenomenal dialogue that really makes the world feel lived in and makes the player want to learn everything they can about the characters and their pasts.

Additionally, I thought the puzzles were awesome in this one overall - some were decently tough while still remaining at least somewhat intuitive - not an easy feat to pull off in this genre!

This is the type of game that really makes you think about tough, philosophical concepts that are more relevant than ever in the real world. The writer does a great job of making a solid argument for opposing philosophical solutions presented by the different characters.

I would definitely recommend this game to all other history/philosophy nerds out there who enjoy top-notch writing, incredible atmosphere, and uncovering lore via detective work and puzzle solving.

Amazing job devs, thanks for a memorable experience.
developer_response: What a wonderful review! I‚Äôm so glad you enjoyed the writing and puzzles, and that the game made such a connection with you. Hope you have a chance to check out Strangeland if you haven‚Äôt already!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068300360', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1653328286}
review:
My partner saw this game and immediately purchased it for me. Knowing I am such a huge fan of classic point-and-clicks and text adventures such as Kings Quest, Zork, and Beholder. 

What he didn't realise is he just found the BEST point-and-click game I had played in nearly 20 years.

This game is so full of charm and wit, the characters all leave a lasting impact on you, and feel meaningful, and well, fleshed out for lack of a better word!

I scoured every corner of this game to find any little secrets and achievements I could, enjoying every last second, until I could find no more, I cannot wait to see more from this team!

10/10 Truly a masterpiece and a work of heart <3 Thank you for the last few years which have been filled with this wonderful game!
developer_response: Thank you so much‚Äîit is wonderful to read about our game making that kind of connection with folks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198303945313', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1678326851}
review:
It's unique story and the ambience is kinda EPIC. Feel like an independent robot with advanced IA. This is actually what I think might happen after humanity is long gone by it's own selfish mistakes.

On the bad/average side, the puzzles are hard and quite out of the box. I mean, write down on paper any coding information you think it's important because you might need something that happened 2 hours ago now. AND the game doesn't tell you again. It's kinda realistic. You didn't pay attention? Well sucks for you.

Of course, heavily recommended still.
developer_response:
So glad to hear you enjoyed the story so much!

For what it's worth, any essential information is automatically stored in the datapouch. But taking notes definitely can't hurt. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198206063319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1676451874}
review:
A gorgeous and well-crafted game. The writing was very well done, and while the puzzles were a mix of extremely satisfying and occasionally head-scratching, the worldbuilding and memorable characters more than made up for its shortcomings. 

I did appreciate being able to 'incorrectly' solve certain puzzle chains, and that the game tries to tell you that you've done something wrong. One such instance led to me reloading an earlier save and doing the whole sequence again, which ended up being an *extremely* good decision. 

If the game had one major flaw, it would be that its climax felt a little rushed and underwhelming [spoiler] (the underground section in particular, it felt a little strange to have control taken away from your character in such a pivotal moment, and it was too short for the return afterwards to feel meaningful) [/spoiler] but other than that, the story was very good and the underlying mystery kept me invested the whole time.

Also, bonus points for including a character that talks only in rhyme. I don't know why, but something about that trope gets me every time. Some people find that sort of thing insufferable, but me, I find it quaint. The fact that there's only one instance of this, I think shows great restraint.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the lovely review and kind words. I think you might also enjoy our follow-up, Strangeland, which also features a rhyming character . :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198030978836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1678077570}
review:
I really enjoyed Primordia but my expectations were set a bit too high by the glowing Steam reviews.

I love the world and the atmosphere, but the story and the climactic moments didn't do much for me. The build-up to the end of the game didn't feel as impactful as I was hoping, but the journey there was a fun experience nonetheless. I loved the dialogue and the worldbuilding. It ranges from funny and charming to bleak and existential and it rarely fell flat. And the voice acting is really well done for what I assume is a low budget game.

The puzzles for the most part were fair and satisfying. But one puzzle in particular was way too obscure--I never could have figured out the answer on my own. What's more, I recommend clicking the "How to Play" button in the menu when you start because I never realized you could right-click on the environments to examine things, and it turns out that a certain puzzle requires you to examine something in order to proceed. Took me a while to get past that hurdle. But besides those hiccups, the rest of the puzzles were great.

I'm not even a fan of point-and-click adventure games and I'm happy I took the time to try it.

[h1]My Rating: 3/5[/h1]
developer_response: Thanks for the candid, yet positive review, and for giving our game a try! It means a lot that people are still playing it after all these years!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991465987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 276, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1678052377}
review:
Primordia was a huge surprise for me. Not sure how, but I managed to not know of the existence of this game, let alone the fact that it's a cult classic - so I launched into it with guarded curiosity, and I was completely hooked in a matter of minutes. The setting, the low-res but very atmospheric visuals, the haunting music and then the excellent writing and no less excellent voice acting drew me in for the opening act like few other games ever did.
While the first act in the wasteland was almost perfect, the second one in the city was less so. There were two things that didn't work that well:
- The game wanted to tell too much backstory compared to the gameplay. This resulted in text dumps, more of them as we approached the end of the game. They were interesting, I would have liked to read them as a novel - but this is a video game, not a novel.
- Several puzzles were opaque to the point of WTF-ness. I may have enjoyed them in the 90s, but now I simply couldn't find the patience to tinker with them all. May be the game's fault, may be mine, hard to tell.

Altogether, Primordia was a very satisfying experience, it's renown is well deserved. Don't miss it if you like point-and-click adventure games!
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060961802', 'num_games_owned': 370, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1678044308}
review:
This game was sitting in my library for far too long before I played it. Now after completing it, I wish I started as soon as I bought it. 

Gameplay wise it is a point and click adventure/puzzle game from 2012, but it hold up well. The problems are easy enough to solve once you have all the pieces, but I personally struggled to find some of them. 

The main standouts if the game are its writing and world building. This is a game about a world where man is gone and all that is left is the robots and machines we made. They share many of the same ideals and flaws that plagued man, and that is what makes it hit home so well. You follow Horatio and his sidekick Crispin on their journey to get back a power source that was stolen from them. Along the way they wrestle with the woes of ideology, religion, and what it means to exist all while learning about what brought this world to what it is now. On top of that, the dust and rust builds a great atmosphere throughout this story. As for my favorite character, it is a toss up between Clarity and Primer. One has a hilarious gimmick and the other has great heart though it is rarely shown. When I finished my first play through I got the Live Free or Die ending and it felt satisfying, but I knew there was more to do. After going through another time and getting We're all in this together, I want to see more of how this goes. I know it's been over a decade, and these types of games are likely to get squeals anyway, but I have hope seeing other with interest to put this to film

Overall this game is great and I slept on it for too long. The world and writing is great and the experience was 100% worth it. Play game. Game good.
developer_response:
Thank you so much! Personally very gratified to read your kind words about the writing/world-building, and I know the whole team appreciates your praise of the game overall.

Not sure if you've tried Strangeland, but the same three of us (Vic, James, and I) made it as well. Different feel (it's an internal, psychological journey, rather than an external, physical journey), but you might enjoy it as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037609243', 'num_games_owned': 641, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1676412734}
review:
In an alternate reality where people actually play point-and-click games, Primordia is a fondly remembered classic of the genre, spawning countless imitators and inspiring generations of game designers with its gorgeous visual direction, idea of a fascinating post-human world and memorable characters. While it is indeed a tough challenge to objectively quantify how popular an artwork actually is, I feel safe assigning Primordia a recognition level of [i]not nearly enough[/i]

Primordia is engrossing, endearing and entertaining. It starts with a short introductory cutscene where the two main characters are introduced - the deadpan, stoic protagonist Horatio and his charming comic-relief sidekick Crispin. They live a reclusive, quiet life, until a hostile machine invades their home and steals the power core - retrieval of which remains the guiding objective throughout the entire game. Forced to leave their secluded desert shelter, they soon find themselves in the city of Metropol, delving deeper and deeper into the history and intrigues that shaped the dystopia they reluctantly explore.

The relationship between the two is with no doubt one of the game's strongest selling points. On one side, it's a reliable, instantly recognisable goofy-guy-deadpan-guy pairing, functioning especially well here as a contrast to the grim reality. Ever since the Wasteland game, moments of comic relief accompany bleak postapocalyptic landscapes to prevent the atmosphere becoming too oppressive to enjoy. On the other side, Horacio is by all means and purposes a father of Crispin, having built him according to his own design. While not shying away from challenging his ideas, Crispin lets his mask of tease slide down sometimes, revealing a deep affection and respect to Horacio, his father figure. [spoiler]One of the funniest and most heartfelt moments when this aspect of the relationship comes to the light is an optional puzzle where Horacio helps Crispin get over his timidness and speak to another robot he likes.[/spoiler] It's an interesting twist on the formula by itself, expanded on by the tension arising from the fact that Horacio had the opportunity to shape Crispin in whatever way he desired. Was creating a companion that questions him a purposeful act, or did he leave in the design a space of freedom for Crispin to develop a personality on his own? I feel this fragment from the short story on the game's official site is the best way to sum up this train of thought - [i]Horatio pre-loaded a lot of data when he built me.  For example, all these words, our core logic, how to field-strip a screw (is that right?) and tie seventeen kinds of knots.  You would think he would have filled us up with this nonsense in his Gospel. But, no. "You can always ask, Crispin."[/i]

The internal struggle between the predestined identity devised by one's creator and the freedom of continuous development is probably the main theme shaping the narrative of the game, along with its extension in form of characters whose purposes are either fulfilled or no longer valid, forcing them to find new guiding principles and values. The writers did not stop there however, delving into questions concerning the nature of law along with the problem of unjust law, problematic nature of established knowledge [i](understood in this case as a collection of facts about the world)[/i] and its interaction with the threats of censorship or malicious interventions, the role of imagined visions of the past in shaping the identity of a person or a society, struggle between a chase for an utopia and respect for personal freedom and many, many more. Multitude of themes and ideas at play in Primordia shows just how much love and heart the devs have poured into their work.

Setting of the game, being not just a delivery vector for the inquires and questions concerning general ideas shaping the world, is also genuinely interesting as an imagined world with an expansive history and lore. That exploration is somehow constrained by the game's relatively short playtime. Still, almost every encounter is not just an obstacle to overcome or a plot device, but brings with itself revelations concerning the broader background of the setting. My favorite example of this would probably be [spoiler]the alien robot who might be communicated with only through the radio, their surname created with a different rule than the one player is used to at this point[/spoiler].

One cannot forget to mention the game's gorgeous, distinctive and imaginative artstyle. Drawing inspirations not just from the classic postapocalyptic visages of [i]Mad Max 2[/i]'s ramshackle, improvised bricolages, added to the mix have been features of H.R.Giger's skeletal, oppressive sharp forms and Art Nouveau sleek architecture, [i](the latter mostly in the design of Metropol)[/i] creating a truly distinctive and fascinating vision. It's a shame how the low resolution of the game does not do the style justice, sometimes turning the characters and objects into featureless brownish-grayish pixel blobs with a hint of blue.

With the game being as great as it is, there are some grievances that stopped me from giving the game a full 5/5 rating. Apart from clunky interface and already mentioned low resolution, the design of some of the riddles leaves a lot to be desired. There is some pixel hunting, not helped by the points of interest blending with background sometimes. The biggest offender here would probably be the [spoiler]hatch on a car in the sewers[/spoiler]. Some may find the puzzles to be obtuse, especially with how many of them presuppose either some knowledge, or intuition, concerning the programming principles and formal logic. However, the toughest puzzles usually have some kind of alternative [i]skip[/i] solution and the Crispin is always there with optional tips prodding the player in the right direction, so I believe this problem to be alleviated somehow [i](except for [spoiler]the Primer's puzzle, where a critical clue for the "right" solution is hidden in an unrepeatable piece of dialogue[/spoiler]. Ugh)[/i].

Still, Primordia remains to me one of the most original and inventive worlds ever created. With witty dialogue, interesting setting and charming characters, it manages to present one of the best post-human [i](and yet still very humanistic)[/i] narratives in gaming, and perhaps among even cultural works in their entirety.
developer_response:
What a beautiful review. The world and its characters were born of all kinds of inspirations (a whole lifetime's worth, up that that point), and I'm so glad you found them engaging.

Primordia did manage to inspire a few other games -- Paradigm, Crying Suns, K'Nossos (still in development), and a couple others credited Primordia as an inspiration, and there are other ones where the inspiration seems pretty obvious (Shardlight, by our friends at WEG, for instance). That, too, means a lot, since we drew so much on inspirations given by other games, stories, shows, books, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970237665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 259, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1676733586}
review:
TLDR: An infuriating pixel hunting adventure in a wonderfully miserable world.

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

Primordia is point and click world building, puzzle solving, and decision making done very, very well. Multiple choices for some puzzles, with consequences and minor changes to the world based on how you go about it. This also includes an entire plethora of endings, covering a massive array of possible story beats.  

You are Horatio, a highly intelligent robot living in the ruins of some kind of ship, when an apparently big bad evil dude breaks into your home, shoots you, and steals your power core. Given you need that to live, it poses quit the challenge to your ongoing wellbeing. Thus begins your journey across the wastes, rubbing things on other things, making people repeat themselves, and showing them random junk in a one-sided and unsolicited conversation until you get back what‚Äôs yours.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] What an interesting world. Very different to most others while drawing some clear inspiration. I loved the BASS references, the idea of a ruined echo of humanity screaming on into the void over a dead world they themselves had killed, and the idea of bluescreening being a curse.  
[*] Multiple methods of solving many of the puzzles, with some of them essentially being optional. 
[*] Philosophical in a nice way. Primordia doesn‚Äôt ram the questions it raises down your throat, nor do they form the basis of the story or the axis that the plot revolves around. They just [i]are[/i].
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Frustrating as all hell. This is a true pixel hunter, and there were at least two occasions I just booted up a walkthrough because I didn‚Äôt want to comb every section of every screen for the doodad I had missed.
[*] For every puzzle that is intuitive and has multiple paths, there are two which require oddly specific ways of getting around. 
[*] Massive steaming plot holes. Why didn‚Äôt Crispin need a ticket? Why couldn‚Äôt we climb over the bus into town? Why couldn‚Äôt we recruit friendly bots more effectively? When metro did what she did in the tunnels, why didn‚Äôt arbiter shut her down? 
[*] The game felt like it was meant to be so much bigger, but got stripped back last minute. Unused places, assets, and interactions. I‚Äôd like to see an ‚Äòextended edition‚Äô. 
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] Allow the data pad to open in conjunction with interaction puzzles. 
[*] A double click to move/change scene.
[*] More variety in the base puzzle solving, the elements available when utilised were exceptionally strong. 
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

Primordia is extremely good. Post-apocalyptic atmosphere, decent voice acting, and strong world building give it major punch in a PnC environment, it is also reasonably priced.

This is an absolute must for people who like to think about their games. It‚Äôs a solid investment for a veteran point and clicker looking for a challenge, and it‚Äôs got a ton of depth for people who like to get immersed in their games.

Primordia is not for newcomers to point and click, partly because of the pixel hunt frustration, partly because it doesn‚Äôt explain itself well. It isn‚Äôt for people who want a clear story and very tight writing, and it isn‚Äôt for children, with some quite dark scenes and concepts. 

Overall I recommend this, even at base price.
developer_response: Thanks for the long and thoughtful review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009758085', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1676198795}
review:
Story was good and I think the multiple endings covered all the options I could think of.

However, the game had too many infuriatingly unfair puzzles that needed both paper notes and walkthrough. Such as:
- Key items in hidden pixels without any clues for them (e.g. conduits in junk yard or floating junk)
- Using items on sidekick looking at nostril instead of actual hotspot since my character "can't reach it"
- Logic puzzle about robot manufacturers was pain in the ass to even write to paper with that robotic speech speed.
- Insufficient hint system, while key characters refuse to repeat essential clues or what they want player to do.
- Some data is available in datapad and other is not. Like the 16 digit council code Primer says only once!
developer_response: Thanks for taking the time to review, and sorry for your bad experience.  For what it's worth, I think Primer's code does stay in your datapouch, but perhaps you were looking at the wrong screen (or perhaps I"m misremembering). And you don't need to solve the manufacturer puzzle, you can just ask Clarity to resolve the dispute between Oswald and Cornelius. But still, there's no arguing with a bad experience... if someone doesn't have fun, that's on the dev, not the player.

author: {'steamid': '76561198182731018', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 259, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 833, 'last_played': 1585921529}
review:
If there's one point-and-click adventure game I would highly recommend to almost everyone it would be Primordia and I am sure many people who played that game can agree with me on that point.

Set in a post-apolgcapse scrap zone where humans are treated as gods but don't exist more, whereby intelligent machines are scavenging for survival and reason. We play as Horatio Nullbuilt while controlling his witty sidekick, Crispin who just wants to get their power core back that was stolen from their ship by an uninvited. The plot thickens once they get involved with robot politics and discover more about the religious subtext that was embedded into them by mankind. You can say these plot progression scenes are quite similar to the first Shrek movie, (please don't force me to explain how or why I felt the effort that comparison).

To avoid getting off track, if you're someone who wants to move on from this recent discussion about AI art and algorithm being able to write stories give Primodia a try. Many things, like voice acting, visuals and narrative are what carry this game. There is also a fascinating discussion about the relationship between humans and machines, code and order and the purpose of these new life forces being programmed to do in life.

There are also many quirky characters, they're all machines of course but are interesting in their rights thanks to their robotic language pattern swimming with personality which says a lot about their creator and what they went through to make it this far.

If any player reading is not familiar with part components and engineering, some puzzles may be difficult to navigate, but for the most part, it is pretty simple to pinpoint what you need to do.

By the end of the playthrough, I felt the story completely wraps itself nicely. Just while I was typing this review I notice how much I miss this game, wanting to replay it again to relive the amazing experience.

I'm trying to resist screaming about how amazing this game was because it is truly a great game that got me thinking deeper about my purpose on this pile of rocks. Want something deep and philosophical, play Primdoria.

[i]Tips: Don't forget to save before the final confrontation.[/i]
developer_response:
"I'm trying to resist screaming about how amazing this game was because it is truly a great game that got me thinking deeper about my purpose on this pile of rocks."

What a beautiful review to start the day with!

You might enjoy "Fallen," my spin-off story, as a post-script on the game: https://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

review:
Ich habe inzwischen 4 Spiele von Wadjet Eye Games gekauft und gespielt, die meisten waren okay bis gut, eines war leider ein totaler Reinfall f√ºr mich und allgemein h√§tte ich auch wenn ich die Pixel Grafik mag doch lieber etwas bessere pixelgrafik und h√∂here Aufl√∂sung.

Dieses Spiel hier ist meiner Auffassung nach so ziemlich das beste von denen die ich mir gekauft habe, das Dystopie setting hat Wadjet Eye ja √∂fters aber hier g√§llt mir das optisch sehr gut, Story ist auch ganz okay. Alles in allem ein ganz gutes spiel wenn auch nicht wirklich 10‚Ç¨ wert meiner Meinung nach, aber im Sale sicher ein Kauf wert.
developer_response:
Danke ‚Äì WEG ist sowohl Herausgeber als auch Entwickler, so viele Spiele, die mit ‚ÄûWEG‚Äú in Verbindung stehen, wurden von verschiedenen Entwicklern gemacht. Tats√§chlich wurde keiner der postapokalyptischen Titel von WEG entwickelt ‚Äì wir haben Primordia gemacht; Josh N√ºrnberger machte Gemini Rue; und Francisco Gonzalez machte Shardlight. Nat√ºrlich gibt es √Ñhnlichkeiten in der Art und Weise, wie wir alle unsere Spiele entwickeln, aber ich dachte, ich sollte es euch wissen lassen!

(Und, ja, verr√ºckt, ein 10 Jahre altes Spiel zum vollen Preis zu kaufen! Mindestens viermal im Jahr gibt es 70¬†% Rabatt.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198010077003', 'num_games_owned': 499, 'num_reviews': 374, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 571, 'last_played': 1675504560}
review:
5/5
Avventura grafica molto bella in stile anni '90. L'ambientazione distopica √® per nulla banale, con le macchine sopravvissute all'uomo in un mondo senza pi√π vita organica, in una storia interessante con i suoi misteri e un passato ben costruito da scoprire. Ben costruiti i personaggi, sia i protagonisti che gli altri, compreso un "cattivo" molto convincente nelle sue azioni e intenzioni. Gli enigmi non sono particolarmente difficili, ma solitamente intelligenti e non assurdi. Molto bella l'idea di avere suggerimenti dalla spalla comica del protagonista, equilibrati il giusto per lasciare comunque il ragionamento al giocatore.
Nel complesso un ottimo prodotto, sicuramente da giocare sopratutto per gli appassionati del genere, certamente consigliato.
developer_response: Che bella recensione, in particolare le belle parole sugli enigmi. Grazie molto!

author: {'steamid': '76561198087730263', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1674546663}
review:
I can understand those that don't like this game or get super frustrated, I love this game and got very frustrated and lost. I don't like these types of games but this one clicks so well with me, the story and voice acting along with a world that feels desolate yet full of life and activity.

I highly recommend this game but for those frustrated with adventure games maybe just watch a youtube playthrough instead.
developer_response: It's true -- we feel like complex puzzles and inventory puzzles are a big part of what makes an adventure game, but many players find those things frustrating, and probably should skip Primordia if so. :)  There are other more purely narrative adventures (sometimes unfairly criticized as "walking simulators") out there like Unavowed for players more interested in just watching a story unfold without puzzles.

review: This game gets an incredible amount of world building and environment done in 6 hours.  Most of the puzzles are very interesting and are solvable with hints from your companion.  A few are slightly hard to find using the cursor on the Steam Deck, but otherwise it was a great fit for the handheld.  It does what good science fiction novellas do, drop you off in a very interesting world that makes you want more but doesn't overstay its welcome.  Strong recommendation, great story, excellent voice acting, solid puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198377045220', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 358, 'last_played': 1674194800}
review:
Loved it. From the art style to the tone of the music, it all coalesced into a coherent experience that matched and added to it. Each character was deeply memorable without being ridiculous like with Deponia, and remained believable.

 Each one sad and beautiful in their own way, each machine like a Greek/Roman tragedy never able to be more than what they are, made for a fate and destiny they could not break from or - worse - could not achieve. Their purpose in existing lost with the beings beyond their comprehension that gave them those fates.

Bought it in the humble bundle, wish I'd bought it full price and wish more for a sequel ten years after the fact.
developer_response:
"Each one sad and beautiful in their own way, each machine like a Greek/Roman tragedy never able to be more than what they are, made for a fate and destiny they could not break from or - worse - could not achieve. Their purpose in existing lost with the beings beyond their comprehension that gave them those fates."

What a beautiful phrasing!

No likelihood of a sequel, but I did do a spin-off story ("Fallen"), which you can get for free on Primordia-Game.com.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095263665', 'num_games_owned': 548, 'num_reviews': 406, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1674407318}
review:
Primordia is a post-apocalyptic, point-and-click adventure game by Wadjet Eye. You play as Horatio Nullbuilt, a simple robot living in a crashed airship with his floating companion Crispin, until one day a big bad robot steals their power core, and they track him to the mechanical city of Metropol. You will meet many other robots that will either help or hinder you. The setting is unique as there are no human characters, they (we?) have long been extinct and are referred by some as gods. Usually, post-apocalyptic stories always deal with human survivors looking for food and water. Here, bots only need power.

The post-human wasteland is very well presented in my opinion. Like the desert wastelands with metallic ruins, and the city that is seemingly made of scrap. The artwork kinda reminds me of H. R. Giger, but somewhat more mechanical and less biological. One thing that this games lack is the "speech portrait", where they show a pretty detailed close-up artwork of the speaking character's face. Maybe its not needed since these robots look pretty distinct from one another, with some probably don't have faces. Still would love a closer look at their speech portraits though.

Gameplay is the usual P&C formula, collecting and using items and talking to characters. There are some puzzles to solve along the way. I'll be honest, some puzzles here can be really hard as sometimes you are given clues, and do not know what to do with them. Or maybe even almost nothing at all! Maybe it's just me not catching up on clues on dialogues or the world, but I think without a guide I would be very, very confused and lost. A helpful tip is to keep an eye on your data pack, as important info are stored there and might present clues.

Despite the lack of human characters, it doesn't make this game less relatable in any way, since these bots have personalities and their own motives. It's probably one of the better P&C games out there, and one of Wadjet Eye's best work. However, there is a problem, which is its length. Its very short, even shorter than Gemini Rue. I would love to see more of this world, as there are sections of the city left unvisited, but mentioned in dialogues or in-game articles, and they seem interesting. 

Primordia's an amazing game, despite its difficulty. The atmosphere and artwork are great enough reasons to try this game, especially if you're a fan of the post-apocalypse genre. And be sure to try its 7 endings! Don't worry, all of them are achievable if you play nice and collect everything. If you're looking to buy this, I recommend just getting Wadjet Eye's Dark Futures bundle, as these games present 4 different, but each amazing, takes on the future world.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the kind and detailed review! You might enjoy our follow-up, Strangeland. It's a less epic and more introspective game, but it has the same animating spirit.

Technically speaking, Primordia is not "Wadjet Eye's work" -- WEG was our publisher, but the game is all Wormwood Studios' work (I did the writing/design, James the programming, Victor the graphics). Gemini Rue was by another developer (Josh Nurnberger).  In fact, in the Dark Futures bundle Technobabylon is by a third developer (Technocrat Games), and while Shardlight was nominally developed by WEG, that's only because the designer/coder, Francisco Gonzalez, was briefly on WEG payroll.  Shardlight is really better thought of as a Grundislav Games game. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198359005836', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1602394651}

developer_response:
Thanks so much! Big fan of Machinarium (I've loved Amanita's games since the first Flash version of Samorost), but hadn't heard of Creaks. I'll check it out.

You might enjoy our second adventure, Strangeland -- darker and more introspective, but similar animating spirit (and higher resolution and many QOL improvements).

author: {'steamid': '76561198041615766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1673887544}

author: {'steamid': '76561198034349712', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 828, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1640017555}
review: I liked the story and the characters. The setting is fascinating as a concept and it kept me interested all the way to the end. author: {'steamid': '76561198073835341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1673286491}
review: So far the only Wadeye I really enyoed playing. Setting and story are great, protagonists and dialog also. The gameplay is pretty decent, puzzles are pretty logical, there are sometimes multiple solutions to puzzels. And some alternative endings!
developer_response:
Thanks so much for your kind words.

For what it's worth, Wadjet Eye Games (WEG) is both a developer and a publisher.

GAMES PUBLISHED BY WEG
- Primordia and Strangeland were developed by us (Wormwood Studios).
- Technobabylon was developed by Technocrat Games, but with art provided by WEG.
- Resonance was developed by xxii games, but with some writing (though no design AFAIK) by WEG.
- Gemini Rue was developed by Josh Nuernberger.
- A Golden Wake and Shardlight were developed by Grundislav Games (which also made Lamplight City, not published by WEG), but Shardlight was developed while the one guy who is "Grundislav Games" (Francisco) was being paid by WEG, which is why WEG is listed as the developer..
- Puzzle Bots was developed by Ivy Games.
- Da New Guys was developed by Icebox Studios.

GAMES DEVELOPED BY WEG
- WEG developed The Shivah, the Blackwell Series, Unavowed, and Emerald City Confidential.

All of these games share some similarities because they're all made in Adventure Game Studios (a third-party freeware engine) and because they use similar voice actors, but there's quite a bit of difference in the developers' philosophies.

So you might want to try out some other games by different developers published by WEG, as it's possible Primordia won't be the only one you enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072108732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1672250877}
review:
This would be a great comic book or visual novel, but as a game it sucks so much. Confusing artwork, non-intuitive problem solving, railroads and too many obnoxious characters... this all gets too tiresome to interact with for the time you get dalayed (or stuck) in game, and when you get the things figured out it's just not rewarding enough.

I can't recommend this unless you're big on point and click games, otherwise you will just get tired and disappointed. Maybe buy on a sale, I guess.
developer_response: Sorry you didn't like it!  It was definitely made for point-and-click fans, so your final advice is probably sound. (Plus, never hurts to buy things on sale regardless!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198128813131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1086, 'last_played': 1682258690}
review:
I'm going to start by saying that if you enjoy stories about robots, post-apocalyptic worlds, questions about identity, making peace with one's past, finding hope among things that seem hopeless, forming genuine connections and staying true to yourself and your ideals no matter how much the world tries to wrong you, then you should definitely play this game. It‚Äôs the kind that stays with you long after you have finished playing it.

Primordia is a game with outstanding writing, stunning artwork, soulful music and simple, but charming animations, all of which come together to create a truly captivating and memorable world.

The puzzles are fun and personally I had a blast exploring the world and hearing what the characters have to say in order to solve them, Memento‚Äôs being my favorite. Some might seem difficult, but the solution tends to be pretty simple. I haven‚Äôt played a point and click game in ages and it took me a bit to re-familiarize myself with the mechanics, so if you‚Äôre finding yourself struggling, that‚Äôs probably why!

The amount of voice lines written and recorded for the game is incredible, from simply inspecting things and interacting with them to idle banter and using items on something that you wouldn‚Äôt even expect to have a custom line. If you think you‚Äôve heard most of what the characters have to say, chances are you haven‚Äôt!

Friendly banter between the characters gives me life. The fact that Horatio and Crispin care so deeply and genuinely for each other not despite their differences, but rather thanks to them, is really heartwarming. I am absolutely in love with these guys.

I‚Äôve had only two problems with the game, first being misleading wording on the second question of a certain logic-related puzzle, which damaged my perfectionist I-solved-every-puzzle-myself pride a bit, but it‚Äôs nothing I can‚Äôt live down, especially considering this seems to have been discussed with and heard by the developers dozens of times by now. The other one is, in my understanding, an engine-specific bug, which causes music playing in the background to move to the audio setting, essentially causing two tracks to play at the same time. It affects your entire save and it cost me my second playthrough and quite some footage I'd been gathering due to me not realizing it was happening on time. (Moral of the story? Keep more save files!)

I‚Äôm not a particularly eloquent person in either of two languages I speak, but hey. This game pushed me to actually try and put my thoughts and emotions into words for a review for the very first time, so that has to mean something. I have been thinking about this game for the past few days and probably will continue doing so for years to come. Horatio and his friends have etched themselves deep into my soul, right next to stories I hold very near and dear. Did my personal history amplify that resonance? Probably. But that‚Äôs what stories do, don‚Äôt they? Among other things, they show you that you are not alone in whatever you‚Äôre going through.

Very grateful for being able to experience such a gem, even if I am a decade late. Thank you for creating and sharing it and good luck with your future projects, WWS.

P.S. Primordia-game dot com has a few treats for enjoyers of the game. I suggest you check them out!
P.P.S. Would really like to see a recording of that anniversary stream you guys did, if that‚Äôs possible.
developer_response:
What a beautiful review -- "not eloquent" indeed!  (Was particularly pleased you noticed the variety of banter/reactions.)

I'll ask Vic about getting the stream posted to YouTube. Hopefully he can do that.

You might enjoy Strangeland, although it's a very different game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198846898763', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1671765339}
review:
Primordia is a point-and-click adventure game that tells the story of Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot living in a post-apocalyptic world. The game has a great story with interesting characters and a unique setting. The puzzles are challenging but not overly difficult, and the pixel art style is beautiful and fits the theme of the game perfectly.

One of the standout features of Primordia is its voice acting, which is top-notch. The characters are fully voiced and the dialogue is well-written, making the game feel like an interactive movie at times. The music is also excellent and adds to the atmosphere of the game. Great little game.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words! Of course, with a name like "robitlover," we probably had a good chance of clicking with you. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199059765807', 'num_games_owned': 30, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1671749352}
review: Wow, as a point and click veteran I was really unsure at the start of this game but is easily up there with Monkey island, Sam and Max hit the road, day of the tentacle etc. really awesome story and the puzzles are very difficult sometimes, I had to use a Crispin hint a couple of times because I was fully stuck, (Turns out I hadn't listened to some earlier dialogue properly) which would have made it obvious. the hints are more like nudges so it doesn't feel like you've totally cheated either. 10/10 loved it

author: {'steamid': '76561198048355006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 409, 'last_played': 1670903458}
review:
I really liked this game. The story was fun and engaging. It was rarely too hard, but, like many older adventure games, there were times where something was on screen, and I had no indication they were there.

The ending was fun too. I haven't seen too many games like this where ending choices matter.
developer_response:
Glad you liked it! And thanks for leaving a review!

Our follow-up, Strangeland, also has some variety in the endings, though less than Primordia -- we focused more on non-linearity than narrative branching.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060674287', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 980, 'last_played': 1671065205}
review: A dense and enjoyable text which manages not to succumb to the "good ending/bad ending" trope that so many games do. It wants to engage earnestly with serious social issues such as the place of religion and ideology in modern society, and does so successfully, in my opinion. While some puzzles are a bit obtuse (oblique?), I never felt cheated by any of them. There's no shame in using a walkthrough, and there are plenty of non-critical secrets to find off the beaten path. If you're an adventure game fan, you'll surely like it, but I think it also succeeds as a story divorced from the medium of games.
developer_response:
What a gracious, and lovely, review. Given your reaction, you might also enjoy our follow-up, Strangeland!

Other than saying thank you, the only thing I'll add is that as a first recourse before going to a walkthrough, we recommend that players try consulting the built-in hints dispensed by clicking on Crispin. Sometimes you may want amore direct guidance, but our experience as adventure game players is that once we open a walkthrough, it's hard to ever go back to solving puzzles on your own. That's why we included hint systems in both Primordia and Strangeland. (Obviously, at the end of the day, of course there's no shame in using a walkthrough! Just wanted to provide this alternative.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198049121918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1670531278}

author: {'steamid': '76561198078996445', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 263, 'playtime_forever': 1006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1416967165}
review:
I realize looking at this Steam store page that for some reason I never left a review after first playing Primordia in 2013 not too long after its release and replaying a couple times in the years thereafter.  So I'm going to rectify that on the 10th anniversary of the game's release being spotlighted by the developer.  

When I think back on the last 10 years of P&C adventure games, it's truly been a golden age.  There have never been so many quality releases from such a wide range of small one-off, one-person indie developers and more established indie companies with full teams and higher production values (for smaller indie companies at least).  I'm old, so I've been playing adventure games since the Infocom text adventure 'grey box' games thru the first Sierra graphic adventures into Lucas Arts' prime and then the subsequent prematurely declared 'death' of the genre when for the most part only a few European studios were putting out what (in retrospect at least) were at best mediocre games, and then the revival of the past decade or so, when the genre has never been stronger.  

And as I think back on the cream of the crop of this flourishing of the P&C genre, Primordia has a place in the top tier.  It's been a while since I played it -- which the 10th anniversary has reminded me I should remedy with a replay --  so specific details of the game's plot and puzzles have faded from my memory, but when I think of the game, I continue to have very fond and well maintained memories of its story, world building, characters, puzzles, et al.  It's simply a great game that every fan of the adventure game genre really must play.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this lovely review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013999199', 'num_games_owned': 442, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1668492038}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044617500', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 434, 'last_played': 1605044470}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024336192', 'num_games_owned': 3064, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1384272425}
review:
Primordia is not just one of the best point-&-click games I've played; it is, hands down, one of the best works of fiction I have ever known.

Beautiful graphics, charming √¶sthetics, delightful voicework, gripping soundtrack. It's all there, but, really, the writing is what shines brighter.
From smart dialogue to engrossing plot, from bewildering amazement to thrilling expectation, from dry humour to truly moving tragedy, from the cold protocols of robots and computers to some of the most human moments you'll see in fiction, Primordia will take you on a wondrous journey: Horatio and Crispin's quest of discovery and devotion.
The fact that all this takes place in a barren planet, inhabited by robots ‚Äì a setting so similar to many that've been fraught with clich√©s and formulas in science fiction ‚Äì makes it even more amazing: the developers managed to pull off such a great game, falling for none of the vulgar traps of the genre.

Speaking of the developers, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33039777]Wormwood Studios[/url] is comprised of only 3 people.
Like [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/813630/Supraland/]Supraland[/url], another example of how far and high talent, passion and hard work ‚Äì not a big corporate structure ‚Äì can take a project.

Do yourself a favour and go play Primordia.
Warm smiles, tight throats, excited wonderment and welled-up eyes await.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this beautiful and generous review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001471900', 'num_games_owned': 1312, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1698379205}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029208692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1669307320}
review:
I was immediately spurned on by my recent completion of Gemini Rue to give another Wadjet Eye game a try. I was pleased it was Primordia. 
The story throughline is presented early, and maintains a steady beat towards its' conclusion. It isn't particularly long, but I feel it goes far enough to tell a story and flesh out some convincing characters. I think the most gracious aspect of the game's design was the ability to consult your sidekick, Crispin, if you get stumped. Though sometimes I wish his responses were less candid and more cryptic. Second to that was the handy data-reader, which tracked most pertinent puzzle information. The overall puzzling here is mostly functional / logical, and rarely leaves you lost. But at the same time, I do recall having a couple hitches when the puzzles weren't as obvious, or the logic wasn't easily telegraphed by the conversation. Overall though I had a fine experience with this game. I think the art design is also noteworthy for its simplicity and effectiveness. It's as if it was sculpted out of melted wax and stained with oil, quite uncanny.
This is definitely one of the good'uns
developer_response: So glad you liked it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198076689222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1668443994}
review: This is a good game, but it's aged a little poorly. It's not -that- old, and it's a lot less rusty than the game which inspired it, but still it's a little rough around the edges. Some of the puzzles are obtuse to the point of being unsolvable (like the kiosk poem puzzle). The characters and voice acting are good, and the world is fleshed-out and interesting. I got strong Torment vibes. I can recommend this game pretty easily, but I think there's other Wadjet Eye published game that are better.
developer_response:
Torment was a major inspiration! Good spotting! Based on Primordia, I wound up hired to write on TTON -- I did a few of the meres and the Inifere character arc. If you liked that stuff (I saw you liked TTON overall), you might enjoy Strangeland. It's a much smoother experience than Primordia, and also has Torment vibes.

And thanks for the kind words.  Rather amazingly, we started work on Primordia in 2000, so it's no particular surprise that it's showing its age. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990094789', 'num_games_owned': 1502, 'num_reviews': 252, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1666901129}
review: One of the most fun adventures I've ever played, great lore building, very intriguing plot, magical characters, witty dialogue, clever challenges. In short, perfection. Hoping for a sequel, prequel, anything from the same universe please.
developer_response:
So glad you liked it!

There is some free ancillary material (including a spin off story) on Primordia-Game.com.  I don't think we'll ever do another game in the universe, but there's a decent amount of extras there, which might scratch the itch.

We did another game, Strangeland (which is currently on sale!), which has a totally different setting and mood, but the same team and same spirit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198400190880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1666748496}
review:
Primordia is a point and click adventure game reminiscent of the practical thinking past of the point and click genre.

[h1]Tone & Humor[/h1]

Primordia has a very contradicting and yet very specific manner that it uses to project tone and humor. It's somber, sarcastic, bleak, self reflective and aware, silly and outright clever all at the same time. More than anything Primordia is very hard to describe!

[h1]Palette[/h1]

Everything is dull, dark, washed out, faded, and at times monotone. To understand why this is a positive for myself and part of the reason I recommend this game, I feel a good place to start and describe is the world setting.

Life has ceased to exist. Mankind now only a myth. You Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot built with an unclear purpose, accompanied by your sarcastic creation Crispin, go on an adventure through Primordia tracking down the heavily armed robot who stole your power core.

Without this power core, Horatio and Crispin cannot continue tinkering away the days. In time their power will run dry leaving them another empty husk like so many that litter the scorched earth.

[h1]Puzzles[/h1]

I found the puzzles in Primordia very hard and at times obtuse, that is until a certain in-game logic clicked into place for me. I was finding it frustrating at times not knowing what exactly to do because I myself didn't fully grasp the fact that I was controlling a robot coming to terms with the society that it's in and attempting to learn about a civilization that no longer exists (humanity).

Specifically I am referring to the location known as the [spoiler]city of Metropol[/spoiler]. It was this area that I started to struggle. The puzzles in this area requires the player to learn and understand the environment they're in in order to reach the logical conclusion.

That is where my enjoyment of Primordia sky rocketed.

[h1]Ridiculous Example[/h1]

I'd give an actual in-game example however I feel like that'd be beyond a spoiler so instead I'll have fun dreaming up a silly metaphor. Imagine you're Dante from The Divine Comedy. You are in what appears to be the third circle of hell, know as gluttony. You look around and are unable to comprehend your surroundings fully nor are you able to figure out what you should do. After piecing together all the information you've read and heard since arriving, you realise that you're in hells equivalent to McDonalds. You are now aware that you're expected to order food here. Understanding this, the environment begins to make sense (more sense than this awful metaphor I'm enjoying typing). Armed with this information you can understand the logic of the items around you, what they do and why. Using this new information, you order a cheese burger overcoming the puzzling situation you're in.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]

I really enjoyed this title. The pace of the plot is great. You can check yourself via trailer, the animations, soundtrack, ambience and over all art style as a complete package etc are fantastic. I highly recommend this title to people who enjoy an immersive point and click adventure game within a sci-fi setting.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words and clever comparison. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199080110472', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1666113157}
review: While some of the later puzzles give you very little to work with in order to figure them out, I would still argue that this is a fantastic point and click game. The visuals are stunning, the voice acting is top notch, and the gameplay, while simple, will make you think, which always leads to a good time. X3
developer_response:
Thank you so much! Always nice to hear from a player who wants harder or more complex, rather than easier or simpler, puzzles!

I‚Äôd steer you to our second game, Strangeland, but only with the caveat that its puzzles (though more than typical contemporary adventures) are probably a little easier than Primordia‚Äôs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025103501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1666098281}
review:
Very good adventure game, reminds me a bit of "Beneath a Steel Sky", "I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream" and "Dreamweb". 

Multiple endings, multiple ways to resolve some of the challenges. Pretty logical puzzle design throughout, some of the puzzles are very satisfying. The in-game hint-system did point me in the right direction as needed, or prompted me to explore a bit further. Very atmospheric art and design, but the colour design did make it difficult to spot some hotspots, which required I look up a hint at least once. 

Quality writing and voice-over, plot was a bit complex but easy to follow. Had the potential to be pretty morose, but there was enough levity to keep it fun without being irritating, and no horror elements. Great voice-acting and music was gorgeous and set the mood perfectly. Very enjoyable!
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it! And thanks for leaving our 2500th review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198388709646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 492, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1669318752}
review:
Really great, atmospheric point-and-click adventure. 
I liked that the puzzles were logical and I had to consult a walkthrough only for three quick glances during the entire game. That's how good the puzzles were. 
The soundtrack is very nice and fitting the overall brown-and-red melancholic theme of the game. It is obvious that a lot of love went into development.

EDIT: And a big plus is, that it works on linux and on FreeBSD!
developer_response: So glad you liked it! Hope you check out Strangeland, which is similarly melancholic (or perhaps moreso), albeit with fewer robots. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197968762153', 'num_games_owned': 1745, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1665004740}
review:
I rarely write reviews, but I feel the need to join the choir in praising the game.
I like adventure games and have fond memories of playing DOTD, Monkey Island, Loom and others as a kid, without having the internet to look up walkthroughs etc.
Primordia sat in my library for some time and I finally picked it up a few days ago.
It has a dystopian end of days theme, the world building is great and "makes sense", a lot of the backstory is left out for you to fill with assumptions and your own imagination, some bits of it are revealed later.
The Graphics are beautiful detailed retro-graphics. I remember thinking back in the 90s, good VGA is better than bad SVGA and that still is true today. 
The Riddles are simple to tricky but everything is logical and makes sense.
developer_response:
Thank you so much. Means a lot to hear such kind words, especially from a longtime fan of the genre!

If you ever make your way to our second title, Strangeland, I hope you enjoy it as much!
