author: {'steamid': '76561198302208299', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 821, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 821, 'last_played': 1662547948}
review:
Primordia isn't a bad game, I think it's just, maybe, not for me.  I love Point & Click Adventure games and I even seek out retro style ones.  I don't mind playing 8-bit or new HD graphics.  What I do generally prefer is an escape, a sense of grand adventure.  My preferences are more high fantasy, but it seems like the majority of P&C games over the past few decades are all post apocalyptic dystopian type futures.  That's okay, it must be what the majority of people want, but I have a difficult time enjoying those settings unless the game is absolutely spectacular in other ways.  For example, I very much enjoyed Daedalic's Deponia series which also takes place in a post apocalyptic type dystopian future.

The game's tone is perhaps a little to somber for me.  Although artistically I can see a lot of work and details that went into the games design, it's not colors or settings I enjoy seeing.  Everything is dull, dark, washed out, faded, a bit too monotone.    That seems to be the same sort of way that the characters come across to me as well.  They just don't have enough personality... but what can I expect they are all robots.  Even wen they display some type of emotion it then seems out of place since they are, again... robots.  Everything considered I do think they did a fairly good job with the story.  It is interesting but it feels oddly paced.  You either progress it at a snails pace or it's sort of revealed in large chunks all at once.  I also feel like there should have been more to it that you could discover.  You learn early on about your own past name but don't really get much more on that till the end of the game and what I got didn't feel complete or satisfactory.  It would have been more interesting to unlock pieces here and there throughout the game and had a clearer more in-depth understanding of who you were/are.  Also the world feels large, but what you are allowed to explore feels so small.

My other issue with the game is that it seems to have a lot of the problems people often complain about with P&C adventures.  A few here and there are forgivable but too many and it makes the game far less enjoyable.  The first is the ever unpopular pixel hunting.  Unfortunately it's difficult to tell what items you can and can't interact with and where items you need are.  For example, finding the tape deck or noticing scrapers bomb, even finding the extra battery.  An option to highlight hotspots would have been nice for making sure you've not missed something.  Though I don't always use them, I do appreciate those options when I'm stuck.

The second issue is that the game doesn't offer quick travel across screens by clicking.  Now this one is arguable because you can use the map to quick jump to other locations, but I found the act of going to the map and selecting the locations more cumbersome than just walking there from one screen to another.  A simple ability to double click the screen exit and quickly jump to the next screen would have been a great addition.  Also, the ability to adjust the character's walk speed could have helped as well.  In addition, I found it odd that when you start in the wastelands you can't navigate around the wastelands by exploring from one screen to the other, the only mode of exploration is to use the map to select locations.  I would have enjoyed "discovering" locations by walking through the wastelands more than just entering the coordinates and then jumping to the location.  While quick jump map points are great especially after you initially discover a location, nothing really beats that sense of exploration and "finding" a new location.

Thirdly, I found too many of the puzzles to be obtuse.  They didn't seem to have a logical solution.  I will admit that I recently broke my arm and had to have it surgically repaired and that as a result I had to take some heavy narcotics.  Being that I couldn't really get up and do much of anything during that time, I decided to play this game.  It's possible that the narcotics were just dulling my mind too much but I felt like the puzzles and solutions just didn't seem obvious enough, didn't have good clues for solving them, weren't logical or we're overly complicated.  I ended up having to use walkthrough or randomly guess at things.  Especially the puzzle involving the information kiosk and the Robot Law puzzle.  I guess considering my condition while playing you'll have to judge these ones for yourself, but even replaying it for missing achievements after weaning down on med I still found myself wondering "how would I have gotten the necessary information to proceed?"  I already knew at that point having played through once (with a walkthrough) but it didn't seem like I found any additional information that would lead me to those solutions had I not already known what to do.

I did find it interesting that the game offered multiple endings.  You could join Metromind, you could kill yourself, you could Kill Metromind.  There were variations on the different endings depending who you helped or saved too.  However, this also brings up another issue I had with the game which is another one that people often dislike from P&C's is that to get some of the endings required you to make certain choices early on in the game without knowing they would have any effect on your ending.  Meaning to get the other endings you probably have to start over from the beginning.

I did enjoy that there were 29 achievements in this game and that they were not all just story unlocked.  Several of them were challenging, but mostly because they required doing certain actions correctly from the beggining and following through to a specific ending.  There's an achievement for pretty much each of the different endings.  If you save at the right time you may not need to replay it to get those endings.  About 11 of them are missable achievements, I believe 10 of them are ending related (if I'm remembering correctly) and that would leave 8 story unlocked ones.  While it's not a bad mix you'll need to get almost all of the missable ones if you also want to unlock all the ending options.  Strategic saving could possibly eliminate the need to replay completely.  Replaying for missed achievements is something I often do with games and I usually don't mind.  This game felt like a chore to replay which tells me how little I enjoyed playing it and how little replay value it has.

I think the best part of the game has to be Crispin Horatiobuilt.  To be honest he reminds me a little of Cedric from King's Quest 5 (with a less annoying voice and more interactivity) or Joey from Beneath a Steel Sky (which I believe this game draws some inspiration from).  Crispin is the majority of comic relief and emotion in the game and in my opinion ,the most interesting character in it.

Overall, I think there are definitely Point & Click fans who will enjoy this game and it does offer a good story, well done graphics and animation, good voice acting, and about 4-6 hours of play time for one playthrough.  If robots and dystopian futures are your thing and you love P&Cs especially with puzzles... you might want to give it a try.  If you don't care for those things you might want to pass.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn‚Äôt enjoy it! I agree that players who don‚Äôt like P&C games with puzzles should skip it. To me the two are inextricably intertwined, but I know lots of folk prefer the more purely narrative sort like Unavowed!

(Both puzzles you mention as stumping you are optional as it happens, though. You can just ask Clarity to judge that case, and you can skip the kiosk entirely! But no matter what, it‚Äôs a game with lots of puzzles.)

I‚Äôd steer clear of our follow up Strangeland given your preferences. It‚Äôs not post apocalyptic and it does have double click to leave rooms, but is even less comedic, still puzzle oriented, no highlight all hotspots button (I have a deep opposition to that, even though I myself use the feature when it‚Äôs there‚ÄîI won‚Äôt derail things by monologuing on it). 

You might enjoy Unavowed if you haven‚Äôt tried it yet, though! Our publisher made it and it‚Äôs fantasy, more comedy oriented, few puzzles, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970507288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1350, 'last_played': 1562543491}
review:
I've played through this game a few times now. I usually give myself a year or two between playthroughs so I can forget the story enough to enjoy it once more. 

This sort of game reminds me of those old King's Quest adventure games, except this one has a post-apocalyptic sci-fi setting.

The art style, graphics, story, voice acting, and puzzles are all on par. I enjoyed listening to the director's commentary as well. Would definitely recommend
developer_response: Thanks so much! Glad to hear you got so much pleasure out the game. You might enjoy our follow up, Strangeland, though it is very different in mood.

M√™me si le jeu est assez court, plut√¥t lin√©aire, et avec une histoire pas forc√©ment la plus inspir√©e du monde, j'ai pass√© un bon moment sur ce jeu, et je le recommande.

Thanks for the kind words!

Our follow up, Strangeland is higher resolution and has much better animation.  (Of course, also a different setting and mood, so perhaps it would fall short for you in other ways...  But it's the same trio of us who made it.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198151344565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1659124982}
review: This game is great! It has a cool story, characters that have depth, user-friendly interface (use your numpad), great sound and multiple endings. On top of it all, the level of detail is INCREDIBLE. There were so many little things you would probably miss on the first playthrough... I had to see an ending 5 times (while hunting for achievements) to get one of the references. Honestly, I'd love to see a movie based on this. Still reading? Just go and play it already!
developer_response:
There actually is a movie vaguely in development. Who knows if it it‚Äôll pan out?

You might enjoy our follow up Strangeland, which has many of the elements you enjoyed in Primordia, though a different mood and setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039603822', 'num_games_owned': 590, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 783, 'last_played': 1657997197}
review:
Great little game.
It suffers a tiny bit from the whole "rub things together until it fits" and sometimes the solutions are a stretch, but it has a few excellent puzzles for sure, and the story is pretty riveting. 
10/10 would try to plasma torch everything in my path again
developer_response: So glad you liked it! Our follow on, Strangeland, I think has a little less such item combining, though to some extent it is an unavoidable aspect of how a stumped player solves puzzles in a P&C.

author: {'steamid': '76561199055898439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 620, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1663105990}
review:
Amazing artwork, superb writing. Hilarious robot vernacular. My only complaint was it was over too soon.

Edit: Since I wasn't expected the developer to respond to this review, I decided to gush more. The fact that it was over too soon for me is in no way a critique--just that I could have spent hours more in this game's distinctively atmospheric world. I'm a big fan of the post-apocalyptic aesthetic and this game really stands out in it's depiction of beauty in decay. I mentioned the artwork, but the music is also excellent and an important part of this game's unique mood. I dig the way using tools to salvage and jerry-rig are in important aspect of gameplay. I dig the way the robots' programmed thought processes are represented. But I think what I liked most about this game is that every character is written and voiced in such a compelling way. Dialogue can feel like a chore in some games--definitely not in this one. I'm going to incorporate 'b'sod' into my everyday vocabulary.
developer_response:
Glad you liked it! We did do a bit of spin off content that you can grab for free on Primordia-Game.com, but that‚Äôs not the same as a longer game. :)

We also made a follow up adventure, Strangeland, but it‚Äôs quite different in setting and mood, even if I‚Äôd say it is animated by the same spirit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055037379', 'num_games_owned': 492, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 578, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 578, 'last_played': 1656898368}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043989302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1654226065}
review: After almost 10 years I've come back to this game for a restart/refresher and boy can I say it still is one of the most impressive point/click games I've seen. The art is incredible and the universe is something you wish you could explore more and more of. Can we also applaud the soundtrack? Yeah, let's do that. One more thing, the voices for the characters all fit so well and it makes you really love them and their own unique personalities. Please pick up this game if you like point/click adventure types.
developer_response:
So glad you enjoyed it! There is a bit more in the universe available on Primordia-Game.com (spin off story, art, poem, etc.). 

We recently released our second adventure, Strangeland, which is quite different but which you might also enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016365353', 'num_games_owned': 1032, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1653071240}
review:
Titolo acquistato e poi dimenticato nella libreria Steam da quasi un decennio, tornato alla ribalta per la recente e quantomai inattesa traduzione in italiano che mi ha spinto a recuperarlo dal fondo del magazzino e a completarlo. Un'avventura grafica sorprendentemente carina e dai temi forti, personaggi carismatici, tutto condensato per√≤ in un minuscolo spazio di azione nonostante alcuni enigmi abbiano risoluzioni multiple, mai scontato in una avventura grafica canonica.
Bella anche la pixel art messa in mostra, pi√π quella dei personaggi che dei fondali di gioco, a volte davvero troppo scuri e scialbi per far esaltare sia i dettagli sia oggetti interagibili.
In ogni caso, un ottimo titolo nel complesso, nient'affatto complicato ma con alcune geniali intuizioni davvero eccellenti.

Cheers...a Crispin.
developer_response: Ha! Sono cos√¨ felice che tu l'abbia scoperto! Un giorno speriamo che Strangeland sia anche in italiano; forse tra un decennio puoi verificarlo. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197971469381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1652849859}
review: Amazing game - loved it. Highly imaginative. Some puzzles could be frustrating pixel hunts, but not bad. Lots of endings, which was fun. Great story and interesting characters overall; good atmospheric music. Some plot points were predictable, but the game did such a great job making the world come to life I wanted to know the details - which is not easy to pull off. One of the best point and clicks I've played.
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it, and many thanks for your kind words! You might also like our follow-up, Strangeland.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994909078', 'num_games_owned': 2591, 'num_reviews': 225, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1652303652}
review:
There are a few design decisions that I am not a fan of in Primordia (many have to do with pixel hunting and some trial-and-error because clues are inconsistent), and I am also particularly not a fan of branching narratives in games - or puzzle solving with different solutions but with one that is silently punished in the game and you don't know until much further, or the end of the game -, but I *loved* Primordia. A game that has many coincidental (or not) similarities with Beneath a Steel Sky, including that frustrating aspect of showing you very little of what promises to be a huge world, it works best when it pushes you to do McGyver like combination of objects, which is a crucial part of any adventure. It looks and sounds beautiful, the characters are decently rounded, and it is an obvious effort and labour of love. 

Recommended.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it! BASS was an inspiration for the artist, who wanted to explore its inaccessible places. So now you‚Äôll have to make your own game to explore ours! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198278573201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1652352502}
review: Replay this game every couple pf years, enjoyed every time. The characters are gripping (for a bunch of robots) and the storyline is fantastic. The art in this is a feast for the eyes, the puzzles and all the interconnecting pieces make for one of the best point and click games i've ever played. Hands down one of my favourite games of all time, and would recommend to anyone who enjoys sci-fi, dystopia scenes and anyone who loves a good fantasy story.
developer_response:
Thank you so much‚Äîfor the review, and for coming back to our game year after year. 

You might enjoy our follow up, Strangeland. Different setting and themes, but same team and similar goals in design philosophy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033736908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1652037999}

author: {'steamid': '76561198180439931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 849, 'last_played': 1677913254}
review:
Where Strangeland, Wormwood studio's OTHER masterpiece, is my personal favorite game in this genre, Primordia touched my heart no less than its successor did. Where Strangeland excels in telling its incredible narrative through the harrowing winds of a tempestuous madness, Primordia excels in delivering an equally provocative narrative through characters, worldpieces, and subtle messages told along the way that reveal a far darker, more sinister background to this bleak and dilapidated landfill we once dubbed Earth.

First off, I need to get this off my chest because I've waited nearly 3 years to say this: Primordia's aesthetic is jaw-droppingly, tear-jerkingly gorgeous to me. I sat for hours in the Unniic just listening to Metromind preach of the grandeur of her City of Glass and Light, and I wish I could go back to make those hours an eternity. Every dusty, broken-down heap, gilded with the faint remnants of a false life, flickering with the melancholy flakes of a binary will that inches to survive; it all was just so haphazardly beautiful to me that it lingered in my psyche for years to come. I think it goes without saying, but the art direction that these games receive is some of the best in the indie industry.

There are a TON of things I'd love to talk about in this review, but I just don't have the time, so I'll limit it to this: Primordia is the first game I've ever played to make me truly question if the antagonist is truly a villain or not. Metromind is a character masterclass on how to truly maroon your audience in the limbo of their own morality. And don't mishear me: other video game antagonists, such as Gwyn, Lord of Cinder from Dark Souls or The Pale King from Hollow Knight, make it perfectly clear that they are morally grey; that have done equally good and bad things and that characterizing them as hero or villain is, at best, shortsighted and foolish. But halfway through her monologues at the peak of the tower, I was seriously questioning whether or not Metromind was truly unjust in both her actions and her ideals, and if I was the fool all along. She's characterized by many to be an authority-hungry power-junky, but if she really wanted to hoard power, she would never have created a city where robots could thrive and never worry about energy usage. She bans religion, and the act of leaving the city, but the robots she cares for just don't know any better. They don't understand that if they leave the city, they'll likely perish in the dunes, or if they worship Man, then they will become preaching slaves to ideals that staunch the act of progress; the very ideal that Metropol runs off of. Every action she took had me question what would truly be the best course of action if NOT that: Either steal the power-sources from outside the dunes and neutralize any hostility in your way, or let Metropol slowly bleed out without the means to provide for its citizens. Either usurp the regents and adjudicators that once held the city together, or let all perish in the wake of your humility. Either stop Horatio and Crispin from taking what's theirs, or let them have it so they can die in silence amidst the nil. It's SOOO interesting, and lingered in my system years after I had completed the game. Because of that ALONE, this game enters my top 10 favorites, and I don't feel a shred of doubt saying that.

Where other mechanical medias focus so much on the age-old, beaten-to-death question, "What does it mean to be Human[?]", Primordia pushes far past that to the point of no return; to a world where we had our chance, and failed, and naught but the scattered shrapnel of that failure remains in our wake, asking us with sorrow, "What remains of Humanity when we are gone?" I can think of few other games that left me staring dead at the screen when it was all over, begging in my mind to relive it all again, if only to die once more. 

...This game costs $10 btw.
developer_response: Wonderful review. Thank you so much (for both of them)!

author: {'steamid': '76561199212705932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1650745522}
review: This game was amazing. Out of all of the games that Wadjet Games have made, this one is probably my favorite. Perhaps with the exception of the Blackwell series. I really liked the characters and the dialogue throughout the game. The puzzles were a joy to solve and most of them were not unfair (which is quite rare for a point and click XD). The setting was beautifully designed and the story was great. Overall, this is a really good game that you can get for cheap, especially when it's on sale.
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it! It‚Äôs not actually made by WEG; they just published our game. (About half of WEG‚Äôs catalog was developed by other studios.) Its a fun group of devs to be a part of, since we all have slightly different takes on the point-and-click genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083557837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1645734152}
review:
This game has a nice story, nice world building, and I found myself very immersed. 

The only time I got stuck was when I didn't realize there was another room on the ship, so I missed out on an incredibly important old towel. In all other cases, it was difficult but in the best way! You need to crack several codes, but don't worry, as the game will save all important clues for you.

Glad I could play it!
developer_response: So glad you liked it! I think we did a better job of showing exits and having the rooms flow in a natural way in Strangeland!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045141882', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 1811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1811, 'last_played': 1648374421}
review:
Do you like post apocalyptic wastelands and corrupt city states?  Lots of lore and lots of robots?  This fun game is for you.  Your choices open up lots of possibilities and a number of endings.  Some puzzles are tricky but for the most part the colorful characters and voice acting keeps things interesting.  I thought their successor game Strangeland had more intuitive menus and controls (I had played that one before this one, also in the commentaries I was miffed I couldnt just read the text and click ahead instead of waiting for the audio to end) but this point & click is also worthy of your collection.  

The Developer really stays in touch with the fans too which I really like, responds quickly to comments.  Give this team your support.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words and for supporting both our adventures!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011581319', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1670082938}
review:
Absolutely recommend this classic point-and-click adventure game. The artwork both conveys the beautiful landscapes and mournful losses experienced by the characters in this a post-humanity wasteland environment.  Multiple options for dealing with puzzles are a lot of fun to discover on repeat playthoughs. Also the voice work/ambient soundscape is truly the best in the genre and is in my personal Top 3 Adventure game soundtracks to listen to at home (along with Technobaylon)!!  

As a long time fan of the creators at Wormwood Studios (and their collaborations with Wadjet Eye Games) I realized that with the Switch release of Primordia -- I should take the opportunity to leave a written review for the game on Steam. Give Primordia a try on your platform of choice, it comes with my highest recommendation!
developer_response: Thank you so much!

author: {'steamid': '76561197986527965', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 412, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1501822967}
review: Very good point & click adventure game. Good plot & stories, well written characters and dialogue, humorous on occasion, puzzles mostly make sense (only 2 or 3 that are annoying), multiple endings. One of the best point & clicks game I've played through.
developer_response: Thanks so much! You might enjoy our follow-up, Strangeland, though it has less humor (probably less puzzle frustration as a trade off).

author: {'steamid': '76561198056429627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 533, 'last_played': 1646449712}
review: Solid game with good, logical puzzles. Choices do matter, and many puzzles can be completed in multiple orders. It reminds me of some old-school games in the puzzle structure (and graphics), which is what I'm looking for.
developer_response: Very glad you liked it! You might enjoy Resonance (a game of the same era with solid puzzles) or our follow-up game Strangeland.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998332408', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1646150268}
review:
By the time Primordia came out, Wadjet Eye had made a real impact as a publisher with Gemini Rue and Resonance.  Primordia really cemented them as the premier publisher for classicly styled adventure games, and with good reason.

Great characters with excellent voice acting, very well thought out puzzles (many with multiple solutions!) that try and stay away from the "adventure game moon logic" trope.  A fascinating story told in an intersting way, and while the art has kind of a monolithic color palette (i.e. brown) the art is so well done and interesting on it's that what seems at a glance to be a very bland visual style is in fact one the best looking games Wadjet Eye has ever released!

Really enjoy Mark Yohalem's deep dive commentary into his influences, themes and thought process when making the game as well.

Truly a classic
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words and for all the support you‚Äôve shown to point and clicks in your prolific reviewing. 

If you‚Äôre a glutton for punishment, Strangeland has a LOT of commentary and annotation, it‚Äôs sort of a big tapestry of inspirations. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198070605428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 999, 'last_played': 1489972133}
review: Will always hold a special place in my heart as the first point-and-click adventure I played as an adult, and how I rediscovered the genre.
developer_response:
What a wonderful review to read -- so glad it brought you back to the genre!

Not sure if you've seen our follow-up Strangeland... different game, but similar spirit and style, and of course a P&C adventure. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198057567694', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1646009667}
review:
Incredibly well-written, beautiful game with an insane amount of personality and charm.

The humor hits, the emotions score and the story captures you into a believable post-apocalyptic world.

It may start off a bit slow and I admit my ADHD brain considered quitting not far from the beginning, but after a while I was entranced - especially after I got the hang of the point-and-click mechanics I didn't have the chance to grow up with.

The soundtrack also stands on its own in comparison to other indie titans in several regards.

There's also a little bit of extra fan service content on the "Primordia game" site for people who don't want to part with the world yet in the form of a spoiler-free visual novella, a character log and a short poem.

The only downside is that the game is quite hard and many puzzles have far-fetched solutions, even with the implementation of a hint-giving sarcastic companion. You probably want to have a guide open in the background.

TL;DR - A masterpiece. Play it.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for these beautiful words. A real light in dark times. 

You might enjoy our follow up game Strangeland; it‚Äôs different but same team and similar philosophy, without somewhat easier puzzles and more helpful hint system. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198140801438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1643820917}
review: This game is a masterpiece. Amazing story and lore coupled with stimulating gameplay characterized by clever puzzles that manage to be tricky while being perfectly logical at the same time add up to a wonderfully immersive gaming experience. I literally squealed in awe several times while playing it. Audible squeals, at that. The dialogue and in-game text is fantastically written and contains some deep philosophical elements, and while the overall tone is serious, there is a good deal of humour thrown in there, too, mostly thanks to your witty little floating sidekick. The game is full of interesting characters that are fully voice-acted, and the VAs all did a solid job. The graphics are old-school and pixely, but serve their purpose without fault and are charming in their own way. Lastly, the game not only has multiple endings, but also multiple paths you can take towards getting to one, judging from the achievements that I've yet to unlock. Some of these paths I didn't even think were possible while playing the game! This is by far the best point & click adventure game I've ever played, and I've played more than 20 games of the genre. In fact, I would consider it one of my favourite games ever of any genre, simply because of all the 'OMG' moments I experienced while playing it.
developer_response:
What a wonderful review to read! Grateful for your kind words. 

You might enjoy our follow on game Strangeland‚Äîit‚Äôs different but shares many of the qualities you mentioned in your review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083961114', 'num_games_owned': 74, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1642749222}
review:
Minor spoilers ahead:  Great game/story, though I don't know why the androids needed religion/gender as it does nothing for their function (unless there were companion/pleasure units, which there aren't.)  Maybe humans wanted to make their creations seem more like them?

I wish there was a little more of the world to explore, There are really only two locations and many associated locations within those.

It's aged pretty well too for a ten year old game, assuming you like SCUMM style point and clicks that is.  This very much had some strong Beneath a Steel Sky vibes tot it.

EDIT: responding to the dev comment:  Forgot about Steeple.  So the robots built by humans built robots as they were made themselves, which makes sense I suppose.  Kind of like the zeroth law of robotics.  Anyway thanks so much for commenting, and of course making such a fun game.  Looking forward to some of the other titles I saw as well.
developer_response:
Glad you liked it! Even finishing a game of this scope was hard for a team of hobbyists, as we opted for depth of areas (plenty of things to interact with) rather than breadth (more rooms). Certainly compared to something like Monkey Island 2 it is much smaller!

The robots have gender (in a very loose sense) because humans gender all sorts of things (ships, tools) including concepts such as justice or the homeland. Most of the gendered robots in the game were made that way by humans‚Äîthink of Clarity like the statue of justice outside a courthouse. After humans were gone, surviving robots continued to play out the roles they had been assigned, and some even gave themselves such roles to make sense of the world. 

The game mentions that humans had delegated even religious functions to robots (hence Steeple) and after humanity disappeared the AI responsible for religion used that as a lens for explaining the relationship of humans and machines. 

Hope that helps!

author: {'steamid': '76561198017232020', 'num_games_owned': 1369, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1355, 'last_played': 1707995919}
review:
The writing on this game is outstanding, as is the voice acting. The world is very interesting, filled with a lot of different and intriguing characters. elegant, with great depth and sadness, warm comedic relief, a grand, meaningful and thoughtful story in a believable world-after-man, awesome voice acting, surprising and creative puzzles, a seamless hint system (Crispin, your floating companion, offers hints and sarcastic comments when you're acting stupidly) a perfect soundtrack and beautiful visuals. Loved every minute of it.

Highly recommended.
developer_response: Thank you very much for those kind words! Given the things you enjoyed about the game, you might also like our follow-up, Strangeland!

author: {'steamid': '76561198150431830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1005, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1005, 'last_played': 1640997526}
review:
Pretty solid point-and-click. The story is compelling, and the world is well fleshed out. Definitely keeps you motivated to keep moving along. The puzzles are really hit and miss though and there isn't much diversity in them. I would have like a bit more depth on the puzzle front. If you've played and enjoyed machinarium, you'll probably enjoy this as well.

Good value for your money, especially if you can get it on sale.
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it! Machinarium is great!

author: {'steamid': '76561198129771193', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 303, 'playtime_forever': 293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 293, 'last_played': 1640552639}
review:
Overall an enjoyable if fairly difficult game. The story was so-so, but it was quite funny at times.

Pros:
- Very well voice acted
- Pretty funny at times
- Interesting take on what would happen to self-aware robots after humans are extinct
- The robots all had definitive personalities that came through well
- Lots of different endings to try out. I like that it gives you options for how to resolve the story - I found it lets you do what *you* would do rather than forcing you to choose between less-than-ideal options.

Cons:
- Very difficult at times. Even having a function to highlight all interactable objects would help significantly. As it was, I ended up having to use a walkthrough for more of it than I'd have liked.
- There is a hint system, but most of the time it doesn't tell you anything, and when it does it's often useless (e.g. telling you your next objective without any hints as to how).
- Unlike most P&C games, you can't double click an exit to quickly go there. You have a fast travel system for most of the game so this isn't a big deal, but it would be nice.

Verdict: 7/10
developer_response: Thanks for giving it a go!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997858582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1641411673}

review: Top notch point and click game. The characters, plot, voice acting, art direction, and soundtrack are all excellent. The mystery drew me in, and I stayed for the witty, philosophical writing. The puzzles and other interactive elements are pretty good, though there's a bit of frustrating pixel hunting in a couple of places. Luckily, you have a companion who will point you in the right direction to get back on track if you miss something. It's become a fast favorite of mine, and I highly recommend anyone on the fence give it a go!

EDIT: Ha! Just saw your Strangeland review! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025739009', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1640614132}
review:
This is frankly one of the best point and click games I've ever played. It actually has a world, a story, a plot. The dialogue and the voice work are greater than the sum of their parts. There is an ease and a flow to the game that had me invested within minutes.

Mechanically, the game has smoothly incorporated a lot of functions that would otherwise mess with immersion. For instance, I ended up utilizing the hint function several times before I even realised that's what it was - I thought I was just making conversation.

Highly recommended for anyone with a passing interest in point-and-click games. I guess I'll dock a point for the fact that a civilisation of sexless robots still bothers to default to the masculine, with a few ridiculous exceptions that just draw attention to how absurd it is. Besides that, it's oddly sentimental, bitter-sweet and immersive.
developer_response: Lovely and kind review. For what it‚Äôs worth, there is an explanation to the robot pronouns in the commentary‚Äîeffectively a byproduct of human engineering, e.g., Clarity being modeled on Iustitia, but that may not solve the irritation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023879124', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1565879160}
review: A lot of the newer games in this genere are not able to capture the magic of the old point and click adventure games the way Primordia did for me. The puzzles were engageing, the story was good, i liked the music and the graphics were more true to the old days in how it captured the imagination and isn't cartoonified like many other games. The start was a bit slow, but when I managed to figure out what to do I could not put the game down until it was finished. If you like adventure games that don't just copy the style, but actually feel like the good old games, this is among the best ones out there.
developer_response:
What a wonderful review to read! We are very much animated by the spirit of the classic adventure games we grew up with, and it means a lot to hear that Primordia captured that feeling for you.

You might enjoy our other adventure (Strangeland), though it is both thematically different from Primordia and maybe a hint more modern (e.g., higher resolution).

author: {'steamid': '76561197980482234', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 4618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1027, 'last_played': 1703700416}
review:
I love Primordia, and I play it around once a year. But should you buy it?

The graphics are as you see in the screenshots; exceptional and stylistic with a retro resolution. 

Voice and music are excellent, and the sound effects are fitting.

The story is excellent but impressionistic. It feels true to life in that common knowledge is never explained, but that leaves us in the dark about so much of the world's history. There are plenty of clues and Horatio being in a strange, unknown land is a plot point, but it's an impression of a world, as opposed to a Tolkienesqe deep dive.

Which is all great, but there are some flaws. Early game decisions can lock you out of the "best" endings (the author and I have had discussions on what defines "best" here), there is the occasional pixel hunt, an unmarked logic puzzle, and some questions that escaped from the LSAT, but most adventure gamers are used to that sort of thing or worse.

It's an exceptional game, particularly for the price. I highly recommend it.
developer_response: Thanks! As ever, an insightful and generous analysis of the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065819152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 1187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1187, 'last_played': 1638570583}

author: {'steamid': '76561198260401907', 'num_games_owned': 1958, 'num_reviews': 320, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1638227812}
review:
[b]"Primordia" is an indie, small sci-fi point and click adventure but it has a huge heart. You will get immersed inside its fantastically designed, post apocalyptic world with the melancholic atmosphere, the emotional dark story and the unique characters. But it is not only the narrative that shines here. The pixelated visuals are so artistic, the puzzles are well built and creative, the music is remarkable, the voice acting excellent and the humor discreet but enjoyable. "Primordia" was developed by a small team but managed to become one of the best point and click adventures of the decade.


Manometer: 9/10[/b]


The good
- It is so artistic visually. Great pixelated graphics with a unique brownish color palette. Fantastically designed post apocalyptic world with a lot of details here and there.
- Awesome melancholic, dark atmosphere. It has something metaphysical in it.
- Great sci-fi story full of mysteries, agony and emotions. The past and the present come together gradually managing to maintain your curiosity till the end. One of the best stories in the genre.
- Marvelous, weird characters. They are well designed visually with unique personalities. Some of them are really crazy. The protagonists, Horatio and Crispin are so loveable and iconic.
- Puzzles are genuine, well built and creative with good variation. They are very challenging without being too difficult. Each one of them gives you enough clues to proceed to the next one. You won't get stuck somewhere for long. Great balance that helps the game's excellent pacing.
- Fantastic music. It is mostly calm and subtle but enhances the atmosphere in the best possible way. Each place has its own musical identity.
- Very good and convincing voice acting performances. Nicely processed robotic voices.
- A lot of well written dialogues. You will never get bored of speaking with the NPCs. Horatio and Crispin can comment on so many different things and object combinations. Also if you stay inactive for some time the characters start making clever comments by their own. There is a lot of work here.
- Good, discreet sense of humor (mainly coming from Crispin) that gives you a small break from the melancholic atmosphere without ruining it.
- Simplistic but smooth and pleasant animations.
- Great overall design that manages to direct your gaze to the interactive objects, although the game is mostly brownish visually. There is almost no annoying pixel hunting here.
- It is philosophical enough. It makes some deep thoughts about communities' structure, artificial intelligence, humanity and civil rights.
- Instead of adding a typical hints' button, they have incorporated it inside Crispin. If you are out of ideas you can have a short conversation and he will give you a little push. It just feels more natural this way.
- It offers fast travelling through a map you are carrying. This is a nice addition to avoid big and boring walking sessions.
- It has multiple endings depending on you decisions during the last parts of the game.
- There are many hidden things to discover, while some information will be revealed only if you do things in a certain way. That gives the game some extra depth and a little bit more replayability.
- It is cheap for a game that good.

The bad
- The upper dropping menu is a little bit annoying. It comes out much earlier before your cursor hits the top side of the screen. You will end up opening it accidentally all the time.
- There is only one puzzle that I found its logic a little bit odd (the memorioum one).
- There are two or three objects in your inventory that are used too many times in multiple puzzles. This is not necessarily bad, but alternative solutions may be more creative.
- I wanted more. Wish it was longer.
developer_response:
What an amazing review! Extremely generous, both in its assessment of the game and in the way you have taken time to provide key information to potential customers.

For what it's worth, one tiny tidbit re: the reusing items con. This was a deliberate choice, maybe right, maybe wrong, based on my view that when you have an item repeatedly used, it enhances the character by becoming a sort of signature accoutrement (Indie's whip, Bobbin's distaff, etc.). Agreed that it can make some puzzles a bit dumb, though. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198140485114', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1676652566}
review:
Well, there isn't many point and click games to my liking out there, but this one had me captured. The whole atmosphere made me dive in head first to the deep lore of this game. This game proves that there were much more care for games from developers than nowadays.
  The game is relatively short, but has a bunch of great and creative puzzles where you actually have to think to progress. The music gives me goosebumps literally and makes the game feel much better.
  It is indeed a game you can not afford to miss!!
developer_response: What a beautiful review. For what it‚Äôs worth, we are still developing games (Strangeland is another adventure of ours) and we try to put as much or more care in today as we did a decade ago when making Primordia. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198274464448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 714, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 714, 'last_played': 1636948760}
review:

Ne vous m√©prenez pas, j‚Äôaime Primordia, en fait j‚Äôai tellement aim√© les personnages, l‚Äôunivers et l‚Äô√©criture que j‚Äôai √©t√© d√©√ßu que le jeu n‚Äôaille pas plus loin, car on parle de quoi quelques heures de jeu et 2 ‚Äúzone‚Äù, soit les dunes et la ville. Honn√™tement, je me verrai tr√®s bien faire un rpg dans cet univers √©tendu (avec des factions, des combats et tout) il y a tellement de potentiel. 

Mais bon je disgresse, pour faire court ces super bon et vous devez l‚Äôacheter, y a pas de raison.
developer_response: Merci beaucoup! J'ai pens√© qu'il valait mieux laisser les aventures au joueur √† imaginer, et une carte avec de nombreux espaces vides √† remplir. Nous avons fait une histoire d√©riv√©e (traduite en fran√ßais) appel√©e "Fallen", et elle est gratuite avec d'autres contenus sur primordia-game.com.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970782311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1635713688}
review:
I've had this game for ages, finally got around to play it. The pixelized graphics are gorgous, audio design is great for the most part. Some voice lines have odd volume/distortion/acting differences, some single lines from certain characters feel like they've been performed by completely different actor. 

Some puzzles were a bit headscratchers, until I realized the game had an automatic notes-list, which had the clues to the puzzles I was stuck on... doh. The puzzles generally were sensible, but one particular one was a bit too much for me, even after reading a walkthrough I still don't have a clue how was I supposed to figure out [spoiler]the last word to enter in a terminal.[/spoiler].

I'm not much of an achivement hunter, but I did see through few of the possible endings (at least some of them can be seen just by loading a save from last possible room & trying out different outcomes). 

On technical side, the game did not crash, ran well, but alt-tabbing caused few odd issues. The audio kept looping in the background, and windows were jumping around as if the display mode had changed. There were odd colored bars on the sides of my screen, it looked like the game wasn't meant to run on a 16:9 display. Nothing fatal, but just weird.

Overall, I feel like this was pretty good game. Thanks, Wormwood! :)
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198107995303', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1634566519}
review: Insane troll logic point-and-click. Runs like crud, stuttering and juddering on a modern machine.
developer_response:
Sorry about your bad experience -- and especially sorry that you didn't pull the ripcord before the 2-hour mark, and so can't get a refund.

It would be good to hear more about your machine in hopes that we can address whatever was causing stuttering.  (It's an old game with an old engine, but we've tried to patch it to keep up with latest systems, so I'm disappointed it didn't work well for you.)  Obviously, that wouldn't address your problems with the puzzle design, but we always try to fix what we can.

Sorry again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198116311040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1633873471}
review:
Phenomenal writing and the perfect length for a game like this. 

The number of cryptic WTF moments is also very low for a game like this and I only needed to look up a tiny hint a couple of times. Most of the puzzles are really logical and solvable if you apply some brainpower. 

Highly recommend this one.
developer_response:
So glad to read your review! Always great to hear that the game connected with another player!

You might want to give our follow up, Strangeland, a look. Different premise but same team, same philosophy behind it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050990958', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1633645636}
review: A brilliant game. Many years after playing some pirated copy, I found this on Steam and bought it. Now runs on Linux.
developer_response:
You rule! What a kind gesture to buy the game and to leave a review!

We've always felt that people playing our game, whether they pay for it or not, is a good thing, and your review just underscores why. We recently came out with another (Strangeland), which you might enjoy... it's on Linux too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015457923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 508, 'last_played': 1593415205}

author: {'steamid': '76561198043388752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1631659999}
review: Yeah! Philosophical, spiritual, very relevant. Voice acting and interesting characters keep things fresh as you explore and solve puzzles. Cool characters. Mythic quest. Clarity was kinda a lame character . I had to glance over a guide a few times by the end of the game, was a bit annoying. Based game. I'd recommend to anyone!
developer_response:
Lovely review, though I will say that Clarity is very dear to my heart. :D

Also, you might enjoy our recent release Strangeland, which is even more philosophical/spiritual in orientation. It's also a point-and-click adventure, but it's more psychological/allegorical than science fictional.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120288886', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1630814936}
review: Great game. Fantastic story, world building, atmosphere, and puzzles. At one point I had to look at a guide but for the rest of it, it was so satisfying to figure out what to do next. Sometimes I would have to put the game down, come back in a few days or a week and take a fresh look at the clues. To me it was the perfect side-game to play when I'm almost done for the night. Should be obvious but don't buy if you're looking for an action game or instant gratification.
developer_response: What a great review to wake up to! Sounds like a great approach to playing the game. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197968321265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1630249567}
review:
A beautiful adventure! Nice, stylized graphics with well fitted, immersing music draw a comical-dystopian world in which you encounter puzzles of varying difficulty to solve.

After i played it through, i really regret of looking some solutions up in a walk through.
That said, there is little replay value in Primordial, because some puzzles can be solved in different ways, which grants you achievements but this is not worthy for me.
I am fully satisfied with the story and i wish i had not taken it as weekend "movie" but as a more lasting task where i tried longer at some point to appreciate it
developer_response:
So glad you enjoyed it! It‚Äôs very hard to avoid the temptation to look up hints, but the important thing is that you have fun, and if you do, it doesn‚Äôt matter how you play the game. :)

You might want to check out our recently released second game Strangeland. Different mood but same team and same approach, though the puzzles may be slightly easier. (Not sure if that‚Äôs good or bad here.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198053346903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 752, 'last_played': 1629083188}

author: {'steamid': '76561198101697269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 1010, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1706045096}
review:
At first glance Primordia looks... strange to say the least and you'd be right but if you love sci-fi post apocalypse adventure games then Primordia is a must play. Within the first hour of gameplay you'll probably be confused about what exactly the story of Primordia as but the slow build up is a great pay off and helps to develop a strong relationship between the two main characters and fantastic world building. 

Primordia has some really great writing, interesting and even challenging puzzles, characters you'll connect with and some fun references to games like Fallout. Even the voice acting is great and really helps to draw you in to the story and characters. Normally I would quickly go over the plot of the game but I feel like anything I say could be a spoiler. 
Primordias art style is almost Gaudi like which pleases the eyes because nothing is ever boring to look at despite the heavy use of orange and browns.  
The relationship between Horatio and Crispin harkens back to that of Foster and Joey from the Steel Sky games another great sci-fi post apocalypse point & click game, and their back and forth will keep you amused throughout the whole game.
 The Gameplay itself is very user friendly like any typical point & click adventure game Primordia is controlled entirely with the mouse making it easy for anyone to play. Primordia can run on just about anything unless you're trying to run it on a potato.
Primordia is honestly an amazing adventure game and I think it's one of those games that you just have to play to really get what makes it so fun. 

At ¬£6.99 ‚Ç¨8.23 US$9.66 in my opinion is more than reasonable and if the price is still more than you're willing to pay you can always wait for a sale.
developer_response: Thanks for the beautiful endorsement! If you think Primordia is strange, I tremble to imagine how our follow up Strangeland would come across... :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198107882774', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1642632573}

author: {'steamid': '76561198097310797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1708, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1723, 'last_played': 1628409264}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089586409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1628060971}
review:
Wormwood, please get started on Primordia 2!

I just finished my first play-through, and this game is incredible, even with it's few minor flaws. The story, dialogue, and voice acting is phenomenal. The graphics aren't great, but the animations are fluid and the character designs are well thought-out. The soundtrack is very immersive and atmospheric. The puzzles are engaging, although many of which were beyond my capabilities (but I'm kind of a dum-dum).

Anyway, awesome game if you like point-and-click and/or AI-post-apocalyptic stories. I'm off to replay it!
developer_response: Glad you liked it! I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôll do a Primordia 2, but we did recently release another adventure, Strangeland.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056676356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1627930296}

developer_response: Thanks! You can also get hints from Crispin in-game. :)

review:
Awesome adventure game! I really liked the weird setting and the banter between characters. Very well written with an adequate amount of backstory. I found myself wondering about Horatio's prior versions and their adventures before the game takes place. Two thumbs up.

Strangeland next!
developer_response: Thanks! Strangeland is very different (and no banter, alas), but I hope you will enjoy it, too!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970306169', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1627419859}
review: Probably my favourite game published under the Wadjet Eye Games label. A world that teases you with its lore and pushes you to dig deeper. A great balance when it comes to difficulty, combined with a good hint system in Crispin should you get too stuck. Finally, there are a surprising number of alternative ways of handling various puzzles, I don't think I've encountered a point & click with so many before.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the kind words and high praise! So glad our game clicked (ha ha) for you. :)

We just recently released Strangeland (https://store.steampowered.com/app/1369520/Strangeland/), which is a very different game, but it might be worth checking out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099618883', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1626019130}
review:
[b] Story [/b]
The game tells an interesting and well thought-out post-apocalyptic story. The story allows for a certain degree of variance as to its flow as well as it offers multiple endings.

[b] Assets [/b]
The game's assets are really unique and well-made. The decision to keep the game in the style of the 90s, i.e. pixelated sprites, has made the game feel nostalgic as for someone growing up in the 90s.

The ambient background music and sound effects are climatic and fit the general atmosphere of the game.

[b] Puzzles and item interaction system [/b]
The puzzles were interesting and a pleasure to solve. To the contrary of some point & click games, all the item interactions are well thought-out and logical. It was nice to have Crispin give you hints whenever it was necessary.

I was impressed with the amount of work the developers put into the item interaction system. Noticing how trying to combine certain two items results in a very specific, witty and unambiguous comment from the main character surprises the player in a positive way.

I liked the many computer science references and jokes, be it hardware or software related.

[b] Summary [/b]
[i] Primordia [/i] can easily be classified as one of the best point & click adventure games I have ever played. Merging the two worlds of post-apocalypse and cyberpunk together and expressing them so beautifully through art style, music and interesting ideas requires a lot of creativity and effort for which the developers deserve praise.

[i] Primordia [/i] easily deserves a 10/10 rating.

+1 for Fallout references!
developer_response: Lovely review.  Thank you so much‚ÄîI‚Äôm delighted to read that you enjoyed all the little touches.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121092798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1627426522}
review:
Easily one of my favorite point-and-click adventures from the last decade. I fell in love with the story, characters, art, atmosphere, voice acting, music, and all of the easter eggs they threw into this fantastic game. I always hesitate to give out perfect scores, but this one truly deserves a 10/10 from me! 

I don't mean that in the sense that the game is "perfect" or that everyone will enjoy it to the same extent. It's just a perfect game for someone like me. I'm a [i] huge [/i] sucker for hidden lore and macabre plotlines - especially if it involves well-written characters. I also grew up on these kinds of "click on everything and try all the things" games so that nostalgia factor definitely helps. 

If you're even remotely interested in any of the things I've mentioned in this review, I absolutely recommend trying this out :)
developer_response:
Thank you so much for this great review! (Your avatar let me know this was going to be a good one!)

You might check out our very macabre, though also more surreal, recent release Strangeland. Quite a different game, but it hits some of the same notes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006187164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1594014829}
review:
Primordia is a unique science fiction point and click adventure, with a world worth exploring.
I'm not a regular point and click player, but I enjoyed Primordia quite a bit. The alternate endings and choices had me replaying sections just to see how the narrative would develop. The world building is just the right amount, keeping you up at night imagining more, but explaining enough to develop the narrative within the game.
Primordia is clearly a labour of love and is worth your time, even if you're not a point and click regular.
developer_response: What a beautiful review.  Thank you so much for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080684810', 'num_games_owned': 570, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1624805924}
review:
The second walkthrough to get all achievements makes me feel much better about this game since I get a better understanding of the plots, the settings and most importantly, the touching details. 
In the first walkthrough, the puzzles bothered me very often. However, it did provide me the most enjoyable but also frustrating puzzle solving experience (the kiosk one).
Although I still can't enjoy much of the gameplay ( I've probably played too many point&clicks games that I grow tired of this type of games), the characters, the subtle details and the writings are the most intriguing elements of this game. The richness of the endings reminds me of Planescape: Torment too. The voice actors also did an excellent job! 
On a side note, I really appreciate the activeness of the developers. This game came out at 2012 but the developers are still active in the discussion and provide response swiftly, which is really rare to see nowadays.
developer_response: Thanks so much! It‚Äôs easy to stay active when our players are so encouraging. PS:T was a big inspiration for me, so I‚Äôm not surprised you detected its flavor. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198071848932', 'num_games_owned': 1225, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1623089127}
review:
This is more a mixed review. I'm giving a thumbs down to water down all the praise. I genuinely think that this game is overrated.

First of all, the worldbuilding in this game is exceptional. Everything is thought out and I can see that the developers spent a lot of time making this world live and breathe.

However the gameplay combines the worst aspects of point and click genre. Pixelhunting, collecting every piece of junk to your inventory and then combining it all together or applying to every interactable pixel you have successfully hunted down. In the end, the gameplay was quite tedious to me.

The single reason why I completed the game is because I had a walkthrough. I don't mind being stuck, but only if it happens occasionally. I don't mind hard puzzles, in fact, I love them. But only when they are built on logic instead of trial and error.

The story for the most part is pretty basic: they stole something from us, let's take it back. Only in the very end there will be some development for this.

I won't say that this is a bad game. It clearly isn't. But I was expecting a lot more after seeing its Steam rating. Maybe I was just unlucky when I got stuck for the first couple times and then my initial displeasement affected the rest of the game. Or maybe I just need to accept the fact that point and click games are not for me.

Anyway, I can't really recommend this game, unless you are a point and click fan and want to experience a carefully built world. Don't hesitate to check a walkthrough once you're stuck.
developer_response:
Sorry you had such a disappointing experience.

I wouldn't want Primordia to discourage you from trying other P&C games, though. Some have no meaningful puzzles to speak of (e.g., Unavowed, Backbone), others have no inventory puzzles (e.g., Loom, Botanicula), so you can find games in the genre that might bother you less. Obviously I'm biased in its favor (else, why bother making such niche games?), but I've always felt that point-and-clicks offer a unique experience that can be a very special one, though obviously not for all players.

As for your Primordia-specific criticisms, they're all fair reasons to dislike the game. You can get hints from Crispin, so consulting a walkthrough is not per se necessary, but some players find the hints themselves inadequate.

Sorry you came away unsatisfied. Our goal is always to provide greater value than the player invests in the game, so that he or she comes away enriched. Sorry that didn't happen in your case.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043643161', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 732, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1623698176}
review:
.

edit:
I was too lazy to write a review but if a developer actually cares enough to respond to my lazy period I guess i'll write one. 

This game feels like a classic. The puzzles are all really well made and don't feel like your just arbitrarily clicking on things hoping to progress, and genuinely make you feel like you solved something. One really good example of this is one of the chapters revolves around you getting a bunch of number sequences that make up a code for a door and you need to figure out how all of the numbers fit together in the larger sequence and it doesn't tell you how, and nor will I, but when you figure it out you'll understand why it's such a brilliant puzzle. 

On the story side they managed to create a world that feels lived in, with a history far longer than what is seen from our perspective with characters that feel both real and consistent. Horatio and Crispin have a great dynamic and their dialogue and voice acting are great. The story is really well written and it really drives you to learn as much out the world and explore the secrets of the past.  

(Minor spoilers... sorta?)

I would say my only gripes with the game is that most of the endings you can get are achieved the last like 3 minutes and can be completely missed if you fail to click on a single dialogue option in the final confrontation and there's like four achievements tied to endings so you have to keep replaying that final dialogue multiple times to get them. It didn't really feel like my ending was as a result of how I played the game up to that point but only choices made in those final moments. I wouldn't say this ruined the experience for me or anything as I was still invested enough to go and see those endings but maybe something to think about for any future releases.
developer_response: Thanks so much for this extended, and lovely review -- you're very generous, and I think your mild criticism at the end is quite fair. I would prefer to have endings that depend on a series of things that accrue throughout the course of the game, but it's hard in an adventure game and "expensive" in terms of design resources vs. player experience. But I agree with you 100% philosophically. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198021230785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1623646609}
review:
As a fan of point and click adventure games, I was surprised that I hadn't heard of this game sooner. Once I was hooked by the story I wanted to see everything the game had to offer in one weekend.
It has a very intriguing story, if a little brief. I find the world the developers created captivating and close to an actual future for us if technology is left to run rampant. Robots have become the primary life form and what has happened to the human race is a mystery. The plot unravels at a brisk pace, which I find refreshing. The more I played the more I wanted to learn about the game world and the lore behind it. 
The voice acting is exceptional. You may recognize several of the voice actors from other indie games. The main character is voiced by Logan Cunningham, best know as the narrator from Supergiant Games' Bastion. 
The gameplay will be familiar to any veteran of the point and click genre. I was able to start the game and hit the ground running without any instructions. The puzzles aren't too difficult, I was able to brute force my way through some of them. 
If I had to give this game a numbered score, it would be 8/10. My only complaints would be its brevity, but honestly that could be seen as a positive aspect. Also there is no way to highlight objects that can be interacted with, which would be a nice option. If you are a fan of point and click games and like a post apocalyptic setting with a great cast of robotic beings, give this game a shot.
developer_response: Thanks so much! I‚Äôm very glad you found our game after all these years!

review: I don't write reviews often, but just finished this and had to give this game more than a thumbs up. The writing is enjoyable, story/lore interesting and could stand on its own. The puzzles are not unreasonably hard or obtuse, and I get a sense of satisfaction after solving each of them (especially the one where you have to [spoiler]get Memorious's code[/spoiler]). This game begs a pre/sequel!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032632811', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 749, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1622687744}
review:
I've always found myself drawn to stories set during an android-oriented end-time and Primordia certainly delivers that bleak yet personal wasteland plot with a unique blend of AI and dead-earth themes. Without giving much away, the plot is a great example of how to raise the stakes of the protagonists' goals. As for specific praise for the narrative, Crispin notably stands out as a quirky, self-aware assistant that manages to play his role [i]without[/i] overdoing it. It feels rare to have a point-n-click/adventuring companion that's actively helpful and welcome company. Primordia had me continuously contemplating its world, characters, and puzzles, even long after I had closed the game.

The stellar environmental art and faithful UI did a sound job of taking me back to an era I wasn't around for. Standard gameplay comes with the classically inconsistent puzzle clarity native to point-and-click adventures, although Primordia's tone would have been worse-off without it. The sense of indifference that comes with a less explicitly lock-and-key world makes Primordia feel, for lack of a better word, organic. A certain audience will find it nostalgic, another audience may yearn for a walkthrough. It‚Äôs a rare breed of game at an admirably high quality that tastes as vintage as the rust and dust that it lavishly depicts.
developer_response: This is just a lovely review -- obviously I'm happy that it's so positive, but it's also has a very personal voice and a clear explanation of what you liked, and what the game's feel is. Thanks so much for sharing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042535807', 'num_games_owned': 1035, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 10641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10641, 'last_played': 1621370410}
review:
Charmingly old-school while still polished and usable, unfortunately in some regards too old-school with some garbage that comes with it. Still worth playing for P&C fans and the story is certainly unique.

Unfortunately, it has the bad kind of pixel hunting. A P&C without hot spot highlighting is just stupid. Sure, let me click and wander aimlessly because I didn't figure the 5 pixels on an object are actually another object. Some description are less than useless. Examine hatch, get response "it's a hatch". I mean... where do these 3 brown pixels lead? Granted, there aren't any overly convoluted stretches of logic. There's a decent number of completely random puzzles and interactions that make no continuous sense, but what can you expect. And asking the sidekick buddy for hints is a nice feature, even though it admits the primary failure of most P&C games.

Graphics are mostly cool and very atmospheric. Animations are mostly great for pixel art, although a lot of the stuff is just pixelated drawings or rendered effects.

There's some clever stuff in the story, great world-building, some really brilliant stuff. Although plenty of mediocre and just filler stuff too. Dialogue is mostly great, the sidekick is stereotypical but still cool.
developer_response:
I‚Äôm glad you enjoyed it, flaws and all!

Our recent release Strangeland has more QOL features, though I am (stubbornly and probably stupidly) committed not to put in a hotspot highlight feature. All the hotspots are much larger, at least. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199149549722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1622024898}
review: This is a great story, told well. The puzzles are sometimes almost entirely impossible so don't feel bad when you search for the walk through guide. But take it one puzzle at a time, try to do it yourself, and enjoy the world they've created. Also, lots of endings and options to try - worth going back.
developer_response:
Glad you liked it, even if you found the puzzles frustrating!

Crispin can also dispense hints (sparing you a trip to a guide), but they are a little less direct than a walkthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963873634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1621827548}
review: Simply amazing!  If you like point-and-click adventure games, you'll love this.  And even if you don't, the story and multiple ending and thoughtful puzzles and, dare I say, mysteries will intrigue and delight you!
developer_response: Thank you so much! As I just mentioned in response to another review, we are releasing our follow-up game (Strangeland) in about 24 hours, and I could hardly be any more nervous. Reading your kind words is a balm!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049940473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 287, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1621818959}
review:
For me this inhabits a sweet spot. It looks & feels old style (e.g. small game world) without being abstruse; yet doesn't sacrifice challenge or agency for sake of streamlining. It's funny and indulgently verbose, yet profound & poignant in an understated way that feels more "show" than "tell", or even is implied. There is lore to uncover but overall the respectable worldbuilding operates on "less is more", and the game isn't too long or elaborate.

It's just really accomplished, one of the best point & click I've played. It's insightful and thought-provoking - but the strong characters come first. These robots somehow worked their way into my heart, and I really cared at the end.
developer_response: What a wonderful review to read! We are a day away from releasing Strangeland and your kind words were like a shot of euphoria and adrenaline alike. I hope our second game connects with players as well as Primordia did with you!

author: {'steamid': '76561199171522538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1621624372}
