author: {'steamid': '76561198034916155', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1621538677}
review: A beautiful adventure with interesting characters, an enthralling plot and a world that invites the curious explorer. As I get older and responsibilities mount up I find myself increasingly valuing these small games that really respect your time. The game's best feature is its hint system that minimizes frustration and always nudges you in the right direction, all without belittling your intellect. At 7 hours completion (and I'm slow!) it's certainly worth your time.
developer_response:
Thank you so much! Especially glad you appreciated the hint system, which took the coder and me an absurd amount of effort to implement. :)

Our next game (Strangeland) releases in a couple days, and respecting the player‚Äôs time was really a core principle with that game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965129510', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1621489782}
review:
Oh Primordia, thou art a game so fine
Set in an enthralling world, a place so divine
Thy history, a joy to find
Short playtime, never too tedious, no bind

Some puzzles were too cryptic for me
I needed help, a walkthrough to see
But even so, a solid experience thou art
I can recommend thee, from the start

For thou art a game for sci-fi and point-and-click fans
A joy to play, with no demands
So I thank thee, Primordia, for thy charm
A game I can recommend with no alarm.
developer_response: Thanks! So glad you liked it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198219425039', 'num_games_owned': 3047, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1621098423}
review:
Grade: S (90/100)

Very charming game that is well worth your purchase.

The puzzle design in this game is its main draw as the puzzles not only feature multiple ways to go about solving them, but even feature choices that alter the world and other characters. I also especially enjoyed the character interactions and humor the game has to offer. The game is very engaging. It's only about 6-7 hours long but you can easily play it a second time to explore other options so I would say its worth the $10.

The story is a bit shallow and the lore leaves me with some unanswered questions, but overall still of high enough quality.

Full Review: https://ravencrowgames.blogspot.com/2021/05/review-primordia.html
developer_response: It makes me immensely glad to read a review focused on‚Äîand positive about‚Äîthe puzzles. Many thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198846117864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1620340251}
review:
Pros: Wonderfully atmospheric graphics, music and sound design; great voice acting; an intriguing story and a world that I enjoyed immersing myself in.

Cons: quite a bit shorter than I thought it was going to be; a few of the puzzles were clunkily implemented (where I guessed the right solution but didn't carry it out in [i]exactly[/i] the way the game wanted me to).

Overall I'd definitely recommend it, and though I did finish it within only a few days that's partly because I was so engrossed that I wanted to keep on playing.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the kind words (and fair assessment). We do have a little bit of additional free content (no more game), if you're further interested in the setting: 

http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html
http://primordia-game.com/log.html
http://primordia-game.com/poem.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198126775145', 'num_games_owned': 629, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1564870853}
review:
Pra f√£s de point and click, esse jogo √© uma verdadeira joia!

Os personagens s√£o muito cativantes, sem exce√ß√£o. At√© os personagens secund√°rios apresentam profundidade e caracter√≠sticas marcantes, al√©m de acrescentarem informa√ß√µes sobre o mundo. Os di√°logos e a dublagem s√£o √≥timos, os puzzles s√£o bastante l√≥gicos, desafiando na medida certa e mantendo o foco na narrativa, o que faz o jogo ter um bom ritmo. 

Tem uma hist√≥ria maravilhosamente bem escrita, que desperta a curiosidade (especialmente para quem curte fic√ß√£o cient√≠fica e o tema da rela√ß√£o entre humanos e intelig√™ncias artificiais) e na qual eu me pego pensando at√© hoje. Tem pequenos momentos, muito sutis e sens√≠veis, que passam quase despercebidos, mas que dizem muito sobre a tem√°tica do jogo. [spoiler] como o momento em que seu personagem encontra um "humano" (n√£o quero estragar muito essa cena) mas n√£o faz ideia do que seja aquilo, o jogo n√£o faz nenhum alarde a respeito, mas voc√™ sabe a import√¢ncia que aquilo teria, em vista de como os humanos s√£o vistos naquele mundo [/spoiler]

review: I mean, Im not sure if the game is good or bad.. but for sure it couldn't hold my attention for too long. Thought it was a bit confusing, specially if played with 'long' breaks in between. Not really my thing or to my current mood. Will maybe give it a 2nd chance in the future.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn't enjoy it -- especially since you're past the point of being able to get a refund.  (Though perhaps in that possible future playthrough you might like it more.)

I always viewed a player's lack of enjoyment as a failure on our part and a breach of a trust:  you came to the game because we made you think you'd like it, and then you didn't.  I hate the thought of someone investing time, money, and hope in our game and coming away unsatisfied.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044113235', 'num_games_owned': 671, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1616636992}
review:
[i]Primordia[/i] is a point-and-click adventure game focusing on Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot residing in desert wastelands after the demise of mankind. With your sarcastic sidekick Crispin, you set off to the mysterious city of Metropol to take back what's yours.

[h1]The Pros[/h1]
‚Ä¢ The art direction is really, really cool. It's steampunk, but not at the same time. I love the designs for the various robots you interact with.
‚Ä¢ The premise is also, [i]really, really cool[/i]. There's a lot of lore and it sorta just sucks you in.
‚Ä¢ It's fully voice acted, and the voice acting is well complimented by a witty script that kept me grinning.
‚Ä¢ For the most part, the story makes sense (I may need to replay it). I'd say it leaves me with "healthy" hypothetical questions, rather than plot holes or cliffhangers.
‚Ä¢ Speaking of hypothetical questions, there's a lot of science fiction themes being explored here. However, I'm very impressed that they address some that I've never seen before in a robots-only setting (which I won't spoil).
‚Ä¢ This is one of the few games I've played where the only character arc was my own, and I was extremely satisfied when Horatio reflected my sentiments to uncovering the plot.
‚Ä¢ I found pretty much all of the characters to be likable and distinguishable from one another. Even if the names are similar, the personalities are not.

[h1]The Cons[/h1]
‚Ä¢ The game in and of itself is a puzzle. You're piecing together how to get from A to B, because someone told you about B but you can't find any evidence of B at A until you've explored all of C, which someone else will tell you about. Needless to say, there's plenty of sleuthing and there were a couple of occasions where I was stuck banging my head against a wall until something clicked.
‚Ä¢ Some environments didn't entirely sell me. For example, characters just happen to have been standing in place for an indeterminate amount of time until you come along. Others felt like going through a grandiose entrance to find that the only animals at the zoo are a few flamingos and an anteater.
‚Ä¢ To add to that, environments are needlessly complicated. There's plenty of things for Horatio to observe but carry no functional purpose. If I got lost I'd just examine everything and eventually Horatio would give a massive clue that I'm supposed to interact with it.
‚Ä¢ Some dialogue checks ask for the "most correct" answer. I screwed up on one and did my homework, came back to retake it, gave a correct answer, but not [i]the[/i] answer.
‚Ä¢ Trying not to spoil the plot, but there's only one ending that I found satisfying and I wasn't able to get it on my first try.
‚Ä¢ This game has a locked aspect ratio that makes black and red bars appear on the sides of my screen, which was weird. Steam overlays don't work well and the audio gets really janky if you alt-tab.

[h1]The Indecisive[/h1]
‚Ä¢ Graphically, I'm uncertain. It's obviously pixelated to an extent, but it appears as though it was originally hand drawn (as aliasing on many sprites suggests). However, the steampunk-esque asthetic falls apart in some places because wood, metal, and brass are all very [i]brown[/i]. This made some areas boring to look at.
‚Ä¢ Though I don't really play point-and-clickers, this game has some of the tropes that I associate the genre with. Characters say their dialogue once, and I often forgot crafting recipes or points of interest. However, when I pulled off a puzzle I felt really good. In that way, this game feels a lot older than it actually is.
‚Ä¢ Crispin, whom you can talk to for hints, can get confused if you mess up on things or do them out of order. For example, I failed a dialogue check and Crispin had no idea on how to advise me thereafter. You should really try and do all the conversations before moving on so that way Crispin works correctly, because though you've spoken to someone, you may not have selected the dialogue tree related to the hint he gives (otherwise the hints lose their luster or he can tell you about stuff you haven't discovered yet).

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
Overall, [i]Primordia[/i] gave me a unique experience in a stimulating setting and story that reminds me of [i]2064 Read Only Memories[/i]. The characters are all robots, but they're neither apathetic nor overly emotional. The story unravels well, even if I end up running in circles during some of the sleuthing. I'm glad I bought it and will likely play through it again.

[b]8.25 / 10[/b]
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words, and detailed, balanced review. The only thing I'd mention for your replay:  while it's true that there are conversations that only happen once, any necessary information (as well as some unnecessary information) is stored by Horatio in his datapouch, so you aren't going to get locked out if you forget something. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197996469501', 'num_games_owned': 758, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1616621317}
review:
Primordia is the best kind of point-and-click adventure game. Aside from the obvious (unique art and an interesting setting), you're able to ask your sidekick for guidance. He doesn't give you the answers, but he often offers a sanity check. "Maybe what we need isn't in this area, boss." Similarly, your character offers up sanity checks and just-helpful-enough advice such as, "I'm not here to fix that", so you know you don't need bang your head against the wall trying to fix it.

This may be the first point-and-click adventure game since I first got access to the internet, where I didn't get so frustrated with a puzzle that I gave up and looked it up. Sometimes you just need a little nudge in the right direction to know where to apply yourself without giving away the solution, and Primordia walks that fine line well.

In addition to the style, setting, and great voice acting, the story outdoes itself with multiple endings that involve doing different solutions to the end puzzle, instead of just letting you pick a different dialog choice (though a few of those are on the table as well). I highly recommend Primordia to fans of point-and-click adventure games.
developer_response:
‚ÄúThis may be the first point-and-click adventure game since I first got access to the internet, where I didn't get so frustrated with a puzzle that I gave up and looked it up.‚Äú

This made me immensely happy. We spent an absurd amount of time on the hint system, for just this reason. I‚Äôm so glad to hear it worked (for you, anyway) and that you had such a positive experience with the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198063206887', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1616560562}
review:
I recently revisited this game after a year or so of not not playing it. No reason to revisit it or start from where I left off, but it was damn well a good choice to!

The story line is HIGHLY immersive and had me wanting more and more with every puzzle solved. After every puzzle I felt closer to the truth and understanding of who I was. I was so enthralled in this quest that upon completion of this game; I felt a void. This void was not because the game lacked completion but rather that I wanted more. I could play an endless amount without getting bored, as I could expect the puzzles to progressively get harder and harder, always challenging me.

For those who haven't yet played: you should TRULY consider this game. The dialogue, story, artwork, animations, and more will surely captivate you.
developer_response: What a wonderful review! I‚Äôm so glad you enjoyed the game and grateful you took the time to share your kind words.

review:
Feels like a 90¬¥s classic point and click. One of the best Scifi Adventures i have played. 
Rich storytelling, great characters, great dialogs, great humor, fantastic enviroment. There are many things to see and find, and multiple ways to solve a "quest" (incl. moral choices that change the story/even multiple endings are possible). 

While most of the riddles feel logic and rewarding, the overal difficulty is high in my opinion. After playing i  found myself wanting more,more more....same feeling i had playing monkey island for the first time. Highly reccomended!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993419334', 'num_games_owned': 617, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1613264318}
review:
Primordia is a very interesting game. That's really the best way to describe it; it has an interesting setting, it has interesting characters, it has an interesting progression of events. The ideas, the lore, the commentary on different aspects like progress and individuality. All of it is interesting, contemplative and creatively rich. There is a lot to talk about, so let's get right to it.

The visual design of Primordia is alien, quite literally so as it seems to draw some inspiration from Ridley Scott, and it affects everything in the game. The UI design, the layout of the starting ship, the dirtiness of its setting, the questions of sentience and morality in its narrative; it's all steeped in this sense of slow decay, where choices are made with the realisation that it won't really make the world better or regain what has been lost, but instead secure a bit of happiness in the face of an ultimate end. It's bleak, but not entirely hopeless, as there are happy endings to be had even in a world of rust and sand - if you can get to it, that is.

Scavenging is important in the world of Primordia, which fits perfectly with its point & click gameplay. Primordia was a game that clearly helped Wadjet Eye Games to set a pretty impressive image of adventure games that make sense, with logical puzzles that still requires some thought to figure out. The amount of solutions that rely on "moon logic" (meaning using random objects with each other for a nonsensical result) is close to zero, which makes the experience so much easier to digest. With that said, Primordia does require more thought than most of its siblings in the Wadjet Eye library, but has a handy sidekick to give you hints as well as alternate solutions for some puzzles to make up the difference. It's quite effective in establishing trust, which leaves room for the game to be a bit more complex. A lot of the time I was stuck simply because I hadn't listened closely enough, or just didn't remember a certain piece of information. In other words, the game requires a bit from you as a player, but it's rarely unfair.

However, there is a negative in the game, and it's somewhat severe; the way that it focuses on exploration clashes with its artstyle. The way that the game handles hurdles is through exploration, meaning that the best way to get unstuck is to look around; maybe there's another puzzle that gives you an item, or maybe you need information from some NPC. The problem is that environments are difficult to see clearly and many interactable elements simply blend into the background. I don't know how many times I walked back and forth across a wooden walkway in the sewers before I noticed that there was something in the water right next to it, and I only discovered it because I happened to move my mouse over it by accident. This is a problem in many point & click games ("pixel hunting" is a term for a reason), but it's particularly bad in Primordia because of the muddy colour pallet and the way that you normally solve problems - by going around the entire world talking to people. 

You can imagine the situation yourselves; you can't for the life of you figure out the solution to that one puzzle, so you end up looking everywhere, interacting with everything just to make sure that there isn't anything new, only to go back to the beginning and find that you just missed a piece of texture that apparently was something important. It's partially a failure of the visual composition where many things could have been improved, from colour choices to visual effects to camera angles, and partially the failure on the mechanical side, with a lack of a "view all interactables" button of some sort. This game more than any other needed to consider the user experience when crafting these aspects simply due to its artstyle, and failed miserably in doing so.

And yet, for being the only real issue in the game, I can't say that it had an enormous impact on the experience. I've given it a lot of space because it simply deserves being pointed out, and Primordia is a great example of the problem. It's annoying and bogs down the pacing, but it doesn't make the world or the narrative less believable like some other games are guilty of. In a way you can say that the flaw matches the game, with its intricacies and mysteries and alienness. If there would have been more urgency in the narrative I would have probably felt much worse about it, but the main character is a scavenger in an unfamiliar place; it almost makes sense for him to stumble around a little. It is still a flaw though, one that undoubtedly should have been discovered and adressed.

In the end, Primordia is a great adventure game. The setting is great, the characters fit in perfectly, and the tone of a world in decline is perfect for the narrative it presents. It has its flaws, and much like many of Wadjet Eye's games it doesn't quite reach the level of truly breathtaking, but dang it if I don't end up caring and feeling satisfied by the end anyway. There is a core of greatness in this game, a reflection of what a dystopic future actually means for the inhabitants of it and if good can still be preserved in it. It's a thoughtful game that deserves your attention, so I suggest you simply give it its due.
developer_response: What a beautiful‚Äîand thoughtful‚Äîreview. So glad you enjoyed the game, and grateful you took the time to share your kind words and assessment.

review:
i am an old fan of point n click, since i played Monkey Island and Day of Tentacles...my best one was Gabriel Knight series (ven if the first one was the best ! )
well..Talking about PRIMORDIA, graphic remind me Discworld but in a steam punk era...in fact lot of this game remind me Discworld...and it's a good thing.
This game it's a classic style like...but with a serious reflexion about humanity.
you get lot of soft humor
this kind of game could be judged by 3 criterias : graphics, story, puzzle
Graphics ; it's old PnC style, "hand drawing"... old gamers would love it
story : interesting ,easy to follow...maybe too much...it's linear, you smell easily the conclusion, but humot and multiple ending it makes the job.
Puzzle : easy...reeeealllyyyy easy... it's impossible to be blocked.

i recommand PRIMORDIA, maybe because i like the old fashion style PnC... but i spent a good moment, not too long, not too short, it's more like a movie to watch  than a book to read.

Enjoy
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it, especially since you're a fan of the classics!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023020656', 'num_games_owned': 1265, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 910, 'last_played': 1612374497}
review:

PROS

CONTRAS
        - Los puzzles son realmente complicados y es mas, en la traducci√≥n al castellano hay algunos irresolubles (En ingles es mas facil)
        -  Hay mucho, pero mucho, Pixel hunting.
developer_response: Lamento mucho que los acertijos y la b√∫squeda de p√≠xeles te hayan quitado el disfrute del juego. En cuanto a la traducci√≥n, sigo agradecido por lo que considero un excelente esfuerzo de un generoso admirador: en la medida en que la traducci√≥n hizo que ciertos acertijos fueran m√°s dif√≠ciles, es probable que sea el resultado de los desaf√≠os presentados por el idioma ingl√©s subyacente, no una deficiencia. del traductor, que tuvo mucho cuidado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073642658', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1625775254}
review:
Really good game, worth it at full price without a doubt.
One of the best, if not the best point & click I have ever played, the story is amazing, it has some different endings too depending on the actions you take along the game. Every problem the game brings at you can be solved with pure logic, if you put your brain to work you will surely come to a correct answer unlike many other games in the genre, where if you don¬¥t know the answer then just try throwing random objects at the problem and it will eventually work. This game discourages you from doing that, making you have to take a longer path to solve the problem if you just try random things. 
The writing is phenomenal, every character is fleshed out, has his own desires and fits a perfect place in the game's world, which is also very well done and feels very real, every detail is thought out and more than once the game surprised me by allowing me to take on a problem from a different approach. The pixel art is really beautiful, and although the resolution is rather low, it's not a problem, as everything is detailed and easy to identify. Also, this game gives me Planescape: Torment vibes for some reason, and I really love that game. Easily a 10/10 game.
developer_response:
What a generous and lovely review. Many thanks for it!

(Also: PS:T was a key inspiration, so your vibes are well detected!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198008445742', 'num_games_owned': 1329, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 874, 'last_played': 1612141490}
review:
What I loved : great voice acting from everyone involved, the style and the look of the game set a perfect melancholic mood that never lets go with only occasional comedic relief moments from your sidekick. Great character line-up, everyone has something to do and is important to your quest. The puzzles can be cryptic but overall are well presented and solvable especially if you have prior experience with point & clicks. The hint system also is a great way to force you to interact with Crispin. Lots of great little details in the enviroments, dialogue etc. that help build an immersive world.
Meh: I found the story to be predictable and overall not that engaging or satisfying, you pick up on most of the details early on and  everything plays out pretty much how you would expect. With all characters being robots there is no real tension when there is a threat of death to your buddies as you know they all can be rebuilt.[spoiler] The way Horatio seems completely unimpressed by Crispin's sacrifice just ruined the emotional impact that scene could've had [/spoiler]

Overall, if you like point&clicks this one should be on your list. I see a lot of people enjoying the story much more than I had so I might be in the minority here.
developer_response: Thanks for the thoughtful and balanced review -- glad you took the time to share it, and that on balance you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198167936235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1057, 'last_played': 1667729838}
review: Remarkable achievement. A beautiful game in story, graphics and music. Together they create an immersive atmosphere where player is compelled to dive ever deeper into the strange Mad Max like world. The player character Horatio Nullbuilt is a deeply religious robot - a contradiction in itself - who preaches the Gospel of Man: how Man the All-builder created the robots. But as the game proceeds, both Horatio and the player are forced in front of new truths. Lies become truths and vice versa, and the law and legal interpretations of different actions play a big role in the discussions Horatio is forced to have both with himself and with the world.
developer_response: What a lovely review! So glad you enjoyed the game, and took the time to share your thoughts.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988904686', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1611519089}
review: Another solid Wadjet Eye game. It follows their MO in that's it's great, old school point-and-click adventure game with fantastic artwork, well-written story, and well-developed characters that falls apart right at the end. Like their other games, you are given a handful of options right at the end that determines which ending you will get, all of which are pretty brief.  I liked the world of this game quite a bit with its complex history and brilliant Giger-inspired artwork, but left it wanting so much more.  I have played nearly every WE game at this point and I don't think I would skip their next one, but I have braced myself for an amazing start and a lackluster finish.  Like Horatio says in the game of a repeating puzzle structure, I know how this all works.
developer_response: Thanks! Glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989954670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1447490393}
review: Great game, good story, and quite beautiful to boot. Not very long but I'd say its length is just right consideting that there is nothing in this game that is extraneous. I'd love to see a sequal someday, but I'm not sure how such a game should be made story wise.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words!

I don't think we'll ever make a sequel. We did do a free spin-off story (not a game) and some other ancillary materials (www.primordia-game.com has them), but given how much work a game takes to make, I'd rather introduce a new world than retread this one. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197971251537', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1610545188}
review:
What elevates this atmospheric point and click adventure is a strong story, excellent writing, good voice work and tight progression. Graphics are quite low resolution, but the art brings it alive regardless. The music evokes a mix of Blade Runner, Deus Ex and Anachronox, and it really suits the game. As for gameplay, it's pretty standard point and click with an inventory, characters help progress the story, so does combining inventory items and using them in the right places. It's mostly logical and I never got stuck for long. There's even a hidden "hint" system that's not very hard to find, and it's good for providing subtle nudges in the right direction. There are several endings, all easily accessible with a judicious save at an obvious point, but a second playthrough is almost certainly necessary if you want to optimise the ending, because some puzzles have more than one solution.

If the low resolution graphics don't put you off, Primordia is well worth several hours of your time.
developer_response: So glad you liked it! Anyone who includes an Anachronox reference is clearly a person of taste. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198051371994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1703572174}
review: Nice little story. I played through it with a guide and really enjoyed it but part of me wishes I toughed it out. Item combinations and locations aren't insane like some 'point and clicks' like to do.
developer_response: Glad you liked it! It‚Äôs hard to escape the lure of guides, that‚Äôs for sure. We tried to blunt that with Crispin‚Äôs hints, but when a player gets stuck in an adventure it‚Äôs hard not to peek.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171675955', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 324, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1590218905}
review:
A great game with an extremely good atmosphere and music to go along with it. At first the setting was a bit weird, but once I got past two or three hours I realized how unique and legitimately well-made it is. Past that, it's a puzzle adventure game--it's not too difficult, but you can make it as hard as you like. 

I still listen to the OST just because of how well it creates the setting of the game in my head. A post-apocalyptic desert, but nothing like New Vegas or any other rendition of the genre.
developer_response: "Unique and legitimately well-made" is pretty awesome praise, as is any comparison to FO:NV. Many thanks for the kind words

review: Loved it... a really nice atmospheric 'old school' point and click, with some good improvements to the standard UI (eg a clickable map for fast navigation, a data store so you don't need to write things down, and a robot sidekick who's full of helpful hints). Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066076926', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 1000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1609449596}
review:
This is the future, Man is but a distant memory. You find yourself in a world where salvaging scraps to survive is the norm and sentient machines are the only signs of life amidst the ruins. Your livelihood has been stolen from you, so armed with determination and an amusing sidekick you set off on your quest to take back what was stolen from you.

A simple styled point and click adventure/puzzle game. Dont let the graphics turn you away, i personally felt it added to the atmosphere of the game. Has a definite post-apocalyptic feel and decent puzzles though they are not excessively hard, most gameplay requires using tools and item crafting to progress further into the story. I thoroughly enjoyed my playthrough and unlocking all the achievements, its just a pity the game is so short (a few hours say 4-6 in one playthrough) but id still recommend it based on the characters and ideas presented in this game, future perspective.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed it, and thanks for the beautiful review.

It doesn't add to the playing time, but there is a bit more free content related to the setting on Primordia-Game.com, including a spin-off story/audiobook.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039278769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 721, 'last_played': 1609279108}

author: {'steamid': '76561198809540951', 'num_games_owned': 628, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1609129011}
review: I'd like to start this review by saying i am by no means a genius. i used the in game help feature a decent amount, and when even that still confused me, i looked up a walkthrough (only to solve my immediate issue, nothing else) all in all, i really respect that the devs created a game that doesn't follow a single route. yes you're solving issues "in order" but something i see in many games are choices that don't impact the main story being made every 2 seconds. in other games, saying things like "hello" and "i just watched you run from the bank with a ski mask and money bag" will only change the next few lines of dialogue, if that (looking at you genshin) but in primordia, choices you make, or mistakes you make, will show themselves in the world. choices. matter. how cool is that?
developer_response:
What a lovely review! Many thanks for your kind words!

In fairness to games where choices matter less, Primordia is a relatively small game with a relatively small number of characters compared to a sprawling RPG, so it is easier to manage all the combinations of choices. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198214689208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1558294136}
review: One of the best graphic adventures I've ever played. The atmosphere, the plot, the dry humor, charater development, such a combination will keep you engaged to the story and entertained throughout it all. Although I should warn you, you'll be left with an empty feeling of wanting more of it; I sincerely love this game.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for this high praise!

Certainly I don't want to leave anyone emptier than they came -- but I suppose what you describe is a good kind of emptiness. :)  In any event, we did do a *little* more content related to the same world, although it's not a game.  You can find it on www.primordia-game.com.  The largest piece of it is a spin-off illustrated story / audio book called "Fallen": http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

It's all free, so perhaps at least worth a glance to see if it helps with the craving!

This retro looking game is very nicely drawn, full of detail. Every character has its unique, interesting personality, and it shows on their (all voiced) dialogue.
The game is mostly rather easy but the atmosphere and story makes up for it. 
There's also some replayability if you miss out on some things on the way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025070619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1625339109}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960830998', 'num_games_owned': 926, 'num_reviews': 264, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1607627241}
review:
This is a solid point and click adventure, with a distinctive style of its own.

Pros:
Excellent story
Really well produced world, lots of back story and consistent theme.
Puzzles are well balanced, they can be tricky, but always fair.

Cons:
Some of the lines, are funny, but become a bit overused for my liking (like smeg in Red Dwarf we have a lot of B'soding).
Resolution on modern systems is a bit of a problem, I had to read community guides to get it looking half decent on my Surface Book.
Because of the above, I couldnt use my pen as a pointer, which I value.

This game deserves a higher rating than I'm giving it , I enjoyed it and can "feel" the effort and quality of work put in. Something just didn't quite click - like it has done with other modern point and clicks I've played. (Kathy Rain for example)

7/10 - would ask B'sodding Crispin for help again.
developer_response: Thanks for the review -- I think those are fair pros and cons, and I can see how, given the usability cons, you would come away mixed. It's frustrating that despite our best efforts, we can't really push Primordia's underlying engine to be able to work well on modern machines. We've mitigated some of the issues, and I think our next game will mitigate most of them, but it's not as smooth an experience as it could be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085833877', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1607348452}
review:
Classic point and click adventure game, set in a post apocalyptic world populated by machines. The game has humorous character interactions and a rich, well delivered storyline which can be affected by player choices. Play was smooth and bug-free. I thoroughly enjoyed this one and would definitely recommend it to anyone who likes the P&C adventure genre. 

The one thing I didn't care for was that the graphics are somewhat rough, as though they were made for a tiny screen, which made the game feel much older than it actually is.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words! You're right that the graphics' resolution is really about a decade or more older than when the game was released. That was partly an aesthetic choice (we grew up on VGA adventures and always wanted to make *that kind* of game), and partly a necessity (the additional animation frames needed for higher resolution can be very demanding).

Our next game, Strangeland (which should be out in February) is SVGA resolution (four times as many pixels!), but that actually makes it even more antiquated relative to the present year given how long it's been since Primordia -- SVGA adventure games came out about 20 years ago. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198022855622', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1702166980}

author: {'steamid': '76561198815207393', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1607144868}
review:
This game was a mix of a lot of things. There was good: great story, characters and setting/lore, some puzzles that were satisfying to solve, good voice acting and music, immersive art and multiple ways to do some things. The game was very atmospheric which was great.

But there was also the bad, of which was mainly how frustrating the game could get. A lot of the puzzles just don't have a deductible solution. I either had to click each and every item with every other item, and then every item with every object in a scene and if that didn't work, give up and look up a guide. It's never a good feeling to have to look up a guide to get through a game, and I rarely resort to that, but this game was just often aggravating. Sometimes there's a random item hidden away in a place you could hardly notice it at, sometimes you'd get stuck even after clicking everywhere on the scene because you had to [i] right [/i] click something instead of left click it...

Maybe this kind of game just isn't for me. But after finishing a game, I step back and ask myself three questions. How much did I enjoy playing it? How do I feel about the game as a whole now that I've beaten it? And will this game have any lasting effect on me, like scenes and quotes that stick with me or affect anything I do in the future?

The answers to these questions are: 1) not really, 2) satisfied with the ending but indifferent about the rest of the game, and 3) this game will probably not influence me as a person or the choices I make.

I won't say the game is [i] bad [/i] but I really don't feel like the experience was worthwhile, considering not only the cost, which I believe is quite fair, but also the time invested in it.

If you really like point-and-click games, I do think you'll probably enjoy this game, but if you're just a casual player, I wouldn't really recommend this game to you.
developer_response:
Sorry to hear about the frustrating experience! At the outset, I should say: a game developer's responsibility is to entertain players, who have invested their money and time (as you note) but also their hopes in the game. If the player isn't entertained, the developer hasn't just failed, he's broken an unspoken promise between him and the player:  "If you will reward the work and love I put into my game with your enthusiasm and money, I will reward your enthusiasm and money with the entertainment my game offers."  

Every time I hear from a disappointed player, it is a great disappointment for me, as well.  But it is particularly disappointing when the shortcomings in one aspect of the game block a player's enjoyment of some other aspect of the game.  In that instance, it's not just a broken promise, but a missed opportunity -- it's clear Primordia *could* have been a game you enjoyed, but sadly wasn't.

Whenever a player is disappointed, I always ask (small recompense) whether the player would be interested in one of the various games I've backed (either on Kickstarter or charity bundles) over the years, since I never have time to play them myself and thus have an endless backlog of keys.  If you'd be interested, let me know.

As for your specific comments, these flaws are, to some extent, inherent to the genre. Unless puzzles are made trivially easy, the seem to turn *very heavily* on a "flash of insight."  Some players' minds (perhaps simply from playing a lot of such games) turn out to be aligned with the designers' minds, so puzzles seem logical, reasonable, and straightforward.  But the exact same puzzles can seem obtuse, unfair, and convoluted to other players.  Primordia gets a number of reviews praising how rigorously logical its puzzles are, and a number of reviews criticizing its puzzles for having no logic at all.  I'm not sure either review is right; the puzzles are logical enough in my mind, but my mind is subject to preconceptions, biases, blindspots, etc.  The puzzles are not logical in a formal sense; they are conventional, and the question is whether the player has the same conventions I do.  If I were a better designer, I probably would be able to find a way to teach those conventions to players unfamiliar with them -- but even with a How To Play description, automated hints, hints you can solicit, and "wrong answer" quips designed to steer players toward the right answer, it's clear that Primordia falls short for plenty of folks like you.  I'm sorry for that, especially because it seemed like you might have liked the game if I could've designed it better!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039058747', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 923, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 923, 'last_played': 1606203519}
review:
TL;DR Great Short Game with Immersive World and Fun Characters but Puzzles/Achievements Can Be a Bit Obscure

It's a short game although the obscurity of some of the puzzles/achievements can make it longer. But the world building is pretty phenomenal. The characters are great and you immediately love them rust and all. Multiple endings are available, some obvious and some hidden away. I admit to using a guide occasionally. Now there's a BEAUTIFUL hint system built in where if you talk to Crispin he'll sometimes give vague allusions to what you need to do or where you might need to look to find an item to solve a puzzle. Say things like "Hey didn't we see a _____ earlier?" or "Maybe we could do something with X?" But I'm not the sharpest crayon in the box and I was fairly new to the point and click genre so I missed some things and sometimes the hints went over my head. He'd say "Maybe we should check around the Junkyard" and I went "I did though!" not realizing where in the junkyard or with what item I needed to be looking. Looked at the guide and went, "Oh. Why didn't I try that?" The achievements though I really NEEDED a guide. Some of them are quite tricky to find without knowing where to look or what to do and some you can lock yourself out of.
developer_response: Glad you liked it! Sorry Crispin wasn‚Äôt more of a help on some of those headscratchers!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079254367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1605508207}
review:
It's the post-apocalyptic future. You are Horatio Nullbuilt and some robot just stole the power core out of your ship. You must travel across the wastelands, pointing-and-clicking your way to discover who the jerk is, where he‚Äôs hiding, and the deeper mysteries of who built you, and why. It's a well-designed, well-written epic journey with fun characters and memorable moments. There are actual logic puzzles to solve and real secrets to uncover. This game is an shining example of what the point-and-click genre can be. It is perhaps only surpassed by the likes of Unavowed (also by Wadjet Eye Games). Definitely worth the $10. 


This game and many many more are reviewed on the Open Betas podcast. Available everywhere you find podcasts.
developer_response: Glad you liked it! Technically only published by WEG (which developed Unavowed), but we think they have good taste in publishing. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198259625683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1605565769}
review:
Me parece un atraco 10 euros por este juego. la definici√≥n es p√©sima, parece un juego del a√±o 1985, que una pantalla moderna y windows 10, yo no se configurarlo para jugarlo en una ventana peque√±a. En el juego no hay opciones de configuraci√≥n, seg√∫n todo esto, no entiendo las altas valoraciones que he le√≠do por ah√≠.
Querria devolverlo y que me devuelvan el dinero. Me siento estafado.
developer_response:
Primero, lamento mucho tu decepci√≥n en el juego. Obviamente, ten√≠as muchas esperanzas en ello y te decepcionamos. Es el trabajo de un desarrollador cumplir con las expectativas de los jugadores, y fallamos en ese sentido.

En segundo lugar, si a√∫n tienes el juego, definitivamente puedes cambiar la resoluci√≥n de dos maneras. Primero, en el men√∫ Opciones, una vez que inicias el juego, hay una opci√≥n para alternar entre el modo Ventana y Pantalla completa. En segundo lugar, en la carpeta donde tiene instalado Primordia, hay un programa llamado WinSetup.exe que puede ejecutar para cambiar la configuraci√≥n.

Por supuesto, Primordia es un juego de baja resoluci√≥n (320x200x256): 1985 es una exageraci√≥n, pero es consistente con los gr√°ficos de principios de la d√©cada de 1990. Lo hicimos porque esos juegos de aventuras fueron con los que crecimos y siempre quisimos hacer. Y cuando lanzamos el juego en 2012, los monitores de pantalla ancha enormes eran menos comunes. Estoy de acuerdo con usted en que, en la configuraci√≥n predeterminada, se ve terrible en un monitor de pantalla ancha grande. Me complace trabajar con usted para encontrar la configuraci√≥n para que se vea lo mejor posible.

En cuanto a un reembolso, deber√≠a poder obtener uno a trav√©s de Steam dado que solo ha jugado durante .4 horas. Pero si no puede, POR FAVOR, h√°gamelo saber en Steam o env√≠eme un correo electr√≥nico a mark @ wormwoodstudios.com. No estoy seguro de poder obtener un reembolso de Steam, pero al menos, tengo claves de muchos otros juegos que respald√© en paquetes de caridad o en Kickstarter, que nunca podr√© jugar yo mismo. ¬°Muchos son juegos de mucha m√°s resoluci√≥n!

Lo siento de nuevo por decepcionarte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004484646', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1179, 'last_played': 1605060331}
review:
One of the greatest underrated gems of the point and click genre. Taking control of Horatio, a stranded robot just living out his life with his sidekick Crispin in a crash-landed ship, you find yourself getting robbed of the only power source of your home by a murderous robot. In order to survive and take back what's yours, Horatio and Crispin venture out into the unknown to recover the precious power core, using any and all salvage, scrap, and determination they can find. Who knows what awaits them in the Dunes, or worse.

Primordia is a fantastic story driven game. It was the one thing that kept me going whenever I got stumped by one of its many puzzles. A very cool factor is that most puzzles can have multiple outcomes, determining on what items you use, characters that help you, and all together choices you make. The ability to make friends or enemies depends on you. And speaking of friends, the characters, along with the whole world, are expertly designed and especially memorable. Each conversation is uniquely voiced out and each robot has their own traits that make them important and interesting. It was always fun to talk to every robot that came across my path, even when some just sounded like a corrupted printer from two decades ago. Pair that up with the bleak and vast world of the Dunes and Metropol, and it's a perfect match that kept me engaged to explore every pixel of this game.

The puzzles are equally interesting. You got your usual point and click style to solving these puzzles with using items, combining several items, destroying and creating certain items using tools, etc. Each puzzle is unique and as said before, can have different outcomes depending who or what you use. [spoiler]This is especially important on the multiple endings[/spoiler]. 

All in all, Primordia is an excellent game. Everything about it drew me in and kept me wanting more. A truly wonderful experience from beginning to end.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this beautiful review!  It is immensely gratifying as a developer to read that your game has made a positive impression on players, and it provides a much-needed morale boost as we push through the final slog to get our next game, Strangeland, to market!

author: {'steamid': '76561198331862151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1721, 'last_played': 1604584170}

Every characters are well developed - even the villain is significantly persuasive. Puzzles have multiple solutions, and they really matter on further storyline.
Highly recommend to play with commentaries.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060125630', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 62, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1710220935}
review:
Best adventure game I played in years. The writing and worldbuilding is impeccable, the story has a perfect  build-up and drive. The dialogue and voice acting especially carries this - it has a great balance between silly jokes and seriousness. It was clever enough to where even hearing the specifically annoying character - Crispin - was fun to hear, and at least he has a role and place in the world. The puzzles were really good aswell - only once or twice did I get stuck at all. I was also left surprisingly satisfied with the endings, the close-offs for each one were perfect, there was no "joke bad ending", each one of them had merit to be in the story.
My only problem was getting confused as the story built up, by the end I couldn't recognize some of the robots just by their names and the secret end "decryption" made almost no sense to me when I first saw it.
Other than that, absolutely excellent game
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it, particularly that you found the mix of humor and seriousness effective!  I'm also very grateful you took the time to share your kind words.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964416237', 'num_games_owned': 1118, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1602408660}
review:
[h1]Score ‚Äì 9/10 (Get it for B'SOD's Sake)[/h1]

Primordia is a high quality, addictive point 'n' click adventure I wish I tried out sooner! The game has an intriguing story, a likable protagonist, plot twists galore, multiple endings and professional voice acting. It's also accessible for newcomers and veterans to adventure games alike, thanks to logical puzzles, alternate solutions, a lack of dead-ends and an in-built hints system (i.e. your sidekick Crispin). There's not much I can fault about this game except maybe they could've gone more wild with the colour palette, but it's a post-apocalyptic adventure after all, and robots probably don't care much for that sort of stuff, hey?

[url=https://www.choicestgames.com/2020/10/primordia-review.html]Full Review @ Choicest Games[/url]
developer_response: Thanks for the great review (I especially liked the longer one of your website) and kind words. We're lucky your brother got you the game in days of yore! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561199008251840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1601244962}
review: My boyfriend (yes, the one who also left a review and said he was buying me this game) recommended Primordia to me because I love Nancy Drew games and puzzles of all kinds.  It was truly fantastic.  The worldbuilding is extraordinary (I love the little computer puns, like needing the "council code" to get into the tower), the story is compelling, and the puzzles are challenging but make sense.  I did get stuck a few times, but the hints from Crispin allowed me to get through all the roadblocks without outside help.  Also, I don't know who voiced it, but the little robot who says "strange robot, go away!" in Metropol was SO CUTE!  I am going forth to recommend this game to all my fellow Nancy Drew fans.
developer_response:
Your review put the biggest smile on my older daughter's face -- it was she who co-authored the lines* and voiced them, back when she was just two and a half!  (*She always called Horatio "strange robot" and the UNNIIC "spooky place.") I showed her the review just before bed, and it was a wonderful note to end the day on.

I wish you and your boyfriend the best! I believe I quipped to him that a low-res puzzle-fest was not necessarily the greatest courtship gift out there, but it seems I was wrong!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068817861', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1600482950}
review:
What can I say about Primordia? It's a classic adventure point and click game from 2012. It's full of robots and ghosted shells. Some are monitors and screens, others are purely mechanical and never-been-human ones. Some carry the mental "genes" of their creators; others don't even know what humans were. 

There are no humans in Primordia. They have long since disappeared. The new age has come and gone. And while the robots are the best possible version of themselves in a way, the world is just as broken and mistreated as it is today.

Primordia is an exceptionally good experience which I recommend to all people who have at least a bit of those little grey cells Monsieur Poirot keeps talking about in the Agatha Christie stories.

Also recommended for fans of the cyberpunk genre - you will see some familiar ideas and ideals in Primordia, as well as depictions of great robots and small ones. 

This is one of the top cyberpunk games in the 2010s without a doubt. Unless you are biased enough to claim that lack of action = lack of concept, design or story.
developer_response: What a beautiful review, with some fantastic turns of phrase (‚Äúghosted shells,‚Äù for instance). So glad you enjoyed the game and took the time to share this kind evaluation of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131995518', 'num_games_owned': 454, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1600016685}
review:
This sums it up pretty well:

An awesome little game wraped up in a very classic style click and point adventure. The hero (Horatio Nullbuilt) and his humorous sidekick Crispin Horatiobuilt (you get the surnames, I reckon) is on his search for his stolen power core he needs badly for his aircraft. What begins as a simple story after a stolen item opens up fast in global and somewhat transcendental. It asks some philosophical questions without being way to out of line or focus-lost. Most puzzles are logical and there are even some allowing for different solutions. The inventory keeps sorted and won't overstuffs. There are no wild and irrational item-combinations. There's just one puzzle that gets heavy on your brainpower. Crispin with his humorous remarks gets in perfect contrast with the highly focused and rational Horatio and the pretty dense and gritty atmosphere of this game. There are some easter eggs like some trader is offering you a water chip for a G.E.C.K. The voice-acting is top-notch for an indie-game and the art-design is just beautiful. Beware of low resolution (640x480), though.

The plot thickens the further you progress and it won't loose itself within numerous sideplots distracting you from your goal. So it's rather fast paced and do favors my preferences regarding story-telling. There are different endings for the plot and those endings aren't simple button pushers (Deus Ex: HR, Far Cry 3, etc.). Some are pretty easy to achieve while others require aditional brainpower and are rather inconspicuous. So you'll probably achieve a different ending than your buddy because there are many actions you probably do instinctively causing different endings.

I honestly don't find anything I dislike on this game so I highly recommend it to any adventure-fan.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the thorough and kind assessment! I should warn that the resolution is actually 320x200‚Äìeven lower than your review indicates. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198145661544', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1599755986}
review: Another one characteristic game of wadjet and I would not recommend it, not because it is bad. I don't recommend it because it is not as good as the other games of the same company. The graphics are the crudest among the rest of wadjet's games, the gameplay is too simple and the puzzles too. Story is interesting and voice acting is really good yet again. The setting is great, it's just that it is ANOTHER post apocalyptic world type scenario and pretty much same goes with all the rest of wadjet's games, so the repetition kinda gets old. It just does not stand out among the other games, so i would recommend it only part of a bundle with all wadjet's games.
developer_response:
So sorry to hear you didn't enjoy it! It's certainly true that there are lots of post-apocalyptic WEG titles (though, of course, Primordia was the first of them!).

My view is that whenever someone plays Primordia and comes away unsatisfied, it's a breach of trust on our part -- you put your hope, time, and money into the game, and came away with less than you put in. I've got a ton of keys to other games I've backed on Kickstarter or in charity bundles and have no time to use; let me know if you'd like on to make up for Primordia falling short!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987510613', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2747, 'last_played': 1598715744}
review:
Primordia is a hidden gem!  I find most point-and-click adventure games to be tedious (and I'm not very good at solving most puzzles, so I often give up before making it halfway through).
However, once you get past an initial puzzle or two, Primordia delivers a very deep experience with intriguing characters that entice you forward.  The voice acting is top notch, and even with pixel graphics (that are great for the resolution used at the time) many of the views are fantastic.  The interface is well done, and the design of the game removes many of the tedious elements of typical point-and-click adventures.
As I said, I'm not great at solving the puzzles, and don't have the patience for many, so I occasionally used a walk-thru guide for hints But I found that as the story progressed, I really wanted to solve progressively more of the puzzles (and did well with them without the walk-thru's help).
Give this game a shot, stick with it and it will grow into a very deep and intriguing adventure you'll fall in love with!
Turning the commentary on gives great insight into the design of the game, the music composition, and the voice acting.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this generous, beautiful review -- so glad that you enjoyed the game and the commentary track!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008452457', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 371, 'last_played': 1701815431}
review:
It is a shame that this game wont be getting a sequel. 
i feel like this game created a universe similar to star wars, in the sense of mystery and possibilities.
i feel like we only got a glimpse of what this world could be. i loved the game atmosphere, the puzzles, the dialogue, and well... everything else.

oh and the endings. Feels like each ending the game offers could start a grand new story to be told.
Like when  [spoiler] horatio jumped off the tower [/spoiler] i didn't feel like it ended, it felt like they story could go on. 
like [spoiler] factor could wake up and take horatio to its care and begin taking over the city forcing horatio to choose sides or something like that [/spoiler]  
and when [spoiler] horatio got the ship running [/spoiler] i thought i was going to see an epilouge chapter and was so bitter that i saw the credits roll. 
i wish that maybe the company will try to create a sequel or a new game based on the same universe. 

and im not going to lie, the puzzles where you had to remember a code or use the data patch menu was sorta annoying and hard to see (at least for me) but it didn't take any enjoyment from the game.

all in all 10/10
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the kind words! It is so gratifying to hear them.

One of my goals in designing the world (and narrative) was that it would be like a map with ragged edges and blank spaces, so the player could (like you) create new stories in his or her own mind.

We did do a little bit more story in the world here: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html  You might be interested in checking it out!

http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

review:
This game is my favorite Point & Click game so far. I finished it for the second time (bought the game 2 years ago) and it's still so great.
The characters are awesome, the whole story is awesome, the dialogs are very nice, and the Post Apocalyptic atmosphere is INSANE.

Oh, and for everyone who heard this is an English language only game : it has been patched (I don't know when) and it is now available in several languages.
developer_response: Thanks so much for this kind review!  We do now have it patched to include Spanish, French, and German.  There is also a Russian fan translation; the translators worked independently of us, so we couldn't integrate it into our build, but it's out there if people want to grab it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253401441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 863, 'last_played': 1595909276}
review:
This sent me back to my teenage in the nineties and all those Lucasart titles. Great game and story, totally worth the hours needed to finish it. If you are wondering if you should try it, just don't, do it. I won't say much to avoid spoiling it, the writing is amazing.

I encourage avoiding guides since the puzzle-solving is really rewarding. Maybe look for some clues -- you can find them -- not complete solutions.
developer_response:
Thanks, Luciano, for the very kind words!

I'd add that players can ask for hints from Crispin, the protagonist's sidekick, and he will give increasingly strong hints the longer you're stuck.  We did that to offer an alternative to consulting an FAQ or walkthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085450333', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1595962838}
review:
Puh. To be honest, I played this game using a solution. It was far too hard for me to solve it myself. The riddles are crazy.

BUT the story is awesome. It really is. I loved the gritty feeling, the despair, a world where mankind was eradicated and only the machines survive. Maybe. Maybe not.

The pixel art style made me think of my youth, Maniac Mansion and Zak McKracken. Maybe one has to like it, but for me, the graphics are not really important. That's not to say, that the graphics are bad, they are pixel art. But the story trumps all.

So, if you love to solve hard riddles, this game is for you. And if you don't, well follow a walkthrough and enjoy the story. It's worth it.
developer_response:
Ha! I'm glad the story was enough to get you through puzzle frustrations! We tried to make to provide some range of challenge by having multiple solutions (including solutions where some NPC will solve whatever riddle for you) and by having integrated hints from Crispin, but it's hard to calibrate it just right.

If the story is what primarily engaged you, we have a free spin-off story here: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html  It's not a game, of course, but you might enjoy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198012762477', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1413162387}
review:
Primordia is probably my favorite point-and-click game -- yes, even ahead of Monkey Island and other classics. The art is gorgeous. The concept of all of these slowly-dying robots eking out a civilization after the fall of man is compelling. The characters are interesting. The pacing is smooth. The finale is grand and the multiple endings are more than just slightly different shades of the same non-option. 

I always wanted to fly. 

To be fair, it does have a few puzzles that were really odd, but the game was good enough to make me want to push through them rather than say, "To the Internet!" at the drop of a hat -- or worse, just walk away. I appreciated the challenge. 

I also like the pun on Metropol: "metro" being short for metropolitan and "pol" meaning city, so City-City, with the added layer that Metropol is now run by [spoiler]the metro AI -- the controller for the trains, which are known as metros in some parts of the world.[/spoiler] What can I say? I'm a complicated man with simple pleasures. 

Buy Primordia!
developer_response: What a lovely review! So glad you liked the game, and grateful you took the time to share your kind thoughts about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120819492', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1595631755}
review: Extremely engaging and enjoyable game. The artwork is gorgeous and evocative, the storyline is interesting and thought provoking, the problems difficult but solveable and there are a number of alternate endings depending on the choices you make which can add some limited replayability. Very worth the asking price, especially if you can get it on sale. Took me 8 years to play it but I'm glad I did, and now I look forward to the developers' new game, which I believe will be called Strangeland. Gem of a game.
developer_response: Thanks for the awesome review! Strangeland is our next title. Hoping to get it out this year.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014069372', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1595209773}
review:
Managed to finish all of the achievements. The Know It All is the hardest achievement in my opinion because I don't see a perfect walkthrough or guide on it. This game is a gem. Really entertaining. I've been thinking a lot on what's the meaning behind b'sod. Now I know it's the BSOD (Blue Screen of Death). Amazing!

There are a few technical problems, though. The game doesn't support 1080p (because it was created 2009), and the screen fillers are red on the left, and black on the right. The second technical problem is that the music hangs when I Alt+Tab. I can't manage to check a message on Discord or something because the music freeze is a bit annoying.

10/10 for the story and all the other elements that made this into a beautiful and enjoyable game.

BUY THE B'SODDING GAME!
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words, and for bearing with the game's shortcomings to find the things worth loving in it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030819562', 'num_games_owned': 666, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 502, 'last_played': 1595228938}
review: Another great Wadjet Eye game. The usual mix of a great story, interesting characters and imaginative world building mixed with an easy control system and great voice acting.
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198057173667', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1595172666}
review: Really great writing and a super unique world. The puzzles aren't unfair and the way they implement the hint mechanic is really seamless. The sales for this game are usually a steal so I highly suggest putting it on you're wish list and waiting until a sale if you aren't sure.
developer_response: Many thanks for the kind words! We put an absurd amount of work into the hint system, which is normally bypassed in favor of online FAQs or walkthroughs, so I'm always delighted to see someone who actually used and appreciated it. :)
