author: {'steamid': '76561198070706012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1595150435}
review: I absolutely loved the game. Great artwork, good music, good voice acting, and great story writing. Amazing execution, I have not found any bug or crash during my gameplay. I found just a couple of puzzles a little confusing, but 99% of the game was absolutely great. Wish it could have been just a little bit longer because it was so enjoyable. Absolutely recommended for both fans of the genre and for people new to graphic adventures. I got it on sale for incredibly cheap and to be honest I wish I paid it more, the developers deserve the money.
developer_response:
Many thanks for the kind review and generous spirit behind it. I'm glad you got the game on sale -- as a cheapskate myself, I always applaud bargain-seeking, and I'd rather more people play our game, which sales always help.

We do have some other games in the works (including an adventure, Strangeland), so the extra bucks you saved on Primordia can always be spent on them, or on the many other worthy adventures out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198277998996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1612266212}
review: A amazing package that sadly was a bit short.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words, and sorry that it ended too soon!  We do have some additional content (including a spin-off story) for free on Primordia-Game.com, though of course that doesn't extend the game itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117913651', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1589564170}
review:
Primordia is an amazing point and click adventure game. As an adventure game fan, I really liked it.

The setting is a dystopian world, where no humans survive and only their robotic creations (and their robots' robotic creations) are left. It is in this setting that the game tells the story of conspiracy, faith, friendship, enmity, and misplaced ideals. It's a unique world, fully fleshed out with appropriate backstory and leaves you longing for more.

The characters are amazing, especially the protagonist and his sidekick. I love their banter and the way they care for each other. Brilliant voice-acting makes the characters come alive.

The puzzles are clever, but not too difficult. There's a little bit of pixel hunting involved, however. And the terminal puzzle can be difficult for some.

There are multiple endings in this game. I recommended saving your game, so that you can explore all the endings and their outcomes.

Primordia is one of the shining examples of how an excellent game can be made using Adventure Game Studio.
developer_response: What a beautiful review! Thanks for the kind words, and for giving a shout-out to AGS, a great engine and a critical part of keep adventure games alive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055371604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1594936306}
review: Great point and click. At the level of the best Lucasarts quality.
developer_response: Thanks so much! That's very high praise -- perhaps *too* high, but who am I to turn it down? :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198435642240', 'num_games_owned': 523, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 645, 'last_played': 1594699703}
review: Una verdadera joya, lo disfrute mucho. Es una aventura del estilo point & click clasico, con una historia atrapante y algunos dolores de cabeza, con un gran sentido del humor acorde a la historia y multiples finales que desbloquear :) definitivamente 10/10
developer_response: Mil gracias por sus amables palabras: las verdaderas joyas son nuestros jugadores.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040125028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1594935500}
review:
If you read Sea of Rust (R. Cargill) or Project Pope (C. Simak) and loved the idea of a robots trying to figure out their place in the universe this is the game for you!

The game opens with two robots under a turbulent sky, in front of a ridiculously ornate telescope. I thought a post-post-apolcalyptic setting would be dark and drab, and there is a lot of brown, but the quality of the art means every panel is beautiful regardless. The voice acting is excellent as well, and as such the game immediately displays the care which went into it's production.

While the point-and-click gameplay is fun and well-done, the writing is perfect. It's a fun conspiracy story but also manages to ask deep questions about the purpose of religion. Does religion need to be true to be useful? Who knows but I enjoyed the way the game asks the questions.

I haven't finished the game yet, but the 4 hours I have so far have been some of the most enjoyable P&C I've played. It may simply be because the game world very much fulfills my particular sci fi needs but this is one of my new favorite P&C games and I absolutely recommend it everyone.
developer_response: So glad you've been enjoying it!  Simak was a big inspiration (actually, City was the most direct influence of his works). I've always wondered whether Cargill was inspired by Primordia. What're the odds a Horatio shows up in it by coincidence? :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198272919573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1594580239}
review:
Just finish the game, it is cool but not impressive.

The art work in this game really gorgeous (to every DOS game lover), and the early half of the game (fixing the Uniic) is pretty fun : their dialogues and interactions are funny, the puzzles are clever and not obvious, only complain is the bgm kinda repetitive after time.

But when comes to the later half (reaching Metropol) it become a completely different game : The story telling become information dumping and most of it unrelated to the current gameplay, the puzzles are illogical and awful (eg: you need to type in specific words in computer to progress, or rearrange about 10 arrays of codes without rule, or password hint given is in between 2~199 you have to try each possible number) you have to watch guide to figure it out.

I suggest checking out Machinarium if anyone wanna get into point-and-click genre.
developer_response:
Very sorry to read of your bad experience with the game. There is nothing worse than for someone to play Primordia with optimism, to even enjoy the first part, but ultimately to be disappointed -- now we've taken not just your hopes and money, but also your time.

My view is that a player should always come away from the game feeling he or she got more value out than what he or she had to put in.  When someone is disappointed with the game, the best I can do is offer my apologies and to ask whether I might provide a substitute key for some other game you might enjoy more.  If you're interested, I'd be happy to provide you a list of games that I've got keys for from backing on Kickstarter or funding charity bundles.

Sorry again, but thanks for trying our game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135441018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1594550681}
review: Great futuristic sci-fi story, lovable characters, multiple endings, good voice acting. Good job from Wadjet Eye Games as usual. I finished it in 8 hours but it still felt kinda short. Beware that some actions earlier in the game can cause some endings to be unreachable, which is a bummer. I think p&c adventure games are never replayable, not matter how hard they try and this is no exception. I missed 2 endings but I'm not going back to unlock them. However regardless of which endings you get, it is a good adventure so I definitely recommend this game.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed it!  We have a little free extra content in the setting at www.Primordia-Game.com, which may or may not help with the game feeling too short (it doesn't extend the game, but does extend the world a bit).

I tend to agree with you re: replayability.  The exceptions would be the QFG games, the branching Indiana Jones games, and the Pajama Sam (!) games, which have so much randomized puzzle variety and move so quickly, they're fun to replay (for kids, or with kids).  I also think you can replay an adventure after a decade or so when the  memory of how to solve puzzles is a bit fuzzy.  For Primordia, replaying with the commentary track might be interesting to some players, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198424342767', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1008, 'last_played': 1643399480}
review: It was a fun trip back to yesteryear. I don't know how I missed it back when it was first released.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed it!

Now it's not just retro but old! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198041726293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1594381834}
review:
Well written. Old school. A few wonky puzzles (and one that literally requires lawyer logic - dev admitted), but overall a highly enjoyable experience. Would love to see a broader version of this, but I'm still satisfied with what lies within the game. Yes, my seven hours of play are the entire game, and some of that is admittedly the game running whilst I was off doing other things. In total, probably five hours of play. Worth getting on sale if you require a dollar per hour value. Worth getting at full price if you care less about sheer time value.

My one caveat: if brown is your least favorite color, this is NOT your game. The visual spectrum is theme-appropriate, which means lots of rust and world decay. Dirt brown is the new black. And blue. And violet. And just about every other color.
developer_response:
Thanks!  Glad you enjoyed it, warts and all.

In defense of the legal logic puzzle, it's optional (there's another path where you can get a law-clerk robot to resolve it for you) and the puzzle actually involves resolving a legal dispute, so it's not like you need to apply lawyer logic to making a souffle or something! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198027154101', 'num_games_owned': 1141, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1696039258}
review: A game that sat in my library for far longer than it ever deserved. After putting 6.9 hours into it in three days I've fallen head over heels in love with the bittersweet world of Primordia. From the bleak, deteriorating world full of wonder, to the sorrowful synthetic music, this game will pull at your heart and mind beckoning you to think.
developer_response: Glad you pulled it out of the slush pile and had such a good experience! It‚Äôs always gratifying to read such a fine review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133628791', 'num_games_owned': 546, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1610232968}
review: Love me some junk-bot core. This game has incredible voice acting and astounding pixel art, not to mention the narrative. It might be a hard sell if you don't like point-and-clicks, but it may pull you through with it's engaging cast and interesting world building. Recommended to pixel artists, narrative designers, or anyone who wants to live out their dream of being WALL-E.
developer_response: Thanks for this awesome review! Brought a smile to me face.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061597788', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 688, 'last_played': 1594085952}
review: Got partway through this with my young son years ago, and either got stumped or lost interest. Finally came back to it recently, restarting from the beginning, and made it all the way through in a few sessions. An interesting and thoughtful perspective on the "fall of man" and the robot age. Voice acting was good (and entertaining). Some things were a little off base to figure out, but I did enjoy the puzzles which required some brain power instead of just clicking around all the time. I've got a little scratch pad of paper by my desk to help with some of the logic/number problems.
developer_response:
Sorry you got derailed when you played with your son. Point and clicks with my daughters is always a great joy. My elder provided the voice (and in fact the dialogue) for ‚Äústrange robot, go away, go back to spooky place‚Äù! (She was two and half at the time.)

Glad you came back to it, though, and enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058990037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1623260994}
review:
This game is an absolute hidden gem!

Highly atmospheric, beautiful art, well worth the price. It tells a unique story set in a dystopian post-apocalyptic world, with a main protagonist who is a robot worshipping the "Gospel of Man".

Oh, and humanity isn't really around. I am not too big into point-and-click, or puzzle aspects of the games, but dying to know more about the lore kept me going.

I highly recommend finishing playing the game, and then replaying it with the commentary on, so you understand all the references.
developer_response: Thanks for the wonderful review, and the shout-out for the commentary -- something we all really enjoyed working on!

It is rare to see a game pull off such faithful visuals to the style of biomechanical steampunk-esque scifi

My favorite genre!

The story is fine as far as writing goes 

But for me this game is all about atmosphere, visuals, lore and character interactions.
Which it does so well, you can actually get immersed into a...

Which is a feat in and of itself

author: {'steamid': '76561198303776137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1593388608}
review:
If you like point and click style games, you should definitely play Primordia.
The world and story kept my interest from the very beginning, I loved all the interactions with the different characters, and together with the music and the wonderful art style it created a full experience for me.
I surely will replay the game as I loved it and also am curious how the different endings play out.
developer_response: Thanks! So glad you enjoyed it. Hope the replay is fun, too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198147019887', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1527184948}
review:
Stumbled upon this game a few years back using Steam discovery queue, and was quite surprised to find this gem.

The premise of a dark post-apocalyptic setting inhabited solely of sentient robots is right up my alley and immediately pulled me in, and the narrative develops it very gracefuly as you explore the world and the events that led up until that point.

You will discover the secrets behind this society of robots while solving challenging logical puzzles, meeting eccentric and unique characters backed up by excelent voice acting. It's at the perfect lenght for this genre and also provides replayability with multiple endings and optional puzzles that further explain the lore of this universe.

This a great hidden gem of puzzle point and click adventure and an easy recommendation.
developer_response: Thanks for the beautiful review!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991913731', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1516605676}

developer_response: Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079273057', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1509717358}
review:
I don't remember how I actually stumbled upon Primordia. Probably it was just on the steam queue, promoting post-apocalyptic games for me? I really can't say for sure at this moment.

Let's, however, try to think on what makes a story good:
‚Äî Storyline
‚Äî Characters
‚Äî Style
‚Äî Theme
If all these parts are actually present and show thoughtful work on them, it's at least worth your attention.
But hey, it's a game, isn't it? Well... I've never really looked upon P&C adventures as full-fledged games. Sure, they're more complicated than visual novels (which clearly aren't games), but the gameplay is all about some puzzles. At worse times, it's about "use everything on everything" ‚Äî and yes, sometimes the game felt like it, but maybe it's because I hardly ever play these games.

So, what do we have here? A short game set in a post-apocalyptic world. With engaging story, which is not too long and not too short. A solid one, I'd say, with a strong, prominent theme that we gradually come to realise with the small pieces we find.
The art is great, contributing a lot to the mood of the whole game. Can't forget to mention always breathtaking Logan on VA. Man just can't do a non-fantastic job at it, can he? That, of course, doesn't mean other voice actors didn't do a great job. I believe I can still recall Ever-Faithful and Crispin even now, years after I played it. Even the song we can play at the ship did catch my attention for a couple days.
What I also love is a seemingly highly-detailed world with little of it shown. I love when a story makes an impression of an enormous history and worldbuilding, but doesn't tell you much, leaving most of it to your imagination. The whole fact that you actually wonder what happened here and there, off-scene, means the author made a great job.

However, I need to say that it has flaws: namely, the endings. You don't have to work much for them, because decisions for them are made in the very end, so you basically don't feel like you've worked for them at all. I get it, more story branching requires more work, and most people who finish the game once probably won't even roll back and try it differently. But then again, I think it could be just a little bit expanded. But well, I'm not the dev of this game.

Overall, I think it's worth that little time it takes to complete the game. Especially when it's so cheap even without a discount.
developer_response:
Thanks for the thorough and thoughtful review!  I was especially glad to hear how much you liked Dreams of Green (the song in the ship), which was my effort at paying homage to two very different things (the poetry of my great aunt, whose poem "The Inheritors" inspired the overall theme of the game, and whose poem "Mimosa Tree" is where the "dreams of green" comes from, though also from Lorca's "Romance Son√°mbulo").

Regarding the endings:

[spoiler]What you say is a fair point, although I think it's an example of how the marketing of a game (or achievements within a game) can distort the game's content.  "EIGHT DIFFERENT ENDINGS!" is something that Wadjet Eye mentions a lot when marketing our game, and many reviewers praise it, but the reality is -- as you note -- they depend mostly on what you do in the end game, not on a pile-up of earlier decisions throughout (which are tracked in a more modest way, determining which robots help rebuild the UNNIIC).

These were not intended to give reactivity comparable to a game like The Age of Decadence (one of my favorite RPGs) or The Mask of the Betrayer (another favorite).  Instead, the choice at the ending is meant to be the player's opportunity to give meaning to the story up to that point.  Is Horatio's journey a futile one?  Has he succeeded in overcoming the hatred and destructiveness hard-coded into him, or reverted back to it?  Has MetroMind persuaded him, or repulsed him?  Does he want to die fighting, or reenact HORUS's self-annihilating refusal to fight, or what?  All of those, to me, are legitimate places for Horatio to end up, and different ways to interpret the story up to that point.  (Is it a revenge story or a story of renouncing violence?  Who was right in the debates?)

I have a completionist streak myself, so I was realistic in expecting players to just reload and get every ending.  But my hope was still that each player would have his or her own "best" ending, the one to them made the most sense and gave the most meaning to Horatio and Primordia as a whole.
[/spoiler]

Whew!  Long-winded explanation, but I figured I'd offer it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079221112', 'num_games_owned': 962, 'num_reviews': 224, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1593446039}
review:
The game is definitely a master piece of point & click puzzle game.   
The wasteland and post-apocalyptic style of artwork suits me very well. Old robots, scraps, lines and pipes...all make a vivid Primordia world.  
The jokes and easter eggs are very funny! I haven't finished the whole game yet, but I cannot help smiling on these things for so many times so far. The little funny pieces are everywhere: half life for a crowbar, water chip in the wasteland...great works! 
The displaying resolution definitely could have some upgrade or an HD remake. I wish the artwork in a higher resolution will make the game greater.
developer_response: Thanks so much! Really glad you enjoyed the jokes!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066230302', 'num_games_owned': 916, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1386051638}
review:
I played Primordia sometime-me ago. My memories of the game may be off, like needing a refresh, but still I will keep stating that it is one of the best point-and-clicks I have played.

First you need to look at the graphics. The pixel art visual on this one is simples outstanding, having a feeling of an old game on modern times and bringing perfectly the cyberpunk theme to life. Everything so gloomy, melancholic and robotic. This alone made me go after the game.

The story is also very nice, especially the dialogs and the interaction between the main characters. I just didn‚Äôt like much the ending. The game has tons of endings and I watched all of them. Some are pretty good, others not so much, and I first got one of the bad ones, not like in bad ending like in a light novel. Bad as in something I don‚Äôt like. So it was kind of my fault plus my on taste interfering.

As for the gameplay, basic point and click stuff. And yes, you can be stuck in this game. Not by bugs and such, but by not understanding how to advance. I think it‚Äôs not particularly the easiest game on the genre, but still worth playing. Also, be in mind that this will be a very short game.

With all that said, I still recommend Primordia. I loved this game, even with my complains, and I hope you like it as well. 

Review em v√≠deo em portugu√™s em breve.
developer_response: Thanks for the generous, but balanced, review! We're lucky to have such thoughtful fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085289553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1643538234}
review:
Primordia: A corroded and claustrophobic world where humans are a distant memory. The game presents a unique, simplistic art style which plays to the strengths of the deliberately old-school point-and-click genre. Though not for everyone, the uniqueness and charm have a certain appeal difficult to put into words.

The writing and story are where this game excels, surprisingly so. Playing this game is akin to reading a good book. Elements of religion and philosophy are all the more enjoyable amongst the backdrop of a world without humans; where machines like protagonist Horatio Nullbuilt can only ponder their existence. The world feels fresh, and though I am a novice at the point-and-click games, it still managed to drag me in with compelling and exciting writing. 

Put simply; I love this game ‚Äî whether that be the nostalgia of picking it up again or thinking about it years after my first playthrough when I was 17. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys old-school point-and-click games.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this beautiful review. I‚Äôm glad the memory of the game has stayed with you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160219490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1594652632}

author: {'steamid': '76561198253522554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1523655243}
review:
This game is one of my favourite adventure games. It's a post-apocalyptic game about a cyborg and his cute drone partner. Primordia has all the great points for a cool point and click game; good soundtrack, compelling story, fun (and not too hard) puzzles and awesome pixel art (had one scene in the game as my desktop wallpaper). 
So if you're a sucker for adventure games, then this is a no-brainer for you. I think it's also quite suitable for someone who's not played many of these games, because of good difficulty.
developer_response: Thanks so much! Glad you enjoyed the puzzles!

author: {'steamid': '76561198088394559', 'num_games_owned': 1924, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1525234560}
review: Primordia es un juego de aventura gr√°fica con una gran historia que deja un mensaje sobre la naturaleza humana y nuestra capacidad de destrucci√≥n y tambi√©n de creaci√≥n. En un videojuego de este tipo, la historia, en mi opini√≥n, es lo m√°s importante y Primordia lo cumple con creces ya que los personajes, tanto primarios como secundarios, est√°n muy bien armados y sus di√°logos no dejan de sorprender (he disfrutado mucho los comentarios de Crispin). Adem√°s la jugabilidad basada en las cl√°sicas aventuras de los a√±os 90 le sienta muy bien sumado al apartado gr√°fico de estilo retro. Eso gener√≥ en m√≠ que mientras lo jugaba por momentos recordara el Monkey Island o el Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis (mi juego favorito y que marc√≥ mi infancia). Los puzzles tiene una dificultad adecuada, no te lo dejan servido en bandeja pero tampoco vamos a estar d√≠as para resolverlos. En conclusi√≥n es un juego muy recomendable, la √∫nica contra es la duraci√≥n te quedas con las ganas de m√°s!
developer_response: Muchas gracias por la encantadora rese√±a, que captura el tema del "dualismo" a la perfecci√≥n.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996859750', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 392, 'playtime_forever': 1055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1055, 'last_played': 1530405171}
review: One of the best sci-fi adventure games I've ever played! author: {'steamid': '76561197983932703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1423691041}
review: You don't see this kind of game all that often and rarely this beautifully executed. The world-building is fantastic as are the inhabitants. Perhaps a majority of the characters to interact with lack any kind of anthropomorphism or facial structure yet each is memorable and is imbued with a sense of feeling, which is conveyed through the excellently written and delivered dialogue. Without spoiling anything your a machine seeking to rebuild the home he shares with his son, His home was broken into and looted of its key component. Its retrieval takes you on journey of discovery on how robots became the dominant life forms of this world and unearth how that truth was lost. The game is engaging and the only thing I don't like is that it ends and there isn't a sequel or at least another game in this universe. 10/10
developer_response:
What a beautiful review! We did do a little bit of a spin-off story (which you can get at http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html) but it's not the same as a sequel game, of course.

We're working on another adventure, which we hope to get out this year, and though it's a totally different setting, we think it has a similar thematic feel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036297204', 'num_games_owned': 1292, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 2697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2697, 'last_played': 1527358993}
review:
[i]Primordia[/i] is one of the best adventures I have ever played. The atmosphere of the post-apocalyptic setting is following your every step, it's so real. You can't escape the misery you see all around you, instead you have to embrace it and live. Even if what you find may change everything, about you and the world you live in.

The cast of characters in [i]Primordia[/i] is very colorful and every one of them is important for your journey. The two main characters, Horatio and Crispin, are especially amazing! I love their interaction, it's so clever and funny. I often quote many of their lines and dialogs. :)

Great atmosphere of [i]Primordia[/i] is supported by beautiful graphic, music also suits the game very well. You will also hear one the best voiceacting here! The most important part is story and that is just perfect! Mind blowing, really. Simple quest for getting back your power core will twist into something far more serious. I love how you are uncovering it slowly, until the very last moments you can't be sure of anything, but it all makes sense in the end. In the end you will understand.

As for gameplay, it's a classic point and click adventure. No pixel hunting though. Some of the puzzles can be rather hard, but nothing you can't solve. I have played it three times. Partly for achievements and partly because I wanted more, I wanted to stay with them for a bit longer. I can feel the emotions even after all these years. I have also read short story that is uncovering more about the events of [i]Primordia[/i]. I can wholeheartedly recommed [i]Primordia[/i] to you, it offers an amazing experience that will stay with you for a long time. If not for ever.
developer_response: Thank you so much for this thoughtful and beautiful review. It's a real joy for a developer to read such kind words.

author: {'steamid': '76561198322256463', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1565812572}
review: A great game for those who love post-apocalyptic settings flavored with a wistfulness for the past.  The atmosphere and ennui of the game made playing this game so fun for me.  I did get a bit stuck in places, but I'm not the smartest player, and there is help out there in the community to get you through some places.  But a lot of people make it all the way through without help it seems.  It's not terribly long, about 10 hours for me, but given that I like to play a wide variety of games, that was a plus.  Check it out!
developer_response: "Wistfulness" -- I think that's the first time I've seen that in a review for Primordia, but it's exactly the right word.  "Master Metaphor," indeed!  Many thanks

author: {'steamid': '76561198088141277', 'num_games_owned': 1936, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1434538450}
review:
Back in 2015 I came across this game and it totally kickstarted my interest in Point and Click adventure games.

It's incredibly polished, clever and funny. The voice acting is also really top-notch, with characters you want to know more about. And don't get me started on the pixelart! It's gorgeous and get ready to mash that screenshot button at all times, it's really that good.

The puzzles are great and require some thinking and a little bit (or a lot) of headscratching.

If you haven't picked it up already I would highly recommend you do! It's quite cheap in sales (2,99 euros) but it's also worth the full price!
developer_response: Thanks so much! I'm especially glad to hear that Primordia got you started in the point-and-click genre! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198062623579', 'num_games_owned': 745, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1514849640}
review: A classic point and click. This game's up there with Gemini Rue in my opinion. Similarly to a lot of point and clicks, there's a few puzzles that are pretty vague, but it's not enough to ruin the experience. The game's setting, music, characters, and art style are all top-notch the whole way through. So it's definitely worth sticking through past the occasional odd puzzle. It's an absolute steal at the current sale price so I definitely recommend giving it a go if you're interested.
developer_response: Many thanks! So glad you liked it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994297497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1590175040}

author: {'steamid': '76561198207829972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1593224891}
review:
Great game.  Interesting puzzles, intriguing storyline, excellent characters.  The dreary visuals are very Geiger-esqe at times and wonderful to look at, and despite that, there are loads of laughs from some of the dialogue and easter eggs.  Voice acting is very good as well.

This is not an easy game, but note that you cannot die.  Some situations are very hard to decipher, and I ended up using a walkthrough for a couple parts because I didn't see some pixel-hunting items or areas (they are not always visually contrasted like in most games).  If you have a knack for computer/mechanical/electrical engineering and programming, a lot of it will be easier.  Some of the terminology will just baffle you otherwise.  There isn't any real moon-logic, luckily.

I really liked that you had multiple ways to get through certain puzzles.  I ended up getting the best ending because I did something good earlier in the game to get a necessary item to achieve that.  So save often, although the game is worth replaying if you don't.

My main gripe was the data unit, the screen is tiny and you sometimes have to hit the down arrow to scroll through pages of text one line at a time.  There were a few things it simply did not store (like the long number sequence needed at the end of the game, WHY?!), and again, I had to check a guide.

For $3 on sale this was a bargain.  I would have gladly paid full price for this back in the adventure game heyday.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the thorough and generous review!

The parts of that number do store, and the completed sequence stores below it (if I recall correctly) if you have someone put them together for you. Otherwise, you have to put them together yourself. I agree with you, though, that the tiny size of the datapouch monitor makes it like trying to read notes on an old beeper or something. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198079962476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1592875939}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025105546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1592859764}
review:
Yet another proof that Wadjet Eye logo in the start credits = great experience. Hats off to Wormwood for developing this one. 

Biggest reason to play Primordia - atmosphere and very well written characters. Post-apocalyptic, unhabitable world where only robots remains and human existence is remembered (and revered) only by an obscure religion is a fantastic tone setter that hooks you right into the plot, and characters met along the way keep you engaged in the story to the very end. To the question of "the best character in this game?" I could easily answer "everyone" and that would be a very defendable stance, but I will give a final nod to our main duo - Protagonist Horatio and his floating sidekick Crispin. Their personalities seems typical (serious, matter-of-fact, a little bit stiff Horatio and energetic, snarky and sarcastic Crispin) for a duet, but the writing level mentioned above gives a fantastic dynamic between them, which leads to a plethora of genuinely funny dialogs. Not often can a work of fiction score a genuine laugh from me this days, but Primordia succeeded on more than one occasion.

This one is much shorter than many of other WE published games, but it actually does have some replay value, as you can approach puzzles in several way, and they can have interesting consequences, up to unlocking two additional endings. Well worth your time and money even without any discounts.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words -- especially glad to hear that it made you laugh!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992523634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 355, 'last_played': 1592520146}
review:
Story is pretty good. Just make sure you verify game contents before you play it. I had problems with other games from this Publisher.

Edit: Sorry about that Mark, I did mean publisher. I have changed the review to reflect that.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed the game!

Regarding your problems with other games, did you mean dev or publisher? (The only other game we, the developer, have is Until I Have You, and if there's an issue, let me know, I'll pass it along to the coder right away.)  If it's the publisher (WEG), there's nothing we can do.

Edit: Got it! The engine all of these games use (AGS) is a little creaky. We recently updated Primordia to the newest version of AGS, which is probably why it worked but Gemini Rue didn‚Äôt. My guess is that Unavowed might work as well (it‚Äôs WEG‚Äôs latest) but you will likely have glitches in the older ones. Even Unavowed may be in an older version of the engine than Primordia, alas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036328736', 'num_games_owned': 3945, 'num_reviews': 726, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1592249215}
review:
[b]Dans la lign√©e des autres productions pr√©sent√©es par [i]Wadjet Eye Games[/i], voil√† encore un [i]point&click[/i] qui pr√©sente des aspects tr√®s actuels sous une apparence tr√®s [i]old-school[/i].[/b]


[i]Primordia[/i] nous invite dans un monde post-apo dans lequel les robots, d√©barrass√©s de la pr√©sence humaine, se retrouvent malgr√© tout confront√©s aux m√™mes probl√®mes que notre soci√©t√© r√©elle. Si l'Homme est devenu un mythe, le besoin d'√©nergie, la recherche du bonheur et le souci de justice √©quitable reste une pr√©occupation. C'est ainsi qu'Horatio et Crispin se rendent en ville suite au vol de leur pr√©cieux cristal.



[b][u]J'ai aim√©[/u] : [/b]

[b]+++ l'histoire : [/b]Si elle n'est au d√©part une traditionnelle aventure motiv√©e par une qu√™te, elle devient de plus en plus int√©ressante √† mesure que l'intrigue progresse et le tout est surtout bien √©crit. 

[b]+++ la profondeur : [/b]Les th√©matiques abord√©es sont s√©rieuses et actuelles et le destin des robots de Metropol est naturellement une belle m√©taphore de notre soci√©t√© humaine.

[b]+++ l'univers du jeu : [/b]Un ensemble coh√©rent et la possibilit√© d'en apprendre pas mal sur le pass√© si on se donne un peu la peine de chercher, par exemple dans le terminal d'information.

[b]++ le style : [/b]La DA est tr√®s sympathique avec un style visuel tr√®s attractif (malgr√© les pixels) et une bande sonore bien agr√©able.

[b]++ les dialogues : [/b]Nombreux et autorisant des choix vari√©s.

[b]++ l'humour : [/b]Il est fin et subtil et le duo compos√© d'Horatio et Crispin fonctionne particuli√®rement bien dans ce domaine.

[b]++ les personnages : [/b]Une jolie galerie de pnj qui ont chacun leur personnalit√© bien affirm√©e.

[b]++ le gameplay : [/b]Il est certes tr√®s classique sur bien des points (inventaire, carte, action, √©nigmes) mais am√®ne r√©guli√®rement quelques petites surprises davantage originales tout en restant toujours parfaitement intuitif.

[b]++ les √©nigmes : [/b]Les puzzles sont bien int√©gr√©s dans l'univers du jeu et son gameplay mais la logique est surtout √† chercher dans l'histoire, ce qui donne un ensemble pertinent et coh√©rent.

[b]++ les diff√©rentes fins : [/b]Le sc√©nario poss√®de des embranchements qui proposent plusieurs mani√®res de r√©soudre certains probl√®mes et permet d'aboutir √† des fins assez diff√©rentes.

[b]++ bonne dur√©e de vie : [/b]Non seulement on peut compter sur une certaine rejouabilit√© pour tester quelques variantes mais on peut aussi consid√©rer que la relative difficult√© peur aussi prolonger le temps consacr√© au jeu.

[b]+ les doublages : [/b]Uniquement en anglais mais de qualit√©, ce qui contribue bien √† l'ambiance.

[b]+ l'aide int√©gr√©e : [/b]Pour les joueurs les moins perspicaces ou peu concentr√©s, il y a la possibilit√© d'obtenir subtilement quelques coups de pouce sans quitter le jeu pour chercher une solution compl√®te sur le net.

[b]+ la traduction FR :  [/b]Toujours agr√©able de disposer d'une traduction FR, surtout qu'elle fait au mieux pour retranscrire les nombreux jeux de mots de la VO.



[b][u]J'ai moins aim√©[/u] : [/b]

[b]- les graphismes : [/b]Ils sont naturellement tr√®s pixelis√©s mais s'ils restent parfaitement ad√©quats dans le d√©cor, en ce qui concerne l'apparence des h√©ros, il vous faudra certainement passer par les fichiers locaux et quelques manipulations conseill√©es pour modifier certains param√®tres pour obtenir quelque chose de visuellement plus agr√©able.

[b]- la lenteur : [/b]Si elle fait pleinement partie de l'ambiance, la lenteur devient parfois un peu p√©nible lors de quelques s√©quences, ...surtout dans les moments o√π on tourne un peu en rond.

[b]- le choix secret : [/b]Tr√®s t√¥t dans le jeu, une action qui semble parfaitement anodine peut avoir en r√©alit√© un impact significatif sur la suite de l'intrigue et notre pleine compr√©hension de l'histoire. En v√©rit√©,  si on a pas rejou√© et test√© un peu par hasard les deux variantes, on ne le d√©couvre qu'en se renseignant un peu sur le jeu.

[b]- la formulation des √©nigmes : [/b]Elle peut √™tre ambigu√´, notamment pour la 2√®me question de Cornelius et Oswald, ce qui peut provoquer des √©checs un peu injustes.



[b][u]En bref[/u] : [/b]

Un [i]point&click[/i] qui excelle dans bien des domaines et qui sait s√©duire par son ambiance, son univers, son histoire, ses personnages, son humour mais √©galement par les th√®mes abord√©s.

A conseiller aux amateurs du genre, en particulier ceux qui aiment le style [i]old school[/i] et qui ne sont pas contrari√©s par les gros pixels.


J'ai bien aim√©, je recommande.





[quote]
[b]Pour d√©couvrir d‚Äôautres jeux Wadjet Eye Games :[/b]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198036328736/recommended/80310]Lire aussi mon √©valuation de [i]Gemini Rue[/i][/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198036328736/recommended/212050]Lire aussi mon √©valuation de [i]Resonance[/i][/url]

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198036328736/recommended/336130]Lire aussi mon √©valuation de [i]Shardlight[/i][/url]
[/quote]
developer_response: Merci beaucoup pour l'examen approfondi et g√©n√©reux de Primordia. Je pense que les critiques sont tr√®s justes et les √©loges peut-√™tre plus que justes. Et je suis heureux d'entendre que, tous ensemble, cela a rendu l'exp√©rience agr√©able. Nous avons de la chance d'avoir trouv√© autant de fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198975897558', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1592112628}
review:
The probabilist puzzle REALLY peed me off, because the text moves too fast before you can write down the problem, and I accidentally clicked two wrong answers and it wouldn't let me reset it again. Was looking forward to solving the problem.

EDIT: Realised I had luckily saved before this so I could solve it properly. I finished the game a few hours after. Overall I really liked it; the art is not 100% my style but the story was top notch and most of the characters had depth and moral ambiguity. It was the perfect length too; after the 'END' or what felt like the end I was worried I'd be sent on more errands but this was not the case. I enjoyed the occasional numerical/ logic puzzles which were perfectly spread out through the game.

I did think some of the problems were a little obscure. [spoiler]For instance, after Clarity fights Metromind you are expected to look again at the station map. The problem is I had already looked at this earlier because it seemed a useful thing to do but the game wouldn't let me, so I assumed it was just decorative, since often in point-and-click games there are obvious things you want to do that are blocked off by the game. I had to look at a walkthrough in cases like this.[/spoiler] However this is more a problem with the genre, I think good point and click games should try and limit the number of cases like this, where you think you should be able to do something but are arbitrarily stopped from doing so.
developer_response: Sorry! It does record the question in the data pouch, and you can ask them to repeat, but a frustrating experience is never what a developer likes to give a player. May your next Binomial Biennial be more pleasant!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040019183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1600839998}
review:
Wow. This game blew me away. I haven't played many point and clicks but I'm definitely interested now. I just hope this one didn't set the bar too high for any others to meet the expectations I have after playing this masterpiece. 

The artstyle and characters are amazing. I fell in love with Crispin. He's hilarious. The world that has been constructed here is so interesting and engaging. I love the concept of man creating sentient AI and then going extinct for long enough that the machines have forgotten what we were and forming a religion to worship us as deities. 

The puzzles can be a bit challenging at times. I opted to have a guide available and referenced it when I got really stuck and Crispin was busy playing his puzzle games. 

 I completed the game in about 4 hours but it was worth every penny. Highly recommend.
developer_response: What a wonderful review! I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll find lots to love i other point-and-clicks, but I‚Äôm so glad to hear the impression Primordia made as you‚Äôve begun your journey into the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031205864', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1591633741}

author: {'steamid': '76561198798999978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1591569851}
review:
Wonderful game. The story was intriguing and beautiful. Such a good worldbuilding and deep lore. The artstyle is amazing, I absolutely loved every single location, the details of the environment were so good, and the sepia tones perfectly gave the idea of the atmosphere. Especially metropol, the apartments and roads in the background were so detailed and cool. Seriously, the art is the absolute best part of this game, so pleasing to watch. 
I really loved the lore behind it, how you learn bit by bit about the game's world, the robots and what happened to humans. I like how even when they dont tell something, they still give a good reason behind it, for example [spoiler]when you learn about the war that caused humans death, but you don't get to know why humans were at war, and it is told you its because the robots remained intact weren't built for war or did not have data on the war, which makes sense.
I gotta say, the ending that struck me the most was Horatio jumping from the tower, committing suicide cause he had no other options. Like, that ending got me emotional. This whole game can make you emotional, but that ending, god, it got me so much,, I still cant get over it. Tho my fvorite ending is "too much power", where you blackmail metromind into letting you go home with the power core. The final monologue Horatio gives, talking about the destruction Metromind will bring upon her city, as well as knowing he's now alone, with no friends, left to witness the downfall of robots, is just so powerful. Really gets me.
[/spoiler].

I loved the puzzles, some of them were very thought-out, for example the questions the two robots ask you in front of the court, or the code for the tower door. I love puzzles that require reasoning and I gotta say these two were a good challenge. I wish there were more like those, tho. Its a pity they didnt put more, but I guess its fine considering how much effort they put in for the rest of the game in general, it was still very enjoyable nonetheless. 
I like how actions you do at the beginning of the game can determine the choices of endings you get at the end. A bit frustrating, but nice.
Also, gotta say I loved the memento Moribuild little "sidequest". took me a little to figure out the solution, but it was pretty cool designed, loved doing it.

I really like the variety of endings that we are given, its nice to see the different outcomes, even tho some are less cured and detailed than others, and feel a bit cheaper and emptier. But the main endings are very well made. This whole game makes you think so much.

I liked this game very much, it was a beautiful experience, and a rollercoaster of emotions. I kinda wish the characters interactions were more thought-out, tho, cause the current ones didn't give me much. I didn't really feel any connection with clarity, she seemed very "cold", it felt like talking to an object every time I talked to her. The only one you can kinda feel the connection with is Crispin. I just wish you could get deep into knowing better more of the characters. Like the little lamp robot that Crispin likes, wish they did more with her, instead it feels she's just there for the achievement. 
I just overall wish there was more depth to characters interactions.
(Also I lowkey wish you could enter the door near the info terminal, like, that door has been bothering me for the entire game, you can knock but can never enter? Idk I just wish they made it "enter-able", and make it be a hotel room or something. I just like interacting with the environment in point and click games, so I wish there were  more environmental things to interact with.

But yeah overall it was a beautiful experience, totally worth the money, I had a really good time (and to be honest, this game has a deeper and more thought out lore and worldbuilding than most sci-fi movies or games out there. I lowkey would love a movie/tv series/ cartoon based on primordia lol)
developer_response:
Thank you so much for the long, and lovely, review! I'm particularly glad that some of the things you specifically enjoyed were the logic puzzles and the Memento puzzle -- some players find those frustrating, so it's wonderful to hear that those puzzles connected with other players like you.

I hope our next game rises to your expectations! If you'd like to find some more Primordia material, there's a bit on www.primordia-game.com, a free spin-off story, some excerpts from Crispin's diary, a poem by Primer, etc.

Again, many thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010870958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1591309080}
review: Great Story, love the character interactions, especially between Horatio and his Sidekick Crispin. The puzzles and figuring out some of what objects go where (I got stuck at one point, so I cheated and read a walkthrough, but the rest I played legit), are some well thought out ones that made me think in some cases. I personally wish there was a sequel just so I could hang out with Horatio and Crispin again. All in all, I highly recommend playing at least once all the way through.

Thanks! So glad you enjoyed it!

It's not a game and doesn't have Horatio or Crispin, but we did do a little spin-off story (free) that you can find here: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198025625270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1591047896}
review: Interesting concept, has a nice little touch of Beneath the Steel Sky with that "companion robot" thing and all, although the art is not very much to my liking.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it despite issues with the art.  Hopefully our next game (at higher resolution) will be more to your liking -- I think Vic's art does better at 640x480 than at 320x240.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068639706', 'num_games_owned': 119, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1562858496}
review: Absolutely amazing adventure game: immersive world, good puzzles, beautiful art. We need more :)
developer_response: Thanks so much for your kind words!  There's a little bit "more" at www.Primordia-Game.com -- a spin-off story, some in-universe texts (a poem from Primer and diary entries from Crispin), and some concept art.  And we do have another adventure, Strangeland, that's close to completion!  Hopefully one or more of those things will help scratch the itch!

author: {'steamid': '76561198132885404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1590279374}
review:
[h1] Just buy the b'soding game, people  [/h1] 

I'm going to cut straight to the point.

This is the best point-and-click game I've played.  I haven't played a ton, so perhaps that's not saying much, but I think this game is much more than the sum of its parts, where each of those parts is masterfully crafted in their own right.

Feel free to read the rest of my thoughts below if you want more than a TL;DR.

[h1] Characters and Dialogue [/h1] 

The characters and the dialog are the apotheosis of Primordia.

I was shocked at how well done the characterizations of Horatio and his sidekick were (I'm desensitized to the kind of characters you find in most modern games, after all).  They are congruent in their beliefs and behavior most of the time while allowing for slight deviations and quirks when the situation calls for it.  In other words, they are not flat, two-dimensional characters that serve as cliches or archetypes or devices to allow for the advancement of the plot.  They feel real and alive, and it might fly under the radar at first glance because of the subtlety with which it is implemented.

Horatio and Crispin may be the highlights of the game since they are the main characters, but that does not mean that the rest of the characters you can interact with in the game were sort of swept under the rug as an afterthought.  No, each of them has their own distinct personality and motivations as well, and none of them, in my opinion, are overdone, underdone, obnoxious, or boring.  I enjoyed interacting with all of them and their dialogue never overstayed its welcome, which brings me to my next point.

The writing in this game is smart, witty, and entertaining.  It's a pleasure to read, it's immersive, and you look forward to the next exchange of words between characters.  This is the hallmark of good writing - when you're able to savor the text and voice acting instead of skimming and quickly clicking through to get to the next exciting plot point.

And it's genuinely funny at times.  I have an obscure sense of humor and it takes a lot to make me go from not cracking a smile to a slight smirk.  But this game did it.  Some of the absurd stuff Horatio, Crispin, and other characters would say to each other was so well done.  If sentient machines with personalities had a great sense of humor, this would be it.  It pays a nice homage to people who have dealt with computer programming as well (Horatio, at one point, sarcastically compares something unfavorable Crispin suggests  with having unbalanced parentheses somewhere inside of him).  This programming humor has the potential to be unfunny and cringe-worthy as it usually is in your typical office space or classroom, but the delivery was smooth and self-aware enough to make it work.

[h1] Art [/h1] 

If you're reading this review, you already know what the art looks like.  Yes, it's heavily pixelated and low resolution.  But of course, that's part of the aesthetic.  I couldn't really imagine Primordia being a game with high resolution artwork and animations.  It just wouldn't be the same.  I wouldn't like it as much.  The way it's done is perfect for the atmosphere and setting, I think, and I wouldn't change a thing.  If you like this retro, low-resolution aesthetic, it's all the more reason to buy the game.

A few times throughout the experience, you view higher-resolution cut scenes at important moments.  It's a pretty large contrast to the pixelated art you're used to seeing, and when you come across these cut scenes, they seem magical and intriguing because you get to see what the characters really look like.  It reminds me of  the contrast between looking underwater with and without goggles.  Both are cool in their own right, but the comparison our brain makes between the two perceptions is where the wonder exists.

[h1] Story [/h1] 

The story of Primordia was unorthodox and interesting.  Perhaps not groundbreaking or original on all fronts, but well developed enough to warrant a playthrough even if the character and dialogue features described above were toned down a few notches.

My favorite part about it is that it's stripped of the extraneous to the extent to where you don't get bogged down in the details and can just enjoy the plot as it unfolds.

It's not very self-revealing until towards the end, where you encounter the truth and a few twists along the way.  The story of Horatio was hinted at a few times earlier in the game, but the way it was fleshed out at the end was a satisfying and cathartic ending to a journey of self-discovery and knowledge.

Two of the endings were very good.  The rest were ok.  I recommend you save at a certain point in the game where you're given the option to [spoiler]think about your final decision[/spoiler] and reload it to get the rest of the endings.

[h1] Puzzles [/h1] 

The gameplay of Primordia is centered around its puzzle mechanics.  You cannot progress forward until you solve them.

The solutions to the puzzles require creativity, backtracking, and odd combinations.

Unless you want to spend a lot of time exhausting all possible options, you may want to use a guide at some points, because a few of the puzzles were so non-trivial that it was hard to find a lead on where to even start or gain a hint from short of wandering around and trying random things.  When I consulted a guide to find out what to do at a few places, I was like "How was I supposed to come to this conclusion?"  In some places, it's like you need preconceived knowledge to move forward.  I'd like to think I'm not a dumbass, but maybe I am, and maybe you will have an easier time.

That said, I'd prefer the difficulty of these puzzles over having boring and generic ones.  If you like problem solving in the context of an interesting plot and likeable characters, well, here is your game.

[h1] Primordia [/h1] 

I've tried to break this game down into its constituent components so you can more easily evaluate the game.  However, the experience of Primordia, like I said at the beginning of the review and like all good creative works should be, is more than the sum of its parts.  So don't take everything at face value.

You'd have to play it to know what I mean, and I cannot recommend you do so highly enough, especially if you're a fan of point and clicks, non-obvious puzzles, sci-fi, or just entertaining characters and dialogue.

Other games in the same genre will have to step up their ingenuity if they want to compete with these developers and writers.  This game is highly deserving of its overwhelmingly positive reviews.

Looking forward to what they put out next.
developer_response:
Thank you for this generous review -- generous in its judgment of the game, and generous in the amount of time and effort that plainly went into writing it.  We're lucky to have such players.  In the ledger of such things, we have gotten back much more from all of you than we put into the game.

I particularly enjoyed the bit about the effort need to go from "not cracking a smile to a slight smirk"; that sums things up nicely.  "ROFL" does tend to mean "a slight smirk" for me as well!

author: {'steamid': '76561198104608051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 717, 'last_played': 1499350088}
review:
Muito interessante! 

Primordia √© um point-and-Click totalmente Old School ambientado numa realidade futurista. 

O que me surpreendeu nesse jogo √© que a hist√≥ria √© contada atrav√©s da vis√£o do protagonista e dos outros NPC's, e da muita brecha pra interpreta√ß√£o do jogador. Esse n√£o √© um daqueles enredos que se preocupa em explicar tudo, mas isso √© intencional, d√° todo um ar de mist√©rio e at√© melancolia para essa realidade que √© mostrada no jogo. Al√©m disso, o jogo tem v√°rios finais, o que estimula o seu fator re-play, uma vez que, depois que voc√™ j√° sabe como resolver os puzzles, voc√™ pode fechar em 40 minutos. Mas o interessante √© que voc√™ realmente tente resolver tudo sozinho, sem olhar videos e outras fontes.

Eu joguei poucos Point-and-Clicks na minha vida, mas sinceramente, mesmo ap√≥s os pr√≥ximos t√≠tulos do g√™nero que pretendo jogar, Primordia continuar√° ocupando um espa√ßo especial no meu cora√ß√£o. Pretendo joga-lo novamente depois de alguns bons anos, s√≥ pra sentir a nostalgia de ver esse game de novo.
developer_response: √â dif√≠cil pensar em uma cr√≠tica que me fa√ßa mais feliz do que esta! O "espa√ßo para interpreta√ß√£o" na trama era algo muito importante para mim, e eu compartilho sua opini√£o de que o jogo √© mais gratificante se jogado sem um guia. Mas, acima de tudo, fico muito feliz em saber que o jogo manter√° um lugar no seu cora√ß√£o - muitos jogos tiveram um impacto profundo em mim, e fico feliz em saber que, √† primeira vista, o Primordia conseguiu o mesmo para outras pessoas. Muito Obrigado!

author: {'steamid': '76561197965193437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 585, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1589715516}
review:
The art, voice over and general atmosphere in this game are really great. It feels and plays like a retro point and click adventure.

HOWEVER :

And now comes the problem, although you can never really get stuck in this game or die(as far as I know), some of the puzzles are too obscure and far fetched for me personally. Even with (vague) tips from your trusty sidekick robot.

I would only recommend this game, if you can finish games like Secret Of Monkey Island without a guide, because this one is quite on the same level. Is that bad ? No. But i wouldn't recommend this to a casual gamer.

Neutral for me.
developer_response:
Thanks for the review, and glad you enjoyed the game!

Not sure we're quite at the same level (for good or bad!) with Secret of Monkey Island, but I do agree that players who don't like classic adventure game puzzles should probably rely on Crispin's hints and (failing that) a walkthrough. I do encourage people to try to solve the puzzles first, though; some people who have only heard bad things about adventure puzzles might be pleasantly surprised!

author: {'steamid': '76561199010306395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1586997175}
review:
An 8 year old p&c that holds up even today. If you like grim, post-apocalyptic, sci-fi style settings, you'll definitely enjoy this.

Though it was developed by Wormwood Studios, there's actually some similarity between this work and some of the games in the Blackwell series, which was made by Wadjet Eye. You have a serious protagonist, a sarcastic sidekick, puzzles with some odd solutions, and you'll have to revisit locations a few times before you solve everything. It made the game feel familiar to me.

I would've liked to explore more of the 'main' location, but I suppose the developers just didn't have the resources to flesh all that out.

I liked it, but don't expect like a Mass Effect sized adventure. The scope of the game is much smaller than that, but nonetheless enjoyable. If you're familiar with Wadjet Eye's work, much of the same quality is still here; voice acting, art and dialogue are all great.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words!

The game's scope was *partly* driven by resources, but we also felt that it was beneficial to leave a lot of "blank space on the map" for players to fill in with their own imagination.  In retrospect, I think there is one area I wish we'd included, the Cathedral in Metropol, which you would have reached via an emergency cable car in lieu of the emergency elevator out of the Council Tower.  (You would have arrived at the top level of the Cathedral and then worked your way down and out, encountering relics from Steeple's days.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197998620764', 'num_games_owned': 1984, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1588318301}

author: {'steamid': '76561198005425476', 'num_games_owned': 1115, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1588088485}
review:
Primordia has a quality premise, a story worthy of your time.

Gameplay is what you would expect; a standard Wadjet Eye Point&Click. Like most, you may find yourself dealing with a small handful of contrived situations. Interacting with objects to generate somewhat nonsensical dialogue options. However, the character motivations and story arc unfold in a desirable and elegant manner. 

I was just discouraged earlier on, to find that the thing I was doing was indeed correct, It's just I had to do it in a specific order or click on the correct thing (eye roll). Out of mild frustration or maybe just being lazy I used a walk-through for some of the more cryptic puzzles, in hindsight I would have had more fun if I made an effort to figure them out. A solid classic adventure game, I do recommend.

-  Greytega, Biomade, Version 2. 8/10
developer_response: Thanks for the balanced yet generous review. I'm glad you enjoyed the game -- sorry you had to use a FAQ (we tried to avert that with Crispin's hint system), but I'm glad you had fun all the same!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060853923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1588130392}
review:
A hidden gem. 
Great writing, great setting, great art, great music.
Would love to see a high-res remake one day.
developer_response:
Thanks! For the kind words!

Regarding a high-res version... While redoing the backgrounds in a higher resolution would be relatively easy, animating the characters would be quite hard -- we'd need to not only have higher resolution sprites, but also more frames of animation because of the higher resolution, otherwise the animation looks choppy (the Secret of Monkey Island remake demonstrates this problem, IMO). Also, while the backgrounds were penciled and then digitally painted (and thus stylistically amendable to higher resolution), the sprites for the most part were pixel art from the outset. To make them work a truly high resolution would require a stylistic shift (again, the MI remake is a pretty good example of this).

Ultimately, we'd rather spend our limited time on new projects, and use what time we spend on Primordia supporting and patching the existing game to make sure it offers the best experience to current users.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046652307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1322, 'last_played': 1587353574}
review:
You have visited the same rust hole over and over again.
Your eyes start to wander until they catch a spec of glint in the corner of the screen.
It's the thing! The thing that the dude with other thing needed desperately so he can remedy his metallic misery.
You click away to find him and deliver the thing once and for all

You: [i] Here is it I have found it! [/i]
Char: [i] Oh..... ok [/i]

This, is Primordia
developer_response: To quote Teshoo Lama, "Do not weep; for, look you, all Desire is Illusion and a new binding upon the Wheel."

author: {'steamid': '76561197998071407', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1587301478}
review:
I LOVE this game. I had zero expectations when I got it. I have nothing but good things to say about it.

The characters--their scripting, their voices, their personalities--whether major or minor are all interesting and likeable, if not full-blown intriguing. The humor and interaction between the main two *immediately* drew me into what was happening and wanting to be a part of it. The story, told in bits and pieces (with mostly unreliable narrators) is fantastic and the environmental vibe of post-apocalyptic robot-only living is really cool. I never had to look up any walkthroughs (which is common for me with point-and-clicks) because I could always click on my lil sidekick for good hints. No puzzles were drawn-out or unpleasantly grindy. I was very happy with the level of detail, and I thoroughly enjoyed exploring entire dialogue trees with everything that was interactive.

Despite coming out in 2012, there is to this game that dates it in any bad way. My monitor is probably a little too large to play it on fullscreen, due to the pixel graphics, but that's about the only thing that wasn't perfect for me.
developer_response: It‚Äôs a joy to start my week by reading your review! I‚Äôm so glad everything in the game clicked for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001282464', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1610939529}
review:
A fantastic point-and-click adventure game.  The setting is interesting, the characters are charming, and the art is something special.  Not too difficult, either; while there were a couple of annoying puzzles and obtuse solutions, I was always able to complete the challenges it threw at me without a walk-through, something that I usually can't do for a game like this.  In addition, figuring out a couple of them made me feel pretty clever.

No doubt a point-and-click aficionado would think Primordia was pretty easy, but I personally think the game was well worth the five dollars I paid for it when it was on sale and is probably worth full price as well even if only for the story and atmosphere.  My only real complaint is that there isn't more of it.
developer_response:
Many thanks for the generous review! Glad to hear you enjoyed each of the game‚Äôs parts, and the collective whole. I doubt this will help the ‚Äúmore of it‚Äù request but we did do some ancillary material, including a spin off story, all of which is free on Primordia-Game.com. No additional game-time though. 

Thanks again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065426173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1586868086}
review:
A fun and well crafted adventure game with satisfying puzzles, good voice acting and an interesting plot. Recommended. 

The only negatives are:

1) The graphics are more pixelated than the screenshots suggest to the point of making it hard to see objects on the screen. I like pixel games but this was a little much for my taste. 
2) The sidekick robot gave tips in-game at times. This wasn't always appreciated and I felt it cheapened the game in places. 

The game time for me was around 7-8 hours + time for breaks and snacks. I didnt use any walkthroughs.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind words! Regarding the hint system, one of the trickier things is figuring out how, how often, and how hard to nudge the player along. The automatic tips from Crispin can be disabled from the options menu, but we have them on by default as more players complain about being stuck than vice versa. But sounds like we should‚Äôve made it clearer how to disable them. 

Thanks again, and glad you like you liked the game despite its flaws and hiccups.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007521055', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1586826100}
review: This game is a solid point & click adventure game with enough challenge to stimulate your mind without using nonsensical puzzles and logic. The story is solid albeit more-so science-fantasy than it is science-fiction. The voice acting is solid and Horatio and Crispin play off each other very well.
developer_response: Thanks‚Äîglad you liked it! I agree that it‚Äôs very far from hard science, though we tried to be accurate where there was actual science involved (like the mechanics of the energy sensor).

author: {'steamid': '76561198138987225', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1376, 'last_played': 1586709350}
review:
Bon, que dire qui n'ai pas d√©j√† √©t√© dit?... Alors tr√®s subjectivement:

+
- le style retro-pixel colle parfaitement √† l'atmosph√®re d√©solante du lore post-apocalyptique et ses nombreux √©l√©ment m√©caniques /robotiques
- les personnages sont attachants
- l'histoire est simple mais bien
- l'humour fin, mignon noir ou de r√©f√©rences pr√©sent (loin des bouses pipi-caca-cul-bite-chatte √† la mode) avec mention sp√©ciale pour Crispin
- les puzzles sont dans l'ensemble logiques et int√©ressants

-
- la traduction risque de faire rater aux anglophobes certaines subtilit√©s
- c'est trop court! du coup on voit assez peut de d√©cors diff√©rents et quand on admire ce genre d'environnement c'est frustrant ;_;
- l'histoire et triste
- non, vraiment, l'ambiance c'est la d√©solation totale, si vous aimez les univers dystopiques  vous √™tes au bon endroit
- Crispin n'est pas disponible en peluche sur aliexpress. pour nous r√©conforter..
developer_response:
Merci beaucoup pour la revue aimable et approfondie!

En ce qui concerne la traduction, je pense qu'elle est aussi bonne que nous aurions pu l'esp√©rer. Le traducteur a travaill√© Primordia avec une patience et une cr√©ativit√© sans limites (gratuitement!). Pour donner un exemple de sa pr√©venance, o√π Primordia a inclus une r√©f√©rence textuelle √†, disons, Un Cantique pour Liebowitz, Flavien ne traduirait pas la r√©f√©rence √† nouveau, mais trouverait la principale traduction fran√ßaise existante et l'utiliserait - de sorte que la r√©f√©rence serait plus familier aux joueurs francophones. Lui et moi avons √©galement √©chang√© des centaines de courriels sur la meilleure fa√ßon de localiser un jeu de mots de Crispin ou une ligne de po√©sie de Primer. En fin de compte, la traduction n'est jamais tout √† fait parfaite, mais les d√©fauts ici sont inh√©rents √† la traduction ou bien la faute du texte original du jeu, pas la faute de notre traducteur!

En ce qui concerne les peluches Crispin, h√©las, la femme qui les a fabriqu√©es n'en a fait que trois (une pour moi, une pour le traducteur espagnol et une pour elle) avant de passer √† un autre projet. L'autre fan qui a fait des peluches Horatio n'en a fait que deux (une pour elle et une pour moi). H√©las! https://pbs.twimg.com/media/DC-rXUpUIAEs0W0?format=jpg&name=medium

Merci encore et joyeuses P√¢ques / P√¢que / Printemps!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970361689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1585804329}
review:
An apathetic robot searches for meaning in an atmospheric post-apocalyptic world. Phenomenal Point & Click adventure; deeply philosophical story, fantastic pixel art, good puzzles. Hidden gem!

[i]Please follow my curator page,[/i] [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/6856591-Designer-Plays/]Designer Plays[/url][/b],[i] for a truly massive number of concise and honest reviews from a 25-year veteran Game Designer.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198048850969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 630, 'last_played': 1585371332}
review:
Very good point & click adventure, simple and very well written. The puzzle aren't illogically complex or forced, they just make sense in the narrative. No pixel hunting either, most things are pretty obvious if you are paying attention. I only got stuck on the haiku part because, well, I didn't paid enough attention XD~~
The worldbuilding is awesome for a short game, and the voice acting is superb. And even though the low-pixel resolution bother me a little, the art still amazing.
developer_response: Thanks for the lovely review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038587044', 'num_games_owned': 866, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1584887892}
review: One of the most beautiful adventure games I've played, the art style is truly magnificent and the story is captivating. I really hope that there can be some type of sequel or at least a game in the same universe.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for this wonderful note -- it's a bright spot in dark days!

No sequel in the works, but there's this spin off story that might be a snack: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

Be well!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998632060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1969, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1967, 'last_played': 1584743131}
