author: {'steamid': '76561197965201123', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1559875898}
review: A bit of a short adventure but quite an amazing story. I love the art style, the aesthetic of it, and the rapport between the main character and his sidekick feels so natural. I just wish the game was of higher resolution and with a longer story.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed the game! I guess leaving the player craving more is better than the alternative, but I'm sorry it wasn't entirely satisfying.

We did do a spin-off story (http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html) and we have some higher-resolution mockups of scenes in the game. We've toyed with the possibility of a higher-resolution version, but the sprite animation becomes exponentially more time consuming (and simply more difficult), so I think we'll probably devote our efforts to new projects instead.

Thanks again for the kind words!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995355816', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1540590566}
review:
This is the sharpest adventure game since [i]Machinarium[/i], which is fitting, because it‚Äôs practically the same subject matter approached from a different angle. [i]Primordia[/i] is a much more cynical game, but not to the point of obsession. Spots of humour frequently pierce the haze of its decayed setting, making many of the characters instantly likeable. The dialogue is top-notch regardless of the tone it‚Äôs carrying, and the narrative it conveys is stellar. It tackles many of the themes that [i]NieR: Automata[/i] would later be praised for, but stuffs them into a much tighter package. I especially appreciate that there are few disposable characters ‚Äì nearly all of them have significant histories to suss out.

[i]Primordia[/i] also avoids the usual adventure game trap of having to ignore the gameplay to enjoy the story. The puzzles are clever and surprisingly varied, requiring nearly as much codebreaking and syntactic logic as inventory management. Furthermore, hints are neatly integrated into the scenario as the main characters naturally discussing what they should do. The primary thing holding [i]Primordia[/i] back is that it‚Äôs [i]just[/i] an adventure game. Outside of small additions like using your tiny, floating sidekick as a puzzle-solving tool, it‚Äôs a pretty bog-standard AGS product. It also looks like deep-fried shit thanks to its miniscule resolution, but at least that‚Äôs offset by a beautifully subdued electronic soundtrack.

[b]Score: 7.5/10[/b]

https://www.imlgames.com/primordia/
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053855195', 'num_games_owned': 771, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1382, 'last_played': 1560327977}
review: Really good point a click adventure. Great Sci-fi setting, story, and characters. I actually like even easier games this, when it comes to point and click I really just want to sail through. I totally had to use a guide for this game, but didnt mind too much. This game will run on a potato. You think this doesnt need stating, but I have played other point and click that taxed my MX250 gpu in my laptop.
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198058882337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 436, 'last_played': 1560263589}
review:
I don't often write reviews, but adventure games have always been dear to me. I have spent hours on them as a kid and this game brought me back to that era of the mid nineties (it especially reminded me of 'Beneath a Steel Sky'). Everything is spot on, the visuals are great! Many indie adventure games try to re-create that distinct look and feel but somehow only few get it right, this game gets it right! Pair that with a great story, witty and engrossing dialogue and a great UI.. it's simply a homerun! The one big downside is that it leaves you wanting more!

I would love to see a sequel set in the same universe.
developer_response:
Thanks so much! The game was born out of the same nostalgic love for the adventure games of the 90s so I‚Äôm glad it connected with your own memories. 

Not sure whether we‚Äôll ever do a sequel. We did do a spin off story, ‚ÄúFallen‚Äù (http://www.primordia-game.com/fallen.html) and we‚Äôre working on a new adventure called ‚ÄúStrangeland,‚Äù though we go slowly since this is a hobby rather than a full time job!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006260075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1560205428}

author: {'steamid': '76561197973095782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1559985621}
review:
"It was this awesome point and click adventure game"
"I didn't know they made games like that anymore"
"Either did I..."

I love this genre more than anything. Wordwood Studios has breathed life back into what I thought was a long dead medium. The world is awesome, the dialogue is great and characters feel well fleshed out. The puzzles can get challenging, but overall have a good level of difficulty. I had to admit defeat and look online only once. Buy this game and help support this studio to continue this valuable work.
developer_response: What a beautiful review! Thank so much for the kind words and for taking the time to write them up. Hope we can keep delivering on your high expectations!

author: {'steamid': '76561198305382891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1559871448}
review: Good vibes, bad puzzles. Got the Dark something bundle, so far they've all been like that. Great vibes, terrible puzzles. Feels like they wrote a story and then added bad puzzles to slow it down. Most of the time I had to look through a walkthrough it was because some important item had no visual significance on the screen. I know they don't want to make it super easy, but I gotta be able to see that an item exists to use. An example is the shard in the Reaper church. I had no idea there was some sharp bit I could get off the plane wreckage, found it by accident trying to talk with the acolyte sitting there. And that item is absolutely key, you can't move forward without it. None of the puzzles gave me a satisfying sense of accomplishment like the old Lucasarts games or Space Quest, King's Quest, etc. THOSE are fine games, this is not.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn‚Äôt enjoy it! Reaper Church is in Shardlight, not Primordia, I believe, but since Shardlight has fewer and easier puzzles than Primordia, I‚Äôm sure the complaint still stands. 

My policy is to share a key to something else for players unsatisfied with Primordia. I have a bunch from Kickstarters and charity bundles I backed with Primordia revenues. Shoot me a message or an email at mark@wormwoodstudios.com if you‚Äôd like!

Sorry again that you didn‚Äôt enjoy the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972330729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 359, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1459884665}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968658555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1559198351}
review:
A lovely point&click adventure, not dissimilar from Shardlight and Gemini Rue.

Superb pixel art, a nice plot, multiple endings, some good choices to be made, great characters, and very good writing, all within a greatly atmospheric world.

A modern classic.

Highly recommended.

review: This is an amazing game. review:
Des jeux post apocalyptiques, il y en a plein ! 
Des jeux point'n click en revanche, c'est moi s√ªr. 
Ce jeu vous transporte dans un monde o√π les humains on disparu (√† vous de faire l'histoire afin de savoir les raisons de leur absence) et o√π vous incarnez un robot √† l'apparence humano√Øde (ainsi que son fid√®le compagnon) pour reprendre une source d'√©nergie vol√© par une entit√© myst√©rieuse. 
Graphiquement, le jeu se rapproche du style r√©tro des point'n click. Couverture minimaliste mais assez agr√©able √† distinguer dans ce monde rong√© par la rouille. 
Une r√©flexion est de mise afin de terminer l'histoire. 
Avec ses 5 fins diff√©rentes, le jeu peux ou pas se terminer en beaut√© pour vous. 
Petit bijou d'histoire comme il ne se fait plus que rarement, le jeu se termine en 3h00 (si vous √™tes r√©actif √† la logique du point'n click) et 10h00 (si vous d√©buter dans ce sport).

author: {'steamid': '76561198286165937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1669578379}
review: what a ride this was. a cool game with awesome art direction and an interesting storyline. it's a short game, but the puzzles will keep you around for a bit depending on your skill. the only gripe i have with this game is the puzzles, more accurately the items. by the end of the game, i had a great amount of items that did absolutely nothing. i understand that there were different endings, and i have no doubt all the items had some sort of use, but you can get items that you needed earlier that cant be used after that time frame. this confuses everything. now, i wont lie, i am admittedly salty that i got the worst endings, but regardless, with multiple endings in a point and click, you should probably make items that wouldve caused different endings (but can't anymore) to be inaccessible. Oh, and another thing, some of these puzzles are really dumb. i had no idea i had to right click on the junk after getting the quest to find glass to look for it, so it was a wild goose chase until i happened to find the solution. two words. T o t a l l y u n i l l u m i n a t i n g .
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the game despite the flies in the ointment. :)  I appreciate the candor and balance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966706551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1558358153}
review: I thought I'd give this a go because I enjoyed the old point and click adventure games. I found this frustrating and slow so just couldnt get into it. Perhaps it has an amazing story later as other reviews have mentioned but after 35mins i just hadnt found myself enjoying it yet and had already got semi stuck a few times.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn't enjoy it, but I'm glad you cut bait -- life is too short for games you aren't enjoying! We did try to mitigate against the problem of getting stuck by having Crispin dole out hints automatically if you were stuck for more than a couple minutes, and by letting the player click on him for hints sooner, but the truth is that it's pretty hit-or-miss whether an adventure game's puzzles "work" for a player, and when they don't, it can be frustrating.

By way of apology, since I always feel bad when someone comes to the game hopefully and leaves disappointed, would you be interested in a key to some other game? I have a huge stock from Kickstarters and charity bundles I backed using Primordia's profits, and I always offer them if someone gives Primordia a go and comes away unsatisfying.  I don't have time to play them myself, so otherwise they're just collecting dust.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990289612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1558340827}
review:
I'd like to preface this review by stating that I don't even remember purchasing this game. I either bought it on discount with steam dollars or received it in a bundle... But having said that, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of classic point and click adventures. One could even call Primordia a "lost point and click classic", although it was released in 2012, if it weren't for the fact that it's quite short. I couldn't help but feel like the devs had to have drawn influence from games like I Have No Mouth, and I Must Scream and especially Beneath a Steel Sky. If that peaks your interest, its worth a few bucks and a few hours...

Graphics 4/5:
For a classic 8 bit style point and click, the graphics were enjoyable and on par. They brought the feeling that I miss and love about these games.

Story 3/5:(after chatting with the devs i slightly altered this portion to better reflect my view)
While i did enjoy many of the characters in this game, there wasn't any obvious plot holes and the story was thought provoking and interesting. It did at times, and ultimately, seems a bit preachy. Not in relation to a certain theology per say but it seemed the writer has certain points of view that they are trying to convey to the audience. It bounces around from feeling very libertarian to sort of anarchist to socialist etc. If you wish to know what I thought I'll tell you but its a bit of a *spoiler* [spoiler]I definitely got a pro-progressivism message out of it. Im not hating on progressive values but thats just my honest opinion.[/spoiler]

Sound 4/5:
Once again, as with the graphics, the music and SFX held that old charm that I enjoy so much. As for the score itself, it was pleasing but did not blow me away by any means. I almost gave this a 3 but the voice actors were so solid for a low budget game, that I gave them the extra 1 for kudos.

Gameplay 4/5:
Mostly standard puzzles here not too hard, not too easy. There are a few tricky ones that are very rewarding and a couple of very esoteric ones that required meta-knowledge or dumb luck to be able to solve. Luckily for me I don't mind doing a little research online but some folks may not like the idea of having to do homework to get passed one little puzzle.

15/20
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed the game! Contra James, I do think of myself as a political person (who isn't?), but my hope with the game was to give a good voice to various beliefs and creeds.  In some ways, your concern that the game is "progressive propaganda" strikes me as an interesting contrast with this one by a user named KilledByPropaganda (!) (https://steamcommunity.com/id/killedbypropaganda/recommended/227000/), which describes it "mak[ing] a strong case against collectivism which is more important than ever these days."  I'm reminded of a time when the first and second threads on the game's GOG forum were one guy denouncing the game as outrageously creationist and another denouncing it as outrageously irreligious. :)

But all of that is really irrelevant -- if the game's politics annoy you, that annoyance isn't going to lessened by anything I can say!  Ultimately, there is no arguing with the player's likes and dislikes; he is the only person with a right to say what does and doesn't work for him.  So, I'm just glad you enjoyed it notwithstanding the writing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005347124', 'num_games_owned': 610, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1558384819}
review: Point and click adventure games are not as flashy as a lot of modern triple-A titles out there but almost without fail their creators, developers, and writers really understand what makes a great game.  These games sell well for a reason, they are generally criminally cheap, they offer excellent narrative, challenging puzzles, great characters, beautiful music and artwork, and cater to the start and stop play PC gamers love.  These are classic PC titles, and Primordia is no different.  The love put into the game is evident immediately and carries through all tenish hours of its story.  Clever and occasionally obscure puzzles were never so difficult I smashed my face into the keyboard and the world of Primordia is full of both well written characters and hauntingly beautiful narrative.  This game is well worth the price of admission, especially to those who hearken back to the older days of gaming.
developer_response: What a beautiful review. Thanks for the kind assessment.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971636562', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1558273357}
review:
It keep getting me surprised that the smaller games like Primordia games are so much more fun than bigger tripple-A titles.

I was nervous getting the game, because it didn't look very appealing to me based on the screenshot but positive reviews convinced me to give the game a chance. Never regretted the decision.

Although the game is kinda short it's very fun to explore it. You have a chance to learn a lot about the lore of the game in the city in the info kiosk. Once you read up on the world, War of the Four Cities and Humanist religion you'll see that the game has a very developed world which shows through environment and characters really well.

Puzzles are also great. I wouldn't say they're hard but in some cases you'll need all your brain power to solve them.

The only downside that this game looks pretty bad  on a 4K screen. There are some setting to make visuals less painful and more sharp but it doesn't help a ton. Still it's playable and great story overshadows visual issues.

Overall I highly recommend the game. It's a great journey into the post-humans world ruled by the machines. Great game!
developer_response: So glad you enjoyed it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197975150865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1208, 'last_played': 1557800299}
review: This game is a masterpiece. The writing is BRILLIANT. It's supremely deep and exquisitely funny at the same time. Some dialogues are mindblowing. The difficulty of the puzzles is just right for a seasoned adventure player, they're never too obvious but always logical and never far-fetched. Also you can ask your sidekick for clues if you are stuck which is a great idea, it saves you from frustration while it doesn't take all the satisfaction of solving it on your own away. The soundtrack and voice acting was remarkably atmospheric and pleasant without exceptions. Furthermore it makes a strong case against collectivism which is more important than ever these days. If you like point & click adventures or just enjoy good writing you definitely want this game. I would mention it in the same breath with masterpieces like Monkey Island or Gabriel Knight.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the game, and thanks for the kind review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198319241796', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1530588692}
review:
This game is a must play for any fan of point and clicks, dystopian sci fi or just general lovers of exceptional story telling.
I play a lot of point and clicks, usually finishing a game after a month or so of sporadic game play. 

I finished this game in one sitting.

The puzzles aren't difficult, and allow the stellar story to progress unhindered for the most part which is a pro in my eyes.
The biggest pro however, is the branching story line towards the climax. I won't spoil but there are multiple endings and you become so invested in the story that each ending carries immense gravitas.

This is a masterpiece of gaming, Hall of Fame tier. 10/10
developer_response: Thank you so much for the kind words and generous review! We really appreciate it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085682053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1556231230}
review:
There are a lot of puzzles and some are a bit hard to solve. I looked up 3 times in the internet, but these was mostly just tiny bits I over looked, like a door. This game is for the hardcore point & click player, so my recommendation goes only to them. The atmosphere is really good, with good music and oldschool feel, detailed looking graphics with low resolution. The world is not too big and if you stuck, it can be frustrating.

There is a helper with you, who give you hints if you ask him, which makes the game playable and the key why I played through. And the dialogs are really good and amusing, I was suprised. Very charming main characters. The story itself wasn't too interesting, but it did the job and worked. At least, I was interested in what would happen next.

I needed 11 hours to play through and then try some different things out. Overall, for the money of 10 bucks, its quite okay for what it is. Guess everyone will use some help at some point.
developer_response: Thanks for the balanced and thoughtful review! Glad you enjoyed the game, flaws notwithstanding!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995487567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1554163032}
review:
Primordia is a beautiful and at times quite sad story about robots living in a post-apocalyptic world. While I enjoyed the story, characters and setting, I did not enjoy the puzzles at all. Reading a walkthrough multiple times made me feel very dumb, which is accurate, but if I had not done that, it would have taken me ages to finish the game. Even if I had paid better attention, some of the solutions seemed obscure to me. And at times it was very easy to miss important items as they kind of blend together with the brown and muddy backgrounds.

But despite these issues, I would still recommend Primordia, as the story is interesting and I liked the fact that not everything is explained about the world. But you do get enough information to get your imagination running. The world is beautiful and desolate at the same time and everything looks so weird. Whoever did the art for this game should open up a gallery, because it all looks fantastic in many levels. Primordia is worth going through even if the puzzles do not click with you, but unfortunately for me the game is overall a 3/5.
developer_response: Sorry you found the puzzles so frustrating, but I‚Äôm glad you were still able to enjoy the game in spite of them!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971160528', 'num_games_owned': 3019, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1562259848}
review:
Pros:
-Good art style. A techno Gigeresque aesthetic.
-Logical Puzzles. Rarely did I run into the issue of what do I do now.
-Interesting lore. Has a version of creationism based on robot origins and the fate their god, man.
-Fun Easter eggs in the game. I noticed quite a few in my play through. 

Cons:
-Not a lot of set pieces. I felt myself wanting to explore more but was confined.
-Some of the jokes fall flat.
-Voice acting a little dull. Falls in to the average for most adventure games. One thing I thought was interesting at first was how their last names are who built them but near the end it seemed overused.

Conclusion:
I think this is a great game for adventure fans. This game fits in perfectly in with the classic 90s adventure games. If you enjoy Sci-fi and adventure games this is a great buy.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it! Thanks for the detailed and thoughtful review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198117050589', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1423, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1709276460}
review:
Note: I did indeed write a very similar review before, but have decided, after playing the game through again, to alter one of my points, go a bit deeper into them as well. Though still, I will avoid any potential spoilers, as this game's story is great and should be experienced first blind.

This game is great with good logical puzzles, enjoyable characters, decent voice acting, and an absolutely incredible world and atmosphere despite what could be seen as a generic or bland color pallet the game tends to feel alive in an alien way, and the contrast of the bright vibrant blues and the rusted decaying brown just makes the game look incredible. The only con I can think of is that the animation can be a bit slow at times.

Thanks for the kind words‚Äîbut now I have to know what the two lines are!

Glad you liked the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970744075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1552879300}
review:
This game, was quite the great story. Gameplay-wise too, it hit all of the right buttons. A decent balance of simplicity with the puzzles, logic, with even a few ways of getting around some of the toughest puzzles. Rarely felt stuck. Absolutely amazing game. The music and art, was just as good, if not the best part of the game. Pulls you in.

But, for the sake of a review, I can offer only one thing genuinely bad about this game.
The game engine, is a little floppy- only in one place. The limited number of saves that I found. But, it was easy enough to get around so, it was just a minor issue. So, in the end, not too many things wrong with this game. Genuinely the best of its type that I've ever played. 100% recommend this to anyone who loves story games. Really.
developer_response: Thanks! So glad you enjoyed the game‚Äîsorry about the save game annoyance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041048332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1545807505}
review:
Bought this on a whim and I am so glad I did.

The low-res visuals might take some getting used to at first, but it's so darn charming.
Unlike some other adventure/point-and-click games, puzzles and item crafting are intuitive and don't get in the way.
The story is great, and the voice acting and soundtrack (and even the jokes!) are much better than I was expecting.  There's even multiple paths and orders to do things.

Honestly, it's now one of my favorite games.  Ever.
Makes me feel like I was born in the wrong decade.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind review! So glad you enjoyed the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106512564', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1550675812}
review:
Another winner from Wadjet Eye Games!  This games excellent story, art, sound design and overall production quality is definitely in line with what I've come to expect after playing several of their titles. Highly recommended!


Pros
---------------------------------------------------------
-Fantastic artwork for a point and click game
-Voice acting is on point and well done
-Engrossing post apocalyptic story/world
-Built in hint system able to get you through most dead ends
-Very stable (recent as of 2018 update seems to have taken care of a multitude of issues)
-Great music 
-Most achievements are attainable without extensive replays

Cons
---------------------------------------------------------
-A few very esoteric puzzles.  Some objects are very hard to locate against the background art
-Somewhat short playtime (~6 hours for me, although i am willing to trade playtime for a cool story like this one)

A must have for any point and click aficionado.  Due to 6 hour playtime I'd highly recommend picking up while on sale but if you don't mind a quicker adventure gaming jaunt then you wont be disappointed!
developer_response:
Thanks! So glad you liked it!

Also, I just checked your review history‚Äîit‚Äôs so great to have someone playing all the indie adventure games out there and saying nice things about them. On behalf of the ‚Äúscene,‚Äù thanks for that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053744908', 'num_games_owned': 1005, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1550072387}
review:
[quote]With satisfying puzzles, an interesting narrative and charming characters, Primordia is a wonderful experience for those looking for their next point and click adventure. Seldom frustrating, though perhaps a little brief, Primordia doesn‚Äôt outstay its welcome offering six to ten hours of enjoyable adventuring, and suitable for those new to the genre and the grizzled veterans seeking to satiate their addiction.[/quote]

I‚Äôve redrafted the start of this review four or five times, each time scrubbing out the words I‚Äôd written as being inarticulate and not expressing what I‚Äôd like to say. And that‚Äôs because Primordia deserves to be lauded for what it is and does‚Ä¶ for whilst a point and click adventure is a relatively easy thing to create (just ask any HyperCard enthusiast), a good point and click is not. Primordia is a good point and click adventure, and whilst it doesn‚Äôt top some of my experiences with the Lucasarts treasury, the fact that I‚Äôm placing it on that pedestal close to the classics should be some indication of its quality.

Primordia, despite its post-apocalyptic setting, doesn‚Äôt fall foul of some of the easy clich√©s that might so easily rear their heads. Its protagonist doesn‚Äôt really want to ruin his day with bothersome adventuring, isn‚Äôt hugely interested in the wider world around him, and, but for a lack of power, would happily remain at home. Sadly with events conspiring against him, Horatio and his robo side-kick Crispin are thrust on a journey which leads them to question their place in the world and the nature of their existence (well Horatio does, Crispin just wants arms).  Primordia‚Äôs narrative is thoughtful without spreading it too thickly, touching on deeper themes but devoid of the heavy handed storytelling that might mar just its philosophical musings. It‚Äôs not perfect, but it explores the ideas it presents in a way that is complimentary to the game, and not in a manner that‚Äôs jarringly incongruent to the experience.

Part of what assists this narrative is the presentation, going the Adventure Game Studio route and opting for low resolution, pixelated graphics. Whilst this necessitates windowed play (you can try to stretch the game out but I guarantee you‚Äôll be back to a window within minutes) the game looks lovely when viewed appropriately, with genuine care taken in its appearance. Despite the inherent limitations, the characters are illustrated distinctly, their forms representing the different personalities that each has. What few cutscenes there are fail to disappoint, and but for those playing the game with subtitles, will find place in the screenshot galleries of many a player. The world could perhaps be described as drab, but how better to describe a ruined and decaying world?

But atmosphere is not created through visuals alone and it‚Äôs easy to forget the importance sound plays. The voice acting, whilst not necessarily stellar, is solid and Crispin‚Äôs quips are especially notable, providing notable light relief in a game that, at times, might become a little dour. Nathaniel Chambers‚Äô soundtrack is integral to the experience, fitfully embodying the dark and oppressive or the sense of wonder and discovery that accompany the journey. If anything the soundtrack recalls Vangelis‚Äô Blade Runner compositions, which whilst I would imagine is intended, nevertheless is high praise indeed ‚Äì these soundscapes may not be individually memorable, but in conjunction with the world, they enhance the gameplay immeasurably.

Of course all this would be for naught if the puzzles were awful‚Ä¶point and click games live and die by this facet of their design. Thankfully Primordia adopts a very logical approach, with potentially real world solutions to the problems that Horatio and Crispin must overcome. What also must be commended is the limitation of inventory junk that might litter lesser games, with our protagonists‚Äô options sensibly limited to prevent frustration or obtuse puzzle design. The puzzle areas aren‚Äôt tiny by any means, but are relatively compact and it‚Äôs nice that it‚Äôs rare to bump into arbitrary walls because an inconspicuous item might be missed. Furthermore, Crispin functions as an in-built hint system providing the player with titbits of help should they be stumped about what to do next. This is a fantastic idea, and something that should be a staple of point and clicks ‚Äì allow the player the opportunity to progress naturally, but should they become stuck and want help give them the chance to seek it without resorting to a guide. 

Primordia isn‚Äôt faultless however, and there are occasional bumps in the experience. Once or twice it may be difficult to work out what to do next (and on one occasion Cripin‚Äôs advice was out of sequence, giving help with a puzzle that occurred after the current roadblock) and separating the right mouse button into a dedicated look did cause one moment of frustration. However, Primordia has all the elements that go towards making a game that‚Äôs enjoyable for everyone rather than just hardcore point and click purists, and it‚Äôs for that reason that it becomes an easy recommendation for those looking at games in this genre. 

https://bubblepipemedia.bandcamp.com/album/primordia
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind, thorough, and lovely review. So glad you enjoyed the game! Given our love and nostalgia for the old classics, it‚Äôs very flattering to be put on that pedestal at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027129179', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1550172108}
review:
I enjoyed playing Primordia for what it lasted, though I'll admit I did most of it with a guide on a second window. The story is entertaining and while not original it will keep you entertained through out (if you use a guide... I can imagine how some puzzles or unlocking progression can become rather dull).

Multiple endings is always a plus and while the story nor it's setting may be super original I enjoyed exploring and learning the bits of lore that we get.

Overwhelmingly positive reviews can be a bit misleading though... this is not a 10/10 game, but I can confidently say it's a solid 7/10 worth your time if you are into the genre (and pay adecuately considering it's got a short runtime).
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the game (up to a point), though I'm sorry you didn't come away more satisfied.  It's kind of you to take the time to leave a review, and to give a thumbs up despite mixed feelings.  Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198018446175', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 564, 'playtime_forever': 1843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1310, 'last_played': 1551034463}
review:
The Art, the Soundtrack, the Voice Over, the Atmosphere... everything is fantastic!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991998060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1356336000}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020817465', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1550011191}
review:
I got this one on sale. I wish i did not. 

It is completely worth the full price! 
While most games bore me these days this one is really entertaining. I am not so much into point- and-click games and I usually don't like riddles, but this one is a diamond.

The mood is great, the music is doing a good job supporting it. Dialog and voice-acting are compelling and the story is interesting. 

I like the art style, but even if I did not, the points mentioned above are carrying the game on their own. Who needs 'better' graphics then?

Looking forward to play the rest of the game and more games to come!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

German review inbound.
developer_response: Your kind words are worth much more to us than the couple buck difference between sale price and full price. Plus, you can use the money you saved on other fun games now!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029159540', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1550098240}
review:
interesting story,  well designed locations, nice  voice acting  , smart riddles and puzzles create a post apocalyptic nightmare with  only robots left in the world  .
It was like reading a good book.
This one offers multiple endings and i think different approaches in some situations .

Highly recommended for younger people but those who are above 30-35 years old will appreciate it more as it brings back memories of another era , when adventure  games used to be like this , mind challenging offering  entertainment  at the same time .

Nicely done , looking forward for the next one !!
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words! As a 39 year old, I am indeed in that demographic. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198447312732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1549639980}
review:
This is my favourite point and click ever made. The gorgeous haunting setting based in a post apocalyptic dystopian wasteland inhabited by the remnants of man. The dialogue is stellar. It flows, it's witty, and reminds me of the character banter Joss Whedon's Firefly is famous for.

Thank you Wormwood.
developer_response: What a wonderful review to start my morning with! Thanks so much for leaving it, and for your generous take on Primordia -- we're lucky you gave the game a go, and that you took the time for a review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978522665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 540, 'last_played': 1548824481}
review: Lovely game. Funny. Sad. Deep.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words -- so glad that you connected with Primordia and took the time to leave a review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961260165', 'num_games_owned': 580, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1549542790}
review: It's a game made to resemble the older games such as hero's quest or space quest. Basically if you weren't born in the 80's you probably have no idea what this genre is and should probably research it. Art style is good and the story is fairly interesting. Would be cool if they made a sequel or prequel.
developer_response:
Glad you enjoyed it, and thanks for the generous comparison to the old Sierra classics (having been born in the 80s, the team all grew up on them ourselves...).

We probably won't do another game in the same setting, but we did do a spin-off story/sequel: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

author: {'steamid': '76561197979303772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1, 'last_played': 1688949230}
review: One of the smartest games I've played all year. Genuinely interesting choices and helpful hint system.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words. An absurd amount of design time and coder sweat went into that hint system, which seems hit-or-miss in terms of player reception, so I'm glad you found it helpful!

author: {'steamid': '76561198128285760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1558989338}
review:
Another fantastic point & click adventure game by Wadjet Eye (this time though taking the role of the publisher while dev credits belong to Wormwood Studios). Unlike their more recent post-apocalyptic effort named Shardlight, where you explored  how human civilization and society can reshape its future after a catastrophe, this time in Primordia the player wanders a devastated barren and sunless wasteland devoid of any life where humanity is all but a memory and old decrepit machines and robots wander aimlessly, others seemigly lost in madness and religious zealotry or simply trying to maintain a purpose in life (?) and keep going. 
Our protagonist, indifferent in the world around him, without memories, with a sole friend/sidekick is drawn in an adventure that will see him travelling and exploring what was once earth,  out of necessity for survival, to mainitain his gears running. As the story unfolds, in typical adventure fashion, he will find himself entangled in a plot full of intrigue and facing some important philosophical questions.

Despite the bleak setting I just described, the game is surprisingly sprinkled over with strong doses of humor, and hearing the banter between our hero and his snarky sidekick is always a delight, making a perfect balance with the grim situations you encounter, but never feeling out of place, instead enhancing the melancholic and sometimes outright strange futuristic world,

And what a beautiful world! The amazing artwork and music really evoke a sense of decay and apocalyptic imagery, with seas of sand swallowing decayed ships, tanks and giant machinery, or streets and undergound passages full of distorted steel and cable. One small gripe people might have is that, again, the game is created using an old engine, so expect low resolutions and especially if you like to play your games fullscreen, things might look a bit messy. Despite that, the pixel art is phenomenal so feel free to tinker the graphics options to find what suits you best. 

Puzzles while never too difficult or too easy, are logical, challenging, some offering slightly different ways to solve them and beautifully designed in general. There are a couple of tough headscratchers but absolutely no dead-ends so patience and careful observation is the key. Sometimes you must learn new clues in order to trigger new interactions  for a puzzle to work (a small criticism)  and in typical fashion for such a game, some pixel hunting is required a couple of times causing a small bit of frustration. However, if you ever feel stuck, there is a very useful hint/help guide built within the game, simply by speaking to your sidekick. Another helpful innovation is the map system that allows you to quicktravel between locations and an extremely useful notepad that writes down all the important and useful info to solve puzzles and progress the game.
Another quality of life addition is the ability for both manual saves and an autosave feature.

What also got my attention is the wide variety of endings that you can get , mostly towards the end of the game, depending on your choices, but a small advice (trying to keep spoilers as low as possible) [spoiler] save before you attempt anything with Gamma, losing him will lock you out of some options later [/spoiler] a design choice that even the devs admitted it was not the best. 

If another small nitpick can be made to the game is that the endings felt a bit underwhelming to me and towards the endgame I would love to explore some avenues more, especially regarding our protagonist [spoiler] and his past [/spoiler], perhaps even an even bigger exploration of the ideas proposed in the story and maybe visit more locations. 

For fans of point and click adventures, Primordia is a really great game that you should add to your collection. With brilliant art, top-notch music and voice acting, its haunting apocalyptic world will definitely offer a few good hours of enjoyment and food for thought after the credits roll.
developer_response:
Thank you so much for the lovely, and thorough, review.  Glad you enjoyed the game, and we appreciate the constructive criticism. :)

Can't promise we'll get everything just right next time (hindsight is always better than foresight), but we'll build on what we learned from this go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099262388', 'num_games_owned': 985, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 444, 'last_played': 1562171903}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053008883', 'num_games_owned': 517, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1549057040}
review: Actually I bought this 2 years ago because of a friend's recommendation. But I just had the chance to play it recently and unfortunately the game's resolution is very low and there is no way to change that. So I've read some comments and now I know that because of the game's engine, there is no way for the developers to solve this problem and they are actually vey sorry too. At first I was hesitant to write this negative review because the devs seem like very nice people and they answer any review in Steam, which is a very rare thing. But in the end the game wasn't playable for me because of the resolution disaster and I think the right thing to do is to warn other users about that.
developer_response:
Hey! 

Sorry to hear of your bad experience.

There are two separate things with resolution.  One is that the game's art is 320x240, just as seen in the screenshots.  That's not an engine issue, but (1) a conscious aesthetic choice to emulate the adventure games we grew up with and (2) a resources decision based on the quantity of animated sprites and the fact that we had a single artist.  The art style is in the screenshots/videos, so if people look at that and think it's outdated and unattractive, they definitely shouldn't buy the game, as there's no helping it.  But it's not something we would (or could) blame on the engine.

There's a separate issue that the engine (which we're in the process of updating) requires some massaging to work with high resolution, widescreen monitors, particularly in Windows 10.  In some instances, the engine can't do fullscreen in that scenario, and when people run the game in a window, it can be very small because it is 320x240 pixels on a monitor with a very high resolution.  That can be fixed by enlarging the window, which I'd be happy to walk you through if that's the issue.  This is an engine issue, but we hope to have it resolved at long last in a couple months.

Either way, if the game isn't playable for you, it isn't playable, and I feel bad that you're disappointed by it and that we've made a liar of your friend. :)  As you've probably seen in other reviews, I'm always happy to share a Steam key to other games to try to make up for the deficiency, so let me know.

author: {'steamid': '76561198847155776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1548562442}
review:
I have never been a fan of point and click games as, they seem boring to me.  This game is different though. The beautiful art, the amazing soundtrack, the on-point voice acting, and the deep story made me more immersed than some "AAA" games.

I don't usually cry but, some parts of the story had me teary. When I got one of the perfect endings, my smile has never been any bigger.

Seriously. Buy this game. You won't regret it. $11 is too cheap for this quality game. High five to the developer.
developer_response:
Thank you for your kind review and, more importantly, for finding such a connection with our game.

I do think there are other great point-and-click adventures out there (no doubt better than ours!), so I hope you give the genre another try.  Happy to offer some suggestions if you give me a sense what you're looking for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026565056', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 597, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1548473104}
review: Primordia is a point and click adventure. You play as Horatio Nullbuilt, a loner robot who is a humanist, who lives in an broken down ship with his homebuilt companion Crispin. One day a big robot with claws breaks into his home, shoot him with a lazer, and steals Horatio's power source. Now Horatio and Crispin need to recover or find a new source of power before they themselves run out of power. Thier adventure will take them all over the sands of a post-apocalyptic earth to a city of robots. The story is very well written and I enjoyed it alot. The puzzles weren't too hard to figure out. The voice acting wasn't that bad. There are a total of 7 ends you can achieve. Wadjet Eye Games keeps delivering such good games and this is no different. And I give this a 8.5/10.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words -- so glad you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013697341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1541336853}
review:
You play a religious robot in a wasteland, that is as much graveyard as it is fertile ground for new beginnings. The dialogue and story show very nice worldbuilding. Slowly you unravel the secrets of what happened and what went wrong. I found the puzzles challenging but never unfair. 
A particularly large area felt a bit overwhelming at first, but once you follow the story, you are on the right path. The graphics speak for themselves.
developer_response:
"as much graveyard as it is fertile ground for new beginnings. "

What a beautiful turn of phrase. Thank you so much for sharing it, and your kind words, with us.

author: {'steamid': '76561198186562583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1551743690}

author: {'steamid': '76561197977046212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1548235883}
review: This game is fantastic in every way - the amazing art, the excellent soundtrack, the enthralling dialogue and story, and the well-delivered voice acting. The game itself is a straightforward adventure game, but with a sort of intuitive approach to puzzles and progress that were mostly straightforward to figure out the first time around. I'd advise if you run into major blocks for more than 20 minutes on any given puzzle, just look up the next step in a walkthrough and then keep trying to figure it out yourself. Play it through in its entirety. What was at first an interesting but slow-paced game gradually grew into a broader story with some interesting themes and it genuinely made me think. Any game that can have this level of emotional resonance and thought put into it is worth the time and money. Give it a shot!
developer_response: What a beautiful and generous review to start my morning with. Thanks for wiriting it. I‚Äôm so glad Primordia connected with you like that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198881395768', 'num_games_owned': 603, 'num_reviews': 517, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1547595349}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009455490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1547404530}
review:
The story seemed to be going some interesting places, but ulitmately resolved in a big bad guy you could either take down or join up with. I'm not even sure the story had any specific themes it was trying to tackle. Definitely something to do with authority, with a dash of a redemption arc with the main character's past being what it is.

As for the gameplay, it resembles an old point-and-click adventure games from LucasArts back in the 1980s and 1990s. Lots of guessing what the developers thought would be clever puzzle solutions without getting any significant context. Lots of clicking on every piece of the screen to make out the one thing that was an object with gameplay functions only to realize it was the 5th time you clicked on something that was a dull gag.

The commitment to poor game design left in the dust decades ago is commendable but leaves a sour taste in my mouth realizing I have to look up an online guide for assistance on something the game should have guided me toward from the start. True, the game does have a hint system in the form of your companion Crispen, but it usually informs you of going to a specific place or doing an obscure task that you can barely determine because of the aforementioned pixel-scanning for every screen your face.

Overall, my feelings on the experience were lukeworm but expected: a game that tried to recreate the past (warts and all), so it feels like it intentionally learned nothing.
developer_response:
I'm so sorry to hear of the lousy experience you had with the game.  Obviously, it doesn't make up for the time or hopes you wasted on Primordia, but I have a bunch of keys to other games that I backed on Kickstarter or in charity bundles using Primordia proceeds, and I like to give them away to folks who are frustrated with our game -- it seems like a reasonable ecology since the games were paid for in the first place by Primordia's profits, to which you've contributed, and in any event I don't have time to play games any more.

If you'd like one, just let me know either here on via email at mark@wormwoodstudios.com.  Sorry again that you didn't enjoy Primordia, but I hope it doesn't sour you to trying other developers' point-and-clicks, even the retro ones, which may be more to your liking than ours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970533201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1547335191}
review: No sound. Mouse cursor doesn't move. Resolution is messed up. Lines moving down the screen - annyoying flickering. Apparently it can be fixed if you do a lot of file editing but I'm not into that. Cannot recommend.
developer_response:
What a pain. So sorry for your lousy experience.

It's no excuse, but by way of explanation, those problems arise from the underlying engine in which Primordia was made (AGS).  We're in the process of porting Primordia to a newer engine, but it's slow going, since we do this as a hobby and we've got some new projects that we want to spend time on, too.

Doesn't make it any less crappy that a game you decided to take a chance on didn't work. I hate to leave customers unhappy, so I'd like to offer to substitute a key for some other game that hopefully will work better -- I've got about 150 different keys from Kickstarters and charity bundles I backed with Primordia proceeds, and since I have no time to play them, I always like to give them away to players who were let down by the game. Let me know if you'd be interested.  You can also email me at mark@wormwoodstudios.com.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047436778', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 478, 'last_played': 1540014431}

author: {'steamid': '76561197977298750', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1544344426}
review:
This is from Wadjet Eye Games, so of course it‚Äôs going to be great. This one felt like they nailed exactly what they aimed to create. It‚Äôs a masterclass in world-building. I love a dystopian world, and this one in which robots rule the land and man, their creator, is but a distant memory was fascinating from the beginning. They did such a good job of immediately setting the tone of the story and drawing you into the world.

Many puzzles can be solved in multiple ways, and each way may lead to a different ending, which isn‚Äôt often the case in point-and-click adventures. I will say that some of the puzzles required more pixel-hunting than you normally find in Wadjet Eye games, but it didn‚Äôt ruin anything for me. 

They also included a great fast-travel system in this, which is something I‚Äôd like in all adventure games. And as a bonus, the main character is voiced by Logan Cunningham, who is the narrator in Bastion and is always a happy inclusion in any game.

Game and book reviews: [url=http://www.looselogic.com]http://www.looselogic.com[/url]
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words! I‚Äôm glad you enjoyed the world and puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989807190', 'num_games_owned': 2273, 'num_reviews': 596, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 196, 'last_played': 1546883452}
review:
Primordia is a project by¬†Wormwood Studios and might be one of the most stylish and animated AGS games that appeared under Wadjet Eye name. Which is probably the main draw of the title - its beautiful looking retro-futuristic surrealist post-apocalyptic landscape, the curious post-human world with humanity turned into some mythical beings of ancient times, great animation work and one of the best voice acting jobs done for the Wadjet Eye game to this day. It also tries to be really nicely paced and designed, with many puzzles having multiple solutions and approaches and story dynamically adjusting itself to some little variables that can happen due to player choice.

That said, it does feel like by the time second half of the game starts, the game starts losing its focus. Some scenes, even with the different approaches to solving them, devolve into the usual trappings of "try to use each item on the thing/other item" and trying to figure out if there are any important things/exits on the scene that aren't obvious. And the common for most AGS games issues with resolution being way too low if you have a 4K screen (especially if you use DPI scaling) is also not particularly pleasant. But the game is nice, it tells a compelling enough story and tells it well and is something I'm glad I spent several hours on.
Edit: According to the developer response, the resolution issue should be addressed soon via an engine update, which will certainly make the game much more pleasant to play on higher res screens. So that's awesome.
developer_response:
Thanks for the review -- I think players will benefit from reading pros and cons together.  We are working on a port to a newer version of AGS, which may help with resolution issues.  We just need to have WEG sign off of the quality control and then we can push it out.  (Among other things, it also incorporates German, Spanish, and French translations.)

It's interesting to me that when players discuss the two halves of the game, they seem pretty evenly split as to which they prefer.  I suppose I should keep my own preferences private!

Thanks again, and happy New Year!

author: {'steamid': '76561198289432773', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 574, 'last_played': 1546878657}

There are hundreds of dialogues and numorous word puns, which can be a significant hazard if you're not good in English, but it is still very worth playing for.
And Crispin is super adorable!

author: {'steamid': '76561198265975752', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1650812911}
review: I love this game. I picked it up in the sale because it was cheap and thought "this could be fun" but boy, was i not prepared for how good this game is. It's like dune if it was written by douglas adams and was developed by lucasarts. It's a wild ride and i enjoyed every minute of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993782240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1622857783}
review: Really good game! I grew up playing old school click-and-point games and this one hit close to home. Music is good and the voice acting sounds top notch. For a minute there, I was pretty sure that the main character is voiced by Liam Neeson. Good gameplay, beautiful pixel art, and a great soundtrack! If your looking for a casual game to play on the side, this is definitly one of the best gems to play. Great game, would recommend it!
developer_response:
Thanks! So glad you enjoyed it!

We were very lucky to have Logan Cunningham (at the time, a minor celebrity for his work on Bastion) as the actor for Horatio. Quite the voice on that guy!

(Though I think my favorite voices are actually Crispin's and Clarity's.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198047427085', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1546364380}
review: The story and art design are INCREDIBLE, but the game is extremely hard if not impossible to finish on your own, due to lack of hints on what needs to be typed in terminal for you to get tower code. Up until that point the game did great job at giving a little advice on what has to be done next.
developer_response: Thanks so much for sticking with the game despite its challenge. We did try to dispense hints via Crispin, but striking the right balance is tough. I‚Äôm so glad you had the generosity to enjoy the parts that worked for you rather than throwing in the towel!

author: {'steamid': '76561197986997483', 'num_games_owned': 846, 'num_reviews': 314, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1546222127}
review: There's a lot to like about Primordia, but I do think the negatives outweigh the positives.  Mostly the problems are the art which is all monotone brown so it's very hard to know what you're looking at, and the fact that the "puzzles" are very light.  The only memorable puzzles in the whole game are the small set of puzzles involving searching an archive.  Those were good.  The rest is far too simple to test your gray matter.  If you ever get stuck, it's simply because you couldn't pick one brown thing out of the background.  The characters were good for this kind of humorous sci-fi.  I wish, however, it had been serious sci-fi because the premise is an interesting thing to think about, but can only be taken so far when the robots have to be human stereotypes for the comedy.
developer_response:
Sorry you didn't enjoy it more, though I have to say that it gives me hope for the future to read a negative review that views Primordia's puzzles as too *easy*, rather than the more common criticism that they're too hard.  I tend to agree with your assessment -- or maybe, better said, they're just too simple.

(The kiosk puzzle is also my favorite, and probably the one that drew the most complaints from professional reviewers!)

Anyway, I hate to leave a customer unsatisfied, especially one with such discerning taste. I have a large number of keys to various games I backed on Kickstarter and in charity bundles over the years, and no time to play them. Since those were backed by "kicking forward" Primordia's proceeds, my policy has always been that if a player is disappointed in Primordia, he or she is welcome to one of those other games.

I know it's not a worthy fix for a flawed game, but maybe it can at least be a chaser to wash the bad taste out of your mouth. Let me know either via Steam or email (mark@wormwoodstudios.com).

Have a wonderful New Year, and sorry again for the disappointment!

author: {'steamid': '76561198101839707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1499542198}
review: I remember thinking "wow, this is a nice game" while playing it. But when I turn back and remember the experience, it was not just "nice". It was great. Now I am trying to find a similar game. I think Tormentum is kind of similar and as good. Yes, Primordia is that good.
developer_response:
So glad you enjoyed Primordia!

Among classic adventures, you might check out Beneath a Steel Sky (a strong visual inspiration for Primordia's artist), I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream, and Sanitarium, all of which have fairly serious, symbol-rich stories.

There are other games that I prefer among adventures, but the stories tend to be a little lighter-hearted.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061821567', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1649852353}
review:
A good story-driven point-and-click game. The puzzles are much better than most, if not all, other games I've played - not too difficult, but still difficult enough to feel rewarding and satisfying to complete. There is a small degree of control over the story - there will be a few instances in which you can take different actions, resulting in different outcomes - all of these make both story and gameplay sense, so they're also satisfying.

The only downside that you should be aware of coming into the game is that it's quite short.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the generous review -- I'm particularly glad you found the puzzle difficulty rewarding, since it's tricky to calibrate that to the right level.

I'm not sure if it will offset the game's length, but we did do a free spin-off story (not a game) in the same setting: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198328453909', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1513736330}
review: This is by far one of my favourite Indie games. The story is compelling and thought provoking, the characters are some of the most likeable I have ever seen, and the overall atmosphere and aesthetic of the game is unmatched. That said however, it can be a short game, I completed it in less than 8 hours. Despite the short run time this game is one of the most memorable I have ever played, and is more akin to art than simple entertainment.
developer_response: Thank you so much for the early Christmas present of this wonderful review! So glad to hear how much you enjoyed the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070298128', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1544993058}
review:
I am going to start with the negative. The low resolution of the graphics is a problem for this game in the same way it is a problem for similar "indie adventure" games like Gemini Rue and Resonance. Point and click adventure games by definition have puzzles that rely on visual cues, and the low resolution makes it impossible to see some of the cues. Another issue is that enjoying the art is part of the pleasure of point-and-click adventures, and the low resolution detracts from that. The production values on the sound, voice acting, game design, etc. on this game are very good. It is too bad that the graphics resolution is not up to the same standard.

The good: this is an excellent sci-fi story. It is told in an engaging way, and the gameplay meshes well with the story. Even though it is somewhat apacolyptic, the tone of the story is not dark or depressing. The game play elements are creative and there are meaningful puzzles to solve. There is a certain amount of pixel hunting, which is made more challenging by the low res graphics. The music and sound effects are very nice and mesh well with the story. The art is very nice, although hampered by the low resolution. One of the characters provides both comic relief and hints, and this is a nice touch. Overall this is one of my favorite adventure games in spite of the low screen resolution. I hope the creative team behind this game gets better funding so they can put out a game with modern technology.
developer_response:
Thanks for the thorough and kind review! I'm glad you enjoyed the game.

We don't really develop with "funding" -- we cover our costs out of pocket, and otherwise it's just a hobby we do in our spare time. Our next titles are higher resolution, but still a long ways from 2018. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198012304720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1545035344}
review:
I really enjoyed this game. Played with the commentary from Mark, Dave, Vic, James, and everyone on from the beginning. As a game dev myself I really felt like I was playing their game with them, so the bloopers and insights into the process felt like part of my own experience as a developer and actually made playing the game the first time more immersive. 

I especially felt Dave's insight as a producer, but Mark's writing insights were great, especially the moments where he reflected on the end of the game before release outside MetroMind's lair. That really hit home for me and helped me accept letting go of my own project we just ended. It felt good to hear that commentary and very refreshing to hear someone able to let go with some words of wisdom while they still love the project. Not many people appreciate what goes into a game. It's far more than just code and art. Your children grow up. Your body ages. Your mind changes. 

Your life is in that screen, living apart from you in another world, which goes on to become part of the private lives of strangers you'll never meet. It defines a tangible sense of place in a shared imagination. I love feeling that as a player. Always have.

And Primordia did that very well. 

The art, while it does suffer from that low res pixelation that I would have loved to see at 1080p without the noise filter, especially as a future-proofing measure, it was still beautiful. And in fact, the resolution actually made my imagination work with the art, which lent itself to the style. That's part of the genre after all. 

The voice acting felt right at home. Every day on my own game I read comments from people who hate the voice acting in my projects, but there's so many good personal memories in each of those recording sessions. There's something beyond a game just being professionally recorded engineering wise, and the performances fitting the world, there's fingerprints of the artists behind it that feels homey. 

And that to me is more important than high production quality and exacting standards. I appreciate the feeling of hanging out with friends making art and imagining a world, playing pretend for a while. I love that. Makes me feel like a kid again, and it's why I wanted into this career. I like having that back, before facing the wrath of Gam3rKill69 for not being ripped out of a hollywood soundstage. 

Maybe I'm alone in that, or unique, but I have a feeling the audience for adventure games with a rich world like this feels the same way. Is it a little cheesy? Yes. But I love it. We don't all have to be Game of Thrones all the time, we can have fun. And this is exactly that.

Logan and Abe were amazing, they sound like my friends. All the supporting cast, the dev team's voices in various cameos -- I loved it all. 

The puzzles were great (except that Kiosk terminal and robot hidden in the dark in the courthouse) and I could generally solve them quickly without interruption. I really liked combining and reusing items. I rarely got lost thanks to that fast travel system, and even when I did I loved the art style so much I didn't mind seeing it again. 

Reviews on a game from 2012, that feels like it was made in 1996, feel more like a review of a moment in time in the life of someone you've never met. It's like traveling back in time and going into their house and looking at photos of their kids and playing with their dog. You can feel them at their desk and hear them working on the game as if it were yesterday. 

You're reviewing a moment in someone's life, and the heartbeat is still in it across time.

It's done. It released years ago. 

But it's never finished. Something in there always lives on, and you can go visit it for a while. 

That's beautiful, and so is Primordia.
developer_response:
Thank you for the beautiful reflection -- I don't think it's adequate to call it a review -- which does a wonderful job of capturing the hopeful melancholy of Primordia and of the experience of making it.

Best of luck with your own projects!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022378098', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 385, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1544990627}

We did do a sort of spin-off story, though it's not a game: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

I'm not sure if we'd ever do a true sequel, but we do hope to make more adventures before we kick the bucket. :)
