author: {'steamid': '76561197969995293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1383440982}
review:
As a huge fan of the classic LucasArts adventures (Maniac Mansion, Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, ect.), I can wholeheartedly say: Primorida deserves to sit among these classics as an equal.

[+] Good and logical puzzles
[+] Great setting/lore and background story
[+] Great characters
[+] Great voice actors
[+] Fantastic artworks
[+] Fantastic soundtrack
[+] Great dialogue writing
[+] Good humour
[+] Different solution paths for some riddles
[+] Different endings
[+] Optional tasks
[+] In-game sidekick that can provide hints before being too stuck
[+] Optional audio commentary from the developers

[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]
Like most adventure games, the play time is relatively short in comparison to games of other genres, but: better short and great than too dragged out and drifting into mediocrity. If you are a fan of old adventure games and want to relive that experience of playing a great adventure game for the very first time, give this modern classic a try, it's worth every cent and second. Once I finished the game, I felt sad that it was over and wished for a sequel that would bring me back to this fascinating and melancholic world and the likable characters that live in it.

Playtime: 6-9 hours
Rating: 9/10
developer_response: Thanks so much for this generous review -- to be compared to those classics by someone who is familiar with the genre means a lot, since the games of old inspired us to make Primordia in the first place!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066059380', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1544416617}
review: Awesome little point-and-click adventure. Great atmosphere, great storytelling, great artstyle, great voice acting. The writing is also quite humorous, and had me chuckling to myself often. Multiple endings give it replay value, and I'll definitely have to revisit it in the future to find out those other endings. Definitely recommended, especially considering how inexpensive it is.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words -- especially glad you enjoyed the humor, which is always tricky to get right!

author: {'steamid': '76561198081477001', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 378, 'last_played': 1670488546}
review:
Well...
Surprisingly, it's much more of a spiritual successor to Planescape:Torment than Tides of Numenera. 
For a NUMBER of reasons.

Sometimes it's not as subtle, but oddly enough, even with all obvious similarities cast aside, the atmosphere is quite reminiscent of Sygil.

If the Nameless One is your role model - grab this immediately.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind review and generous comparison to PS:T.

It absolutely was an inspiration for Primordia -- the principal one, from a writing standpoint.  If anything, you could argue it is less a "spiritual successor" and more a straight variation on a theme, like those Elseworlds comics where Batman is Dracula or whatever.  ("What if TNO were a robot??")

I had the great fortune that Primordia served as an entry to working on TTON; I got to write a small amount of the text in the game (some of the Meres, the Council Clerk, the philethis, and Inifere, plus some other sundry material).  I haven't actually played the game, but I did feel quite humbled to write any part of a game bearing the Torment moniker, just as I did to have as colleagues writers like McComb, Ziets, and Avellone.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984393339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1543723588}
review: I ended up having to use a walk-through quite a bit, but that's because I'm a dumb bastard.
developer_response: Nah, different people connect with puzzles in adventure games differently. There's a degree to which it's just "what am I thinking of?" and if you and the designer think in similar ways, it's pretty easy, and if you don't, it can be very tough. Puzzle design is really hard to get right, and it's definitely what I struggled the most with on Primordia. So, it's on us, not you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198053734082', 'num_games_owned': 1694, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 860, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 860, 'last_played': 1543565865}
review:
Bought in a bundle without knowing much about it except it's published by Wadjet Eye Games and another game in the bundle was Gemini Rue (which by body required at the time). I stuck gold because what we have here is a high quality four-man (+Dave as producer / voice caster) point & click adventure game with gorgeous 320x200 graphic.

Story is set in post apocalyptic, distant future cyberpunk world which is a rich environment for imaginative locations, story, characters. You name it. Overall story is pretty solid and will satisfy even the most seasoned adventure players.
What really stands out are the dialogues. Intelligent, interesting, believable, diverse, humorous and account for your actions if you do them if different order. Professional voice acting enhances everything with appropriate styles for each unique character. Protagonist for example is voiced by Bastion narrator. You can tell writer truly put effort and thought into it because the text never feels like a boring filler and there is plenty of it.

Puzzles are smart and original but grounded in logic. Also greatly vary from one another in terms of solving mechanic, making classic 'use object here' just a part of the repertoire. Difficulty wise they sit in the sweet spot between obvious and complex but lean a bit toward complex side. Until you solve them that is, when you'll realize it was just the right amount. To help with steady progress game tracks hints you collect and notes them conveniently for review at leisure. And for when you get stuck, clicking your sidekick will provide a very nice subtle hint for every possible situation. I even dare say this part is so well done it might be best in-game hint system ever done in an adventure game. Think of it as more advanced and fully voiced [url=http://www.uhs-hints.com/]uhs-hints.com[/url].

Another innovative detail (for an adventure) is ability to fast travel to and from nearly every location, neatly and stylishly incorporated into the UI. Good thing it is because there is no way to skip walking animations. Same goes for lengthy conversations, you'll have to skip text in small chunks at a time. But ok, as world-class nitpicker, I managed.

The one shortcoming is its a bit short (8 hours) with roughly only 40 screens to visit spread across two main areas and a lot of revisits, especially in the second part. Most locations are two screens wide though, and view smoothly pans as it follows your character. Gorgeous visuals and rewarding sense after solving puzzles more than make up for its length and repetitive locations.

Nice bonus are numerous and highly detailed Dev Commentaries (and voice actor bloopers) that you can enable right from the start (mind the spoilers). Lastly, a spoiler-free digital novella [url=http://primordia-game.com/Fallen/Fallen%20Complete.pdf]"Fallen"[/url] by Mark Yohalem (Primordia designer & writer) tells about a spin-off story set after the game reached its conclusion.

Like most Wadjet Eye Games this one is also made with proven Adventure Game Studio, meaning it's light on resources and runs on all major OS. Technically, things could have been better. In fullscreen game does not run on monitor's native resolution but changes it to a multiple of 320x200 and then stretches to fullscreen. Typically such games render in native but draw in best-fit multiple and then get stretched to native. Difference is: in the former has more blured pixels and Steam overlay is low resolution, while in later everything is fine. I had to play in 640x400 fullscreen (native 1366x768) because GPU apparently does not support 960x600 I always set multiple to in these cases. Windowed mode does not suffer from any of this but unacceptably breaks immersion. I believe the issue is down to AGS version but may be how the its features were implemented in the game itself. No clue really but highly doubt it's my drivers. All I know there are no solutions or I'd find something in couple of hours of troubleshooting. Experience was slightly less of what it should have been because in windowed the pixels looked so much better (sharper). And I love my pixels as I remember them from the 90s - crystal clear.
developer_response: Thanks so much for this generous, and thorough, review, and for persevering through technical headaches.  In particular, I was struck by how you took time to say something nice about all sorts of different aspects of the game. We're really lucky to have fans like you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048618049', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1543605635}
review:
I really enjoyed this game, its been a while since an adventure game really was fun for me.

The puzzles were all very well played, some were easy and some were difficult enough to really make me think.

I would definitely recommend
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words -- so glad to hear you enjoyed the puzzles, something that is always hard to get right!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993520790', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1543551877}
review: Excellent point-and-click adventure game. Quite moody and with great atmospherics. It's not too hard and puzzles are quite logical. Story is engaging as well. Overall, a rare game in the new decade.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words, and for giving our game a spin!

author: {'steamid': '76561198071372539', 'num_games_owned': 867, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 404, 'last_played': 1483474127}
review: If you are wondering if you should grab Primordia you should first know it comes from Wadjet Eye games. If you don't know Wadjet Eye games i would suggest just go ahead and grab every game they made. If you like point and click games you should just go ahead and play everything they released. Prob the best company out there still making them.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the review!

I wholly endorse the sentiment re: WEG, which publishes and develops great games, but I do want to note that there is a distinction in the two roles.  WEG didn't make Primordia (or Resonance, Gemini Rue, Technobabylon, The New Guyz, Puzzlebots, or A Golden Wake) -- it was just the publisher.  Wormwood Studios (us!) developed Primordia, and each of those other games had its own separate developer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972248306', 'num_games_owned': 873, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1543347864}
review:
Super story and world, and I like the pixel art.

Some of the puzzles were great, others were a biiiit too far fetched, but most of the time you can ask your sidekicks for a few tips, which helps.

I would love it if the game got a sequel :)
developer_response:
Thanks so much for leaving such a kind review.

While I don't think we'll ever do a game sequel, we did do a spin-off story, which is available for free as an audio book or illustrated eBook: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html Not sure if it will scratch the itch, though at least it doesn't have unfair puzzles. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198038629568', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1544529366}
review:
Primordia is a charming adventure which takes place on a planet inhabited solely by robots. In this world humanity is nothing but a myth. Humans have dissappeared a long time ago and many do not believe they even existed. Only some still wonder about them and keep their memory alive. The Gospel of Man acts as their holy book and they do their best to honour these enigmatic creators, even in the face of adversity and downright persecution.

The two main characters of Primordia, Horatio Nullbuilt and Crispin Horatiobuilt [all robots have their maker incorporated in their 'family'name ], make a pretty good team. Horatio's seriousity is well tempered by Crispin's humour, while his ingenuity is completed by Crispin's mobility. Any time Horatio gets stuck and can't find the solution to a particular problem, good ol' Crispin may actually help him out with some kind of suggestion or advice. [This mechanic offers help to players while at the same time preserving in-game immersion] Secondary characters are also well designed, though I wish some of the less important ones were given more lines. 

Puzzles are neither too easy, nor too difficult. Dialogues are interesting and very funny. The music is fine and the pixelated graphics are well-suited for the job. Some backgrounds are really beautiful. Last but not least, the game has multiple endings, for basically any kind of solution available at the end. 

What makes Primordia stand out is neither the interesting graphics, nor the great voice acting, though I do admit to finding both of them endearing. The game's great virtue is telling a important human story. Its heroes are involved in a easily recognisable struggle, especially if one belongs to a country or nation which suffered through the ravages of totalitarisism. 

The game's robot world ponders important questions. What is the greater good? What is progress? What sacrifices are we willing to make for the greater good or progress? What is justice? What is truth? What does it mean to believe in a religion or an ideal? What's left when we are left alone? How do we best honor the memory of our gods, forefathers or fallen? Is there redemption for our sins? 

Though at first it may seem completely at odds with the setting, Primordia offers a original tale about truth, friendship and freedom. And for that it has be commended. 

8/10 Graphics
7/10 sound
9/10 gameplay
10/10 story
-------------
8.5/10
developer_response: So glad you tried and enjoyed our game and took the time to leave such a generous review.  We're really lucky to have players like you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026549916', 'num_games_owned': 986, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1520570488}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015381850', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1371406352}
review: In a strange way, Primordia makes me feel like I'm playing Beneath a Steel Sky for the first time.  The world is beautifully worn without feeling desolate.  It's fun to get lost in.
developer_response: Thanks for the generous comparison! BASS was a huge inspiration on Primordia's artist (and co-creator) Victor Pflug. I'll let him know that you felt the connection. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198060460930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1545503934}
review: Highly entertaining point-and-click adventure game that feels like a homage to Beneath A Steel Sky. Has wonderfully scripted banter between the two main characters, and a storyline that draws you in. The environments are amazingly well put together, that it helps to tell the tale, and helps it have more believability.
developer_response:
Glad you liked it (and enjoyed the banter)!  BASS was a major inspiration on the game's artist/co-create, and it definitely spilled over to influencing the story, too.

Thanks for giving the game and go and taking the time to leave such a kind review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042276572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1543089658}
review:
Ein klassisches Point & Click Adventure.

1) Die Story:
Die Geschichte kommt etwas langsam in Fahrt und gerade der erste Akt hat durchaus seine L√§ngen. Dann aber entfaltet sich eine spannende Geschichte welche durchaus auch einen gewissen Tiefgang besitzt. Zwar besteht die Hintergrundgeschichte aus alt bekannten Versatzst√ºcken, andererseits muss man das Rad ja nicht jedesmal neu erfinden, zumal dann nicht, wenn alles so sch√∂n ineinander passt. Und w√§hrend man versucht herauszufinden was im hier und jetzt passiert lernt man gleichzeitig entscheidendes dar√ºber, wass die Welt zu dem gemacht hat was sie heute ist. Wenig √ºberraschend stand am Anfang ein Krieg. Eine insgesamt sehr sch√∂n komponierte Geschichte. Einzig das Gef√ºhl f√ºr die zeitlichen Ma√üst√§be will sich nicht so recht einstellen. Liegt der Krieg jahrhunderte zur√ºck? Oder vielleicht nur Jahrzehnte? Oder noch weniger? 
Die Story an sich ist recht d√ºster. Aufgelockert wird das ganze jedoch durch Crispin, unseren Robo-Sidekick, der gerne mal einen Spruch auf unsere Kosten heraus haut (und umgekehrt).

2) Die R√§tsel:
Die R√§tsel sind nie wirklich unfair, aber oft durchaus knifflig. So kann es z.B. nicht schaden bei Gelegenheit auch Bogen und Stift neben sich zu haben, denn obwohl alle wichtigen Informationen sch√∂n praktisch mit geloggt werden hilft die eigene Visualisierung manchmal doch am besten. 
Obacht sollte man bei den klassischen Inventarkombinationsr√§tseln geben, denn hier kann die Reihenfolge manchmal den Unterschied machen: Objekt A l√§sst sich dann z.B. nicht mit Objekt B kombinieren, Objekt B jedoch sehr wohl mit Objekt A. 
Sollte man einmal wirklich nicht weiter kommen kann man seinen Robo-Sidekick befragen der einen dann zuverl√§ssig wieder auf die richtige F√§hrte bringt.

3) Die Steuerung:
Es handelt sich bei Primordia um ein Point & Click Adventure mit 1-Click Steuerung. Sprich es werden keine Verben oder Symbole ben√∂tigt. Der Klick mit der linken Maustaste bewirkt eine je nach Objekt angemessene Aktion (reden, nehmen, benutzen, dr√ºcken, √∂ffnen, etc.), mit der rechten Maustaste schaut man sich das Objekt an.
Die Tastatur kommt aber auch zum Einsatz. Nicht nur, dass es Shortcuts gibt, man muss bei Gelegenheit auch schon mal ein Terminal bedinen.
Dank der praktischen Mini-Map kommt man auch blitzschnell von einem Ort an den n√§chsten ohne wie bei den meisten anderen Spielen lange durch die Landschaft laufen zu m√ºssen.
Verl√§sst man einen Bildschirm kann man allerdings die Situation nicht wie schon lange √ºblich per doppelklick abk√ºrzen sondern muss warten bis die Figur √ºber den gesamten Bildschirm gelaufen ist. Umso √§rgerlicher, dass man sobald man geklickt hat seine Meinung auch nicht mehr √§ndern kann sondern abwarten muss, bis man am n√§chsten Schauplatz angekommen ist um dann umzukehren.

4) Die Technik:
Dieses Spiel f√ºhlt sich wirklich alt an. Und zwar nicht nur 2012 alt (das Jahr in dem es erschien) sondern 1992 alt. Und man mag es nicht glauben, aber standardm√§√üig wird die Grafik via Direct3D gerendert. F√ºr das echte Retro-Feeling empfehle ich aber, dies im Optionsmen√º auf DirectDraw umzustellen. Dann werden vor allem die Sprites besser (bzw. pixeliger) gerendert. 
Trotz der bewusst veralteten Technik erzeugt Primordia aber auch in anderen Belangen Retro-Feeling. So ruckelt die Kamera beim scrollen doch gerne einmal.
Anders als 1992 √ºblich gibt es hier aber auch eine (wirklich gelungene) Sprachausgabe (in Englisch).

5) Das Fazit:
Mit rund 6 Stunden Spielzeit bewegt sich Primordia am unteren Ende dessen was ich f√ºr angemessen halte. Diese 6 Stunden sind daf√ºr aber umso spannender und ich hatte zu keinem Zeitpunkt das Gef√ºhl, dass mir reines F√ºllmaterial vorgesetzt wurde. Ich war eigentlich von Anfang bis Ende am Knobeln. Wer Point & Click mag und dabei einem Endzeitszenario nicht vollkommen abgeneigt ist kann bei Primordia bedenkenlos zugreifen.
developer_response:
Vielen Dank f√ºr die sorgf√§ltige und gr√ºndliche √úberpr√ºfung! Sie haben Recht in Bezug auf die vage Chronologie der Spielgeschichte. Das war zum Teil bewusst - um es mythischer zu machen als historisch -, aber es sollte auch zeigen, dass Maschinen, die mit radikal unterschiedlichen Verarbeitungsgeschwindigkeiten arbeiten, die Zeit so inkonsistent wahrnehmen k√∂nnen, dass sie Zeitalter von Jahren und Zeitpunkten von Jahrhunderten bilden.

Trotzdem vielen Dank, dass Sie das Spiel einmal probiert haben. Ich bin so froh, dass es Ihnen gefallen hat!

author: {'steamid': '76561198079278295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1602088224}
review:
First impression wasn't very good. The game wouldn't start, the mouse was acting funny, but after checking Discussion I got everything up and running, I'm sort of got overwhelmed...

5 hours of that detailed story, classy art, that enormous background of the world, I enjoyed it a lot. The design of the game is really good, the gameplay. The puzzles are very clear and can be done without random taking chances, and if your brain locks up, there's an inbuilt, but non-invasive system of the hints. 

Lovely.
developer_response: Thank you so much -- first of all for trying our game, second for persevering past your initial mixed impressions, and third for leaving this kind review.  I'm so glad you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022160541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1543045777}
review: While I'm not exactly a veteran of point and click adventure games; this might be my favourite, or at the very least the most well rounded example of the genre I've played yet. Strong and engaging story and premise, varied and unique characters, puzzles based in actual logic (some even feature alternate solutions which is awesome) with a good hint system, nice pixel art and music to set the atmosphere. A very polished title, I enjoyed it from start to finish, particularly since it didn't overstay its welcome. Worthy of the overwhelming praise, give it a shot!
developer_response:
So glad that you enjoyed it! I hope you stick around with the genre -- even the classics are more "Hurt Me Plenty!" than "Nightmare!" difficulty, and many of them are absolute gems. In particular, I'd recommend the Monkey Island series, Loom, and the Quest for Glory series.

Anyway, thanks for trying our game, and for taking the time to leave a kind review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083642038', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 558, 'last_played': 1532855248}
review:
I submitted this game to the "well of machine fun" nomination for a reason.

Primordia is one of the most heart-wrenching, mind-blowing and well-composed games that I had the honor to play, to date. The story, the art, the characters, the choices. It sits there, with Nier: Automata and Undertale on my shelf of favorite stories that leave you with questions and with wanting more. Please play it.
developer_response:
What a wonderful review ‚Äî thanks so much. 

I‚Äôm not sure if it is the ‚Äúmore‚Äù you‚Äôre looking for, but we did do a spin-off story (not a game) called ‚ÄúFallen,‚Äù which we‚Äôve got on Primordia-Game.com. 

Thanks again for the kind words!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049898093', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 817, 'last_played': 1484487767}
review:
Mankind is no more... but there are still machines and they are a lot like humans... in some ways.
You are one of those machines and you are struggling to survive.
On your travels you will learn a lot about the world, it's history and your part in history.
But... you will also leave your mark and shape the future.
You can have a big impact on how this future will look like...
developer_response: Many thanks for giving our game a whirl and for leaving such a nice review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011539099', 'num_games_owned': 1244, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 4169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1656, 'last_played': 1660756425}
review:
While i only played this game (to completion) 2 times in the 5 years i brought it, it is always on my mind!
i actually can remember most of the game perfectly, it's one of those stories that just sticks with you, the universe that was created for the game is vast and unexplored, not in a bad way, it does feel that there is much more out there, but we are in "This Story" so we can't go poking around, even so, it leaves you with a curiosity to know more.
And this is just story-wise because HOLY DAMN, The Art is AMAZING, and it actually inspires me a lot to this day!
i really wish i was better at reviewing or saying nice things about a product but.... all i can say about this one is:



You like Sci-Fi?
-Get this

You like Robots?
-Get this

You like Steampunk/Cyberpunk?
-Get this

You like Deep Pixelated, Story-Driven Games?
-GET. THIS.



10/10 - No question! i really wish we can go back to this universe one day, it's too unique!~
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind review. It‚Äôs a wonderful thing to read at the end of my Thanksgiving day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003069918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2131, 'last_played': 1422238977}
review:
I stumbled across Primordia some years ago, and it couldn't have been a better coincidence on my part. The game has been one of my personal favorites for quite a while now. I always try to find an excuse to gift it to friends who haven't played it yet so I can get them in on it, too. I admit, I'm a little biased. It just so happens the game rolled a lot of my interests together into one experience. Apocalypse fiction? Fascinating art style? Haunting, moody sci-fi? Sad robots? [i]I'm in.[/i]

In all seriousness, though, I think it's a beautifully put together game. The love everyone at Wormwood poured into it really shines through. The deep melancholy of the soundtrack and haunting art style build such a solid atmosphere. I loved picking around the ruins of the world and unraveling the full story bit by bit with each puzzle solved, or item examined. I loved the characters, the personalities they exuded in their dialogue, and all the idiosyncrasies of their cobbled together robot society I was exploring. I loved my jaded, weary, hermit of a protagonist who was still lonely enough to build himself a friend. I love Horatio Nullbuilt v5, my favorite robot.

Primordia is one of those games that I'll be thinking about forever. It makes me wish it had a bigger fandom so I could find more excuses to talk about it all the time. It's just a lovely little thing that I'm really happy to have found.
developer_response: Thank you for the kind words, beautiful review, and support over the years. We‚Äôre very lucky to have fans like you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053623932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1542001882}
review:
How strange a game.

The first adventure game I've ever played, Primordia is a unique (or, perhaps, a uniic) experience for me. As far as it goes I've seen a few other adventure games before, mostly in text lets plays, but actually playing one and running head first into their major faults is an interesting feeling. So, pros and cons
PROS
-Interesting story full of gray morality and no real answers
-interesting characters that are fun to interact with
-a few clever puzzles that will make you feel brilliant for figuring out
-numerous endings
-pleasantly ambient soundtrack that adds much to the atmosphere

CONS
-adventure game logic
-no real "satisfying" ending

Seems like a short list of grievances, but that first one is about 50 different complaints rolled into one. "Adventure game logic" usually ends up meaning puzzles that have one UND PRECISELY ONE solution, meaning you can ONLY use that cable on these specific items and you can ONLY open that door by doing something that only the person making the puzzle would think of. Without wishing to spoil, that is NOT how I would clean a rusty gear. Some of the puzzles are just obtuse in a way that would make sense in the real world, but it's honestly not fair to call it a puzzle when the game doesn't say there are certain ways certain things interact, so often the only ways a person can see to proceed is to rub everything they have against everything else, or to look up a walk though. Some puzzles are brilliant and do actually punish you for taking the easy way out or not thinking laterally, but most of them, particularly in the back half of the game, make a bad habit of either withholding information or just forcing you to try everything on everything else. In a more personal complaint, I would think that covering something in oil would make it slick, not sticky. Clearly the developers have different ideas.

All in all though as an adventure game, though i have little experience with them, I'd say this one isn't bad. The story is it's main selling point, and it is an interesting one. From a starting point of looking for the thing that stole your ships powercore, you learn there's an entire city of robots run by a psychopathic train system with a warped idea of progress and no implementation of Asimov's Laws. You learn how you used to regard the city, how you've changed since, and what your whole purpose was in the process. You might even make some friends along the way. There's even a kind of melancholy in a lot of the endings. Without question this is a place where you don't get easy answers and the work it takes to get those answers makes them all the more precious. I won't say any of the endings are satisfying, but at least I can say they all fit. 

If you're on the fence about it the real question comes down to "Do you like adventure games." If you do, this is a good one. If you don't, it's not likely to change your mind on the genre, but hey, at least it's not space quest. Give it a try, if it pleases you.
developer_response:
Thanks for the thoughtful and thorough review.  On top of being well written and fair, I think it will be helpful for a lot of players.

I will say that the rusty gear puzzle might be a bad example for the adventure game logic point -- it actually has three solutions (clean it with oil, get another robot to clean it with oil, or have it cleaned by the rust-eating submersibles [a play on cleaner fish]), so it may just be that you stumbled into the least logical of them. :)  Still, the overall criticism, or perhaps simply "highlighting," of adventure game logic is fair.  Ultimately, these aren't true logic/physics puzzles.

I hope you try out other adventures.  If you're finding the puzzles frustrating, you might check out Loom (which has logical and fairly easy puzzles) or Quest for Glory (which has lots of different puzzle solutions).

author: {'steamid': '76561198140801074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1540564197}
review:
A great click'n'point. Primordia has an amazing and original world setting, a good story and interesting puzzles. Not only that- it has optional puzzles and different choice options. I'd love to see more from this setting and style. 
Pros:
* Beautiful pixel art, amazing music and stunning voice acting. 
* A natural feeling inbuilt hint guide (Thank you Crispin)
* A wide set of different puzzle types, that are fun and challenging.
* Choices and optional puzzles that make the game replayable and also more rewarding to your story choices and playstyle. Theres also 'non puzzles' that are simply interesting lore points and secrets the player can figure out themself.
Cons:
* One or two puzzles didn't really feel that intuitive to me and took me poking a walkthrough to figure out [spoiler] It did not occur to me that grease would work as an adhesive, and a few things I only figured out after mashing items against interactible objects[/spoiler]
* Some of the optional achievements can be troublesome to get unless you want to replay and know what to look out for. This isn't a huge problem though as achievements are often for replay rewards anyway.[spoiler] The Kiosk achievement for unlocking all the words has to be done before you use the word that is made from all the previous clues, or you loose access to the kiosk.[/spoiler]
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed the game (and the hint system)!  The grease puzzle is definitely a dubious one; thanks for persevering despite it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198010492777', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1543936471}
review:
I love Wadjet Eye. I love Wadjet Eye games, I love that they keep doing what they're doing. But I just can't with them anymore. They have got to (even if it's just upscaling) offer a real settings menu including modern resolution options. The only excuse for releasing your games in 480(!!) with  no customization options is that you're working with an ancient engine that only renders to that resolution - which presents its own list of questions and issues.

Primordia has more of the great voice acting and lovingly-drawn setpieces you know and love, but unfortunately also does literally everything you remember hating about adventure games. Get ready for:

- Use [X] on [Y] in every scene until something randomly works
- "Adventure Game Logic" that honestly isn't as bad as it could be, but still present
- No in-game note-taking tool, despite having events that are mentioned only once, include important numbers/words, and will not be repeated
- No "Current Objective" box. I'm not asking for the breadcrumb trail and big yellow arrow, but if you Alt-F4 out of this game and come back to it two days later, you might as well start over, because you will not know or remember what you have or haven't done, so you're just lost all over.

At this point, I feel almost like Wadjet Eye is just cargo-culting old adventure games, doing what they know was **in** those titles without understanding **why** those titles did that, or why it does/doesn't work. Wadjet Eye, I just can't recommend (or buy) any more of your games until you get with the times and make an adventure game that feels like it was made this century (and I don't mean graphics-wise)
developer_response:
Sorry you didn't enjoy the game, but you shouldn't take it out on WEG -- most of their games have different developers and we only did Primordia.  So the problems you have with our game, aside from those that are engine-specific, shouldn't necessarily be present in other ones.  For instance, many of WEG's more recent games hardly have puzzles at all, so they shouldn't be as frustrating.

We're working on updating the engine (something of a fool's errand, since Primordia's more than half a decade old at this point), but ultimately we can't "solve" the underlying resolution issue since the pixel art is what it is.  What we can do is make it so that it requires less fiddling to *run* at modern resolutions, but the graphics will always be fairly chunky.

The other criticisms are well taken and the feedback is appreciated.  The only thing I'll note is that we do have an in-game note system, the datapouch, which records all of the codes, clues, etc. that are necessary for advancing.  I'm not sure if you missed it or found it un-user-friendly.  To some degree it, and Crispin's automated hints, function like a quest journal, but you're right that it's not like modern RPGs in giving you explicit reminders.

Hopefully you were able to get a refund, but either way, my policy is to pass along a key to some game (from one of the many charity bundles or Kickstaters I've backed with Primordia proceeds) that you might enjoy more. If you're interested, please either shoot me a message or email me at mark@wormwoodstudios.com. Hopefully I'll have something that's more satisfying.

Thanks again for giving our game a shot, and for taking the time to share your feedback!

We did do a little bit of spin-off material on Primordia-Game.com, including a quasi-sequel story "Fallen," but it's not the same as more game content. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197997210695', 'num_games_owned': 421, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1701160488}
review:
This might be the best point&click adventure game that I've ever played. There's a reason why this is one of the highest rated games on Steam. 

The setting reminds me of good sci-fi books by Lem or Asimov that I read as a kid. The story and characters are memorable. Locations you visit are interesting and let you learn more about the world, it's history, and how it ended, The simple soundtrack adds to the atmosphere. The puzzles are great, not too easy, but logical and don't require you to search for a guidebook. 

I really wish there were more games like it.
developer_response: Thanks for the very generous review. As someone who grew up with Lem and Asimov, too, it‚Äôs a really nice thing to read.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076753188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1627652153}

author: {'steamid': '76561198140338476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1532965926}
review:
This is a game I will never forget. 10/10
I don't even like robots, but this game is such an experience. Puzzles are a bit overcomplicated in a few places, but the storytelling is EXCELLENT. "Thanatos" is a truly striking ending that still gives me chills long after I've finished this game. It's breath-taking, poetic in a "fridge horror" way, and possibly the best sort of mind-blowing story I ever encountered.
It's freaking awesome, man.
developer_response: Thanks so much for leaving this kind review. It means a lot, personally, to know that the game connected with players, and it makes a big difference in our ability to reach new customers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008280448', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1698359652}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998647125', 'num_games_owned': 837, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1495785716}
review:
How did I not recommend this after playing it?

This has a great story with great characters. 100% worth checking out.

Maybe wait for a sale, but it's good enough to pay full price for.

Edit: Also, the dev team is great. I'm pretty sure they helped me resolve an issue with midi drivers for one of their titles, perhaps this one. On that note, make sure you have a midi synthesizer if you pick this up.

It bears repeating that the story and characters here are great. It's a very compelling world they build here. It gives you a lot of food for thought. If you appreciate a good adventure game or a great story, you really should check this out.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words and for taking the time to leave a review. I‚Äôm a cheap guy myself, so I always tell people to grab it on sale, though the price difference isn‚Äôt that huge at the end of the day!

author: {'steamid': '76561198086501729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 255, 'last_played': 1493389988}
review:
Adventure games aren't typically my thing and it isn't rare for me to get bored midway through, but I ended up seeing Primordia to the end. 
The atmosphere and setting is so interesting I just wanted to see more of it and I ended up really enjoying the characters and writing. Other than that what else is there to say? It's an adventure game with multiple endings, enjoyable characters and lots of trial and error "try clicking on and combining every item you get" type puzzles. 

If you like adventure games or you're just interested in the world, I'd say give it a shot.
developer_response: Glad you enjoyed it and stuck with it, even if the puzzles came across as trial-and-error!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055909608', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1500872459}

author: {'steamid': '76561198097657561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 306, 'last_played': 1532234107}
review: Review forthcoming

author: {'steamid': '76561197999314306', 'num_games_owned': 1174, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 693, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1537258918}
review:
Primordia is an oldschool point'n'click game. It doesn't even seem like it was made to [i]resemble[/i] adventure games from '90s - it could really pass as one, if the devs had a time machine to give it a try.

Great visuals, good audio, interesting story, world and characters, fun dialogues. Sensible difficulty - most puzzles make sense and even though there is no hot spot indicator, you don't really need to pixel hunt. And if you're stuck, you can always count on Crispin's help. Some puzzles even have alternative solutions.
Fast travel is also a nice quality of life addition.

[spoiler]Objectively:[/spoiler] 8/10 - a must-play for all pointers'n'clickers.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words -- they mean a lot, especially coming from someone who knows old-school adventures. I'm glad you enjoyed the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004433268', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1536901413}
review:
8/10

Primordia was sitting in my back log from a Humble Bundle or something at some point, and it was something I'd kept putting off.  The last time I'd played a point & click adventure game was probably over 20 years ago, playing Kings Quest VIII.  I didn't have particularly good memories of the genre, but I figured I'd give it a shot.  I am quite glad that I did.  Primordia is actually built so that you can't get truly "stuck", unlike the forebearers of the genre.  It has an attractive setting, very good voice acting, and some good humor in there too.  There were a two instances in the back half/third of the game that I ended up having to consult a walkthrough for a push in the right direction, but otherwise careful reading (and failing that, diligent experimentation) and a little thought was usually enough to work through the puzzles.  There's even in-game hints that you can get from your companion if you need them.  I wasn't expecting much out of Primordia, but I was quite pleasantly surprised and spent an enjoyable couple of afternoons working through it, and then immediately going back through it again to try a couple of different choices.
developer_response:
I'm so glad that Primordia got you back to the genre! The "walking dead" and "no path to victory" framework that plagued some of the adventures of the 80s and 90s is more or less gone from point-and-clicks. And while nostalgia does bend a lot of indie titles in "retro" directions, there are significant novelties in indie adventures too -- here, I'm thinking like Dropsy (a very weird game), Resonance (where you have a "party" and gather dialogue topics like inventory items), and the various Amanita Design titles (kind of easier, opener versions of the Goblins series).  So, good stuff!

Anyway, thanks so much for the review and for giving Primordia a chance!

author: {'steamid': '76561197968493680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 386, 'last_played': 1536559600}

Unfortunately there are so few of these games out there that have such a good quality in storytelling and of course artwork.
Story starts easy but deals with some heavy philosophical questions later on. But always in a pleasant way.
If you like difficult riddles in an apocalyptic world full of good humour-> buy it  
9.5/10
developer_response: What a generous review! I‚Äôm very glad you enjoyed the game and equally grateful you took the time to share your kind words. We‚Äôre lucky to have such fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165372392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1536445801}
review: I've never been a fan of "point-and-click" games and probably never will. However, Primordia's immersive atmosphere/world along with its impressive story/lore was more than enough to keep me pressing ahead from start to finish. If PaC games aren't a factor(no pun intended) then this game is for you. For those not familiar with OR not a fan of these type of games then I would suggest to "try it before you dislike it."
developer_response:
I'm so glad you enjoyed the game despite being averse to point-and-click adventures, and I'm grateful you took the time to leave such a nice review.

Since I'm a P&C evangelist:  you might want to give Loom a try.  Its puzzles are very reasonable, its lore is really great, and it's a beautiful game in all senses.  (I prefer the EGA version, but the VGA one is probably a bit more approachable.)  It's really the game that first made me an adventure game fan.

You could also try Full Throttle, which has a very different kind of protagonist and a fun story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078840356', 'num_games_owned': 832, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1535060265}
review:
[h1] Spoiler free review, with a short and (little) longer version:[/h1]

Buy this game if:

‚úÖ you love a 90's graphic style
‚úÖ you're fascinated with post apocalyptic scenarios
‚úÖ if you're looking for a "short" and linear (yet awesome) adventure 

Don't buy this game if:

‚ùå you don't like enigmas based on item crafting or on codes

Verdict 9/10

Beautiful, deep and unforgettable game, with multiple endings.
Time required to finish the game: 4.5 hours 
Time required to complete it at 100%: 5 hours

[b] Detailed version [/b]

[u]Let's cut to the chase: why this game has received so many good reviews?[/u]

1- Complex, original and well explained story and lore, perfectly placed into the post apocalyptic scenery as the reason why [b]the world has gone to ruin is actually clearly explained[/b]

2- Excellent multiple endings, well rooted both from the main character's perspective and from the other characters' and villains, [b]which are quite original[/b]

3- remarkable voice acting

4- good map, item menu and quest tracker

Thanks for reading and for bearing up with me, leave a comment below if you have any questions or observations, have an amazing weekend!!
If you're enjoying this review format and content you will find more of them at my curator page, which i encourage you to join and follow at: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32344423/
developer_response: Thanks for the kind and well-presented review.  So glad you liked the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198111790660', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1535313561}
review:
(Dont let my hours fool you, I played through this game mostly offline)

Now, usually when I see concepts for great stories, I expect a bit of disappointment, where the devs will explain too much, or too little, and the story will fall into a "bad intrigue novel" kinda territory.
This game is a marvelous exception, and is intrigue done well, with the game's creative (and very ironic) view of humanity topping this desolate, interesting world.

So yet another Wadjet Eye point'n'click masterpiece? Definitely, and kudos to the main developers at Wormwood for the fun open-ended puzzles, at least half of them have multiple solutions, even the ones that seem entirely hopeless! And I can't go without crediting the amazing art, voice acting, and story that surrounds this world of sand and 'rustpunk' utopias, filled with lore and worldbuilding at almost every screen you visit and antique you pick up in an odd mix between Utopia and Dystopia. The story will struggle between the two, and whether this world is a potential Utopia, or a crumbling Dystopia, and your decisions can be based on if you think Humans were real in this game's lore, or not, or if you think Robots deserve something better than what was left for them, or not. This game gives you just enough story that you feel satisfied by the ending you choose, and just enough mystery that the game stays memorable long after your playthrough.

Of course, some of the puzzles are difficult, but none are illogical, and the pixel style Wadjet Eye loves to use can put off a few people, heck, the fact it's point and click can put off people even more, but this game is wholeheartedly worth it's positive reviews, and this game's dark charm can help keep this game memorable, also, developer commentary, free dev commentary, mmm gimme, get this game, experience it now.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind review! It's always nice to hear that someone has enjoyed the game so much!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031558270', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1558671358}
review: I want to like this game, but it's basically unplayable. The cursor is sticky and difficult to move. With a point and click game like this having the cursor not work is a death sentence. I've seen that there are some tutorials online that may be able to fix this issue but who has the time or inclination to go digging around in config files and drivers? And even then you have no idea if a tutorial will even work. Until the devs release a fix for this mouse pointer issue I can't recommend this game.
developer_response:
This is a totally fair complaint.  We do have some detailed suggestions as to how to address the issue, which arises from an incompatibility between the engine in which we made the game (Adventure Game Studios or AGS) and modern mouse drivers.  AGS has its roots in DOS software, and as time goes on, its compatibility has gone down.  The mouse problem is one example of this, but not the only one.  You're right that it's ridiculous to ask players to work around problems like this; I wish I didn't have to, and you've appropriately posted a negative review.

A new version of the engine seems to have fixed some of the compatibility problems, including the mouse.  But porting Primordia to it is not so easy; the new engine breaks the game in other ways, and we've been working to make sure that we've fixed those breakages.  It's slow going though, because it's largely a matter of testing every little thing in the game since the glitches from the new engine are unpredictable and idiosyncratic.  Again, this is not an excuse to, or relief for, a player who paid for a broken game.

The only reliefs I can offer are: (1) to give you personal tech support to help get the game running acceptably, if you're interested in giving it a go or (2) offering you a key to some other game that doesn't suffer from Primordia's flaws.  On the latter point, I've "tithed" Primordia's proceeds to back Kickstarter projects and support charity bundles, so I have a large number of keys I'll never use (I have no time any more) that are properly earmarked for players like you who supported Primordia and got shabby treatment in response.

If you'd like to take me up on either offer, just shoot me an email at mark at wormwoodstudios dot com.

Hope I can help, and thanks for trying the game, even if it was such a frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985471896', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 608, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1534621002}

author: {'steamid': '76561198303682348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1515286102}
review:
I always thought that point-and-click adventures were lacking in excitement, but when I played Primordia (NOT Technobabylon, as I accidentally typed earlier, but that's a good game too) I was completely surprised. This game has so much to it - every character has missable dialogue options, there are items that you have to track down that give you more pieces to the story, and there are many ways to solve the problems you are confronted with. The humanity-based religion that some of the robots adhere to is really interesting, especially since the robots are free-willed and free-thinking. I was enamored with this game's characters, setting, and overall atmosphere. The only annoying thing (which happens in pretty much every point-and-click) is the repetetive dialogue that Horatio says when you're trying options out that don't work. 

I 100% recommend this game to anyone who is interested in a cool sci-fi story about robot-like humans and the implications of that.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind review, although you mention "Technobabylon" when I think you mean "Primordia" (though TB is a great game too!).

As for Horatio's, "There's no time for that!" and "How would that even work!" ... yeah...  We did try to have lots of unique failures, but it turns out that it wasn't nearly enough. :/

author: {'steamid': '76561198046285693', 'num_games_owned': 158, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 837, 'last_played': 1577735165}

developer_response: Thanks for the kind review! Not sure if either will scratch your itch, but perhaps between the two of them they'll give some relief!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001079869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1677105061}
review:
I actually ended up liking this game but only with a walkthrough.

The puzzle design is incredibly frustrating which hurts it especially because there are so many "puzzles" in this, far more then in your average wadjete eye game, you are NOT restricted to a set of rooms when expected to solve them, there's barely any logical connection between items because they are so sci-fi, you can't cancel animations like in later wadjet eye games and the inventory is very fiddly tho it's very reliant on item management.

Everything else is still really good like you come to expect from wadjet eye games, but the puzzle design sadly is very frustrating.

If you can look past having to use a walkthrough in order to enjoy it, it's still well made but if you like me are not that enticed by the setting ontop of it, it's only recommendable if you're, like me, playing through their whole catalogue.

Really wouldn't recommend this to newcomers or if you haven't played any of the other ones.
developer_response:
Hi Woolsow:

So sorry that you found the puzzles frustrating.  While we think that challenging puzzles are an integral part of adventure games, the line between "challenging" and "frustrating" is a fuzzy one, and as inexperienced developers I'm sure we didn't always stay on the right side of it.  We did try to help with this by providing an in-game hint system (via Crispin, who will automatically provide contextual hints if you've been stuck for more than a few minutes, and who will provide hints when asked if you click on him), but it turns out that the lines between "vague comments," "helpful clues," and "puzzle spoilers" are *also* fuzzy, so some of Crispin's hints are probably not helpful enough, while some are probably too direct.

It's certainly not players' obligation to put up with, let alone *pay for* a developer's learning curve, however, and I hate to see someone put their time, energy, and attention into Primordia and come away unsatisfied. I've got a large number of keys from various projects I've backed in Kickstarter or charity bundles I've backed -- I try to "tithe" Primordia's proceeds to support other indie developers, so these keys really belong to Primordia's customers more than they do to me.  Since I don't have time to play them, anyway, I'd be happy to share one to a game (or a couple games) that you might find more rewarding than Primordia.  It won't make up for our shortfalls, but it might offset them.  If you're interested, just let me know.

Thanks for taking the time to play our game and to leave a review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041951673', 'num_games_owned': 623, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1534235720}
review:
As an avid point and click lover I have to say this game was fantastic

Contrary to its bleak and dark setting this game is full of life, every bit of dialogue is just so amazing backed up with even better voice acting. You will wind up falling in love with the main characters especially the quick witted and often sarcastic floating sidekick that quickly became one of my favorite video game characters of all time. The length was short and sweet, deffinitely something you could put a good amount of hours into for fun casual puzzle solving gameplay. Overall I highly reccomend this game for anybody in love with the genre as much as I am or looking for a story to dig ur hands into

author: {'steamid': '76561198002584334', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1533749692}
review:
Primordia d√©peint un lointain futur de r√™ves bris√©s et de terres d√©vast√©es o√π diverses g√©n√©rations de machines tentent de subsister. L‚Äô√©nergie et les pi√®ces d√©tach√©es se font rares, et ce n‚Äôest donc pas une surprise si le d√©but de l‚Äôaventure s‚Äôamorce sur un vol de noyau d‚Äô√©nergie.
Le duo form√© par Horatio et Crispin, le sidekick conscient de son r√¥le, fonctionne √† merveille et l‚Äô√©criture comme le doublage accompagne parfaitement ces deux comparses qui vont devoir quitter leur √©pave et se rendre dans la gueule du loup pour r√©cup√©rer ce dont ils ont besoin.

Les √©nigmes ne sont pas toutes √©videntes mais on progresse relativement bien dans ce petit jeu d‚Äôaventure, qui se termine typiquement en un peu moins d‚Äôune dizaine d‚Äôheures. Courte mais dense, l‚Äôaventure s‚Äôach√®ve en proposant plusieurs fins et sa qualit√© d‚Äô√©criture est excellente, et aborde de nombreux sujets philosophiques et moraux que l‚Äôon pourrait trouver dans une soci√©t√© de machines qui chercheraient une raison √† leur existence, la nature de leur cr√©ateur, ou tout simplement, des th√®mes que l‚Äôon retrouverait dans une soci√©t√© post-apocalyptique, comme la question de la r√©partition des ressources et du bien commun.

Que dire de la direction artistique, si ce n‚Äôest qu‚Äôelle d√©peint parfaitement ce d√©sert radioactif, crasseux et mort arpent√© par une poign√©e de vagabonds rouill√©s et d√©glingu√©s, au gr√© d‚Äôune trame sonore qui sait √™tre m√©lancolique, pesante ou pleine d‚Äôespoir.

A quand une suite¬†?
developer_response:
Merci beaucoup pour la gentille critique.

Je ne pense pas que nous allons jamais faire une suite. Nous avons une petite histoire appel√©e "Fallen". Vous pourriez en profiter: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html Malheureusement, nous n'avons pas r√©ussi √† le faire traduire en fran√ßais.

Nous esp√©rons faire encore plus de jeux d‚Äôaventure avant de passer au travers d‚Äôun style visuel et d‚Äôune densit√© th√©matique similaires. Mais nous sommes tous des amateurs, donc √ßa nous prend pour toujours!

(Excuse Google Translate ...)

author: {'steamid': '76561198050109100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 867, 'last_played': 1455453056}

author: {'steamid': '76561198083805250', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1560109839}
review:
O deserto pode ser solit√°rio. Ainda mais quando se √© um androide desmemoriado.

Esse √© o ponto de partida de Primordia, point-and-click que remete artisticamente aos grandes cl√°ssicos dos anos 90. Nele acompanhamos Horatio Nullbuilt 5, que junto a sua cria Crispin Horatiobuilt vive nos destro√ßos da nave Unnic. Ap√≥s ter sua fonte prim√°ria de energia subitamente roubada por um grande rob√¥ fortemente armado, a dupla precisa primeiramente garantir a sobreviv√™ncia imediata para buscar energia em Metropol, cidade a qual Horatio odeia, apesar de n√£o lembrar o porqu√™. As repostas surgem ao longo do jogo e seus m√∫ltiplos finais. 

Apesar do estilo pixelado abordado ser prejudicado pela alta resolu√ß√£o alcan√ßada no dia de hoje, h√° de se saborear o valor nost√°lgico da arte. Os personagens, apesar de incongru√™ncias entre gameplay e cutscenes, t√™m designs diferenciados entre si e mostram suas personalidades √† primeira vista, como a imagem de peregrino rob√≥tico de Horatio ou o visual cyberaristocrata de Oswald. Os pontos de destaque clic√°veis s√£o facilmente vis√≠veis, evitando o pixel-hunting de que v√°rios jogos do estilo sofrem, embora alguns pontos s√£o destacados demais, se destacando no cen√°rio e, somado ao fato de Crispin prover dicas sobre a resolu√ß√£o dos puzzles quando consultado, torna o jogo relativamente f√°cil quando comparado √†s obras da Sierra ou LucasArts. Uma qualidade do jogo raramente vista no g√™nero s√£o as m√∫ltiplas solu√ß√µes das barreiras encontradas pelos personagens. Uma fetch quest pode ser evitada respondendo um teste de l√≥gica, por exemplo.

Trazendo quest√µes filos√≥ficas de forma sutil, como o surgimento de religi√µes, o papel da austeridade e da leni√™ncia na imposi√ß√£o de leis e a corrup√ß√£o oriunda do poder, o jogo traz muito conte√∫do para se refletir ap√≥s o fim do jogo, o que √© a cereja do bolo de um jogo recomendado para quem gosta do g√™nero.
developer_response:
Que revis√£o ador√°vel - e como agrad√°vel ter um jogador que *n√£o* pensasse que havia ca√ßa de pixel em Primordia! Obrigado por tomar o tempo para dizer coisas legais sobre o jogo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280946765', 'num_games_owned': 421, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1602866306}
review:
This game is amazing.

When I bought it, I really didn't expect anything from it, but from the very start it caught me with its narrative and... and everything it has.
The story is deep and after seeing different endings and some parts of game you feel that you will never forget this. 

I press F for you, guys, who made it. It's beautiful.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words, for taking a taking time to leave a review, and for the "press F" joke, even though it resulted in my laughing scalding coffee up my nose.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073600298', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 162, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 497, 'last_played': 1532893998}
review:
[b] Pros: [/b]
- Solid voice acting
- Really interesting storyline
- Likeable characters
- Logical puzzles (if a bit difficult)
- Sense of humour, with several hidden easter eggs to find

[b] Neutral [/b]
- Early 2000's/late 90's graphics gives it that retro look, not for everyone
- 7 Endings
- Around 7-9 hours long
- Trading Cards
- Achievements

[b] Cons: [/b]
-None

[b] Notes: [/b]
- Remember to examine everything and constantly check your inventory to see how you can interact with the world
- Crisper (heh) will give you hints when talked to

Personal Rating: 4.5/5
developer_response: So glad you liked it! Thanks for taking the time to write a review!

author: {'steamid': '76561198237824350', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1532815879}
review: Loved it. Amazing story, puzzles and ambientation in general. The only thing I would improve is the resolution, but other that than, the game is excellent.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words and for taking the time to leave a review! Our next adventure is higher resolution (though still low compared to contemporary graphics), so hopefully we can improve on that while keeping the rest up to snuff.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067863244', 'num_games_owned': 314, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1698241506}
review: I've played through it blind, then with a walkthrough. Both times it's left me wanting to explore the world beyond what's shown in game. Easily recommended.
developer_response:
I'm so glad you liked it, and thankful that you took the time to leave such a nice review.

I'm not sure it will scratch the itch, but we do have some (limited) additional stuff related to the game's world on Primordia-Game.com: a few pages of Crispin's diary, a poem by Primer, and a spin-off illustrated story/animated audiobook set at some indeterminate time after the game's events.  (No characters from the game appear in it.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198216906548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 1444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 950, 'last_played': 1601814597}
review: I absolutely loved this game. A very unique and emotional story. Great ambience and voice acting. Too bad they are not makeing a sequel, would have liked that. But, one can only hope :)
developer_response: Thanks so much -- I'm very glad you enjoyed it. You probably already know, but we did do a sort-off sequel story, "Fallen"; it's not a game, of course, and it's not a proper sequel, but you might enjoy it: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

author: {'steamid': '76561198063536822', 'num_games_owned': 243, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1503233208}
review: There's this really particular kind of setting I love where massive, mythical, irreplaceable entities are integrated into the functioning of a civilization. Primordia has one of those and it's fascinating to explore!
developer_response: So glad you liked it! Thanks for the kind words.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116793599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1532450259}
review:
First point and click I've ever played through and I'm really happy with the game. 

Lovely post-apocalyptic visuals and entertaining characters/dialogue/voice acting throughout. It was rather challenging at points, and on some occasions, I valued my time over struggling to stumble across the solutions, so I looked up answers on a guide. Twice toward the end, the game crashed due to "internal errors". One of the errors I was able to resolve by looking up a fix (switched memory to 50mb in winsetup.exe >> Advanced settings), the other one at the very end that I didn't bother to fix as there were alternate ways to go about it.

9/10
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the kind words! I hope this is the start of a long journey through the point-and-click genre, which has so many excellent games (most of which should not require you to fiddle with memory settings!).

Your user name also made me smile because years ago I played an innovative text adventure called Blue Lacuna (http://blue-lacuna.textories.com/).  Funny to see the words paired again here!

Thanks again for the review and for giving Primordia a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021287868', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1532450996}
review:
Slow paced but entertaining the puzzles were really good too.
I liked the visual style and atmosphere of the game.
It somehow gave a feeling of bit western-ish story feel, and (my) ending fitted to that theme perfectly.

Note the games starts to crash after reaching Metropol a lot, it is easily fixable with the instructions listed by Sherlock here:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/227000/discussions/0/846940247688329190/
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the kind words, and for your perseverance in the face of repeated crashes. Hopefully we'll manage to squash that bug some day, though unfortunately it's an engine bug (as opposed to one unique to our game), so it's tricky.

I'm really happy that you enjoyed the puzzles -- not every does, but I'm glad they clicked for you!

Thanks again!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999111995', 'num_games_owned': 631, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1670652564}
review:
After completing the game and enjoying it so much, I felt like I had to leave a review.

Firstly I just want to say that I did not expect much from Primordia since I never play Point & Click games. However, I was pleasantly surprised by this game. I picked it up during the Steam Summer Sale and gave it a chance. This game was enthralling in every aspect. 

I love games that are set in a post-apocalyptic world which is what intrigued me initially. The story is one that I personally have never known to be done before. A world where humans are extinct and all that remains are robots. I LOVE IT! I also found the graphics to be charming and brown (or rusted red).

Now the part I was not prepared for was the actual gameplay. Since I was not familiar with Point & Click games, I did not know how smart this game was going to be and what it would require me to learn. So I have to admit that I got stuck almost immediately and I shamefully looked up a walkthrough guide. But if I would not have done that I would not have known the things I needed to closely look at and pay attention to. I did not use the walkthrough the entire game because I didn't want to ruin all the fun so it was just at the beginning of the story. Eventually I started writing things down with pen and paper. Which wasn't necessarily required since anything important is recorded with the in game data pouch item. But I found it more fun when I started writing down clues and decrypting them.

Overall I had a blast playing Primordia. I recommend it to anyone looking for something new(If you're like me and never really played a point & click game) that is a challenge, while also being entertained by characters in a story-driven game. 

Thank you! to Wormwood Studios & Wadjet Eye Games for this enjoyable experience. Now I must move on and look for my next adventure.
developer_response: Every part of this review made me smile, but most of all the last sentence. I am a little jealous of all the great adventures you‚Äôll be able to experience for the first time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198095811485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1531544760}
review: Wonderful little game. There are essentially only two locations that, while small, are very rich. The acting is great, the writing is great, the artwork is beautiful and the puzzles are both fun and genuinely challenging. And most importantly, even though the puzzles can be challenging, they are all very plausible. Never once did I feel that a solution was unreasonable. Even the puzzles that gave me trouble, once I completed them I thought, "Of course that was the solution. I'm just an idiot". As far as point and clicks go, this is one of the best I've played.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind review! Particularly glad you liked the puzzles, which are a tricky thing to get right. I know some players find them too tough and some too easy, but I‚Äôm glad we hit Goldilocks point for you. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198058774598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 228, 'last_played': 1530906432}
review:
* I got this for $5 on sale * 

For $5, and with the multiple endings you can get, I'd say the game is worth it. The puzzles are pretty challenging and the story is well done. But I would have a hard time justifying the $10 pricetag with about 3-4 hours of gameplay. You probably would spend more on it if you didn't look up some puzzle answers like I did, but I still think it's a bit short for a game of that length. 

If you're cool with that length of a game for that price, I'd say you'll enjoy this game. It has interesting characters, good voice acting, and the story is unique and interesting. I enjoyed it a lot.
developer_response: Thanks for the nice review! I‚Äôm impressed by how quickly you beat the game. I hate for people to come away feeling like they may have gotten less than their money‚Äôs worth, and while I know you said you got it on sale, perhaps I could offer you a key to another game as a dessert? I have a bunch from using Primordia proceeds to back Kickstarter projects and charity bundles, and I never have time to play them!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041969368', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1530902848}
review:
It is great. SO DEEP NARRATIVE.
The sound, the story, the music, the freedom to think things through yourself.... about urbani, civica and other cities...
DAMN thats good, the game is great, and i dearly wish that there will be a continue to this story, as civics or urbani to see how the war set off,and how humans were.

10/10. To specify, at first i played cracked version of this game, but after seeing how good is it,and how gratefull the developers are, my heart was cracked too,and i bough this game and multiple copies to my friends.
 Too pity it wasnt spreaded much among the gaming community, they are all chasing for AAA games these days. Sad... it is one of my most beloved games now.
_____________________________
[Update] -  may 2019. still my most favorite game, seen it on sale, hope more people will see it
--------------------------------------------------
[Update] -  september 2020. Still my most favorite game, i put effort to more people seeing that, and feeling what i felt
developer_response: What an extraordinary act to buy the game and review it. I‚Äôm so glad you enjoyed the game. Your kind words are certainly worth more than the royalties, and I‚Äôm also pleased to know that my live-and-let-live view on cracks has been vindicated. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993037718', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1530396956}
review:
The writing in Wadjet Eye-published games continually impresses me. This is my second game of theirs to play, and I am now actively seeking out their back catalog to complete. If you enjoy adventure games, but find yourself frustrated with overly simplified stories, then I suggest checking Wadjet Eye out as a publisher and developer.

Primordia is an intimate game despite it being about a vast stretch of wasteland and giant city-state, and its writing manages to be accessible and adult-themed without being sensationalist. Writing for most games seems to be driven by an algorithm something along the lines of: children's games have elements A, B, C, so, logically, our adult-oriented stories must contain the exact opposite. This can produce unnecessarily sordid content that actually intereferes with the story-telling. Thankfully, the writing here is much more nuanced. Some uncomfortable things occur. I felt shock, dismay, and despair, but it all served a purpose -- nothing was in there just to induce those feelings. By the end, I was both elated and saddened and I had a great time getting there. Two thumbs up.

EDIT: For factual accuracy and grammar.
developer_response:
Thanks!  Most of WEG's catalogue was developed by third-party developers, and each developer had a different writer.

- Primordia was made by Wormwood Studios, and the writer was Mark Yohalem.
- Resonance by xii Games, writer Vincent Wesselmann.
- Gemini Rue by Joshua Nuernberger, solo developer.
- Technobabylon by Technocrat Games, writer James Dearden.
- A Golden Wake and Shardlight by Grundislav Games, writer Francisco Gonzalez.
- Puzzlebots by Ivy Games, writer Erin Robinson.
- Da New Guys by ICEBOX Studios, don't know the writer.

The in-house WEG games are the Blackwell series and The Shivah, with Dave Gilbert as the writer.

But your positive reaction definitely is a credit to WEG as a publisher!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970650133', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1530512257}
review:
While not as emotionally moving overall as other adventure titles I've played, Primordia pairs extremely effective ambiance and memorable characters with good voiceover work to craft neat little game that kept me entertained to the point where I actually completed two playthroughs in one day.

Although it was styistically very strong, it suffered from some of the minor annoyances that games of this genre tend to have; the puzzles are often more illogical than they are difficult. Only a minor grievance, though, and not really even that; I purchased the title expecting exactly that.

Anyways. Excellent choice if you like point-and-clicks, really nice worldbuilding, charmingly dorky computer humor, dystopias, and/or robots. Well done, Wormwood.
developer_response: Thanks for the kind words and thoughtful review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168115429', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1558879285}
review: Honestly the best point and click out there in my opinion. The story is really good, the voice acting is amazing and best of all; the atmosphere is perfect. It has everything that makes a point and click good. I will definitely play this masterpiece again several times.
developer_response: Notwithstanding the impostor syndrome that your very generous words provoke, it is wonderful to read them.  What a nice review to find after a long and tiring day of work!  I'm so glad you enjoyed the game, and grateful that you took the time to share your thoughts.
