author: {'steamid': '76561198038106467', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 1244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1701965898}
review:
Il punto forte √® certamente la storia, appassionante, con tanti piccoli segreti da scoprire a seconda della nostra curiosit√† e attenzione. Tante tematiche sono gi√† state trattate in latre opere fatascientifiche, come l'IA che arriva a divenire coscienza autonoma, la supermacchina a gestione di tutto, l'apocalisse nucleare. Mai per√≤ sono stati trattati dal punto di vista esclusivo della macchina, che qui risulta umanizzata. 
Ho notato con piacere anche la possibilit√† di varianti nella risoluzione degli enigmi, incluso quello finale che arriva ad averne almeno sette! Molte belle le ambientazioni apocalittiche del deserto e cyberpunk della city. Fenomenali le musiche. Anche il pixellato √® abbastanza buono. Gli  enigmi sono abbastanza difficili ma per fortuna c'√® un originale sistema di aiuti come l'Ipad di Horatio, i suggerimenti di Crispin e metodi alternativi di risoluzione. Devo dire che non mi dispiacerebbe afffatto un seguito, un preludio o anche uno spin-off ambientato nello stesso universo narrativo.
developer_response:
Grazie mille per le belle parole!

Abbiamo una piccola storia spin-off, "Fallen", che puoi trovare qui: http://primordia-game.com/fallen.html

Una volta, √® stata registrata una traduzione in italiano, ma sfortunatamente sembra che l'account Youtube che lo ha pubblicato non sia pi√π online. : /

author: {'steamid': '76561198063839366', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1500441566}
review:
Primordia is a story driven Point and Click staring Lead Horatio and his friend Crispin who are both robots in a post apocalyptic world where only robots exisit but humans are all but non-existent and no one knows what happened to the humans or even what humans look like. Another robot steals from Horatio and both Horatio and Crispin must find what was stolen from them and why they were robbed.

The best parts of this game are the story, characters and atmosphere the game sets up. You will want to talk to the characters as what they say about themselves and the world are interesting to listen to. There are different dialog options you can choose from like asking about who they are or what happened to a certain character. As you explore the world, much of what you find will give you hints about what happen to humans why the world is in the state its in currently.

The puzzles that you find in this game will make you stop and think as they are not easy to solve and will take time for you to figure out. Luckly Horatio's friend Crispin is helpful in giving hints that will help you solve puzzles and pick up some objects you can't reach. 

I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys point and click adventure games like Machinarium but has a great story in an interesting post apocalyptic world.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words! I'm glad you enjoyed the game and found Crispin a helpful help system. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198098837072', 'num_games_owned': 327, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1529850738}
review:
NOTE: This review used to be negative, I was unsure whether to vote positive or negative, because the game has its good sides and flaws. After meeting the developer, I was amazed by how a developer can be so respectful and humble. 

If you are into fast-paced games, this game is probably not suited for you. It is about a world where no humans seem to be around [spoiler]-because they went extinct-[/spoiler], and you're a scavenger robot who lives in a wasteland with a company of a robot you built. A robot comes and steals your powercore, and there the game begins.

So, I loved the conspept, it is quite clever. But the slow-pacedness of it just kills some hype in you. Art style seemed to be cool at first, but as I continued playing, it got a little old.

Still finished the game though. I would suggest the game if you're into post-apocalyptic world and tech concepts like me, but let me warn you, it is quite slow.
developer_response:
So sorry to hear that you didn't like the game.  Obviously, point-and-click adventures aren't for everyone, but that doesn't make it any less of a failure on our point that you came away unsatisfied.  As I often say, when we offer our game for sale, we're asking players to take a risk -- to put their money, time, and excitement into Primordia.  When the game disappoints, that means we didn't hold up our side of the bargain; it's really a breach of trust.

It looks like you're past the point where you can get a refund, but even when people *can* get a refund, I always like to offer to a key to some other game that a disappointed player might like more.  For a long time, I've backed Kickstarters and charity bundles use Primordia's proceeds, and since I don't have time to actually *play* these games, I think of them as pinch hitters when Primordia swings and misses.  Can I offer one to you?

Feel free to shoot me a message on Steam or email at mark at wormwoodstudios dot com.

Sorry again for the disappointment, particularly since it sounds like you came to the game optimistically.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254632411', 'num_games_owned': 3822, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1529588993}
review:
Actually, my intention was to go on playing another point-and-click game, 'Technobabylon'.
But as my save files for that game have vanished magically from my PC, I decided to try 'Primordia' instead.

And wow, I'm so glad this happened!

'Primordia' has a good story, remarkable characters and an awesome atmosphere.

If you like point-and-click / adventure games and aren't afraid of big, fat pixels - give it a try!

P.S.: 'Technobabylon' is also a great game, of course! :)
developer_response: Ha! For once, the finicky weirdness of AGS yielded something good for us. :) So glad you enjoyed the game, and hope you get back to finishing Technobabylon!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007284738', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1504466956}
review:
I recommend this game to everyone I know who is interested in games... and yet never wrote a review. 

The puzzles in this game are great, the scripting is brilliant and the setting is excellent. The worldbuilding is probably it's strongest asset, it feels really consistent, and doesn't spend too long throwing exposition at you. 

I completed this a while ago, and keep thinking about it... so yeah... get it!
developer_response: Thanks for the generous review and for spreading the word about Primordia. We‚Äôre lucky to have such fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198024311750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1524986621}
review:
This was a really interesting game. Primordia is an old-school style adventure set in a post-apocalyptic and post-human world where various factions of robots control cities and mirror certain aspects of society past. The gameplay is quite difficult and I did need a guide a couple of times. Despite being able to ask for Crispin's advice the game doesn't hold your hand or make things too obvious compared to many others. To solve the puzzles requires some thought but sometimes there are multiple ways to achieve an objective. Unfortunately I found the interface a bit clunky and it was a little difficult and slow to keep track of all the information you need. The voice acting is definitely a highlight and brings Horatio and Crispin to life along with the other characters. Even those which are essentially voices of computers are really well done. 

Where Primordia succeeds the most would have to be the story, which is deep, intelligent and humourous. Although it is a little predictable overall regarding AI/machines, the game discusses topics such as religion, creation, justice and politics through the lens of its robotic characters. There are multiple endings depending on your actions and choices. Some are "happier" than others but I think my ending must have been one of the worst. Overall, Primordia is a very good game despite some of the frustrations regarding the B'Sodding interface.
developer_response:
Thanks so much for taking the time to review Primordia, and for your balanced assessment of it. I agree that the UI is a little clunky -- partly it's a resolution issue (at 320x200, any UI is going to be tricky), but partly we could've just done better. Hopefully next time we will!

Thanks again, and so glad you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029838187', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1528830074}
review:
I cannot recommend this game enough. To quickly sum up my views:
Great voice acting and dialogue, the writing is really good and never overexplains or pushes boring walls of text at you. The characters you meet are immediately likeable and helps shape the narrative.
The art and the setting is cool, I was immersed right from the start.
As for the puzzles they seemed surprisingly fair without being boring, there were mostly logical solutions. I only had problems once or twice.
Telling a narrative through the setting, the scenery and slowly encountering new characters made for a very interesting world, the plot also ties itself up really well. Unironically perfect, would rate 10/10.
developer_response: Thanks so much for the kind words! So glad you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198334794221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1530538013}

author: {'steamid': '76561198163977244', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1528336337}
review:
As with all the games produced by Wadjet Eye, this one has no lack of soul and scenario. It's a very detailed, stylish, and interesting game, with just the right amount of real worlld allusions; a nearly perfect post-apocalypse that leaves just enough hidden from the view. I was absolutely enamoured by its gloomy, rusty looks, and the fact that all the actions and quests were quite obvious (as in you never had to combine a toad and a chest to created some potion many adventure games used to do) is only a plus. It has good voice acting, and great sound overal.

It is clumsy at times. It has a few plot holes, some things don't make sense, metaphors are quite in-your-face, however, for a short adventure those aren't real sins. I am sure, was it a longer game with much larger budget, it would answer all the questions there is left, and dwell deeper into the lore, but with what we have, it is almost perfect.

I only whish it wouldn't be so short. Additional (for an adventure game) features implemented (log with important notes stored, or a map instead of the classical edge of the screen sliding) suggested a much longer playtime, more locations, and more content, but alas, it was very short. Be it as it may, I still very much recommend it - it won't leave any adventure lover unimpressed.
developer_response:
Thanks for the kind assessment!

It may not help with the game's limited scope, but we do have some other (free) material in the same setting available on our website, http://primordia-game.com/.  There's an illustrated short story / animated audiobook set after Primordia, a few entries from Crispin's journal, a poem by Primer, some artwork, etc.

My intention with with "ragged edges" of the world was that they would encourage the player to add his own material from his own imagination -- the way old maps became less detailed as one gets farther from the center, forcing the traveler to fill the blank spaces up with imagined adventures and dangers. It doesn't work for every player, of course; I think sometimes it comes across as a tease or a broken promise, which is why it's good to have some extra content on the website to offer by way of apology. :)

Anyway, thanks again for the kind words and for taking the time to share them. So glad you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067612501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1528073452}

developer_response: Thanks so much for the nice review! Glad you enjoyed the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198016913653', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1527893599}
review:
[h1]Without Creativity, Art is just technique.[/h1]

Probably my first real experience with a Point and Click adventure as an adult.

[list]
[*]The art style was great. Made it a little hard to find items though.
[*]Hard, like really hard. I needed a guide. Would have never finished if I didn't have guidance.
[*]A great story and theme.
[*]Was suprised that there was some crafting.
[/list]

I was pleasently suprised at this game. Was also suprised at how hard the puzzles were. I would have never guessed what some of the things you needed to do were.

You shoud play it.

[url=https://www.twitch.tv/collections/VG96Bs_iMxUh5A]Get a Sneak Peak by wathcing my Twitch play through.[/url]
developer_response:
Thanks so much for the kind review! I'm so glad that Primordia helped bring you back to point-and-click adventures. There have been a slew of very good ones in recent years, so hopefully this will be the first of many.

Thanks, too, for the Twitch stream, which I bet helped draw others to our little game. We're lucky to have evangelists like you! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198063495681', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 157, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1527345929}
review:
No soy ningun experto en aventuras graficas. Habiendo dicho esto, "Primordia" no es un gran juego. Es bastante corto, con una dificultad media, y que tiene una buena historia pero que de a momentos senti que se quedo a medio camino o que no estaba totalmente desarrollada.
Esto es algo que aparece en la jugabilidad, habiendo muchos "callejones sin salida": items que no usas mas que para sacar logros, npcs que parecen tener una historia pero que en realidad no, informacion presente que te expande el universo pero que no se desarrolla en ningun momento ni se transmite a jugabilidad.
No es un "mal" juego, pero tampoco lo senti como uno que valga la pena recomendar.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972499798', 'num_games_owned': 502, 'num_reviews': 219, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1526531286}
review: I didn't finsih this game but I'd still recomend it, voice acting is fantastic, the world buildling is great.  The puzzles are mind-numbing though, I'd rather they just turned this into a walking simulator so I don't have to try combining every item in my inventory to advance, or using an inventory item on every single area the screen of every location I've been to to find the way forward.  You'll probably get frustrated like me and play through it with a guide next to you.  But, everything else in the game makes up for this.
developer_response:
So sorry you found the puzzles so frustrating. It's very kind of you that despite that, and despite not finishing the game, you still left a positive review.

I hate when players come away from Primordia unsatisfied. I have a ton of keys from games I backed in Kickstarter or from charity bundles (I try to "tithe" Primordia's sales to support other developers), but no time to play them. Would you be interested in a key to a less puzzle-heavy title that you might enjoy more? If so, just drop me a message.

Thanks again, and, again, apologies!

review:

It's a short game, but doesn't feels short due to solid and charming story, character, and setting ^^
The game is fully voiced, sometimes if the player idle, the party will have a little chat.
I really like the character naming, lke Crispin, Horatio's partner have full name Crispin Horatiobuilt version 1 because Horatio made Crispin ^^

The puzzle is nice, sometimes hard for me because machine/mechanical terminology.
I hope this game will become series ^^

author: {'steamid': '76561198046189760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1525329370}
review: Game keeps crashing. Had high hopes for it too. Oh well.
developer_response:
Darn it, how did I miss this review when it came in?  Were comments previously locked?

(1) It's definitely not your fault, at this point AGS (the engine it was made in) is like the crazy rat's-nest electrical wiring you see in Hanoi, and meanwhile Windows 10 computers are expecting well-grounded, up-to-code infrastructure.  (Err, that metaphor didn't really work...)  If anything, the miracle is that people manage to get Primordia running at all.

(2) Would be delighted if you tried the game again, but it's not your obligation to find a way to satisfy the game's demands, it's our obligation to satisfy the player's demands.  We let you down, not vice versa.

(3) I have a pile of keys to other Steam games, which likely will work much better than Primordia, that I've backed on Kickstarter or charity bundles using Primordia proceeds.  (A kind of "give back" tithing I've tried to do.)  Since I have no time to play games any more, they just sit around bit rotting away.  As a matter of basic justice, I offer them to players disappointed by Primordia.  Can I hook you up with one (or a couple, there really are too many at this point)?  Feel free to shoot me a message or an email at mark at wormwoodstudios dot com.

Thanks again for the patience you showed the game, and sorry again for letting you down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256519988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1523515909}
review:
[i]"What happened to the humans?"[/i]

I swear, that's me favourite line in the whole game.

This game has a way of grabbing your attention and not letting go until the very end.

   Yes, with a lot of point and click games, some parts WILL be frustrating and you'll undoubtedly think you clicked yourself into a hole that you can't escape from, but the beauty of Primordia is that is no matter how lost you think you are there is [b]still[/b] a way to continue. 

   The thing that got me most about this game was the world that Primordia is set in. I couldn't go anywhere without finding something interesting. There's a thing with humans that I'm not sure if I should give away, but it made me wonder what Horatio would do if he found a human on his travels.

This game is 100% worth it. Trust me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021087888', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1519610241}
review: I'm not exactly happy with Primordia. The main characters were fun, the graphics are very nice and a lot of it is good, but it had a lot of guide-dang-it moments for me and it left a certain sense of inadequacy I can't really put my finger on. It's not that I wouldn't recommend it, but I have a feeling it's not really for everyone. I've played worse point-and-clickers and it's above average for sure, but it's not timeless classic material.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999825207', 'num_games_owned': 785, 'num_reviews': 205, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1523864761}
review: I loved Primordia. It was a really interesting take on old-school "point and click" games with an original setting, great voice acting, and interesting premise. I wish it had been a bit longer and that a couple of the puzzles were a bit more clear, but as it stands I am definitely recommending this game regardless.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987448766', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1522871500}
review:
Absolutely loved this! A great cast of characters in a dystopic but very atmospheric world. Story is deep enough and keeps you engaged with the game. It's hard letting it go.

Even though it's fairly new this is an oldschool style adventure. So unfortunately some pixelhunting, would have like a highlight all feature but that's a bit picky. 

This is for sure one of the better adventure games out there so give it a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999673530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1356, 'last_played': 1585727515}
review:
100% worth it!

A true gem. Wonderful, surprising, rich story, well-developed characters, good voice-acting, cool post-apocalyptic vibe and so much polish and attention to detail. Puzzles range from easy to not so obvious, where you need to pay attention to the most subtle cues. Rich multiple endings (not like ME3 lol). Storytelling done well, can't stress enough how much story is packed within this one. 2nd playthrough was even more enjoyable, you start picking up on a lot more details and it really gets you thinking about some of our contemporary issues.

Good job, Wormwood, please make more!

author: {'steamid': '76561198125392208', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 138, 'playtime_forever': 424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 424, 'last_played': 1522599345}
review:

... A≈º do czasu, gdy naprawdƒô siƒô przy niej siƒÖdzie, bo wciƒÖga bez reszty. Wydaje mi siƒô, ≈ºe to przede wszystkim kwestia klimatu. Wszechobecny brud, piach i rdza, roboty z problemami egzystencjalnymi czy osoba g≈Ç√≥wnego bohatera przywodzƒÖ mi na my≈õl powie≈õƒá "Kamienna ƒáma", kt√≥rƒÖ w og√≥lno≈õci radzƒô omijaƒá szerokim ≈Çukiem, lecz kt√≥rej nie mo≈ºna odm√≥wiƒá specyficznej atmosfery. Mo≈ºe to zas≈Çuga protagonist√≥w, kt√≥rzy, dobrani niczym stereotypowe przeciwie≈Ñstwa z podrƒôcznika MBTI (INTx i ENFP), tworzƒÖ niezapomniany duet. Tutaj na pewno warto wspomnieƒá o ≈õwietnej grze aktorskiej - zawadiacki Crispin, przemawiajƒÖcy g≈Çosem Abe'a Goldfarba, ≈õwietnie wsp√≥≈Çgra z melancholijnym Horatiem, granym przez bo≈ºyszcze gier indie, Logana Cunninghama. Pod wzglƒôdem projektu gra jest prze≈õliczna w swym turpizmie, gorzej niestety z wykonaniem (animacje bohater√≥w  czy obiekt√≥w wyglƒÖdajƒÖ czasem po prostu ≈∫le), ale mo≈ºna to chyba zwaliƒá na datƒô wydania. Zagadki stojƒÖ na do≈õƒá ≈Çatwym poziomie - nawet w przypadku frustrujƒÖcego "zaciƒôcia siƒô" pomocƒÖ s≈Çu≈ºy Crispin, kt√≥ry podpowiada to i owo. author: {'steamid': '76561198202462030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1470340320}
review: This game left me wishing for more and I hold it dear to my heart

author: {'steamid': '76561198126076637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1570931305}
review:
You don't find games like this very often. Primordia sends you to another world, one bursting with deep themes and haunting art. The characters draw you into their individual stories, each one portrayed subtly enough to be believable. The puzzles fit perfectly into the world and I enjoyed solving them. They're the kind of puzzles that you want to figure out on your own, because you know they make sense and you don't want to break immersion. I recommend turning off the auto hints.

If I had any gripe with this game, it would have to be the voice acting. But you can turn that off as well in favor of text only if it's not to your taste. 

This game knows how and where to leave a trail of hints building up to a powerful theme. It's masterful storytelling in a world that feels like a real place with characters that feel like they have souls. What more could you ask for?

author: {'steamid': '76561198038965576', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1527301741}
review:
The best P&C game I've played yet, [i]Primordia[/i] thrilled me with excellent world design, an engaging plot, memorable characters, and fun puzzles. At such a low price, I can't imagine why you wouldn't pick this up. If you're still on the fence, allow this review to push you to (hopefully) the buy-it-now side.

[h1]PLOT (8/10)[/h1]
You are Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot hermit living in the wasteland with his floating lamp sidekick Crispin. Life is quiet, until a large robot breaks into your house and steals your power core. Energy is a precious resource, so you aim to get that core back before you black out.

The story unfolds into a grand adventure with many memorable characters, good pacing (though slow to start), clever writing, and some strong philosophy. The only drawback I would say is how short it was, though equally sweet. I would estimate it took me around 10 hours to complete. The review says less hours because I play a lot in Steam offline mode.

Finished [i]Primordia[/i] and want more story? Check out [i]Fallen[/i], a spin-off extension of the story post-game!

[h1]GRAPHICS (10/10)[/h1]
Goodness gracious, the art is masterful. Every scene had my eyes glued to it like candy, and most areas of the game were a picture I would use as my computer desktop. The environments are so beautifully detailed, you just can't help but admire the effort it must've taken. Mind you, the setting takes place far beyond apocalypse and the world is in a state of decay and ruin, so expect mostly Earth tones. Great for a colorblind guy like me.

[h1]SOUNDTRACK (6/10)[/h1]
Haunting melodies that match the melancholy atmosphere of the game very well. They're not distracting in any way, however I was paying more attention to puzzles or dialogue throughout the game.

[h1]PUZZLES (8/10)[/h1]
As you'd expect with a P&C game, there are a lot of them. These generally revolve around logical reasoning, or memory of past locations and dialogue. The puzzles were great fun, and while a couple had me scratching my head, they all were reasonable enough that I didn't get frustrated. My favorite puzzle of the game was getting [spoiler]Memorious's code![/spoiler]

[h1]VERDICT (9/10)[/h1]
I haven't played a P&C game in a while, so I'm glad [i]Primordia[/i] was the first to welcome me back to this genre! A big thanks to the devs who made such a great adventure!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971398029', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1518706413}
review:
Primordia harkens back to classic 90s point-and-click adventure titles, with a well-written story, full of unique art and world building, hampered only by a few weird rendering issues and a handful of obtuse puzzle designs.

Definitely worth checking out.

Overall: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198081901619', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1518658284}
review:
This is a puzzle/point and click game with a dystopian post-apocalyptic setting. So if you're a fan of those elements I'd definitely recommend this game. It uses steampunk themes and rustic enviroments really well. The story was well paced and really immersive, the music and voice acting added to the charm too. The characters are interesting and truly feel like they belong in the game world.

As for the cons, there is a bug that skipped over entire dialog sequences at times, only fixed by reloading a save or re-opening the game in my experience. Some key items are hard to miss as they blend into the background because of the low resolution or the overall general artwork blending in at times. But other than that the experience was great and definitely worth a shot for people who like atmospheric story games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999938574', 'num_games_owned': 977, 'num_reviews': 590, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1518133440}
review:
TL;DR: The story really had me hooked, but Primordia's gameplay is far from today's standards. I am torn between whether recommend it for the story alone or don't recommend for the gameplay. I guess the latter is more important for a videogame.

Primordia has a great story and cool post-apocalyptic setting, but gameplay wise it's just like a point and click adventure from the 95'. Pixel graphics, pixel hunting (mostly due to the low resolution and everything blending into one brown mess), some puzzles have nothing to do with logic and even when you know a solution you think "wtf?". Furthermore, the main hero is followed by a really obnoxious sidekick (he calls himself that) who tries to be witty, but instead produces boring monologues written by a 10 year old.

Moreover, the game also has a bug when all dialogues are instantly skipped without a single button press.

I have no idea why it has so many positive reviews: the only good thing about this game is story with multiple endings. And even then, you get to choose the ending in the very last scene: your actions during the game have zero impact on how it ends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171569614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1518262488}
review: Absolutely fantastic. Great puzzles with multiple ways to solve them, awesome backstories and a whole robot universe that feels like it's living and breathing on its own. 11 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008091679', 'num_games_owned': 465, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 674, 'last_played': 1518079004}
review:
A puzzle adventure where the only enemy is your own problem-solving ability. If you're not up to puzzles, guides work just fine without ruining the narrative aspect, which is truly the gem of the game. (If you avoid spoilers of course.)

The atmosphere is excellent, being a post-apocalyptic setting that does not feel as used and abused as the label. The reds and browns feel fresh despite their lifelessness, the barren, blasted landscape seems alien rather than cliche, and the ruins impart a sense of history, the sensation of a world frozen in its last moment as the sands and rust slowly consume it. 

The inverted parallels with our own society I found interesting. The way revelations wove disparate elements together was also great. The story was touching, with the opportunity of a best ending but also *choices!* and *consequences!* that allow one to explore other paths. It won't completely change everything, but enough to not feel arbitrary. 

I did not feel it was too short. The pacing was right, it was a complete story, and everything was grounded in the overall narrative. If absolute length is a concern consider it a novella, short yet satisfying. 

There is a short story, "Fallen" on their website, that follows but is otherwise unrelated to events in the game, that adds to the world and I would recommend as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069860606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1517426720}
review: If you like point and clicks, this ones worth it. The storyline is extremely well done (there are mutliple different endings depending on how you go about solving things) and to top it off, all of the voice acting constantly keeps your attention with what I felt was great dialogue. Give it a chance, on sale or not, you won't be dissapointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077226873', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 603, 'last_played': 1515173400}
review:
*This game was gifted to me*

What a gem of a game. 

I have a soft spot in my heart for dystopian/post-apocalyptic/cyberpunk/steampunk settings and stories so this game quickly became a favorite of mine. Great writing with quirky humor, fun characters, and a memorable world all made the experience thought provoking and enjoyable.

I appreciate that the puzzles, while challenging at times, weren't overly difficult so they didn't bring the game to a screeching halt or distract from the story. 

There are a few choices to be made in the game as well as a variety of endings depending on aforementioned choices so this game does have replay value. Not that I needed another excuse to complete various playthroughs, but it was interesting to see the various endings and where certain characters could end up. 

Crispin is too awesome to be my sidekick, but hey, I'm not complaining. 

That's all folks. Another great point and click adventure game well worth your time.

review:
Very, very short.

Clumsy metaphors for belief vs. nonbelief as well as capitalism vs. communism. 

Some of the "puzzles" (aka actions-in-order) were pretty obtuse. 

Not nearly as satisfying as some of the other games from Wadjet Eye, so dissappointing in that way. (Technobabylon, Gemini Rue even with its clumsy philosophy come to mind.)

Overall if you get it for like a buck, knock yourself out. Otherwise it's not worth the price of admission.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051978405', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1676112277}
review:
I have never played Point&Click games before but decided to buy this one purely based on its look. And I wasn't wrong in thinking that I'll like it.

The story is amazing. Note that I'm a fan of post-apocalyptic stories. Voice acting is just a good.

I enjoyed the gameplay so I will consider similar games in the future.

However I think I played it wrong because the ending was not what I expected. I assume it has so many branches based on what I did. Will play it again and try different path.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012998958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1547852284}
review:
Enjoyed this PnC game very much.
Characters are great, well thought out and executed. Crispin is an outright hoot.
Game play is smooth and keeps you wondering where you're going next.
Map and data pad make it easy to move around and use your items.
This game hard in places, insanely hard in a few spots but overall the difficulty is just right.
Would love to see another episode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148855849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1516358216}
review:
First part is for people considering to buy the game. Second part is my actual review on the game. They're separated by lines, so use that to skip ahead if you just want to know more about the game itself. Forwarning: I'm not an avid point and click adventure player so I can't compare this to other games in the same genre - If that's what you're looking for my review probably won't be helpful to you.



If you're not a fan of point and click adventures, and stories aren't drawing factors for you for whether a not a game is worth playing (despite gameplay that may or may not suit your tastes) then this game isn't blowing anything out of the waters with its gameplay enough for me to consider you buying it.

HOWEVER, if your into stories at all and the point and click formula is even slightly tolerable (or curious to you) this is a must buy.

Price wise unless if you get profoundly more stuck then I did at certain sections (about 10 hours for me to beat it and look over each ending - reloading is fast) and the time to cost ratio is worrying to you (or your more skeptical at the base price) wait for a sale. I bought this for $2 on sale and I'd STILL recommend the game at base price despite the time to cost ratio because of how good the story of the game is itself.

________________________________________________________________________________


I was hooked on the art style before I was hooked onto the description. You generally shouldn't judge a book by it's cover but I'm an absolute SUCKER for pixelated games of any nature.

I'm also a sucker for sentient robots and post apocalyptic scenarios that don't involve zombies.

This game was gorgeous enough just from the screen shots that despite it being a point and click I considered it. The deciding factor was the rating of the reviews and the fact that it was on sale so I said "even if I end up not liking it it's 2 bucks I can't be mad".

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Again coming from someone who doesn't like the genre, gameplay was better then I was expecting it to be. Beginning lead you through a lot more easily then I would have thought a point and click would have put into a "tutorial" section of the game and (at least for the early areas) I only had one real nag point and it was the one section of your ship home that I didn't realize you could walk out onto by walking through a wall that didn't seem at all (to me, anyway) to be a door.

And the point and click puzzles towards the end are generally me being frustrated from not seeing clues that are kinda slapped into your face once you realize what they were (which is it's own kind of annoying but I digress). Dialogue can't be repeated, and EVERY bit of dialogue needs to be listened to. You're given very few hints from your companion Crispin and in some sections they aren't even helpful. "Do this thing you already know you need to be doing" Yes, Crispin, but [i]how[/i]. 

I won't lie the amount of times I skimmed or had an NPCs comment fly over my head to be stuck for an hour wondering what I was doing wrong only made everything harder. There are brief but unreliable auto saves -- it's better if you save before talking to people so if you need to you can listen to their dialogue again.

If you like thinking there are a lot of challenging puzzles that put your mind to work though. Not too much, but just enough to make you feel smart for getting it. The only hard part is figuring out what pieces you need to solve things, if you're missing anything at all.

As a side note this game is not friendly to pick back up after a couple of days or a week. You might as well restart from the beginning - you don't really get a feel for what you were doing previously at all unless if you have a good memory.


[h1]Story Story Story (and art)[/h1]

Before I actually start this out, can I just point out that this game has voice acting? Yeah, [i]voice acting.[/i] I was taken by surprise but pleasantly so - it was great work and generally fit the game well.


When I say this game has the background story building of games like Horizon Zero Dawn I'm not kidding. You're given a world and a small objective to begin with, before being given an area that might as well have jumped out of the past. That past area at a superficial glance is nothing much but then it becomes SO much more after just a little delving. The art, meanwhile, draws your curiosity in and really settles you down into the games atmosphere and how the world really does seem to be crumbling into nothing but rust.

As you keep exploring the story goes from your first objective to a much more intense objective and then all the pieces of the old world slowly come together. Getting clues from ones left behind in the age of man, figuring out what exactly happened who your character actually was (or IS) was intense and the multiple different endings that can spur from it being a point and click adventure game where your mind is the only limiting factor in what ending you go for HONESTLY has given the genre some pointers in that regard for story alone. It wont be as easy for me to pass over them in the future, and it's definitely earned this game a spot among my favorite games (including but not limited to Aragami, Breath Of The Wild, Horizon Zero Dawn, Ori and the Blind Forest, etc).

The only thing I found extremely disappointing about this game was that there wasn't more. I'll definitely be chewing on this story for weeks to come.

________________________________________________________________________________

TLDR: Story's amazing enough that even if you're not a fan of the game genre I'd recommend it, even at base price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963841825', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 866, 'last_played': 1475388118}

author: {'steamid': '76561198067323324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1516269055}
review:
Holy cow.
I do enjoy a point and click adventure but I often find them lacking.
Then there's Primordia.
It's epic.
The atmosphere is coherent and consistant. Characters are really fleshed out and interact well with eachother. The side kick thing at first seemed like a bad idea but boy was I wrong. 
The art is amazing. The world has a hidden story to it. 
Even the villan that seemed at first "oh another power hungry boss..." in the end gave me valid arguments to doubt my actions. 
It might not seem like it but it's a gem.
I do hope they will expand the universe and make another one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099375398', 'num_games_owned': 150, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1573847847}
review:
This scratches an itch I didn't know I had. A seriously thought provoking story, built in a lovingly crafted world, with beautiful art, believable characters and great voice actors. The obvious negative regarding the low resolution became unnoticeable for me after a short amount of playtime and I found myself entirely immersed; as if my hands could reach out grab the plasma torch and retire Crispin at any moment. As for the sequel/prequel the Dev's have said is never going to happen...



I am waiting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126923200', 'num_games_owned': 532, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1515540434}
review: This was much better than I originally expected. At first, I was a bit disappointed how the graphics looked, the resolution made me squint a lot. But I got used to it really fast, once you begin exploring the world and the puzzles, even making mistakes was fun because it would eventually nudge Crispy to make a sarcastic remark. It makes me nostalgic for the old days and games like Discworld. I recommend you get this if you like good puzzles, characters you're gonna get attached to (believe me you will), post apocalyptic setting, and of course.. ROBOTS! Robots are awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198098476026', 'num_games_owned': 939, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1515526241}
review:
One of the best adventure games I played. This game got an amazing atmosphere, great pixel art graphics, nice soundtrack that fits the post-apocalyptic world very well, amazing voice acting, humorous dialogues, great story and nice puzzles that makes sense. Only problems I encounter are some glitches with the game. Some of the sprites from inventory gone missing. Steam overlay bothers with the game making it skip dialogues. Also sometimes the game crashes but it was due to configuration issues. 
9/10

If you encounter any issue with the game then configure it as shown below and it should fix the crash issues.

[olist]
[*]In Steam, right-click "Properties" on Primordia
[*]Go to the "Local Files" tab
[*]Select the "Browse Local Files" button
[*]A file explorer window will open. Double-click "winsetup.exe" (or just "winsetup")
[*]Look at the bottom of that window, there is an "Advanced >>" button: click on it
[*]In the new area that appeared, there is a "Maximum Size" drop-down that shows "20MB". Change the value to 100.
[*]"Save" (or "Save and run") and it should work :)
[/olist]

author: {'steamid': '76561198066811930', 'num_games_owned': 642, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1505069278}
review:
[quote]"Together, we can build a Primordia; every day a moment of creation".[/quote]

[h1]General Impressions[/h1]
There is a certain wistfulness that permeates an existence without affection. In [i]Primordia[/i], building a robot is the equivalent of birthing one. To oil cogs into a machine's first breath is a labor of love. However, just as much as human birth can blossom from a seed of spite, machines too can click and clank about as the result of nothing short of duty and necessity. 

Playing as Horatio Nullbuilt (built by [i]null[/i]), wistfulness is your paragon; humanity, your faith. 

With that premise, [i]Primordia[/i] may prove not be a game for everyone ‚Äì even if such thing did exist. On the other hand, its infinite amount of excellently delivered wisdom make the game quickly and universally take root within every heart brave enough to play it. 

In that sense, I believe there has never been a point and click game quite like [i]Primordia[/i]. Although it stands atop of a hill with the classics ‚Äì the [i]Monkey Island[/i] series, The [i]Broken Sword[/i] series, [i]The Longest Journey[/i], etc. ‚Äì it holds something that few of its older peers have: it has the vision, the eloquence and the language of modern day games. It takes the best if its genre and holds it close to its heart, while tossing away the majority of what so many people have always disliked about it ‚Äì like not knowing when or in what order to combine items or being stuck in convoluted puzzles ‚Äì and from that, it draws its strength and appeal. 

However, [i]Primordia[/i]'s strongest trait lies elsewhere: in its story. The universe it weaves is one that begs you to belong to it. Which is quite the accomplishment, considering how the vast majority of said universe is tarnished by decay and, upon a first glance, seems wholeheartedly uninviting and cold. 

And yet, as my last decision of the game dawned to an epic close, I didn't want to leave. That scrap of the Earth deemed as its most crude and barren shell felt like home, and Horatio Nullbuilt and Crispin Horatiobuilt felt like family.

There are, out there, creative births that make us wonder how far we can stretch the definition of 'art'. In [i]Primordia[/i], it is just as endless as a robot's love.

review:
A very beautiful game that i have thoroughly enjoyed playing, so much that i wanted to play it on my laptop aswell. but guess what, the save games from the pc don't work on the laptop, crash crash crash. yea i have read the forums, only solution was to start fumbling with shit i don't understand, so yeah couldn't make it work.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062954777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 580, 'last_played': 1515296687}
review:
I bought this game because of the good reviews.
I didn¬¥t expect much when I started the game, but the more I played, the more I came to appreciate it.
It was a very refreshing experience and definitely a gem that deserves more attention.

After playing through all the endings, I took some time to read the negative reviews.
Basically they seem to be bugs that happened years ago, or people frustrated over not finding an item on the ground.
IMO the riddle difficulty was spot on, and the story guides you well into areas where you would need to look a bit closer. 
But ... I also had to check a walkthrough, because I missed an item on the ground. The positive side is that if you get stuck then your sidekick(s) will give you useful info on where to look.

Anyway. It¬¥s an amazing game. There¬¥s no rason not to get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093032043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1562153892}
review:
Now [b]this[/b] was an experience. And a b'sodding good one at that. I don't have an all too extensive history with point-and-click games, but I felt that Primordia was unique (UNNIIC?).
 
The story of Primordia takes place in what seems like a distant future, where humanity is but a bleak and redundant memory in the most ancient of machines. Biological life has been eradicated and solely machines roam the surface of the dying planet. We, the player, follow Horatio Nullbuilt V.5 and his companion - Crispin Horatiobuilt V.1 - in a quest to retrieve the power core of their ship that has been stolen. The duo search the dunes in the first arc, but soon arrive at Metropol. The Last City. The City of Glass and Light. Though they soon discover that their expectations were wildy inaccurate...

In my opinion, the plot of Primordia is quite intriguing. Morality [spoiler] and the preservation of mankind and machines [/spoiler] is discussed [spoiler] in an excerpt from the files of Horus and conversations with MetroMind [/spoiler] and we encounter myriads of wacky characters all with their own personalities, motives and backgrounds. There are several endings, although most can be achieved by [spoiler] going back to a save from the last scene in the Tower [/spoiler].

Overall, the game covers the adventure of a machine suffering from partial amnesia (not a medical term) who is dragged into intrigues and conspirations and who is forced to realize his identity in a abysmal post-singularity world. Will you save your friends? Will you save Metropol from descending into chaos and ruin? Will you fulfill your [spoiler] ancient mission or your [/spoiler] dream? Is there even hope for the Last of the Four Cities?

Art: What can one say but simply [i]astounding[/i]?

Music/Soundtrack and SFX: Really quite atmospheric. Fully voice acted.

Story: Solid 

Gameplay: There isn't too much 'gameplay', but it runs smoothly. Minor graphic glitches and movement errors. 
I suggest that fullscreen mode should be added for increased immersion, but sadly, the game likely won't be getting any updates. 

Some issues I had included text being shown at a ridiculously rapid pace [spoiler] and my inability to steal Oswald's oil before Clarity started accompanying Horatio and Crispin [/spoiler].  

Primordia isn't all too replayable, but the first playthrough will be fascinating for the player. Remember: almost EVERYTHING interactable has a use, so when you obtain a new item always try to combine it with all other items in your inventory, and most objects and structures out in the map. (Always click everything with everything you have.) If you're stuck, try consulting (clicking on) Crispin. 

I genuinely love Primordia and of course recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040434465', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1645145743}
review:
Greetings Steamers! As an old graphic adventure's player and a experienced gamer in many genres i must say im impressed with every single part of this game since i buyed and completed it. 

The music ambient songs fit with every enviroment of the game and this last ones make the player get involved in the actions of the game. I liked the puzzles and map exploration of the game as well as Horatio and Crispin comments and jokes in the decissions and findings.

Also i've seen Crispin's comments and advices make the game easier, wich is not a bad thing for unexperienced graphic adventures players who want help, because you can choose not to ask Crispin for advice, so the game maintains its dificulty and makes you think.

The art is fantastic, a perfect example of decayed futurist world with an own and original style that i believe every graphic adventure fan and game art fan will love.

By the way I've read some negative comments about this game complaining about the ease or difficulty of the puzzles and also the "pixel hunter" expresion refering to the map exploration and its secrets and i can't less than ask myself: isn't that part of the game genre? why whould it have to be that easy? aren't the graphic adventures about thinking the different puzzles and ways to get the final satisfaction of completing the story? I understand the "i'm stuck" problem, i've lived it many times in this genre, but it's not an excuse to make developers responsible for "not making the game as easy as i want to". I think the game is perfectly complete and does not need facilities but mindful players who must apreciate the details and think more when doing the puzzles, wich are created to think and resolve them.

At last i must say the only thing i dont like about the game just to help devs: the Metropol city robots. The robots make a constant walk along the maps you can explore into the city, and i liked the way how diferent robots appear and leave when you change of map and in the different parts of the game, but the ones moving constantly into the maps just go nowhere turning at the end of the roads and coming back the same way. That gives you a kick in the city involve sense(if you know what i mean).

To end this reviwew I definitely recommend this game... no... this piece of digital art to every single person who's searching for an adventure with a great story, many ends depending on decissions and a impressive way to get involved on it.
Thanks to Primordia developers for this story, i wont lie, i want more and me like others in this community would like to see more games like this soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249048284', 'num_games_owned': 1528, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1511418618}
review: This game is a wonderful classic point-and-click adventure that anyone who is a fan of post-apocalyptic, dystopian tales will enjoy. The story is immersive, uplifting, sad, and at times philosophical, all at once. The characters are decently interesting and the dialogue is pretty witty, especially whenever Crispin's sarcasm starts up. The art is aeshetically pleasing and a good reminder that even games without great graphics can be good. I quite enjoyed the soundtrack, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124045758', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 724, 'last_played': 1472400229}
review:
All humans are gone, whats left are some robots, but what happen?
This underestimated post-apocalyptic game tells a very interesting story of Horatio, a stoic robot who values his solitude and independence. 

I really liked to play but caution it may tell you a story which open your mind and also contain profound material about  human being.

 - not for people with depressions
 - you may need a large vocabulary / english knowledge (no translation)
 - pay attention to your steps (alternate endings possible)

all in all, instructive, exciting and also fun :)

Enjoy

author: {'steamid': '76561198036544073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1514869572}
review:
Short but challenging. Where Primorida really shines is the storytelling, presenting an engaging setting and characters. Gameplay is maybe not as complex as the Sierra classics, bordering on more of a graphical novel where you mostly have to figure out which two items to combine. But it is beautifully rendered and voice acted; the sound track is best described as "haunting." 12 hours represents two and half play throughs for achievements.

As a game, I was underwhelmed; as an interactive novel, I was enthralled.

Note that the Memorious kiosk achievement is still either broken or just *really* tempermental, similar to the Peeping Tom achievement. Seemes like there's a trick to getting the "Metropol" page to load.

Spelling or grammatical errors in this review are the direct result of Magellan gin and wine.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010307201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1515962084}
review:
Charming game for sure.
I'm just not a fan of pixel hunting. I got stuck at some point - I knew exactly what I had to do but did not have the item to do so. 
Checked a walkthrough on youtube and turns out I had been missing an entire 'screen/scene'  because there is no way of telling that you can actually go over that direction unless hovering your mouse there.

I would like ro recommend this game, and i know it's dated, but it could really do with at least highlighting all the paths you can take.

call me sour.

-edit- see comments (may contain spoilers for the first 20 minutes of the game)

author: {'steamid': '76561198026362756', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 928, 'last_played': 1499286396}
review:
Man is dead, only machines remain.  Primordia is a wonderful adventure game developed by 
Wormwood Studios and published by WEG.  They have the perfect formula.  Great story, great characters, and puzzles that don't drive you to the point of insanity.  That being said, I love puzzle games, and for those of you that want to enjoy the story (and not burn your brain over puzzle solving) can find some wonderful guides to help get you over any obstacles you may encounter.  
What makes WEG games stand out is the little extras they throw in.  In this game, they practically have an entire bible written in.  I love games that have all of this extra information.  It adds that much more to the main storyline, even though it is not mandatory.  
In short... just get the game and play it.  It is not very long, but it is definitely worthy of the WEG name.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960739818', 'num_games_owned': 721, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 463, 'last_played': 1514409487}
review:
A really pleasent game, although it's to be expected from Wadget Eye. Aside from a technical hitch where the game started with a black screen, it played flawlessly.

Although short, the story was well written and really interesting. The puzzles for the most part wern't too odious (although I had to reach for a guide once or twice) and were generally fun and more to the point logical. Some of the puzzles were apparently optional but it doesn't feel like I missed anything and nothing felt like a "sidequest". In addition, your actions do have the odd consequeces and there are several endings available.

Initially I was put off by the whole 640x480 thing that AGS has going and the way it crappily scales up, but all too quickly I was gripped by the art style - that pixel art is glorious.

It would be interesting if further games in this setting are released.

review: Classic style game with classic graphics but excellent story and nice gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064392148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 231, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1620495976}
review:
Another gem that proves that a great story is what makes a great game and not some high quality graphics.

Through the quest of Horatio and his sidekick Crispin to recover their power core, discover a world where humanity destroyed itself and where sentient machines with very human-like behaviours seem to follow the same path than their original creator.

A self-reflection and metaphor of our own society in a sci-fi world that could very well be one of our possible futures.

A must play game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016770721', 'num_games_owned': 5546, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1514291384}
review:
Clever. Funny. Depressing.

Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054072408', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1514260383}
review:
Primordia is an adventure game in the vein of old school greats, with puzzles that are challenging enough though not annoyingly so. 
The art and music are gorgeous and, most importantly, it has very well written story that is both interesting and thought provoking.
Reminded me at times of games such as Beneath a Steel Sky without being so gritty.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992082934', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1514201572}
review: Beautifully designed game that reminds me and seemingly everyone else of Beneath a Steel Sky. This is one of the best adventures I've played in years. Excellent writing and art design. Apparently there's a range of possible endings too, which is a plus.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998739385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1399602287}
review: Absolutely the bomb.  This game is one I still love revisiting from time to time.  The world is rich, the characters are fascinating, the story is excellent, and the puzzles are clever without being frustrating.  I wish this game were more well-known, it's an absolute joy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017918223', 'num_games_owned': 583, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1514054005}
review:
The plot was very nice! A lot of twists and turns, a lot more than meets the eye!

The characters too, were excellent. A lot of character, even if they seemed simple and one-dimensional, they evolved depth throughout the game, and developed into a lot more nuanced characters. However keep in mind that the game is quite short, and as such the developlemt is limited to that time frame. I would have liked for a bit more personally, but the game works well with the time it has.

I, personally, stayed mainly for the characters. Your floating assistant is f*cking hilarious, and the protagonist and him play off each other so nicely, it's worth playing the game for those two alone. My favourite character has got to be Clarity though, I just kind of like her personality I guess.

The gameplay was frustrating for me though. I have never been a big point and click fan, and as such a lot of Point and Click elements frustrated me greatly. Some of the puzzles were very clever and rewarding, but a lot of them also basically couldn't be solved by any other way than by walkthrough or blind clicking. I could just be stupid, but that was my general experience. There were too many of these in my opinion.

The audio work is excellent! The music isn't phenomenal on it's own, but it blends in perfectly with the atmosphere and setting. The voice acting too is excellent, the game wouldn't be nearly as interesting if it was missing. The actors doing the voices really did a great job here.

TL;DR:
6/10 - Above average, but not worth the current price, pick up on sale. 

The game was good, but WAY too short for it's price tag, honestly seems like such a waste of such a great environment. Personally it did not leave enough of an impact in that timeframe to warrant such a playtime for such a price, but on sale it's defintely worth picking up!

author: {'steamid': '76561197978312779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 130, 'last_played': 1550596549}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089355754', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1707268880}
review:
Imaginemos un futuro donde el robot haya sucedido al hombre. Por no hacer muy largo el an√°lisis; esta aventura te mete de lleno en dicha distop√≠a y te anima a descubrir c√≥mo ha permanecido la imagen del ser humano/humanidad ante sus propias creaciones artificiales.

Ambientaci√≥n retro sublime, personajes carism√°ticos, buen doblaje y una gran cantidad de lore por descubrir. Adem√°s tiene un trato del humor-ciencia ficci√≥n muy sutil e ingenioso y muchos di√°logos te arrancaran una sonrisa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057422975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1513520955}
review:
Primordia is a great game with a strong atmosphere and characterization, and it explores themes of loss, friendship, and redemption.

You play as Horatio Nullbuilt, Version 5, and supporting you is Horatio's sidekick/son, Crispin. The premise is pretty standard, you are on a journey to reclaim what was taken from you, but the execution is where the game truly shines. Primordia's world is devoid of life, and yet a few machines persist in carrying out what functions were once prescribed to them. Primordia's world, however, is not devoid of feeling or emotion.

The dialog in Primordia is very strong. From Crispin's snarky remarks to Primer's street poetry, every single character in the game is charismatic, memorable, and interesting to interact with. For example, Clarity, a character you meet in the later half of the game, has some fairly amusing dialog. The writer for Primordia, Mark Yohalem, works in the legal field, and Clarity is a robot built with little to no error margin when it comes to matters of law and justice. She is rigid, uncompromising, and she lays the absolute legal beatdown on poor Horatio on matters of property ownership. It was also not surprising that Horatio had to resolve some unrelated ownership disputes later on, but I digress.

Primordia's main antagonist is another example of a well-written character; it truly believes that it is doing the right thing, and in a way, it is. In a world devoid of humanity, right and wrong are just words, and ideals are worth clinging on to. I have to commend the voice work in the game, too, as it is spot-on. Logan Canningham, of the Bastion fame, voices Horatio. Horatio is appropriately raspy, somber, the perfect tone for a religious leading man. Others are similarly well cast, such as Crispin's upbeat attitude that doesn't wane throughout the game, the Legionbuilt, and so on. There is more to mention about the characters in Primordia, but suffice to say, the game strikes gold when it comes to characterization. 

The story, which is fairly short, is satisfying: there are emotional moments, there are moments of idle banter that flesh-out the world and the machines ‚Äúliving‚Äù in it, and there is an inevitable conclusion that changes everything. There are several endings to Primordia, and I don't think any of them are weak or abrupt, and it was cool to see how certain plot elements were referenced or expanded on. I felt satisfied viewing each individual ending, and that's not something I can say about the majority of games that have multiple endings. My only real concern about the story is that it could have been a little longer, perhaps utilizing some of the cut content, but it's not a big deal. I was just sad that it was over.

The mechanics, on the other hand, I do have some issues with. The game has a really low screen resolution, and while the pixel-styled graphics lend well to the desolate world of Primordia, alt-tabbing or using the Steam overlay can be really jarring on modern systems. On several instances the game would auto-skip all dialog and sound after alt-tabbing or using the overlay; not game breaking, but a little annoying. Another problem, I feel, is that because of the game's screen resolution, item-hunting can be a pain. This really goes for the point-n-click genre in general, but finding stuff on screen can be a chore when you can't highlight everything you can interact with. That said, if you're a veteran of the genre, this shouldn't be much of a problem.

When it comes to gameplay, I never felt like Primordia was unfairly obtuse or poorly designed. Crispin, Horatio's sidekick, can provide some valuable information if you're stuck, though his advice can be fairly vague at times. I did scratch my head several times, completely oblivious to a puzzle's solution, but prevailed eventually. As with other games, trying everything usually resolves the problem in the end. Also, I feel it salient to mention that certain puzzles in Primordia can be failed and the game can proceed regardless. This doesn't have much of an impact other than modifying one ending sequence‚Äîthe only exception occurs early on in the game, and failing this puzzle locks you out of future content. Keeping several save-states as you're playing through is recommended.

Mark Yohalem originally recommended that I play through Primordia, and I am certainly glad that I did (after much delay though). The dialog, and some of the atmosphere, actually reminded me of Star Control II, probably one of my all-time favorite video games: a game that combines humor, melancholy, and strong characterization. While the gameplay elements may lack in some way or other, the overall experience is rewarding and worth the time. If you've been eying the game, give Primordia a try. I definitely recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030793549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1456928524}
review: Great atmosphere and world design, if you enjoy classic point and click games as well as unique sci fi then buy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198167271759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1691630713}
review:
When you reach the conclusion of this game, you'll be left wanting to find all of the many many alternative endings.  

You'll feel real tenderness for your fellow robots living in this world post-Man.  Existential questions are natural and logical, mythology and religion are woven into the storyline effortlessly.  

Sweeping lines and highly detailed animations make this game worth the price tag, simply as a feast for your eyes.  Great voice acting, challenging puzzles, and an effective atmospheric soundtrack will keep you engaged.  Humor is peppered into this unforgiving environment, making the impending heat death of the universe just a little more bearable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120497876', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1483582720}
review:
Un tr√®s beau point & click, vraiment agr√©able dans son style graphique, et l'univers qui prend forme dans les volutes des d√©cors est super int√©ressant. Les personnages sont attachants, on se sent vite complice dans l'amiti√© qui lie les deux principaux, et chaque pnj donne envie d'en savoir plus sur le monde qui est propos√©.

Les √©nigmes sont plut√¥t bien tourn√©es, certaines sont assez simples, tandis que d'autres demanderont un peu plus de temps de recherche, pour une vraie satisfaction une fois r√©solue : pas de choses "tir√©e par les cheveux" ici, que du logique, et les astuces fournies par le petit personnage secondaire sont l√† en cas de p√©pin pour vous remettre sur la bonne piste.

Les musiques plongent bien dans l'ambiance, et √ßa a vraiment √©t√© un plaisir de jouer quelques heures √† Primordia. Les fins alternatives selon vos choix sont aussi tr√®s int√©ressantes, je n'ai pas refait le jeu moi-m√™me mais je n'ai pas h√©sit√© √† regarder un ami le refaire pour d√©couvrir des choix diff√©rents, y compris dans la fa√ßon de r√©soudre certaines √©nigmes (ce dont je ne me doutais pas).

Le jeu vaut vraiment le coup, moi qui est souvent d√©√ßue par les point & click, celui-l√† m'a fait changer d'avis!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009586673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 685, 'last_played': 1513288981}
review: Excellent game

author: {'steamid': '76561198039380902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1483450869}
review: This is a beautiful game. I found myself completely engrossed in its post-apocalyptic world and soulful characters during my all too brief time with it. The art style is certainly giger-esque but the world itself is much more humourous and warm than this would suggest. The point and click gameplay underneath this is relatively standard for the genre, but for the most part I found the puzzles made absolute sense, and I never found myself in the common "how on earth did they expect me to figure that out" scenario point and click titles are so known for. The voice work and sound fits the world like a glove, and I found the story went to some incredibly interesting places. My only real complaint here is the length of the game; it's incredibly short, and I found myself wanting quite a bit more of it when I'd reached the end. Given the price, this doesn't effect my reccomendation too much and it may be worth some limited replays due to divergent endings, but bear in mind there isn't a huge amount of content here. Nonetheless, what is here is absolutely stellar, and one of the best point and click adventures I've played in a while. Recommended to anyone who counts themselves a fan of the genre and wants something with a little bit of heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047420079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1512818366}
review:
Primordia is a great classic point&click adventure with a remarkable story.

It's post-apocalyptic world populated by (rusting) robots is captivating throughout the whole relatively short timespan you spend in it.
The philosophical themes are neatly integrated without overextending the scope of a video game.
The art is phenomenal.

From a gameplay standpoint there are some QOL additions to the standard point&click mixture, e.g. a map with a fast travel feature. There are some potentially frustrating puzzles, as is to be expected. Keep a walkthrough handy, if you're not too proud for that.

On the whole, Primordia is worth its money for the story alone. Not often you find such a neat little story in a video game. If you have any interest in point&click games at all, you should check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006847683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1497356450}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996445360', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1514345683}
review:
Definitely a thumbs up if you like the old King's Quest / Space Quest without the negative 'King's Quest Logic.' (Pie the Yeti)  Great puzzles, snarky humor, and decent voice acting.  And 100% owl free!   

Alas, since I am more of a story person, I used a guide far more than I should have.  Starting bit by bit after trying to find the crystal and remembering to take the plug/crystal back out of the terminal after using it.  But afterwards, the solutions were both clever and logical.  My reactions were more 'Ohhh, I see! That makes sense" rather than, "Oh...Duh...Why didn't I think of that."  Also, on some of the more difficult puzzles, it looks like there are multiple ways to solve them, so if you do get stumped, you're not completely stuck and need to reach for the guide.  Lastly, just like the Quest Games, you‚Äôll need to click everything and take anything not nailed down.  Unless they tell you otherwise, in which case don‚Äôt worry about it, which is nice.    

I guess the only thing that differentiates it from the Quest games is the inability to die. Right from the start, you‚Äôre clearly a sturdy robot and not some janitor, so that makes sense why they aren‚Äôt included. Deaths can be hard to balance in adventure games to make them useful, interesting, or simply hilarious. As such, I can‚Äôt honestly say I miss them, as many of the deaths in other titles can range from tedious to downright infuriating.  I suppose it‚Äôs better to be stuck on a puzzle but able to move around than to be stuck at a save point dying over and over again due to bad pathfinding, narrow walkways, a simple mis-click, or not having a freaking pie.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973312067', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1011, 'last_played': 1562125525}
review:
TL, DR:
Pro: 
>Interesting characters
>excellent voice cast
>lovely vistas
>exploration of religion and religiousness without being sanctimonious
>multiple endings
>semi-sensible puzzle solutions

Con: 
>puzzles aren't given enough clues on whether you can solve them yet or not
>other than 3 endings that all involve your final choice, the rest of endings are harder to figure how to get there. 
>screen resolution is limited to two sizes only due to the limitations of the engine used.
>the adventure game studio engine may require older DirectX libraries than what will be installed with game


Primordia is a game about the earth after us, the stuff we leave behind: junk, devastation, and robots. The game readily explores the concept of religion in non-human sapients, which is fresh and unique in sci-fi settings where religions are regulary viewed with disdain and are associated with less advance societies. The humanist religion is based around man the builder, creator of wonders and robots. In this world humans are missing, where they went and how they went are mysteries; but our lovely robots have carried own in our absence. Our inventor protagonist, Horatio Nullbuilt, is trying to reclaim what was stolen from him in the opening scenes of the game. This puts him on path to solve his immediate problems and eventually his quest leads him to the city of Metropol where the secrets are slowing unraveling the city.

The game is not without it's humor from the banter between Crispin and Horatio, references to other famous robots, and Horatio's object commentary.  

If your stuck on a puzzle try using Crispin, on an area you can't reach. The game never tells you about this before you have to figure it out. 
  
If you like post-apocalyptic worlds without mankind, adventure games, and robots: this is probably up you alley.
