author: {'steamid': '76561198027375283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1061, 'last_played': 1491439781}
review: I really enjoyed the voice acting, music, art and story of this game. It takes me back to the days of Kings Quest 6, Space Quest IV, and Quest for Glory IV: Shadows of Darkness. The game puzzles are very easy to figure out and mostly make logical sense. I just wished the resolution could be improved to have HD graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022391714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1514414025}
review:
A steampunk dyspotia where you get to play as a machine, it is a nice take on the apocalypse which isn't focused on how human survived.
Definitely a great Indie game

author: {'steamid': '76561198201424228', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1482750176}
review:
Excellent point-and-click game. I played it about 3 or 4 times, also outside steam and all I can say is I'm kind of waiting for the sequel, or a different make, the lore and the whole story is magnificent!

Very well made, the story is rich and coherent, every character is unique with their own features.
Although the world is somewhat limited to the locations given, it heavily influences player's imagination - one of the rarest modern video game features!! And its totally awesome.

If you're a fan of such 8-bit, p&c games THIS IS A MUST.
It will suck you till the very end, or even more, trust me.

Definitely recommending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119123927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1592911587}
review: If you love a good point and click puzzle game then this one is for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198073544150', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1490489692}
review: Excellent Writing !

author: {'steamid': '76561198034359218', 'num_games_owned': 199, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1479338595}
review: Primordia is one of the best written and smartest games I played, from dialogue, to puns and wits. The puzzles are fun and not extremely challenging, and the story evolves nicely. The themes covered are conscience, myth and history, making analogies about their relationship with their creators.  This was the most interesting part of the game, the writer knew how to use this to make me think about my relationship with the world around me, how limited a being can be by its own "programming" and how someone's right is not a general right. A very philosophical game to play, and one of the best from Wadjet Eye.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013412988', 'num_games_owned': 776, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1479044978}
review: Fant√°stico, de lo mejor de Wadjet Eye. Personajes muy carism√°ticos, ambientaci√≥n de 10, puzles originales que te hacen interactuar con interfaces retrofuturistas, historia interesante, muchos finales... Todo un acierto.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970524508', 'num_games_owned': 1898, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1488442220}
review: This game was a fantastic golden oldie. Resolution not so great, but reasonable puzzles and full voice narration. Definitely worth playing if you're into adventure games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972862181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1489881794}
review:
Superbe jeu d'aventure, aux graphismes certes pixels mais sublimes, √† l'ambiance fin-du-monde extraordinaire et saisissante, √† la bande-son m√©lancolique et futuriste. Le servi par un tr√®s bon sc√©nario, et m√™me de l'humour toujours fin et cadrant bien avec le reste.
Une r√©ussite, je recommande fortement ce titre aux amateurs de point & click et aux autres, qui veulent d√©couvrir un bel univers, une histoire passionnante et des personnages bien travaill√©s, aux dialogues qui font toujours mouche.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179693198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1468846127}
review: I've had this game for a bit. I've found since the months I've played it that the story has stood the test of time. Something about Primordia is unforgettable. Now I will admit that figuring things out can be really frustrating at times but the storyline for me is so amazing that I'm willing to forgive the rough spots. I guess I will be a fan for life.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010824743', 'num_games_owned': 7494, 'num_reviews': 316, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1429203869}
review:
One of the greatest point and click adventures ever created.

Dont get irretated by the pixel artstyle. This game has a fantastic story, a great synchronisation and the artstyle is really art and not an excuse for missing high resolution.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049215805', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1483896520}
review: Amazing story and audio :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995657597', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1489477388}
review:
It was interesting and kept me through the whole thing, though there were a few points I couldn't figure out the creators 'logic'. That's not uncommon though, as what is obvious to it's creator may be extremely obscure at time to others. 

The graphics looked pixelated, but even giving it some leeway for being fullscreen, they were still a bit too pixelated for my preferences. There seemed to be no antialiasing at all. 

Sometimes the things you have to find, despite having no clue they are supposed to exist, are small objects, blend in very well with the clutter and trash, or are in dark areas and not really visible.  This isn't exactly an uncommon theme with these types of adventure games. 

Still, I rather enjoyed it, and hope the author takes the criticisms to heart and makes an even better game next time. 
I'm going to have to give it a yes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028997078', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1489428882}

author: {'steamid': '76561198019131378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1542743839}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001258363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1488857771}
review:
I hardly recommend this game to anybody new to the genre. While the game offers multiple solutions to their puzzles, the most important ones are quite complicated for the casual player. It offers a handy hint system to keep progress (Sometimes a bit too vague however) but you'll find inmense difficult spikes in some parts of the game.

If you can handle the challenge the game is a very solid adventure from beginning to end. Starts with a simple premise and snowballs the plot through the end. It also offers multiple endings so you can experiment with alternative solutions and choices in consequent playthroughs. The graphics and artstyle offers wonderful atmosphere and character design, but I advise you to play it windowed since the sprites don't transition well in full screen.

Overall a must have for the fans of this kind of games, specially veterans which want tough puzzles but not a single or convoluted solution to solve them. It might force you to find a guide sometimes, but even so the story is great enough to experience by its own merits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006813714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1477235299}

review: Loved it. The graphics are old-school, but kind of fit the overall aesthetic and theme of the game. Great world-design and history, intriguing characters, the interactions between the main character and side-kick are genuinely funny, fantastic puzzles, and I really enjoy the fact that the game uses branching logic - I need to replay at some point because I know I missed both achievements and alternative storylines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157332920', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1510888343}
review:
A classic point-and-click adventure game in a unique and engaging world, Primordia was a treat to play.  The art reallys draw you into the world, the characters endear themselves to you, the interface runs smoothly, and the story grows from a simple quest into something much grander.

It's a great game and well worth a playthrough.

review: Tr√®s bon clic'n play √† l'ancienne. L'histoire est prenante, avec sa dose d'humour dans les dialogues (textes et voix), et plusieurs fins sont possibles. La r√©alisation est bonne, le design plaisant, un c√¥t√© Machinarium en plus mature. Et pour les non anglophones, un patch fran√ßais est disponible, renseignez vous.√áa vous permettra de connaitre mieux toutes les ficelles du sc√©nario car du texte et diverses infos sur l'univers vous en aurez. author: {'steamid': '76561198053474628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1650800396}
review: Awesome world. Awesome art. Awesome plot. Sometimes the actions needed to advance in the game are a bit obscure. (A lot of point-and-click games do this and I personally hate it. Difficulty shouldn't be added this way, it destroys the feedback loop and only makes the game cumbersome.) But, who cares? If you get stuck just use a guide and move on, because this game deserves to be played.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966557804', 'num_games_owned': 1248, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1487624715}
review:
Primordia centers on the travails of two robots, Horatio and Crispen, who live in what is eventually revealed to be a warship on the edge of the ruins of a great city, Metropol. Their wasteland idyll is broken when another robot appears and steals the pair's power core. As robots, they require power, and embark upon a journey in a wasteland that reflects the splendour of a now dead world. 

Historically, I am not a fan of point-and-click adventure games.  But this game may have changed that. While I did occassionally cheat and look for solutions online, the tale of our two robots drew me in like the scent of a pitcher plant draws in flies. Upon reflection, the story reminds me of something that would have been published in Metal Hurlant three or more decades ago (minus the gratutious sex). 

The game makes explicit, though with subtle insertion, reference to other  speculative fiction masterpieces from multiple media. Fallout, Half-Life and A Canticle for Liebowitz being the ones I could clearly identify. Furthermore, the development team, usually the writer, provide liner notes revealing the design decisions they made in making this compelling tale. As someone interested in the division of labor in video game production, this was fascinating in its own right. 

If you like dystopian or melancholoy worldbuilding, this game is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189257809', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1488095816}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009899995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1487400790}
review:
Short point and click adventure with a great story and interesting art style :) 
Also enjoyed the two main characters and the amount of jokes back and forth between them kept a smile on my face while playing haha.

Definitely would recommend to others if this is their sort of thing also a little after I started playing just the art style and the story and the characters all together just made me think either graphic novel or manga styled cartoon would suit this games universe for further story telling haha I don't know why but it just did.

Cheers for a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198253846720', 'num_games_owned': 205, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1482593133}
review:
[quote][i]Annotation: [/i]After having a comprehensive conversation with the developer (which can be found underneath) I decided to change my review entirely. In case you are interested in why this is important to be mentioned, you can find the original review below. But first for the important point:

This game has the nicest developer I have ever heard of, in my entire life. Although I couldn't enjoy this awesome game as much as I should have, he was friendly and really supportive. This review was intended to be a negative one, but after I was responded it's really not fair to give him a negativ rating. So yes, this is basically a review for the developer, not for Primordia, but I just have to point that out. If you don't believe me, check the other reviews. He literally responded to every single one, even after more than four years of service. ([url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197989271430]Go check him out[/url])

However, so far for this review, every single line under here is what matters according to my view on the game. Thanks for reading until here. [/quote]






[quote=Titanic21][/quote]
[quote]You may hate me for this review, just as a warning.[/quote]
[quote]I know that the pixelart style was created on purpose, but a game doesn¬¥t get good by looking like it¬¥s retro or whatever they meant to. I don¬¥t mean that it¬¥s a bad game, please no, Primordia has a rich story, good gameplay and awesome sound design. But also... bad graphics. I am conscious about this game was intended to look like this and I don¬¥t want to say that Primordia requires cinematic graphics. Point and Click games usually don¬¥t look astonishing, that¬¥s not important for the genre. But in this case it¬¥s a little worse. I am almost sorry that I have to complain about this game, which is nice in all other aspects, but the graphics are what makes Primordia really less enjoyable. Eventually it¬¥s NOT helpful for solving puzzles when all objects look the same and you have to find them by slowly moving your cursor all over the screen, as if this was a hidden-object-game. It¬¥s hard to even recognize the textures and by looking closer you¬¥ll get more confused than you already are. I bought this because I like point ¬¥n click games a lot, and I have to admit that Primordia looked a lot better in the trailer. I wish the developers would have designed this more like Daedalic would have done, instead of Lucas Arts¬¥ way, so that I could enjoy the game. The harder I try, the more I see how pointless it is. Playing such an awesome game is exhausting if you can¬¥t clearly detect important elements. [/quote]
[quote]To not repeat me I will close this review now, if you read closely you should already have understood what I was saying. I  do seriously hope that you¬¥ll have different experiences while playing Primordia.[/quote]

L'aventure est bien √©crite, les paysages sont de qualit√©s, la bande son colle bien √† l'ambiance du jeu et rien √† dire sur le doublage (jeu enti√®rement en anglais, mais je crois savoir qu'un patch fran√ßais existe).

author: {'steamid': '76561198035125428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1665524490}
review:
Dear review reader,

To write a review for this bright gem of adventurous point and clicking is like ignite a dim star on dark hevenly arch which is already littered with thousand brightly shining suns.
Yes.... I know.... my words and sentences will imediately drop down through a grating of review sewage to simply form higher mean value of positive review percentage, BUT!!!!.....

.....I do not mind.... that is how good this game is.

Well for review: Its great, its hand drawn, got great SFX and music, its about robots, its about apocalypse, its about war, about our extinction, but then you find out its also about hope and friendship and like six people that got together and made wonderfull game. (and did not try to rip you off for 50 bucks or so(I got mine for ten!!))

Its really abut much more, but I am confident that you will find out for yourself.

Thank you.

(also... sry for mstakes)

author: {'steamid': '76561198006409656', 'num_games_owned': 1352, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1558758618}
review:
B'sod! 
Enjoyed the game. Haven't played point and click games since back in the day but read good things about Primordia so I thought I'd give it a chance. 
The music and art style are great.
The story unfolds as you progress and isn't drawn out (game feels about the right length). The dialogue and Crispin's humor keep the game interesting.
It's got good voice acting.
The puzzles aren't overly complicated or frustrating but not too simple either. 
Highly recommend trying the game out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970512270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1483688408}
review:
Primordia  8/10

Amazing world, amazing story, amazing voice acting, amazing graphics. If this had come out in the 90's we would be remembering it right next to Monkey Island, Full Throttle, and King's Quest. Wonderful throwback that a friend and I played together. It's only about 8 hours and worth the investment. Get a beer and snack and immerse yourself in this story/world.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968500907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1475278214}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970685997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1485546104}
review:
An excellent Point & Click adventure.

Positive:
+ good story
+ nice graphics
+ funny characters and dialogs
+ multiple endings
+ challenging puzzles

Negative:
- low resolution, sometimes puzzles are just hard because you missed some object
- some really hard puzzles
- constant feeling that you missed something due to the parallelity, that puzzles are spread over wide areas and the multiple endings

author: {'steamid': '76561197990985782', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1547535743}
review: One of the best adventure games of recent years, if not ever. Smart, funny, well-written, thought-provoking, and beautiful. First game I ever bought for a friend as a gift.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048977350', 'num_games_owned': 2302, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1485207544}
review:
This certainly was something different - clearly draws some inspirations from Beneath A Steel Sky, but also puts its' very own unique spin on them. 

Not as long as Technobabylon but superior in quality of setting and atmosphere, with writing at least on par if not better. 

My favourite Wadjet Eye release so far, worth every penny and every minute.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980757134', 'num_games_owned': 496, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1485105777}
review:
This game is the perfect mix of likeable characters, a compelling story, sarcastic humor, and awesome retro graphics. The friendship between the two main characters had me so invested in their stories that I got a bit emotional at some parts, and even all of the side characters you meet in passing were wonderful while they're on screen. What really brings them to life is the perfect voice acting, but the retro art design really endeared them all to me as well.

The puzzles are good, not to challenging but not too easy either. The game seemed to focus more on exploration and world building than puzzle solving, and for this story I think that was the much better choice. I also liked all the various pop culture references peppered throughout the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071836996', 'num_games_owned': 682, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1485137442}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993334380', 'num_games_owned': 789, 'num_reviews': 207, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1527294245}
review:
Loved this game. I felt some emotional tugs by the end of it, and didn't want the game to end. I feel like there's so much that could be explored, but appropriately, there's only so much that can be told for this story. I was still satisfied though. Definitely stocking the flames for adventure in me!

Definite recommend! Cheers!

author: {'steamid': '76561197983682079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1485042185}
review:
The ending is extremely predictable and there's nothing groundbreaking about the story. The puzzles are standard clicking of things and trading. 

I will say that the voice acting and character development are good. Good enough that I'm recommending this product (I originally did not recommend it). There are also some unique environments that I particularly liked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014655696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1483820482}
review: A really nice but short "point and click" game for those that doesn¬¥t have the patients or rediculous logic that many other games of the genre require. For once you dont¬¥t need a walkthrough to beat the game but the game itself supplies plenty of hints to keep you going.  It has an intresting story that doesn¬¥t outstay it¬¥s welcomeand if you¬¥re new to the genre then this is the one for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961368529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 437, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1484720218}
review: Bought this game on a whim after going through my queue. I'm so glad I found it because it took me back to my early gaming days playing the old point and click adventure games. The story, artwork and voice acting are really well done and I found myself easily drawn in. The puzzles are decent, some requiring me to grab a pencil and paper and jot some things down, but not too difficult where I had to cheat and look up the solution. The game was a welcome break from the competitive multiplayer games I find myself playing too often.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002643036', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1484588238}
review:
Takes me back to the old days of the point and click adventures for DOS. Great atmosphere, driving story, and lovely pixelated graphics. Tons of time frustrated in how do i solve this puzzle, and what do i do with this ****ing item? Had to break out my pencil and paper to make it through this, haven't had to do that since MYST on my dad,s Win95 NEC laptop. It does have a note style system in game that will help, but somethings are better left to nostalgia. I digress...

NOTE: Disable steam overlay! it is documented in community, look for my question if you want to know more.

Get this game if
- you like solving puzzles (Not Tetris)
- Thinking (almost over thinking..?)
- Sarcastic, whitty humor (Yeah, I don't really have to tell you more... Do I?)
- robotic steampunk hybrid style (Gotta love them hybrids)
- immersive story telling (they still didn't tell me a bed time story!)
- dragging and clicking the mouse cursor over ever pixel on the screen (It is fun.... . . .  .   .   .    !)
- Multiple endings (You don't really HAVE to save the world!}

avoid this game if
-  you cant think longer than 5,000,000 microseconds (go play tetris, wait you couldn't make it through that either...)
- cant stand to see pixels (Under 12 years old?)
- dragging and clicking the mouse cursor over ever pixel on the screen (Is it fun.... . . .  .   .   .    ?)
- Hate story driven game play (Go do something in *Cough*craft)
- you don't have the money for it currently (Add it to your wish list!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198351433507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1529088298}
review:
Primordia was an impulse buy of mine during the Steam winter sale, and I'm very glad I gave it a shot. Primordia is a great visual experience, effectively atmospheric and complex in ways I didn't expect. The puzzles were surprisingly difficult and the choices you make as a player actually have some weight. The plot is rich and unique, but the character composition is what I enjoyed most about this game. 

The interactions you have with the denizens of Primordia are varied and always well acted and written. The only tiny, tiny exception to this was Crispin's role as a comic relief character at the beginning of the story, but as things progressed it became clear to me that the devs were self aware with their writing and this actually increased my love for him as a character. The only disappointment I felt was when the game ended. 

If you find yourself even a little bit interested in this game, I highly reccomend that you give it a go. If you find yourself still uninterested by the time you reach Metropol (uh, spoiler I guess?) then it probably isnt for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094201381', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1587270125}
review:
good story so far, but buggy, if you happen to see an item in your inventory glitched, try to restore an old saved state, cause is going to crash on you on some random event after that. 
the first crashes solved themselves via re launching, but now im near the end of the game "I guess" and I cant continue. 
mouse response is awful. 
on the other hand many achievements are m issable on the 1st play. so keep your wits tight, this is not lucasart. you missed it once, you missed for good. 

fun game, bad controls, bugs, some crashes, buy on sales.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047316933', 'num_games_owned': 1485, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1561661584}
review:
Primordia is one of the best adventure games I played in years. The writing is superb, the voice acting is surprisingly good, the setting is very interesting, there are both easy and challenging puzzles and several endings. I read some complaints about the low resolution but I played in fullscreen on a 24'' monitor and had no issues.

Cons? Nothing really, except I wish it would have been longer with more locations to explore! (that Metro map) But alas, there's so much an indie developer can do as a first project, and Wormwood Studios exceeded all my expectations.

If you enjoyed the old LucasArts and Sierra adventures you should definitely play Primordia, it's the best adventure in Wadjet Eye Games catalog.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081247408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1484536368}
review:
I love the voice acting and the humor, but as a big fan of this genre of games, this one has too many solutions that essentially just require you to take every item in your inventory up to every item in the environment and click it.

Why would I use a nuclear bomb on a patch of oil when it says "I dont want to just throw this around" when I click something else.  Why would I use a cable to get up to a hatch when it clearly says "This isnt long enough to do this" when clicking one part, and at other times as said it wasn't sturdy enough to use for that type of work.

I want to recommend it, but no.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135493822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1484510701}
review:
I have played a good number of point and click games. This is what I WANT from a point and click game.  

a) Beautiful artwork (why?  cause it is a point and click...you need some bang for your buck. Syberia is a great example of this, though it fails in other regards)

b)  Puzzles that are challenging, but intuitive (point-n-clicks RARELY get the 'intuitive part'...I'm looking at you Longest Journey).

c) Good voice acting (if they are not text-based) and dialogue.

d) Memorable characters (yes Myst...your puzzles were lovely, but there was no one there!!!)

e) A cool mechanic (you know, like the time-turning or the pill-popping‚Ä¶ala Fran Bow and others)

f) Consequences (if not, choices are meaningless, and point-n-clicks are the perfect medium for giving players choices that matter).

Given these personal metrics, I must give this game high marks in all categories.  

a) 9/10.  Many folks may disagree. I admit, I was skeptical when I saw screen shots of the game...it looked dated and drab.  But the music and the voice-work mixed with the pixelated brown and reds...somehow it worked beautifully. The style perfectly suited the story.  I thought it was an absolutely beautiful game, with its own unique atmosphere.  Nothing else is quite like it.

b) 8/10 ‚Äì Seriously, this is the first point and click game where I said ‚Äúwell, if I really had these things, this is what I would do‚Äù and lo and behold‚Ä¶it was the solution!!!  Plus, there was a fun mix of number-based, logic-based, and text-based puzzles.  The only downside is that I wish there were more!!  And to be fair, not all were challenging‚Ä¶it is a pretty easy game.  But I was never bored or frustrated, so I consider it a win!

c) 10/10 ‚Äì loved every single voice.  And‚Ä¶I mean‚Ä¶they are robots.  And somehow, this game had better voice acting than 90% of the games out there!

d) 8/10 ‚Äì Loved the leads, loved the sides, loved that one lone guy (*sniff*).  More interaction would have allowed better character development for side characters‚Ä¶but it is just a point and click game after all.  The banter is spot-on!

e) 6/10 ‚Äì you get a sidekick who helps you out. Nothing to write home about‚Ä¶although‚Ä¶to be fair‚Ä¶he is a really awesome sidekick personality-wise!! 

f) Yup.  Consequences and multiple endings.  Woohoo!! (I don‚Äôt want to score this part‚Ä¶just wanted to cheer for the effort!)

Cons?  Not much.  It is a good time for the price. It is a little short‚Ä¶but it is not ‚Äúempty‚Äù.  Ie, I would rather have a short, full game than a long game of needless filler. If you feel the same, buy it!

Hope this helps!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971428787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 509, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1480145651}
review:
As someone who hasn't played a point-and-click adventure game in a while, but played them a lot as a kid, I really enjoyed this game. I rarely finish a game and immediately start it over, but I did for this game. I'd say if you liked anything like the older king's quest games (like, 6 or earlier), leisure suit larry (PC Point & Click ones of course not the console garbage) or Day of the tentacle, etc, you will very likely really enjoy this.

I think the biggest compliament I can pay this game is that I DID actually refrain from using any guide my first play through. AND I really did want to for a few puzzles. But in the end, I was able to progress after some thought about things. I Wanted a better ending though of course, so I played it again, but I didn't feel like any puzzle was TOO far "out there" in terms of obtuseness. It is a point-and-click game, so there's always SOME degree of click-spamming the whole screen in frustration, but I felt it was at a minimum with this one.

I'd buy a sequel for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995434263', 'num_games_owned': 259, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1578472241}
review: Top notch point & click, awesome soundtrack and the setting is good. Alot of stories set in the post-apocalypse don't really go anywhere or progress in a way that interests me, but primordia tackled a future without humanity and the progression of robot society. Definitely a must play. The characters are awesome aswell, the art is beautiful and the puzzles are just hard enough to do but not need a walkthrough.  play it!! [-c¬∞‚ñ•¬∞]-c

author: {'steamid': '76561198056791135', 'num_games_owned': 43, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1484353034}
review:
For those that are fans of Robert Heinlein, Arthur C. Clarke and (most relatable to this game) Isaac Asimov, then this is the game will blow your mind.

Admittedly after several hours of frying my mind over the game I resorted to a guide and just enjoyed the excellent voice acting and in depth storytelling.

The gaming interface is a little clunky and a highlight option to find out what items are useable would have made things easier, but the over all atmosphere of this game pulled me in.  Your two main characters are likeable with some offhand banter to bring you more into this dark Machinarium type world.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989905774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 542, 'last_played': 1484323004}
review:
Summary : 

Buy it!

Long story:

First of all, when you start the game having a 1080p display, the graphics seem extra old, pixelated and just ugly. The reason behind it seems to be the fact that the pixels were drawn by hand. There is a way to "resize" the original 300xsomething resolution and get a nice 1200xsth window without losing quality of detail. (Settings are changed using a separate exe file located in the installation folder)

The atmosphere of the game is fantastic. You immerse yourself into a beautifully done post-apocalyptic world filled with dust, junk and characters with their own personalities, thoughts, beliefs and so on. It is a well-thought world based on one of the possible continuations of mankind's history. The game offers multiple completely different endings affected by your interpretation of the world and events around you.

The puzzles are fun to solve, you can get hints if you get stuck and there is only a couple of moments when the solution felt not 100% logical to me personally. The interface needs 5-10 minutes to get completely used to, there is a "how to play" option in the menu.

I think that purchasing this game is a good idea for point&click experts as well as those new to the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967397955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 812, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1488701530}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041971048', 'num_games_owned': 1493, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1553981053}
review:
When I first saw this game it looked like a bleak, soulless game. The colors, the crude graphics. Screenshots don't do this game justice.
But 5 minutes in, and i've fallen in love with world and characters. The game tells an epic story set in a very interesting world where Man is no more. The writing is excellent; Horatio and Cirspin's (the main character and his sidekick) relationship is fun and they play off each other really well. And there's a peculiar character you meet a few hours in that is one of the best characters I've seen in recent years. His name starts with a P; that's all i'm going to say.

It's an excellent game but I thought the ending was a little underwhelming. Still very worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198275390906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1493350090}
review: This game was worth every penny. This was the first point and click style game i've ever played and I fell in love with it within like 10 fucking minutes! Like so many reviews have said that the voice acting works well, the characters and memorable, and the puzzles throughout are witty, but not too hard that it's unfair(except for the fucking monocle puzzle like WTF)....Anyways no spoilers here. Just buy this game for the story alone even if you don't like this style of game. It'll make you think about how you percieve the world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062489928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1483693704}

author: {'steamid': '76561197962298460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1516230174}
review:
Between the dunes of a once fertile planet lies a broken vessel, which purpose has been lost to time. Within the hull lives Horatio Nullbuilt and his companion Crispin. They make use of what they can salvage from the dust-covered wrecks of the wasteland, trying to survive on their own in a dying world. The loss of their energy source will lead them from the solitude of their home and to the city of Metropol. A pearl of the wasteland and a beacon of energy, filled with robots like them. There machines trade, live and prosper as their creators once did, the Humans, which long ago walked the once green earth. 

Although a game about automatons and their emotionless struggle, Primordia convey emotions of the opposite nature. The game feels timeless in the sense that it deals with our eternal pursuit for purpose.  It stays relevant by exploring our theoretical future in which we have spoiled the earth that gives us food, shelter and life. 

In a time where we are constantly bombarded with filtered happiness from social media, Primordia reflect our inner feelings of loneliness and solitude. It may seem that this game is a homage to the old point and click-era of the 90s, it is not, it stands tall on its own.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970948993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1482760936}
review:
As somebody who would normally avoid point & clicks, I can safely say that Primordia is a treasure of a game and definitely worth playing regardless of your view towards the point & click genre.

Heartfelt, funny and engaging. I wish I had a personal Crispin.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039131560', 'num_games_owned': 392, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1494894143}
review:
I should've written a review for this game a long time ago. To be short, I believe this game is more than worth the price and provides enough to be recommended to veterans of the genre and people unfamiliar with point-and-clicks alike. Without further ado, let's dive into it.

[h1]Story[/h1]

[i]"Man built us to build, Crispin." -Horatio Nullbuilt, version 5.[/i]

The world of Primordia is one of the most original sci-fi settings I've seen in video games thus far. Humanity is long gone and the almost uninhabitable Earth is populated with robots built by other robots. Very few, if any, remember who humans were. Some worship "Man, the All-Builder" in their memory, others believe they were just a myth. Power is scarce in the wasteland and those who still function must do what they can to survive. The nature of the world is shown very well and sets an unforgettable mood for the whole adventure.

[i]"All of this for a b'soding power core!" -Horatio Nullbuilt, version 5.[/i]

The plot starts simply: you, Horatio Nullbuilt, lose the power core of your ship to a mysterious intruder. Facing certain death from slowly running out of power, you pursue the thief and get involved in mysteries far beyond your understanding. The adventure is quite interesting and, while the plot twists are somewhat predictable and the mystery isn't too hard to solve, the tension and tone of the game keep you on your toes, wanting to explore the mysteries of insane ancient robots, Man himself, and a city of glass and light whose promises of free power seem just too good to be true.

[i]"Why is everyone we meet crazy?" -Crispin Horatiobuilt, version 1[/i]

The characters are by far the most interesting part of the story. Despite being robots, pretty much all of them are relatable and believable. From our sarcastic sidekick Crispin and a devout Humanist preacher named Ever-Faithful to a pair of upper-class robots trying to settle a legal dispute and a warbot who encrypted his own logic to deal with the horrors of the war, the cast is diverse to say the least. There were a few who I've found to be a bit bland and one-sided (Clarity and the main villain for example), but those were few and far between.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

[i]"Are you really trying to build us an energy sensor from a bunch of garbage?"
"Crispin, I built [b]you[/b] from a bunch of garbage."
"From spare parts, boss! Spare parts!"
-Crispin and Horatio[/i]

The gameplay is standard for the genre: pick up stuff, combine stuff, use stuff to solve puzzles. In addition to that, when you can't reach something yourself or simply need some help, you can use your floating companion Crispin, who also acts as the game's hint system. Perhaps the biggest strength of the game here is that the puzzles integrate well into the story. The hints make sense as actual conversation, the solutions are usually as straight-forward and practical as possible, and the characters react adequately during these situations. There were only one or two cases of "pixel hunting" in the whole game so that is a big plus as well.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

[i]"Look at all those lights! It's amazing boss!"
"It's trouble. Trust me."
"Sweet, sweet trouble."
-Crispin and Horatio[/i]

The world and the characters are both beautifully crafted. There are many games these days that use pixel art, but Primordia took it as a challenge rather than a cop out. The game is simply gorgeous. The only negative thing I can say about its look is that the characters have very few sprite animations and the reuse becomes noticeable in a few scripted events. The music is similarly amazing. I still remember the track that plays when you read the Gospel of Man. Finally, the voice acting. In case you haven't noticed from the trailer, the voice of Horatio Nullbuilt is Logan Cunningham, the main voice actor in Transistor and Bastion. His work is as top notch as it is in those games and the other VAs are quite good as well. All in all, presentation is one of the game's strongest points, perhaps even more so than the story.

[h1]Possible negatives[/h1]

[i]"It jes needs a little fixin' up, tyro." -L.S.[/i]

- The game is quite short. Depending on how much you explore and how quick you are with the puzzles, it will most likely take you between 6 and 10 hours to complete.
- There are some technical difficulties. The game forces you to a pretty low resolution due to the engine limitations and alt-tabbing can cause voice over to break. Also some of the achievements may be bugged. A few people reported not getting achievements when they should, I on the other hand got a final achievement while still missing two very important parts of the ending.
- You can solve a few of the puzzles in a multitude of ways, but these "choices" may have long-lasting consequences that are not properly telegraphed.
- Most puzzles are logical but a few are still obscure. For example, the game never tells you that something inside your inventory can be disassembled.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

All in all, Primordia is a great game with a fantastic story and amazing presentation. The not too difficult gameplay might leave a few veterans of the genre slightly disappointed, but it makes the game accessible for people not usually interested in point-and-clicks as well, and the story more than makes up for it anyway. While the game is short, the price is very generous and I'd say Primordia uses the play time it does have very well. This one is a definite recommendation from me.

[i]"Farewell, farewell, linger not for my sake. Your mission is calling! The city awaits!" -P.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198078634264', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1484270557}
review:
I haven¬¥t completed this game yet at the time of writing, but [u]I need to see no more before I make up my mind[/u].

BUY THIS GAME! It's unlikely you would regret it.

The game is exacly what the store page leads to belive, and than some more.
The game is not too short, like some other games in the genre. There is enough content to enjoy.
The puzzles are not very hard, but also not completely obvious. The art style is robust but very good!
The voice acting is falwless. And The game is filled with (mostly sarcastic) humor. Humor is difficult to do right, but I assure you this game is done just right!
You can tell work and love was put into this game. It wasn't made in one day, so to say.
The storyline progresses as you progress in the game, keeping the game even more interesting. I find the story original and interesting. Not predictable, but once you progress it makes sens. A good storyline!

The game will make you laugh, it will show you beutiful places, it will spark you imagination... It's just worth buying! Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061526122', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1483420494}
review:
This was an impulse buy while it was on the Steam winter sale, and it was one of the best impulse buys I've ever done.

There is something truly unique and amazing about this game, and if you're reading this and wondering whether or not you should buy it, let me give you the rundown.

Excellent:
-The story is compelling, and populated with incredibly unique characters. One of my favorites is a fairly minor character that speaks in a religious cadence, and it's just such a cool little scene, it really stuck with me.
-The characters are diverse and incredibly easy to become attached to. They are so well written, that you could name a character from hearing just a TINY snippet of their dialogue.
-There are some truly genius puzzles here that absolutely blew me away. 
-The art is pretty breathtaking. The whole game feels alien and strange, but a familiar shadow seems to hang over it. It's just fucking great.

Meh:
-The voice acting for both Horatio and Crispin, the two main characters, is a little...off. Horatio I kind of got used to, and his monotone drone ended up being more part of his personality than anything, but Crispin has some pretty well-written lines that are delivered pretty awkwardly, and I found him pulling me back out of the game a little bit every so often. That being said, Crispin is delightful, if a tad annoying.
-Some of the puzzles are absolutely rediculous, with some of them being outright pixelhunting. With as intelligent as the rest of the game is, it makes these puzzles even HARDER, because you expect the answer to make more sense. For instance (No spoilers here, don't worry.)
     There is a part of the game where your path is impeded, and the answer is the first thing that comes to your mind: "Crispin should just move that." And that is, indeed, the answer to that quandry.
     There's a part where you need to find an item, but you aren't told where it can be found or where to start. Had to resort to a walkthrough on this one, because the answer lay in a very cluttered, dark area of the screen. You never think "This game will resort to pixel hunting", because the rest of the game is just...too well thought out.

So most of my complaints are "Come on, Primordia, you're BETTER than this!", which should absolutely tell you something. How this isn't a HUGELY known game is beyond me.

In conclusion: Buy it, you son of a bitch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117485389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 667, 'last_played': 1483390644}
review: Primordia has an expansive world, engrossing story, and characters that are endearing. Although the game is short, (about 4-6 hours), I enjoyed the heck out of it. The puzzle solving scratches the same itches as "Grim Fandango", while the atmosphere is reminiscent of "Fallout". I want more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970719052', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 772, 'last_played': 1654661277}
review:
TL;DR:

It's a PCA (Point and Click Adventure). No actual puzzles, just good old-school inventory combining and environment clicking!

Graphics:     8/10 (Sub-HD resolution. All the scenes, characters and animations are VERY well drawn/animated.)

Sound:       10/10 (Fully voiced, fully music'd, and it's all high-quality. Doesn't get better!)

Interface:     9/10 (Art'ed menus that fit the game; intuitive and minimalistic.)

Story:           8/10 (Engaging, entertaining, fascinating and everything is tied together. Nice!)

Characters:  9/10 (Horatio reminds me of Ben from Full Throttle. Crispin is quite entertaining, deep "B" listers, too!)

Toughness:  5/10 (Security through Obscurity. Score with autohints off. Discworld = 10/10, for reference).

Length:        7/10 (Took me 12h to beat without hints. I liked it and didn't want it to end!)

Overall:        9/10 (Great fun if you like PCAs, post-apocalyptic themes, robots, and a fun 
sidekick!)


Thanks for a rather great PCA! I'd really like to see a HD version sometime, but it's still totally worth it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025041121', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1483283522}
review:
The game gripped me shortly after beginning. My heater was broken, it was freezing outside. But this wonderful adventure had hooked me. The world is one of the best-presented I've ever seen. The characters are very well presented to make you curious for more. I just wanted to spend more time exploring this world. It's also filled with humor that lightens up the somber setting, it's difficult to explain just how well the combination works.

The puzzles themselves vary in quality, with some doing a great job in feeling like you're just solving problems that would exist in the world rather than an arbitrary roadblock by the developers. Others... Not so much. One particular puzzle stands out as an example of this problem (slight spoiler warning, though I won't give the answer)

You need two different objects that can obstruct a vent. The first is easily gained by cutting off the tip of a robot's finger. However, the game doesn't allow you to cut off the tip of another finger for the second item. This is a frustrating limitation, and can easily lead to resenting the puzzle. The fact that important objects are often indistinguishable from the background only adds to the frustration.

HOWEVER, and I can't stress this enough, while this kind of uneven quality in puzzles should suck the fun out of an adventure game... It doesn't. The rest of the world is too entrancing. It single-handedly rekindled my love of adventure games. I bring up these drawbacks to help emphasize how truly great the rest of the experience is, that even these issues don't sour it.

TLDR; If you're considering buying this game, do so. Do it now. Play it. Enjoy it. Have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005948395', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1482894286}

author: {'steamid': '76561198033285455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 411, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1483212480}
review: HOLY COW!!! Through out the game I kept remembering how it felt to play Riven and Myst. It has been MANY years since then and for a modern game to take me back to my childhood like that is one of MY first signs of a great game. The puzzles, the dialog, the art, the interface, and the music... I could not have asked for better. Definatlly on my top 5 BEST puzzle games of all time. I actually care about what happens to each character. Try you hardest to solve the puzzles on your own, they are VERY rewarding. Also take care there are more than just a couple endings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963902299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1483167518}
review:
TL;DR: If you love noir and/or sci-fi, get this on sale and play with a walkthrough, because it's not a super-fun game, but it's an awesome experience!

A very classic-feeling adventure game with a perfect blend of science fiction and noir - and not the watered-down versions you might be used to, I mean think classics, the genre-defining stuff people still remember from 50+ years ago. As a fan of both, I was very satisfied. It's a smart story excellently told with top-notch writing and art. Kudos to the devs for having the game run in super-low resolution - no accidental ruining of the retro feel by hi-res glows or particle effects. You want retro? This is retro. The art direction is consistent right down to the screen resolution.

As a game... not so much. See, it's an adventure game, and that means exactly what you think it means. Personally, I bought it for half-off and after the first 40 minutes or so I opened up a guide - so much more enjoyable! The writing is witty, the world-building is amazing, the story unfolds with perfect timing... why be bogged down with "find the hidden active zone in the dozen screens you have access to" or "use X on Y in order to use X, Y, and Z together, no other combination works"? Those games are dumb. When you actually have all the items and clues the puzzles are usually not stupid, but you never really know if you do - the fundamental failing of adventure games. Don't put yourself through that just to get at the good stuff. Keep a walkthrough open and peek at it any time you're starting to get the slightest doubt on how to proceed.

I am not the kind of person who usually goes into games for storytelling, but I am a sucker for sci-fi and an even bigger sucker for noir, so this was totally worth it. If I'd known how good a time I would have I might have even paid full price! If any of what I wrote sounded interesting and you have the time to kill, it's definitely worth at least the price of a movie ticket.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150898237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1656125709}
review:
This game is absolutely fantastic. I don't think I can do it justice here, but I will try.

This game is a work of art. It's very fun and the puzzles are stimulating, but the real treasure is in the dialogue and the world. This game explores the nature of religion, justice, and creation in a post-human, post-apocalyptic world. It's so achingly beautiful. I also literally cried at the end. It's a rare story that can reduce me to tears, but this one did it.

Mechanically this game is great as well. The music and the voice acting are wonderful, and the graphics are perfect for the story. The game flows well, and I think it was a good length. The character arc of Horatio was fantastic and satisfying - any longer and I think the game would lose some of the power of its narration.

The details are what really make this game. Explore everything. Talk a lot to Crispin. Right-click on everything. Go through all dialogue options. This world is compelling, and beautiful, and utterly desolate. Horatio, the protagonist, is similarly compelling, beautiful, and desolate. If you're looking through the reviews because Primordia's on sale, please just buy it. You will 100% not regret it, I promise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961259997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 412, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1483771053}
review: A highly polished, fully voiced retro adventure game with an engaging post apoctalyptic sci-fi story. Lasts about 6-8 hours depending on how long it takes you to figure out the puzzles. There is a small amount of replayability via optional achievements as well as a specific set of hidden objectives you must complete in order to get the best ending. Support the devs and buy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027608865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1483072359}
review:
If you enjoy dark dystopian sci-fi, beautiful artwork, and a storybook gameplay I highly recommend you try Primordia!

As a point-and-click storybook game, Primordia does not dissappoint. It's smart, well-illustrated, and presents a compelling story. The writers took care to build an internally consistent world complete with mythology and believable motives. It's a world I would not be dissappointed to return to in a follow-up title. 

There is an obvious retro-feel that permeates not only the art style, but also the story and game-mechanic. Primordia's writing reminds me of 1980s robot sci-fi including a few text-based games from that era. The art is clearly influenced by visual work from that period including Lynch's Dune. There are multiple endings, and I enjoyed that the best of them still presented a dark and morally clouded set of choices for the main character.

The only criticism I have of Primordia is the same criticism I have of similar point-and-click games; many of the inventory combinations and item uses are not intuitive and are occassionally inconsistent. Also, while the side-kick character was a wise choice for an in-game hint system, his personality occassionally feels out of place. FYI: There were also 2 achievements which I believe I met the criteria for but did not recieve. Probably not a bug, but other reviewers have had the same problem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046859840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1598829756}

author: {'steamid': '76561198054901830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1543762853}
review:
I liked this little game. It could be a little bit longer maybe but I guess I can still give it a second run later - with the developer commentary turned on and with trying to find out the solution for a few "side stories" i missed.  Puzzles and solutions did make sense which was quite refreshing. In a whole game there was only one point where I really needed to look the solution up*.

Sometimes the game engine is a little choppy, especially in scenes with parallax scrolling attempts, which is funny with all the power computers have nowadays. I see the 320*200 -ish resolution is kind of intentional "retro style" but the engine does not have to :). After seeing some concept art which obviously was not low-res I even wonder whether it would harm the game If it was made in high resolution... The current result is still fine. So, I guess it was not the worst decision anyway.

All in all, a very good adventure game. With the current Steam sale price any adventure games lover should give it a try.

* [spoiler]The kiosk "puzzle": Art? Seriously, ART? It could easilly be any random word! :)[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198108028866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482988397}
review:
Primordia is a retro-styled point and click adventure game set in a dystopian future in which Man has gone extinct. Only machines remain, struggling to survive in the junk-filled wastelands. The protagonist will have to face many challenges in order to retrieve his source of power, gradually learning about the hidden thruth of his world along the way.

The gameplay is very simple, as is every other adventure game: you'll have to explore, find and combine multiple items and use them at the right places to progress. What separates this game from the others is it's theme and its great humor. The last being delivered by a lovable sidekick who also serves the purpose of a hint bot. The puzzles are clever and challenging but not impossibly hard. 

The story is filled with rich and interesting lore, but is very linear (except at the very end, where you have multiple endings available). Each dialogue feels thought out and unique.

The graphics are very reminiscent to those of Fallout 1: pixelated and low-resolution with dark brownish tones, which is tolerable since they seemed to be aiming for the retro theme. The only exception is the handful of brief cutscenes presenting very detailled close-ups of the action, which help with the immersion. The soundtrack is atmospheric and blends well with the setting. The voice acting is truely amazing.

There's even some replayability value for those who wish try the commentary mode.

[b]So in short;[/b] for a 7 hour game with a good storyline and challenging puzzles paired with immersive soundtrack and great voice-acting, the pricetag is well worth the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034172959', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1511554415}
review: Primordia is a point 'n click developed by Wormwood Studios which provides a good storyline, well-written dialogues, old-school graphics, an atmosphere somewhere between Machinarium and Blade Runner and a cool soundtrack by Nathaniel Chambers. A truly enjoyable experience for the amateurs.

Highly recommend 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197961914449', 'num_games_owned': 695, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 497, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482824796}
review: Another quality title from wadjet eye games. This time: a post-apocalyptic wasteland robot adventure where you uncover the origins of yourself, and the apocalypse.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983781898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482746785}
review:
Don't let metacritic ratings bully you.  Multiple endings are good, game is good but relatively short and small.  I picked this up on sale for 2$, felt like a steal, highly recommend it on sale.  If you've ever played any good point and click adventure it's good.  Again, short, average playtime should run 4-5 hours if that.  Can probably speed run the game in under 3.

That said, if you want a good interactive story that's bleak and interesting to think about as far as post apocalyptic science fiction goes, it's great.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982790927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1631054881}
review:
I was glued to the chair for several hours wringing my brains to solve the puzzles, because yes, I refused to get "outside" help like walkthroughs and other aids. 
And that says a lot.
I never expected this from a point and click game.
The voice acting is flawless and the characters are really nicely made. 
Loved it to bits!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970576399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482810424}
review:
Promordia is probably the best point-&-click i've played since the mid 90s.  The story, atmosphere and voice acting are all great but what REALLy set it's apart from modern point-&-clicks is that it is one, continuous game, not seperated in short episodes so you keep your stuff all the way through.  

My only complaint is that it was too short but that is a great complaint to have.

Also, room has been left to make a sequel, one that hopefully involve humans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053293750', 'num_games_owned': 1568, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482698784}
review: A great point and click adventure through and through. The art style is fitting, the voice acting is great and the puzzles are generally logical and fun. However, the story is the part that really shines. The story in itself already has a lot of twists and turns, but the amount of symbolism is mind boggling. If you are interested in discussion of philosophy, this game offers you a lot to think about, such as religions, laws, good-vs-evil, progression and more. Highly recommanded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097347605', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1575824006}

author: {'steamid': '76561197972624697', 'num_games_owned': 893, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 685, 'last_played': 1476586739}
review:
A brilliant point & click adventure game. Engaging story, great voice acting, interesting characters, and a perfect balance of difficulty with the puzzles.

Many memorable characters from this game, and the writing at critical points is top notch. The antagonist and the setting are very well done.

The palette is pretty much brown, blue, and grey. Perhaps more color would have been nice, but I really can't criticize when the artwork is so beautiful. The graphics are otherwise retro-style and very well done.

If you are a fan of classic adventure games, I can't recommend this enough. I love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171251725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1482220582}
review:
[NO SPOILER!!!!]

Primordia ist ein klassisches Point&Click Game im Retro Stil der fr√ºhen 90er Jahre. Die Handlung entwickelt sich durch das L√∂sen von R√§tseln, kombinieren von n√ºtzlichen Gegenst√§nden, sowie den Entscheidungen √ºber das falsche oder richtige Handeln. 

Worum gehts?
Der mysteri√∂se Android Horatio und sein kleiner Gehilfe Crispin durchstreifen ein postapokalyptisches Szenario in einer W√ºste. Woher sie kommen und welches Ziel sie verfolgen bleibt ungekl√§rt. Was ist mit dieser ehemals fortschrittlichen Welt passiert, von der nur Ruinen √ºbrig geblieben sind? Und welche Entscheidung f√ºhren die Beiden Freude an Ihr eigentliches Ziel?

POSITIV: 
+ detaillierte Szenarios
+ guter Soundtrack
+ d√ºstere Atmosph√§re
+ super (!) Synchro
+ fein ausgefeilte Charaktere
+ Spiel l√§uft fl√ºssig, gute Steuerung, jederzeit speicherbar

NEGATIV: 
- keine deutsche Vertonung, schade
- frustrierende R√§tsel, ziemlich knifflig
- Das Volumen der Musik kann nur bedingt reguliert werden, Volumen ist manchmal schlecht abgemischt. 

FAZIT: 
Ein wirklich sch√∂nes Spiel mit viel Atmosph√§re und einer interessanten Handlung. Die Dialoge haben mich oft zum lachen gebracht weil Horatio und Crispin ein wunderbares Team sind (was sich liebt das neckt sich). Als alter Hase darf ich das sagen: die 90er Atmosph√§re wirkt NICHT aufgesetzt, ganz im Gegenteil. Ich habe mich dabei erwischt wie ich das Release Datums des Spiels √ºberpr√ºft habe, um sicher zu gehen. 
Das einzige was mich frustriert hat waren die kn√ºppelharten R√§tsel. Nachdem ich Stunden umher geirrt bin habe ich einen Blick in die Ausl√∂sung geworfen nur um fest zu stellen dass ich da wohl nie selbst drauf gekommen w√§re... dies ist jedoch ein sehr pers√∂nlicher Kritikpunkt. 
Wer also auf dystopische gruselige Sci-Fi Geschichten mit schwarzen Humor steht sollte vielleicht ein paar ruhige Abende investieren um die Welt von Primordia zu erforschen. Viel Vergn√ºgen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198056675328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1482289305}
review:
Great world, awesome voice acting, humor and interesting characters.
Surprisingly logical story, conneted with world in many small details.
Great art direction.

Awful resolution, obtuse control scheme on some puzzles, and some bugs, that can strait up crash the game, requiring you to manage more then 1 or 2 saves.

If devs could fix resolution problem (even with just "smoothening" everything down), it could be quite a hidden gem of whole Steam catalog.

As it stands - it is awesome game for people, who dont mind to look past few obvious flaws, but not the game "everyone" could possibly enjoy at this state.

Oh yea and it is somewhat short.

review:
TL:DR ; Excellent jeu !

L'univers est attachant gr√¢ce aux touches d'humour diss√©min√©es dans les dialogues, les √©nigmes sont de qualit√© sans √™tre insolvables, et les multiples fins font que l'on peut sans probl√®me relancer une partie par pure curiosit√©. 
Ce jeu raconte une histoire, et tout ceux qui ont grandi avec les "livres dont vous √™tes le h√©ros" pourront y trouver leur compte. Je l'ai achet√© pendant une promotion et ne l'ai lanc√© que tardivement, et tr√®s honn√™tement je le regrette presque.
Le mode plein √©cran est pour moi presque obligatoire en revanche, ce qui pourrait √™tre le seul b√©mol, mais ce jeu vaut chaque centime investi.

review: Saw a picture of this game in a google image search it looked rather interesting so i added it to my wishlist months Later i saw it on sale and bought i must say this is probably one of the best I've played even tho i wasn't particularly drawn to it being a point and click game but the games story landscapes and characters really make this game if you can you should definitely buy this

author: {'steamid': '76561198126106060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1481611695}
review:
Primordia is a simple point and click game. Like all games in this style it is all about the depth of the story and music that really makes the game. Well the music is a 4/5 and the story 5/5.  Graphics are a bit simple but are by no means disapointing. It enforces the fact high def is not needed to be visualy pleasing.  I did laugh a lot at the side kick who if you happen to be stuck, can be prompted to give clues, after a few great entertaining remarks that is. That and the multipleways to end the story add to very good replay without thinking about the achievements. The puzzles range from easy to hair pulling, till the OOOOOHHHHhhh I am an idiot moment. 

So in short, good replay, great story, worth every cent I spent on it & I have recommended it to friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038133830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1481525390}
review: 7/10. Good game but not great. The setting, the music, the art style, and the writing are all good, but the sameness of the aesthetic does get a bit monotonous by the end of the game. So much brown and gray everywhere. It's also a little on the short side, and has the usual flaws of point-and-click adventure games. You know, like "I'm stuck because I didn't see this tiny object that's barely visible against the monochrome background." If that doesn't bother you then you will probably like Primordia more than I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025357025', 'num_games_owned': 2577, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 687, 'last_played': 1481434418}
review:
Digging through Wadjet Eye catalogue is a pleasure every time, so when I finally found the time to try Primordia out, I wasn't expecting any less than a great adventure. But wow, I wasn't expecting it to be [i]that[/i] great, either.

Obviously, most of the reviewers around here have already described the game much better than a non-native English speaker ever could, though it never hurts to praise a masterpiece. And as with any other masterpiece, it doesn't seem necessary to break it down to individual components and discuss whether the mechanics lack gunplay. The only thing that matters here is the feeling, what it's like to live through the story of Primordia.

You know when you're close to finishing a book so good you almost don't want to read the last few pages? It's as if a significant part of your life is about to be taken, and you try to savor every single word there's left. Oh boy, I still remember the devastation I felt as a kid when 'Pippi Longstocking' ended. [spoiler](don't judge me, I love that book)[/spoiler] A horrible yet extremely satisfying moment of experiencing something beautiful and important. And it's exactly what a quality adventure game should be ‚Äì a book you will never forget.

Primordia bears this very feeling in its core logic. Its world, consisting of rust and despair, might not be of the attractive kind, but the minute you dive into it, you'll have enough reasons to stay. It is surprisingly smart, detailed, vivid and, even less expectedly, highly amusing thanks to the characters populating it. Despite the depressing tones, the amount of intelligent humour makes it one of the most likeable worlds in the recent adventure games history.

No wonder leaving it is incredibly hard. I found myself thinking, "This is not enough! Why would you end it so soon? I want more!" and loading random saves to listen to random dialogues once again. But while Primordia surely is a short experience, I doubt making it longer would've made any difference. You just can't have enough of worlds like this one. 

Primordia is indeed a hidden gem of the genre. Well, not really hidden anymore, but it definitely is something that deserves more attention. Every piece of attention you can afford, to be precise.

Thank you, Mark. I'm sorry it took me so long to play it. <3

author: {'steamid': '76561198275711758', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1159, 'last_played': 1487132014}
review:
[h1] So what happens [i] after [/i] the robots take over the world? [/h1]

[i] Primordia [/i] is here to answer that question. This amazing point-and-click game takes place on a dystopian Earth at an unspecified point in history. The few humans that remain have fled underground, living in low-g bunkers and looking at a once-green Earth through pictures and little garden chambers. Over the years, we have faded into myth, and now the Earth is ruled by our creations, some of who worship our memory as a creed called "Humanism."

You are Horatio Nullbuilt, a wasteland-dwelling robot of undeterminate origin whose only companion is Crispin Horatiobuilt, a floating, armless robot with an endless supply of sarcastic remarks. Together, they lived a pretty uneventful life. They were trying to fix up a crashed airship, a relic of the long-forgotten War of the Four Cities, so they could at last fly away from the Dunes and go wherever they want. Unfortunately, their progress is halted when a mysterious robot named Scraper shows up and "plunders" their power core--an item they cannot survive without. When trying to find power in the Dunes fails, they have no choice but to travel to Metropol, the last city, where their power core has been taken. To make matters worse, an anceint robot named MetroMind has claimed your power core for the betterment of the city, since it is crumbling under her inept rule and she needs all the power she can get.

From there, it is up to you how the story ends. Choose carefully, your every move has consequences.

The voice-acting is masterfully done. Every character is unique and full of personality. The story and lore are very well-crafted as well. Unraveling the mystery of the world you're in never fails to be fascinating, and if you play through it just right, the ending is beautiful and cathartic.

Like my review? Check out my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/27019034-%EF%BC%B2%EF%BC%A5%EF%BC%AF%EF%BC%AE%EF%BC%A1%EF%BC%B2%EF%BC%A4%27s-Reviews/] Curator [/url] page!

Take control of an andriod who seems to have some kind of past with the, city of glass. Help him and his assistant. AKA the floating bomb unravel mysteries, and build a new future. All while dealing with the many inhabitants. The machines!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067481163', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1174, 'last_played': 1480878537}
review: Thoroughly enjoyed this game, I downloaded this immediately after completing Shardlight (another game by Wadjeteye Games). You play as a robot named Horatio in a world where there are no more humans, only robots. Horatio has a sidekick/friend that he built, named Crispin, who accompanies you on your journey. I really like how Crispin is a sort of hint system as well as being a constant source of sass :P If you like old school style point n clicks, you're going to like this one. The story is engaging, the voice acting is great, the music is awesome. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985172866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1480841958}
review: This game is an absolutely amazing experience for anyone who enjoys point and click adventures. It has compelling characters, puzzles that make sense (and are rarely frustrating), multiple endings...just get this game. Half price, full price, quarter price, whatever--it's worth every penny.
