author: {'steamid': '76561197997421384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1556609204}
review:
This game is a work of art.  It has a profound atmosphere to it- something that just so perfectly sets the tone with the perfect blend of dystopian future, a sense of doom, and yet also quite wry humor.  The visuals, the dialogue, and the themes all marry together so well.


It would be so hard to fully explain why this game is so magnificent.  The visuals are impressive, the voice acting flawless, the gameplay intellectually challenging but requiring no particular finesse or agility, it is a game that anyone could play.  With multiple endings and some multiple paths, it has a little bit of replay value.  Even for one playthrough of about 5-6 hours though, the price of a movie ticket for this game is a steal.
TL;DR:
10/10, buy this game you ponce.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053561874', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 996, 'last_played': 1480757001}
review:
If you liked those games in the 90s, you will like this one too.
It has an amazing story and multiple endings.
Remember that the good ending is always possible and is not hard to find.
I may play the game again once I forget a little bit the story, just to unlock all achievements.
On second play I will activate the option to check what the game developers have to say about game. These thoughts are accessible in each screen as you walk arround. Unfortunately the background noise in Metropol is slightly louder that their voice.

review:
Great adventure game, very atmospheric and interesting setting. Plot is interesting until the the end and all the stages of the game nicely add to the story. Reminds me of 'Beneath a Steel Sky', which I also thought was excellent.

Puzzles make sense but are variable and not too easy. Good voice acting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063240948', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1480532237}
review:
Worth every penny. The game is just amazing, the voice acting, funny and smart dialogs, characters which will stay with you after you will finish, and world which is just mesmerizing. I just genuinly would love to see with my own eyes Metropolis and Dunes, and especially Goliath. 

And the art. The pixel art in this game just reminds me of Beksinsky work. It's beautiful, dark, full of gorgeous details. This game, for me at least, doesn't have any weak sides. The story is dark, and really gives lots of to think about. It's just a great game and everybody should give a try.

A point and click masterpiece.

Don't let appearances fool you. The rich plot of this game will leave a void in your heart when you realize it's over as the world has been built so thoroughly and carefully that you can't help but want to know more. If you can learn to appreciate the aesthetic, it is definitely worth a play through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993891762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 56, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1527526723}
review:
Obvously, i'm making this review because of the steam awards badge, and i'm not very good at reviews, but don't get me wrong, this is the game, that deserves some praise. 

Primordia brings you to the era of old school quests, and just doesnt want to let you go. The plot seems to be simple at the beginning, but as you spend more time playing it, you realize that it leaves you with so many questions and emotions. And of course the beautiful soundtrack completes the perfect atmosphere and now is forever stored on my PC and phone.

The discount is huge now. Go get that masterpiece.

And yet again, year after, i still nominate this game and update my review for anyone, who loves a good stroy and good music.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960318983', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1480255152}
review:
Amazing game. I'm a huge fan of point and click adventures, been playing them since Monkey Island. This is probably one of the best you can get and just as good as the "classics". Great storytelling and story (which starts with a simple McGuffin making you more and more curious about how everything else unfolds), great atmosphere, great characters and great puzzles.

It's easily worth the full price and a real bargain when on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969912736', 'num_games_owned': 1731, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1472764167}
review:
Where can i start to review this game?
On the surface it's an old shool point-and-click adventure, but the story, the voice acting, the art and the setting are simply amazing.

Set in a post-apocalyptic world where machines have became sentient and capable of build (and re-build) themselves.
In this world, humans are only a fading memory, kept in partially corrupted data gathered by some and spread in a form of a religion.
Most of the world is now covered by the desert, where most of the androids live in a single huge city.
This is the background where Horatio, the protagonist, starts its (his?) journey to find a stolen component of his ship, revealing part of his (and our) past in the process.

The amazing art (all hand-made) and the attention to details of the world makes me heavily recomend this game to any point-and-click adventures fan with a soft spot for the post-apocaliptic setting :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198000105112', 'num_games_owned': 860, 'num_reviews': 216, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92, 'last_played': 1531804219}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089798955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1558980272}
review: Ein starkes Spiel. Leider sind ab und zu die Texte sehr schnell weg, sodass man nicht alles mitbekommt. Aber unbedingt zu empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057878731', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 451, 'last_played': 1468080025}
review:
This beautiful pixel game tells the story of Horatio Nullbuilt, who, in the search of energy for his home, finds something out about his true origin. Set in a dystopia that you just do not want to leave, Primordia offers funny and still emotional writing that comes with a set of diverse characters.
One of the best adventure games I've played in some time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005755819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2417, 'last_played': 1417931486}
review: This is one of my favorite adventure games ever. I loved the old Lucas Arts games like The Dig and this reminds me of those. The characters and story are intriguing and the voice acting is great. I really hope we can get a sequel some day!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971481606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1016, 'last_played': 1481224066}
review: I absolutely love this game!  Not only did they manage to *perfectly* capture the old point & click nostalgia, but they've beefed it up with fantastic voice acting, truly compelling story and a fantastic dash of humour.  I wish there were a lot more games like this around!

author: {'steamid': '76561198117895890', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 744, 'last_played': 1567541094}
review: Are you the sort of person who loves a good point and click, cyberpunk game where robots disscuss complicated politics, metaphysics, theology, Shakespeare and witty banter, all while wandering around a eerie dying earth setting where you try and make sense of a world populated by corrupt, demented machines? Well... you are a person with oddly specific tastes... and your day has come!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982968871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1392229175}
review: Other than a few rough puzzle edges this game is literally perfect. 3 years after playing it I still remember everything very clearly. Diverse characters, interesting dialogue, and a memorable monolithic / derelict world. While I don't want a sequel to this. I would really enjoy another entry in the universe (similar to how the Walking Dead comic is different than Telltale's game).

author: {'steamid': '76561198028175799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1511386849}
review: Primordia is an excellent game. Very reminiscent of the old point & click adventure games you played as a kid. So, if you're looking for a game that makes you feel like a kid again, you've found it

author: {'steamid': '76561198285994376', 'num_games_owned': 141, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 64, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1480215855}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035660930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1480208045}
review: If you're a fan of point and click adventure games, this is definitely something you should pick up. Primordia has excellent characters, a fantastic story, and the graphics are definitely up to par for the game. A few of the puzzles can be a bit tricky, but none are too difficult to necessitate a walkthrough. The game also features multiple endings, which is a definite plus.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993275425', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1517891347}
review: I'm a huge sucker for Point & Click Adventures, especially ones from Wadjet Eye, and this one in particular blew me away. There was something about this world they built, I wanted... no, NEEDED, more from it when I was finished. There aren't many games out there that I can say that about. Truly one of the best stories I've experienced from a Point & Click Adventure in decades.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021717955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 259, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1700682531}
review:
Absolutely fantastic storyline, beautiful pixel art graphics & music (get the soundtrack too, it's also on Bandcamp), no crazy or illogical puzzles.

I already completed Primordia three times before getting it also on Steam and did a fourth run for the Steam achievements.

Still valid in 2023 ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197995522964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1493658633}
review:
A beautifull pixeled adventure with a rather interesting story and an unsually straightforward point and click system

Edit

Now that i have had more time to play and replay, ponder and enjoy this game i have come to realise how much i truly like it, from the story to the art, i dare say we need more games like this, not just as a nostalgic window to pixel art but as genuine pieces that can stand on their own merits. I remained engaged and replayed the game a couple of times, something i seldom do, especially with adventure games.
 In short, give it a try, it will not dissapoint in any way and may even surprise people who never tried the genre

author: {'steamid': '76561198116162251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1485607479}
review:
This was a difficult game to get into, but the story line made it worth it to keep going. It's a similar playstyle to games such as Spy Fox/Freddie Fish/Putt Putt but harder. This is not a game that you play for the graphics. Don't be afraid to google hints for when you're stuck. 

Pros: Plot, humor in the writing

Cons: Graphics, difficulty

review:
26/12/16: EDIT - I've honestly been feeling a bit differently about this game recently - And I've come to actually feel like I can recommend this game.  Namely due to elements (like Crispin) helping you piece together the puzzles and story.

OLD REVIEW
All my problems with the game are equally balanced with the things I liked.

I can't recommend it, because I just didn't like more.

Credit where credit is due, the 'witty sidekick' is actually funny, and that can be really hard to do.  He is surprisingly not annoying.

However, in a post-human, desolate wasteland planet earth.... how did they get so many planks of wood?  How have they not all rotted and decomposed away?

author: {'steamid': '76561198029839679', 'num_games_owned': 893, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 283, 'last_played': 1468680308}
review:
[b]Primordia might be the single best point & click game in existence. It is a classic point & click adventure game set a in post-apocalyptic world with stunning and handcrafted pixel art, outstanding narration and one of the most atmospheric soundtracks you will ever encounter.[/b]

[h1]Graphics:[/h1] Each place you visit during the game offers very well-drawn and thematic pixel art with a good animation quality. More importantly, everything offers a feel of authenticity, which keeps you immersed in this post-apocalyptic sci-fi world.

[h1]Sound, Music & Voice:[/h1] The soundeffects are very decent for a point & click game. What really outshines all else are the soundtrack and the narration. The soundtrack is the most immersive and fitting I've ever encountered in this genre. It has around 40 (!) different tracks, which is very rare to see for such a game. The narration of the two main characters is very well done and their lines vary between fitting, serene and often amusing. In fact, it was so well done that I had to listen to the hints despite having solved a puzzle, just to hear all they had to say!

[h1]Gameplay & Story:[/h1] You control two robot companions, stranded in a post-apocalyptic world, where man has perished and become a myth. Your task is to solve different puzzles in the typical point & click style. Your goal is to repair your broken down ship and leave this world. You will visit different locations within the gameworld to find objects and solve puzzles which consist in many cases of applying one or two items to a certain location. Many of the puzzles are challenging but fair. Only for a few I had to go 'pixel hunting' and click everything on the screen to find what I was looking for. Should you have trouble solving a puzzle, your trusty robot companion at your side will always have a few hints for you ready!
The world is incredibly well built and the story kept me glued to the screen until I reached one of the many endings after around 12 hours.

[h1]Funfactor:[/h1] I enjoyed this game more than any other point & click adventure game I have ever played. In my opinion it even outshines the well praised Machinarium. Minor gripes were some technical issue while trying to launch the game for the first time.

[h1]Verdict: [/h1][b]MUST BUY![/b] Amazing world, story, pixel art, narration and soundtrack. If you have not played this game yet, it is my personal favourite point & click of all times. A must to play!

author: {'steamid': '76561198301450732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1478755555}
review:
First off, I highly recommend this game.

Pros:  Fun play experience, decent storytelling, fairly decent voicing of characters, game was priced fairly well.

Cons: Some of the clickables in game aren't readily apparent and in one instance incredibly easy to overlook (elevator control panel at one point in game is a prime example). The game is short (I really wish it had been longer, I didn't want it to end. The game is able to be completed in under 2 hours.)

It's pretty rare when I find a game that I enjoy as much as this one.  It is fairly reminiscent of Septerra Core, which is a major plus.  The game is well polished and priced quite well for the level of enjoyment you get playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025184357', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1558815596}
review:
Won this in a contest and picked it out cause good reviews and I like adventure games.

It's a point and click adventure game with an older sprite style and more detailed Giger-esque backgrounds. Overall I would reccomend it.

Pros:
>Good story - robot society after humans are gone
>Variety of characters with personality
>Easy to get around - you can walk and you have a map that teleports you to key spots.
>Puzzle quality and variety - From building tools to opening doors to judging court cases I can't think of a point that really struck me as needing unintuitive logic to solve.
>Hint system - robot buddy that you can ask for puzzle suggestions, usually helpful
>Takes notes for you - game jots down important information for you, which can help for puzzles. Couple spots you might still need pen and paper to work something out, though.
>Hot keys for menu stuff
>Does a good job getting into your thought processes - a few puzzles with multiple solutions, some puzzles animated to let you try something even though it doesn't actually work.
>Flavor text - if you like subtle characterization and banter, you can look at most everything for description stuff.
>Multiple saves - Save whenever you want however much you like.

Cons:
>Can't easily get out of item use - have to go into inventory to get your regular cursor back (hot key makes it bearable)
>Some pixel hunting - at least one puzzle where you need to notice a small, muddy colored item in a dark, muddy colored area
>Hints aren't always helpful - sometimes it hints what you know you need to find, not how or where to find it. Other times it's so obtuse that it's really no help at all.
>One or two puzzles that use a game feature only once - ran into one that required using the describe feature, which I didn't know was there and which had never been necessary to get info about items or progress puzzles before then.
>Loading issue - due to the chosen game engine, can't load saves past your 20th most recent save. Have to delete saves to get the one you want in that 1-20 section.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986753054', 'num_games_owned': 959, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 817, 'last_played': 1476977045}

The puzzles aren't difficult but they aren't all "casual" either--a very nice middle: keeps the game flowing without it getting boring.

I loved the allegory.

This is a must-play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003564916', 'num_games_owned': 1241, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 557, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 557, 'last_played': 1558827008}
review: I really enjoyed this point 'n click! It had a rich and immersive story, and very decent puzzles that were logical and challenging. The art was really cool, if just a little bit void of color. But taking place in a post apocalyptic era usually does that. The characters were diverse and unique and very relatable. The comic relief wasn't [i]too[/i] annoying. And he gave actual helpful hints if you get stuck. Also, the voice acting was actually really well done! Not neeeearly as cheesey as some other ones out there. The story, though, is what really held me. Its got an awesome spin on robot society and what they would "believe." It also has multiple endings and multiple ways to solve puzzles, so good replay value. And if you like achievements, it's an easy 100%. You can tell a lot of love went into making this... It's not one you will soon forget!

author: {'steamid': '76561198251084562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1476330449}

Mientras la juegues estar√°s reflexionando continuamente sobre una multitud de temas muy interesantes como.... mira, compra el puto juego y prep√°rate para pasar tres o cuatro tardes disfrutando de √©l y de tu mente.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003670246', 'num_games_owned': 388, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1504982995}
review:
Wow, that was really great!

I think it just takes the title of my favourite point and click game, it has great story, with many endings, the characters are done wonderfuly, voice acting is one of the best I've heard, I love the voices and dialogues/monologues. The artstyle is great, shame it isn't in great resolution.

The only thing I don't really like about this game (other might like it) is difficulty of this game. Puzzles are nice and hard, which I like, but some of them are just too hard, sometimes items or places of interaction are really small, or hard to find, overall it's easy to get stuck in this game. I used guide more times than on dark seed or I have no mouth and i must scream, really.

tl;dr
Overall, it's great game, great story, characters, voice acting and artstyle, but gamers who don't like puzzles will need to use guide, a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152189027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1475946628}
review:
A very well made game with a cool story. I liked the retro look and game play as well. Some parts I found to be a bit criptic/unclear but overall it was fun figuring out the assorted puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980497191', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1476051447}
review: This point-and-click starts off slow but once it gets going really drags you in. The puzzles are fun and sometimes challenging without getting frustrating. The humor in the dialogue is great and the actual story is pretty interesting as well. This game has a strong atmosphere that reminds me of old games like Falout and Syberia and if you like either this is definitely worth checking out. I wouldn't recommend purchasing this at fullprice though, as 10‚Ç¨ seems a bit steep. 5‚Ç¨ is definitely the correct price for a game like this. Anything below it is a steal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198235851916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1551239347}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051329300', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 587, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1476632871}
review:
Primordia is a point and click adventure game where you help Horatio to get back his power core that a evil robot took..... I mean stole from him ;) There are many nice puzzels and dialouges in the game and you can get many diffrent endings on the game. 

Pros:
-Nice puzzels
-Some humor
-Horatios sidekick Crispin
-Good dialouges with voice acting (that you can turn of if you dont like to hear voices)
-Good story with diffrent endings
-Many achivments for achivment hunters

Cons:
-Some achivments are really hard to get
-The grapic is okay, sometimes is hard to see things (its not bad)
-No resolution settings

A great game you defently should pick up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014383097', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1475889405}
review:
Enthralling from the very beginning.

Lovable characters, great banter between them, and a world that alludes to a rich history will make the setting one of your favourite.

Highly recommend this game

author: {'steamid': '76561198005351852', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 625, 'last_played': 1475885398}
review:
When I saw this game, it has some interesting feels on it and when I found out it is like those old school point and click games, I decided to get this one since I didn't play one of those for long time, most were some kids game or other, but this one has nice apocalyptic mood on it and I love it's visual style.

The controls are simple, just point and click, getting into inventory is simple as moving my mouse up to see it and if I ever feel lost what to do next, I just need to ask someone what they would do.

This game also feature the multiple endings, but I don't know yet how much there is since I did play for couple of hours.

If my review is pretty confusing, I don't blame you.
When I review MY reviews, I'm thinking myself: "What was I talking about"
So I put some pros, neutrals and cons with reasons on this game.

PROS
+ Art style
It has nice pixel art style like those old school point and click games and I like the designs of the characters and others

+ Voice acting
Like any other point and click games (or any games) they have voice acting and they sound pretty good or even well done in my opinion, especially Crispin being sarcastic and mostly paranoid about like giant cannibal robot.

+ Good sidekick
Like I said about Crispin, I like his charming punchlines and sarcastic nature.
He also is reliable on certain area where you need get something or get somewhere, he even give some ideas what to do next

+ Puzzles
Who doesn't like puzzles, not you?
Then why did you pick this game, if you don't like puzzles?
Anyway, this game mostly puzzle on certain parts where you have to either combine, poke with it, ask or anything else and this game is not like you can get stuck forever, you just need to think about what would you do or first gather info and then figure it out or ask Crispin what would he do on that, not like he straightforward tells you, but suggest something.

+Robots
It's about robots

NEUTRALS
= Story
This game has that simple story, I wont spoil anything else, but the beginning, you are Horatio who is trying to rebuild the crashed ship to fly with it, but then some big unknown floating robot comes to ship, shoots you and steal your power core, after that you woke up and decided to do something about it.
Welp, I'm not usually care about the story, but it is huge part of this game, but I don't usually follow it or even "know" does story make good sense, so that's why I put it as neutral because... I'm terrible to review the story part.

= glitchs and bugs
there are some minor bugs and glitch on this game, but it's not severe or annoying, it's just there and it wont stop you to continue to play this game, just some quick freezing that you almost don't notice all the time and other rare glitches.

CONS
- Games length
I do admit, it does make the game longer since you have to figure out the puzzles, but when you finish the game on first time, you just know almost all of it and you can just blow this game maybe almost under of hour, unless you think there is still something missing in it.

CONCLUSION
I really like this game, too bad it is short, but it did took me over 5 hour to pass it first time and it is pretty addicting since I did played nonstop from 22:00 PM to 4:30 AM.
It has only one cons in my opinion and that is not even a huge problem and I think this game pretty great since art style is beautiful and progression interesting on it.

In other words, this game is worth for your attention if you like point and click games.

Welp, that's all for now.

Doktor Greenman, logging out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126868637', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 546, 'last_played': 1484858581}
review:
I'm a little late on this one but I just felt the need to leave a review on it.

I grew up playing point&click adventure games, and I played pretty much all of the 90's classics, so unfortunatly nowadays it can be quite hard for me to find a game that keeps up with the expectations I have for this kind of games but I can tell you that Primordia is on par with the best games of this genre. 
It's a blast of joy and nostalgia to play a title like this that makes me feel like a kid again exploring a new awesome unknown world.

Primordia has a Beneath a Steel Sky vibe to it that instantly got me hooked, but even if you didn't play any of the older point&click titles Primordia would be a great place to start because it's so damn charming!

The story of the game is engaging and well-written, the soundtrack and voice-acting is great, the characters are memorable and make you feel attached to them.
The game puzzles are not too hard but they offer a good challenge, although this may vary from person to person depending on the experience you have with this genre.

The only downside I can think of is that the game is a bit short but the multiple endings and achievements give Primordia a good degree of replayabilty that other games lack.

This game is a MUST-PLAY, and I just want to thank Wormwood Studios and Wadjet Eye Games for this amazing experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034086983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1475992953}
review: Fantastic

author: {'steamid': '76561198018042499', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1475811809}
review:
This game was surprisingly amazing. Not only does it look and work like a great 90's point and click game like Full Throttle, it actually FEELS like one. While playing it I constantly forgot that it wasn't a classic game from decades ago. The art, story, characters, dialogues and puzzles are all fantastic. The past years I haven't had much patience for these kinds of games (even though I used to love them) mostly because I can rarely get engaged enough with the story and characters to keep playing and paying attention to long conversations. In Primordia every single piece of dialogue is very interesting and mysterious, revealing more about the world and its history, or it's just plain witty and funny. The puzzles are great too, very intuitive most of the time. The hint system is pretty good too, not breaking immersion and sometimes just the right push in the right direction. I used hints a few times and rarely felt like I was cheating, so that's pretty great.

TL;DR - Primorida is an amazing game, but <SystemUser> is welcome to select their own terminology.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025774687', 'num_games_owned': 1080, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1475824823}
review: I have just finished the story, but I am still missing some content. However, I felt the need to write a review right now because this game has simply enthralled me so deeply in its lore and characters in such a short amount of time that I would absolutely reccomend this masterpiece. I chuckled at some of the references, and the witty replies of your "trusty sidekick", and I say: pick this game up right now, it's so worth the price!

author: {'steamid': '76561198209667324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1475801382}
review:
Story: 9/10
Design: 3/10
I came for the story, because I don't like retro-pixel-games in general. But the story was good, I loved it. I loved the characters and the atmosphere. Also yes, some of the puzzlez were hard to the point where I asked myself 'how should I have figured that?'. Nevertheless, I managed to get to the end and  [spoiler]look through all three endings. [/spoiler]
But oh-my-god the choise of the font. You can't take the text with the font like this out of the box expecting it to look good. Comic sans would look nicer, honestly. (Or Courier.) Fallout 1-2 put the text into the box, and it looks whole and readable. On the other side, maybe it's a problem of expectable screen resolution. Text looks jammed and chewed. WIth other stuff I can live.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031759923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1654980325}
review: If you took a little from Grim Fandango, Fallout 2, and Planescape: Torment, melted them down till they were completely mixed together and poured that into a retro-style pixel-art adventure game, you would have something close to Primordia. I was really glad to discover this game, even though it took me years past its release. The setting is intriguing, the characters well defined, the music and voice acting impressive, and the visual art style really holds up in that retro way. If I had to find something to critique it would simply be that I wish there was more of Primordia to explore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003615331', 'num_games_owned': 323, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1709345080}

author: {'steamid': '76561198259446899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1475731459}
review: It's the end of 2016 and I just finished this game. Wow! What an amazing story. It's this kind of depth that we're missing in so many new games. The story gets you hooked immediately and the puzzles are well-crafted and fun. Hope to see more games like this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071261553', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1475648212}
review:
‚ÄãPrimordia √© um jogo de point-and-click no estilo bem das antigas mesmo, feito na saudosa engine Adventure Game Studio e √© altamente reminiscente dos jogos cl√°ssicos da Lucas Arts. A tem√°tica do jogo √© p√≥s-apocal√≠ptica, toda a humanidade foi exterminada da face da terra e tudo o que sobrou foram os rob√¥s que os seres humanos constru√≠ram, e tamb√©m os rob√¥s que foram constru√≠dos por outros rob√¥s. Os pr√≥prios rob√¥s s√£o a √∫nica for√ßa na terra que os mant√©m sobre opera√ß√£o, eles se auto reparam e at√© constroem outros rob√¥s a partir de partes de coletadas dos escombros e lixo do mundo. Como o menos complexo e menos avan√ßado n√£o pode gerar o mais complexo e  mais avan√ßado, isso gera uma cadeia de degenera√ß√£o em que os rob√¥s v√£o ficando mais decr√©pitos e desgastados com cada gera√ß√£o conforme eles pr√≥prios caminham, lentamente, para serem tamb√©m finalmente apagados da exist√™ncia junto de seus criadores humanos.

Voc√™ experiencia a est√≥ria atrav√©s dos olhos de (Ou o termo correto seriam receptores oculares?) Horatio Nullbuilt, um rob√¥ eremita que habita uma aeronave destru√≠da no meio do deserto. O objetivo de Horatio √© restaurar sua nave, ele tem o sonho de voar, mas o n√∫cleo de for√ßa da nave √© roubado de Horatio por um rob√¥ coletador; Scrapper. Nisso Horatio √© for√ßado a perseguir esse inimigo para tentar recuperar seu n√∫cleo de for√ßa, vital para tanto o funcionamento da nave como para o abastecimento de energia do pr√≥prio Horatio, sem o n√∫cleo Horatio pararia de funcionar.

O jogo tem um ambiente pesado e triste, a arte do jogo tem uma qualidade muito alta; os personagens e o plano de fundo dos ambientes s√£o todos muito bem desenhados, o jogo tem toda uma est√©tica bem original e muito bonita. Toda essa qualidade nas ilustra√ß√µes do jogo refor√ßam a atmosfera s√≥lida de tristeza e desola√ß√£o que o jogo exala.

Essa qualidade est√©tica do jogo sofre, todavia, n√£o por erros do desenhista das sprites e background arts; mas sim por limites relacionados a engine do jogo. Como eu mencionei, Primordia foi feito na Adventure Game Studio e essa engine √© muito antiga e tem limita√ß√µes muito extremas para os padr√µes atuais, a mais gritante delas sendo a resolu√ß√£o de tela muito baixa. Durante as cutscenes em que o foco se aproxima mais do personagens √© poss√≠vel ver claramente como a qualidade da arte do jogo √© muito maior do que a baixa resolu√ß√£o nativa nos permite enxergar.

Apesar da premissa deprimente de Primordia, o tom geral dele √© muito menos "pra baixo" do que ele poderia ter sido. H√° tamb√©m muitos momentos c√¥micos entrela√ßados na hist√≥ria gra√ßas aos di√°logos entre o personagem principal, Horatio, e o seu fiel companheiro que ele pr√≥prio construiu; Crispin. Enquanto Horatio faz o papel do personagem mais s√©rio, Crispin √© o personagem mais engra√ßado que faz varios coment√°rios engra√ßados sobre os eventos e outros personagens os quais os nossos her√≥is encontram durante sua aventura. Esse tom de com√©dia ajuda muito a aliviar o peso da premissa do jogo, tanto para o bem e para mal que isso implica.

Os personagens do jogo s√£o todos eles muito interessantes e bem escritos. Crispin, por exemplo, recebe atrav√©s do arco de sua hist√≥ria majoritariamente marcada por momentos engra√ßados um desenvolvimento surpreendentemente s√©rio e heroico no final. A pr√≥pria antagonista do jogo √© um personagem bem equilibrado no sentido de que, apesar de suas a√ß√µes parecerem mal√©volas a primeira vista, ela tem raz√µes l√≥gicas e razo√°veis para agir da forma que age e faz v√°rios argumentos at√© bem fundados.

Existem muitos outros personagens √∫nicos e memor√°veis no jogo tamb√©m, mas o que pessoalmente mais me cativou foi um que participou muito pouco da hist√≥ria, o apropriadamente nomeado; Sad Robot. Ele √© um rob√¥ de programa√ß√£o aparentemente corrompida, ou extremamente simpl√≥ria, que espera solit√°rio e paciente por algo que nunca vai acontecer e √© imposs√≠vel fazer ele perceber e entender isto. Achei ele algo metaf√≥rico da condi√ß√£o humana.

De fato os personagens que povoam o mundo do jogo brilham tanto que ofuscam o personagem principal. O Horatio, personagem principal, em si pode at√© n√£o ser o personagem mais interessante da trama, mas enquanto protagonista; enquanto her√≥i, a√≠ sim ele pode ser tamb√©m visto sobre angulos interessantes quando comparado com os her√≥is de outros v√≠deo games. Horatio √© quase um anti-her√≥i, ele n√£o est√° afim de aventura, ele n√£o quer salvar o mundo, ele n√£o usa da for√ßa bruta e nunca parte pra briga, ele n√£o tem interesse em matar nenhum vil√£o; ele √© simplesmente algu√©m que quer sobreviver e restaurar a sua aeronave, para completar ambos esses objetivos ele precisa resgatar um item que lhe foi roubado.

A est√≥ria do jogo √© definitivamente o ponto mais forte, ela √© marcada por personagens carism√°ticos e √∫nicos. A atmosfera do jogo √© segurada bem firmemente pela alta qualidade da m√∫sica e da arte visual e do voice acting, e o conjunto desses elementos √© algo que fortalece ainda mais o efeito de uma est√≥ria que por si s√≥ j√° √© interessante e bem escrita. Analisando ela do come√ßo ao fim √© poss√≠vel ver como ela foi bem pensada e tamb√©m bem realizada, os eventos s√£o amarrados de maneira muito boa atrav√©s da trama, coisas que os personagens dizem no come√ßo da aventura se tornam muito mais significantes √† luz dos eventos no final do jogo. Os mon√≥logos que os personagens lan√ßam nos v√°rios finais poss√≠veis s√£o altamente reflexivos e bem escritos e refletem bem a perspetiva dos personagens atrav√©s dos eventos que se passaram. Se trata obviamente de uma est√≥ria que foi escrita com muito amor e esmero.

Os √∫nicos pontos verdadeiramente negativos que eu tenho contra o game est√£o contidos no seu gameplay: At√© os melhores games point-and-click sempre tem esse ou aquele quebra-cabe√ßa que n√£o faz sentido absolutamente nenhum, geralmente resultado de o jogador ter que usar de uma solu√ß√£o que requer uma l√≥gica totalmente absurda que s√≥ fez sentido na cabe√ßa do designer. √â nesse quebra-cabe√ßa maldito em que voc√™ vai agarrar e n√£o conseguir progredir mais na hist√≥ria sem consultar um 'walkthrough' na internet. Quando voc√™ tem que fazer isso, voc√™ inevitavelmente se sente menos investido no gameplay do jogo. O Primordia em si faz at√© um bom trabalho em impedir que o jogador tenha que consultar a internet para se desagarrar de um puzzle, faz isso usando um sistema de dicas atrelado ao seu parceiro Crispin. Todavia, houve um puzzle relacionado a um terminal em que eu simplesmente n√£o vi l√≥gica absolutamente nenhuma e a dica que o Crispin deu em rela√ß√£o a ele foi praticamente in√∫til, mesmo depois de ter olhado a solu√ß√£o na internet eu ainda fiquei sem ver como √© que o designer do puzzle esperava que eu fosse adivinhar a solu√ß√£o.

Primordia definitivamente tem a minha recomenda√ß√£o, se trata de um cl√°ssico moderno dos point-and-click, mas o que mais brilha nele n√£o √© qualquer coisa inerente ao g√™nero point-and-click ou mesmo aos video games, o que brilha nele √© o seu enredo; ele conta uma hist√≥ria que seria ador√°vel em qualquer meio. √â um jogo que "passa por baixo do radar", n√£o recebe o reconhecimento e aten√ß√£o que realmente merece, mas os poucos que conhecem ele sabem que se trata de uma obra-prima, um cult-classic (n√£o √© atoa que o mesmo est√° entre os 100 jogos mais bem avaliados da Steam). Primordia, apesar de n√£o ser t√£o conhecido hoje, sem d√∫vida ser√° vindicado pela hist√≥ria. Daqui a vinte anos muitos poucos se lembrar√£o dos jogos de grandes t√≠tulos que hoje muito vendem tais como Halo ou Gears of War, mas quem jogou Primordia, dele se lembrar√°.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049701098', 'num_games_owned': 3699, 'num_reviews': 832, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1475683259}
review:
Wormwood Studios made their introduction onto Steam a memorable one with Primordia, a post-apocalyptic sci-fi point and click title. You will guide Horatio Nullbuilt through the futuristic, rusty dystopian wasteland known as Primordia. Horatio, and his floating comic-relief sidekick Crispin, need to get their stolen power core back; either that, or face death when their charges run dry and they shut down. They soon find out that getting their power core back is the least of their worries, as there's an entire city known as Metropol that's run by a corrupted master computer.

As you wander the lonely, desolate landscape of Primordia, you will come across many robots to interact with. Some of them are self-aware, some of them utter their pre-programmed responses, some will become friends, and some will be enemies. Man has ceased to exist for many years, though the exact timeframe is undetermined, but long enough for them to have vanished into legend. Horatio is a believer in Humanism, a religion that sees man as god; he even carries his copy of the Gospel of Man with him. The story is absolutely stunning, and the same can be said for the dialogue; I will forego delving any further into either so that you may truly enjoy the experience for yourself.

This is another point and click title that is obscure in its puzzle solving. There are many times that you will need an item which is hidden in a place that you'd never think to look. For people like me that completely suck with even the simple point and clicks, a guide will absolutely be necessary. However, for more advanced enthusiasts of the genre, you're in for a real challenge and treat. Every puzzle is a "think outside the box" type, and very few are expected or familiar. Even a large portion of the achievements are enigmatic. With a guide, you're looking at about 5-6 hours of playtime, without one you'll easily approach 10 hours.

The artwork of Primordia is done in a monochromatic rusty theme, for the most part consisting of dark browns and dirty oranges. There are subtle glimpses of neon reds and blues, and some places that are steel grey, but they're few and far between. The art does a fantastic job in bringing out the feeling that everything is coated in thick layers of rust, dirt, and sand, and that humans have been dead for centuries. Likewise, the pockmarks on Horatio and many other characters and places conveys the likelihood of near-constant acid rain. The melancholic, dismal, void-of-life atmosphere of the title is both exceedingly strong and somehow calming. The soundtrack is comprised of ambient, semi-industrial tracks that compliment the art wonderfully.

If you've been holding off on grabbing Primordia, stop waiting and just go for it. You simply cannot rob yourself of a detailed, highly immersive experience such as this one. Truly one of the greatest point and click adventure games of the modern era, Primordia is the complete package; visuals, audio, enjoyable characters, story, dialogue, and challenging gameplay. Even though it's a steal at $10.99 CAD, you can also find it on sale for $2.19 CAD at times, either one is a huge bargain.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071982834', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1640860581}
review:
First let me start off by saying that the reason I have not written a review for this masterpiece sooner is simply because I didnt feel like I could do it justice. I still dont feel like I can do that, but I will take a shot. 

It is easily my favourite point and click, I love everything about it, from the artwork to the story to the voice acting. The only thing I wish they would improve on is the fact that they are not going to make any more content in Primordia's universe. This game truely is a gem though, and for its price even more so I would say that if you love story games, or want to try one, Primordia is one of the best choices out there. 

Sorry for the crap review.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983179230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1601239458}
review:
This is what a point-and-click adventure should be. Story, characters, dialogue, challenging puzzles, atmosphere, art style. The only bad thing about this game is that it eventually ends. Until that point, it is an absolute treasure.

The banter between Horatio and Crispin is probably the best part of the story. Anyone who was ever a fan of the classic Lucasarts point-and-click adventures should get this game at once.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965502125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1474771295}
review: An excellent point-and-click. Truly engaging characters and top-notch storytelling. There's a constant hinting at a rich backstory which fits perfectly into the narrative. It hooked me from the start and I basically just plowed through it from the moment I installed it. I wished it could have gone on and on in spite of the wonderfully satisfying ending(s). Just looking at the images on the store page makes me miss the bleak yet beautifully drawn landscapes and locales.

review: I've reached a point where I trust WadjetEye published games to be awesome stories with mechanics that enhance the experience and don't get in the way. This was no exception. It's a great game, has great characters, a story that keeps you thinking, and and ending that came too soon. Hope Wormwood Studios does a follow up some day.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980389987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1471655397}
review:
This game is inspired.  If you like realistic sci-fi stories then buy this.  Primordia is thought-provoking and engrossing from start to finish.  So few games can build up hype and then exceed your expectations, but for me Primordia did.  This game starts with great art and characters, then weaves a deep world full of inspired lore, and closes with some encounters that left me marveling at the game's writing.  Without spoiling anything, I was not expecting the dialogue in the antagonist encounter to be that effective and it completely caught me off-guard.

My only complaint is that there were one or two places where click-able objects weren't clear enough.  The actual puzzles all make sense and they range from simple crafting to serious lateral thinking.  Also I suppose the game would have benefitted from a few additional animations for some of the weightier plot moments, but that's forgiveable.

Can't recommend this game enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994291527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1473449134}

author: {'steamid': '76561198006314495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1472765641}

author: {'steamid': '76561197992615560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 561, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 561, 'last_played': 1472614742}
review:
If story is more important for you in a game than mechanics or visuals than you will enjoy Primordia as it is a decently written story.

> Great game lore / interesting setting
> Great plot and semi twist if you don't see it coming, I enjoyed the little seeds throughout the game like the ship being named "UNIIC" [SPOiLER] (VGER anyone?).
If the writer reads this not that I minded the ending but I think the twist would have had even more punch if Horus had followed through with his mission instead of Metromind carrying it out, big bad being the big bad is not as fun of a twist as the good guy was the bad guy. Would have made the final choice more interesting and a more interesting realization for the player "I'm a humanist trying to save humanity but I killed them?", my two cents as a wannabe writer, was still good though
[/Spoiler]
> Main character deals with interesting themes, and can choose different paths, "Progress needs transformation needs art needs freedom" reminded me of 'what can change the nature of a man' from Planescape: Torment... was interesting to think about it, as were the logical arguments of the robots
> Sidekick character is more funny and likeable than most comedic relief companion characters, reminded me a lot of Morte from Planescape:Torment while still being unique and memorable as his own character [Spoiler] I felt a great deal of loss after he died, almost found myself getting angry like the main character and strongly felt his absense in the scenes following his death, great immersion!
[/spoiler]

Mild Cons:
> Puzzles were okay, not overly hard or easy. I enjoyed the logic puzzles more so than go search a map for random item (I could see others minding those quests less), the wingman quest though had me chuckle
> Game is short, 9 hrs for me with frequent pauses leaving the game running while I took breaks
> Graphics are reto pixels but not bad if you zoom out, took my eyes a bit to adjust in the beginning

For me money well spent, memorable story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022793090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 593, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1536831197}
review:
"Until we realize that things might not be we cannot realize that things are" a great poet once said.

I have to admit that I didn't fully enjoy Primordia on my recently finished first playthrough (there will be more) - it started excellent so the further into the story I got, the more I was waiting for it to disappoint me. But it didn't. 

It's somewhat ironic, that game so "retro" - from it's visual form, through mechanics, to themes - feels so fresh. After playing so many contemporary adventure and semi-adventure games it's nice to see that there are people who don't see stories just as shiny boxes filled with emotions. Instead of killing some characters who got a lot of screen time to make viewer shed a tear and considering job well done, Primordia focuses on building an atmosphere, allowing emotions to occur naturally, and, what is recently rare in storytelling, tells a story. Rather than having a bunch of characters hoping from place to place pushed by expendable plot, the game has a topic which it wills to explore.

I might say, that Primordia is philosophical, that it's meditating upon metaphysical themes, but we may not quite understand each other, since the meaning of word "philosophical" has devalued. The game isn't trying to make some "social commentary" or present a political concept, but it asks fundamental questions, questions that, one may say, are ancient. But, as a (great) poet once said, only weighty ideals live long enough to be called ancient.

Every element of Primoridia harmonizes with each other. Unique and rich world isn't original only for originality's sake - a wasteland world where robot's seek their raison d'√™tre, a city ideologically based on vague and hollow Progress, a court where the judge has two advisers - justice and mercy, the Gospel of Man which was given to robots by their creators... Primordia becomes more like a biblical parable than a typical belletristic story.

The meaning of life, the wonder of existence, presence of evil in the world, relationship between creation and creator, between robots and man, between man and God - Primordia not only mentions these themes, but also discusses them. It reminds us why people used to tell each other stories. It was because they had something to say.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082219313', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 667, 'last_played': 1472571185}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999920602', 'num_games_owned': 701, 'num_reviews': 622, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1479168185}

author: {'steamid': '76561198146068002', 'num_games_owned': 773, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1516861957}
review:
This was an interesting game. Don't be fooled by the endings you think you see. Somehow, I managed to mess up the game so badly that I only got sad endings. These are the endings that no one talks about. The endings where the main character's friends are all dead, and he goes back to his ship, and reprograms himself to forget about what happened at the city. The ending when he has nothing left to live for.
Yet, I have seen other playthroughs where he manages to save his friends, and the ending is full of hope. It all depends on you. Will you save your friends? Will you join the AI who ruined your life? It is all your choice.
and in the end, what does it mean to be human?

author: {'steamid': '76561198044934933', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 608, 'last_played': 1534861586}
review:
[h1]Dystopia w≈õr√≥d Point 'n Click[/h1]

"Klikane" przygod√≥wki kojarzy≈Çy mi siƒô zazwyczaj z kolorowƒÖ oprawƒÖ i weso≈ÇƒÖ historyjkƒÖ. WyjƒÖtkowo≈õƒá Primordii wynika z bycia przeciwie≈Ñstwem takich gier. Na ekranie dominujƒÖ odcienie brƒÖzu i szaro≈õci, a historia oraz soundtracki przygnƒôbiajƒÖ zamiast uprzyjemniaƒá nam pobyt w ≈õwiecie gry. Czy warto zainwetsowaƒá 40 z≈Çotych w tytu≈Ç, kt√≥ry ma predyspozycje do wywo≈Çania u odbiorcy depresji?


[h1]"Man built us to build"[/h1]

Wormwood Studios wykreowa≈Ço bardzo interesujƒÖcƒÖ wizjƒô przysz≈Ço≈õci, o ile inne tytu≈Çy wykorzystujƒÖ postapokaliptyczne ≈õwiaty do zaprezentowania ludzi walczƒÖcych o przetrwanie w niekorzystnych warunkach, tutaj na ≈õwiecie ludzie ju≈º dawno wymarli. Pozosta≈Çy jedynie roboty, kt√≥rym nie przeszkadza zatrute powietrze, brak ≈ºywych organizm√≥w (no, mo≈ºe poza "nie≈õmiertelnymi" karaluchami) czy kwa≈õne, radioaktywne deszcze. Roboty te tworzƒÖ swego rodzaju spo≈Çecze≈Ñstwo, budujƒÖ nowe roboty, wykonujƒÖ funkcje takie jak
sprzedawanie d√≥br, pozyskiwanie energii lub wydawanie osƒÖd√≥w. Niekt√≥re z nich nawet wierzƒÖ w Ludzi, nazywajƒÖc ich swoimi bogami lub perfekcyjnymi maszynami, kt√≥re rozpoczƒô≈Çy Primordium budujƒÖc pierwszego robota na swoje podobie≈Ñstwo. Inne natomiast, uwa≈ºajƒÖ Ludzi za mit wymy≈õlony specjalnie po to, aby uzasadniƒá to, ≈ºe Postƒôp mia≈Ç kiedy≈õ sw√≥j poczƒÖtek. Jednak nasza przygoda nie zaczyna siƒô w centrum tego wszystkiego, a na odludziu (odrobociu?), na pustyni gdzie nasz protagonista pr√≥buje posk≈Çadaƒá sw√≥j statek do kupy.


[h1]Horatio Nullbuilt, version 5[/h1]

PoczƒÖtek naszej podr√≥≈ºy ma miejsce na wraku statku UNIIC, kt√≥rego to w≈Ça≈õnie sterowany przez nas bohater pr√≥buje naprawiƒá. Bohaterem tym jest Horatio, zakapturzony robot wyglƒÖdajƒÖcy jak pustelnik. W naszych zmaganiach pomagam nam Crispin, ma≈Çy inteligentny robocik, skonstruowany przez Horatio. Nie posiada ko≈Ñczyn, ale potrafi lewitowaƒá, dziƒôki czemu pomaga nam, gdy trzeba zajrzeƒá do trudnodostƒôpnego miejsca. Potrafi tak≈ºe szyderczo dogadywaƒá bohaterowi, co dodaje walor√≥w humorystycznych dialogom pomiƒôdzy nimi dwoma. W grze zagadki sƒÖ do≈õƒá wymagajƒÖce, jednak Crispin podpowiada nam od czasu do czasu, gdy mamy jaki≈õ du≈ºy problem z odnalezieniem odpowiedzi. Kontakt z rozumnymi formami nie ogranicza siƒô jedynie do Horatio i jego ma≈Çego kompana, na naszej drodze spotykamy r√≥≈ºne inne roboty, ka≈ºde z wyjƒÖtkowymi, zapadajƒÖcymi w pamiƒôƒá osobowo≈õciami. To wszystko sprawia, ≈ºe ≈Çatwo jest siƒô wczuƒá w klimat i bogactwo ≈õwiata Primordii.


[h1]Warto![/h1]

A rzeczywi≈õcie jest siƒô w co wczuwaƒá, tajemniczo mroczna, wywo≈ÇujƒÖca trwogƒô muzyka, t≈Ça, kt√≥re sƒÖ piƒôkne na sw√≥j obrzydliwy i przyt≈ÇaczajƒÖcy spos√≥b, zagadki, kt√≥rych rozwiƒÖzanie daje poczucie satysfakcji oraz historia, kt√≥ra pokazuje nam innƒÖ perspektywƒô, o kt√≥rej nigdy by≈õmy nie pomy≈õleli. Gra posiada kilka zako≈Ñcze≈Ñ, ka≈ºde z nich daje pow√≥d do rozmy≈õla≈Ñ i refleksji. Je≈ºeli umiecie dobrze jƒôzyk angielski, lubicie klimaty sci-fi, nie przeszkadza wam nieprzyjemna atmosfera i lubicie zadawaƒá sobie filozoficzne pytania - to jest tytu≈Ç w sam raz dla was.

author: {'steamid': '76561198183149694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1472163427}
review:
After a total 11 hours of playing, I've finished Primordia. As a point-and-click the gameplay is mainly based on puzzles and some basic crafting, but its steampunk atmosphere, its hughely charismatic characters and its deep and thought-provoking messages are the strongest part in the game.

In general, Primordia creates a powerful discourse about justice, law, charity, industry and energy, community and knowledge, energy and history. Most importantly, about logic and free will. As a player, you are brought to wander in an environment that is partially an echo of men's life, partially an odd representation of robotic life, where to the decay of humanity is counterposed the need for energy of the last city on earth. Every knowledge is lost in the dust, and Metropol, the city where the two protagonists will find themselves in, is a ghost city whose only side still provided with energy is a long road. 

I will be haunted by its finale for a while, also because of its powerful credit OST. It leaves its scars, but worth, worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198326582668', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1591494558}
review: What a great game! The story was easy to follow but gets lost at times. Puzzles are well placed but I found them easy enough not to get fustrated. All round a great story with hilarious dialogue. Worth the money. ^_^

author: {'steamid': '76561198044743387', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1, 'last_played': 1471736140}

Cons:

author: {'steamid': '76561198003114902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1189, 'last_played': 1681189249}
review:
I love the writing, atmosphere, characters, and soundtrack of Primordia. It's a sort of post-apocalyptic dystopian future in which "Man" went extinct in the distant past and robots are all that is left on planet Earth. I liked that a lot of the story went unspoken and has to be pieced together as you play the game, and I find it funny that I have come up with my depiction of the "unspoken" backstory in my own mind. I also thought the voice actor for Horatio was excellent.

That being said, the movement is a bit clunky (even considering that it is a 2.5D retro game) and I wish there were more areas to explore. Also, the game being pixellated did not add much to the experience. I often wonder what the game would look like with hand-drawn sprites instead of pixel sprites (probably much cooler).

Overall, I would recommend Primordia if you have the patience for a point-and-click RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171459646', 'num_games_owned': 1990, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 986, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 986, 'last_played': 1470972110}
review:
A great, if somewhat short game with quality writing and great music. The puzzles (mostly) make a lot of sense, and there are quite a few optional way of advancing in the game and alternate endings.
A must for the adventure genre fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048747188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1564295260}
review:
This is my first point-and-click game and.... im in love. This game got to me, the story, artwork, characters, all of it. This game is funny, the areas are interesting and actually make you want to look around, while not bieng soooo big that you just dont want to be bothered with trying to find all the things. Also, the logic in this game is solid. There are no moments where you use a rubber band and a rock to make a rocket ship or anything. It all made sense as i played through it, and when i was stuck, i was still invested enough to want to keep going.
Also multiple endings that are really awesome. I think that just about covers it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995375910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 983, 'last_played': 1621109612}

author: {'steamid': '76561198052358891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 480, 'last_played': 1679236399}
review:
While I normally don't care for point and click adventure games too much, I highly recommend this one if you like a good story. The world and characters are expertly crafted and for once it seems the game doesn't treat you like an idiot. What I mean by that is holding your hand throughout the game and telling you what to do. You figure it out, however long that takes and I have to say that it makes the game much more rewarding. Many points allow you different ways of continuing on that have different impacts. You can even mess up at things and make certain little side quests uncompleteable. But trust me when I say it doesn't ruin the experience.

I actually felt invested in the characters and I lost a few friends during the game. When I care enough that I stop playing for a minute to just take it in when something big happens, I know the game has done what I wanted of it. The game is actually rather short though and left me with a question about something that doesn't add up, but perhaps I just missed it. 

Overall I would suggest this game to anyone. Oh, and don't look up answers!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961819936', 'num_games_owned': 289, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1470181929}
review: Fantastic characters, setting and story. Meaningful choices with great endings. Beautiful artwork, great soundtrack, and really good voice acting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045796166', 'num_games_owned': 1054, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 853, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 853, 'last_played': 1418743184}
review:
Primordia is a cyberpunk game about faith. Much like in the movie Tron, the main character is a robot with a mission he forgot. A mission given by his own creator, Man.

Primordia is a point-and-click adventure game by Wormwood Studios. The main character is a robot with amnesia, but made for a very significant purpose. It is still his choice to fulfill this purpose. He can be a faithful warrior that defeats the evil progressive mind and unites the robots, or he can run away from it. In the game, the robots live under a totalitarian secularist regime, where the belief that the machines were created by a mysterious being called Man is forbidden. His faith in Man keeps the protagonist alive. It is a very interesting twist for the cyberpunk genre.

The graphics are beautiful, as well as the soundtrack. The voice acting is complete and very well done. The voice of Crispin is the best. The dialogues are funny and the developers opted for a more dynamic gameplay, allowing the player to engage in the story without huge dialogues.

One of the advantages is a map that saves the player a good time that would be wasted wandering around. Another advantage is the "automatic notes", which saves you the trouble of writing down important information. There are several ways to solve the puzzles, and the developers sought to avoid puzzles that are incoherent with the setting. There is a great internal system for tips, preventing players from getting stuck.

If you like games like Beneath a Steel Sky, or games that allow you to immerse in an engaging and deep atmosphere with unique and intriguing stories, you should give a chance to Primordia.

Positive points
* Amazing setting.
* Good writing and voice-acting.

Negative points
* The engine is limited.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042721313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1469945635}
review:
Another great adventure game from Wadjet Eye Games and props to the developers Wormwood Studios. The story is hands down the best part of this game. I could see a movie made out of this story because of how rich and interesting it was. If you liked Gemini Rue, I think you will like this.


Pros:
- Great story
- Good voice acting
- Good artwork

Cons:
- I only had a few issues with some of the puzzles being a little to vague to solve without staring at a screen and thinking for 15 minutes, but it rewards those who like hard puzzles. 
- The only minor bug in this game is that when you shift-tab to view the Steam overlay, the audio/text will not play/appear. I had to restart the game several times and load a save to get around this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079828028', 'num_games_owned': 252, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1469898477}
review: Though challenging at times, the solutions always made logical sense. Primordia is one of the best point-and-click games I have had the pleasure to play through. You are Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot who essentially spends his life dumpster-diving and building from what he can find. Likewise, every piece of information gathered through dialogue and observation has a purpose. This game isn't just "put this on that and see if it works" and it never hands you the answers unless you ask (Crispin acts as an in-game hint giver), and even then, solutions are never simply GIVEN. Crispin is like a hand that'll guide you to the right area, but won't tell you what to do when you're there. Loved the story. I wish there was a sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989328210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1407625930}
review: One of the best point-and-click adventures ever. Story, characters, world, briliant.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035245709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1469830564}
review:
Ok I just finished this and first: this game was horribly crashing until I recently updated it, though unfortunately, I was already at the end of the game.

The story is kind of...sad. Beautiful. The puzzles interesting and fun. I liked Technobabylon more though. Those fucking crashes ruined it for me to an extent...

The end was just...hm. I miss the feeling of a final closure to the beautiful story. I revolted against MetroMind to the very end but the story ending was like....like the authors wished to finish the game early and stopped caring about the script. 

I sensed considerable laziness from the developers in the game, here and there, mainly in the story development. Not in the puzzles though, some of them were sure tough to solve - the kiosk was the worst hurdle and figuring out some codes literally hurt my head. 

Also, the puzzle where you need to answer two robots in answering three questions is broken...in the second question only though. You are asked which of selected statements MUST be true but all of the statements DO NOT NEED TO BE true so I had to find the answer online.

Also, I'm not a good puzzle solver.

All in all...this game DEFINITELY needs more story into it. And the story parts of "Humans destroyed themselves"? Cmon...that's lame. Human destroyed themselves / robots destroyed humans / wars between robots and humans....it's just not original. I mean: the Gospel of man, that is so beautifully written, I swear I read it many times. That is poetic. That was ART!! So was the philosophical laments of the MEMORIUS in the Kiosk. And Crispin! The Dunes! The Goliath!! All beautiful and very original, at least to me. 

Honestly, reading the gospel of man at the start of the game hyped me incredibly. I expected that the game was going to be preseting very hard, unsettling, maybe existential questions in its story. Conflict of religious beliefs among postapocalyptic robots? With philosophical insights and two-sided arguments I can relate to? 
I dig that. 
After reading the gospel of man at the start of the game, I realized that not only the author means the story, he is actually capable of meaning it! But...the story does not really go fully in this direction and remains a "beautiful adventure game" with a great story plot. At the start, I thought "this is going to be a masterpiece" but it was not. To be a masterpiece, it needs even more human soul given to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999303681', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2044, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1705051667}
review: Great little point and click with interesting setting, charachters, and story. The art style is fantastic, and the puzzles were just hard enough for me. Multiple endings and fun acheivements merit a seccond playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049532721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 699, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1469642471}
review: I love point'n'click adventures, but Primordia is only slightly above average. I couldn't immerse myself into the atmosphere and the whole world design was "too human". I didn't believe at all they were robots. All the characters could be replaced by humans (except Metromind, I guess) and you woudn't feel a difference. This is definitelly not my idea of a post-apocalypse AI world. However, the story was nice with interesting characters and a great sense of humour (I am looking at you, Crispin), it is definitely worth a try. 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198067001787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1677935926}
review:
Simplemente precioso, 9.5/10.

Primordia es un juego que consigue mezclar aventura, puzzles, distopia, e incluso humor, de una forma que jam√°s hab√≠a visto. El juego en s√≠ mismo contiene cierta carga de tristeza pues pr√°cticamente todo est√° destruido/decr√©pito, pero, incluso siendo un juego basado en pixel-art, consigue maravillarte con todos los niveles. Todo tiene un contexto y est√° bien construido, la historia est√° magistralmente desarrollada y no tiene agujeros, adem√°s de contar con varios finales. Adem√°s, este juego pondr√° a prueba tu √©tica en ciertas partes.

La m√∫sica, aunque no es lo que m√°s destaca, ciertamente encaja a la perfecci√≥n y m√°s de una vez querr√°s quedarte en una zona para escucharla.

Lo √∫nico que puede tirar a alguien hacia atr√°s es la jugabilidad, en ocasiones puede resultar algo frustrante pues el personaje no se mueve muy r√°pido, y el sistema para usar objetos es un tanto rudimentario.

Otro apartado notable es la dificultad, a la cual le pongo muy alta. No en el sentido de que puedas morir, pues es imposible, si no que los rompecabezas que se nos presentan suelen ser verdaderos rompecabezas, y puedes pasarte mucho tiempo intentando resolver algo. Es m√°s, da igual el orden en el que consigas objetos: no te olvides de uno solo, porque habr√° cosas que las usar√°s todo el juego.

Aqu√≠ acaba mi an√°lisis. Aunque es una historia completamente lineal en la que no tienes casi nada de libertad para desarrollar la historia de diferentes formas, es ciertamente una grand√≠sima experiencia que recomendar√≠a a cualquiera que disfrute de una buena historia.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025482130', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1623044820}
review:
I held of on buying this game for a very long time due to how minimal it seemed, but after playing it I wished I hadn't done so.  This game is as close to flawless as an adventure game can ever be.  It has the best writing and the best soundtrack of any video game I've played and has a surprisingly deep setting and lore to it, which is impressive considering the small size of the game world.  With just a few locations, it creates a realistic world that had me immersed for hours.

The story and atmosphere of the game did a remarkable job of drawing me in and building tension, but where I believe the game stands out the most is in its setting.  The game takes place in a future in which life has long been extinct and Man has become a mythical deity worshipped by the remaining robots that now wander the lifeless desert that covers the earth, or even dismissed altogether as nothing more than legend.  Glass and light have become precious resources and what little remains of human invention is constantly scrapped to build new robots.  This is the kind of creativity that is lacking in most adventure games, and the subtlety with which it was presented was refreshing.

It was surprising to see a post-apocalyptic setting in which humans take only a background role and the nature of the world before is long forgotten.  Rather than barrage the player with the history of the world, Primordia puts the story and gameplay first while allowing players to discover the lore on their own, avoiding many (though not quite all) of the tropes that plague post-apocalyptic, dystopian, and robotic science fiction settings.

The game takes itself seriously and the comic relief exists for the amusement of the characters rather than that of the player, which is a skillful way of keeping the story believable, though Crispin's lines did make me cringe in more than a few points.  The primary cause of the chaotic dystopia is the degradation and corruption of the robots' programming, which becomes increasingly apparent as more of them are encountered.  All of the robots from the days of the humans are dead, insane, or rebuilt to the point of having no memories of the previous era, and the world inhabited by the rusting automotons that remain of civilization is chaotic, unpredictable, and bleak.  The dramatic irony of many characters' situations as well as the limited color palette contribute a depressing and hopeless tone that makes this an especially memorable experience.

Primordia is an essential contribution to the adventure genre of computer games, and one that I will gladly recommend to anyone who has an interest in interactive stories.  If you are considering getting Primordia, then please do yourself a favor and don't make the mistake I made of waiting for several years before buying it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003708563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1468895462}
review:
The story told in Primordia is as deep as the story that is untold. This is a sign of very good quality writting and I cannot reccomend enough to give it a try. The voice acting coupled with a few sound effects, and a very good soundtrack helps the story telling a lot.

Gameplay wise, there isn't much to say as the point and click adventure game nature kinda limits its possibilities. However, I noticed that some puzzle have several solutions, you can sometime use you sidekick to do things for you or just left click on him for a hint.

Loved it !
