author: {'steamid': '76561197987156904', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1468992036}
review:
Great art, engaging story. However, the game has a critical flaw that permeates the entire experience: discovering how to progress is less an exercise in logic and more an exercise in clicking and walking the world. Many of the components of each puzzle are only tangentially related, oftentimes only in the most esoteric ways. Progression is further  hindered by the game's lack of robust programming. Sometimes you will try something that should work, only to find out that you were supposed to perform that action through slightly different mechanisms. 

The game also does not handle choices well. Now, there aren't many story-altering choices to make in this game, but the creators should have given the player more indications of what the effects of their actions would be, as well as more indication that certain paths could have been taken. I felt cheated out of the ending I would have chosen because of the problem I mentioned above. I clicked on something, nothing happened, and I went on my way, not realizing that I could have performed the intended action. This changed the ultimate ending.

Still very much recommended, but don't be ashamed to open up a guidebook if you get stuck.

Edit: Also, the save system was bad. They could have easily done it better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028004126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1468801315}
review: I can say, without any exaggeration, that this is hands down one of the best adventure games I have ever played in my 40 years of life. I binge played it in a day from start to finish and I could not stop. It's amazing. 5 alternate endings, multiple ways to solve certain puzzles, amazing storyline, beautiful ambience and timeline, and fantastic "life lesson." 10/10. I wish I could lobotimize myself and forget this game and play it again from the beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988091166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1468661070}
review:
P&C Adventure.
A strange android and his sarcastic famulus explore a robotic, dystopian, rust-red near apocalyptic world.

Plus Side:
Great Setting, good plot and writing, beautiful artworks.
Puzzles are decent and strongly intertwined with story & theme (not just abstract lever sequences).
Great ending(s)!

Minus:
Could be bigger. 
Hardcore Adventurios will blast through in one, albeit long, day
Lastly, the game could communicate some plot aspects better, if only through repetition. Miss a few dialogues and you might miss out on some twists.



Verdict: 
3,5/5

Absolutely delightful surprise. 
Even some seemingly not-so-polished mechanics, like the clunky datapad, for instance, just add to the game's rusty charm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037393879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1468666495}

author: {'steamid': '76561198082187634', 'num_games_owned': 616, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 494, 'last_played': 1468153507}
review:
Similar Games:
Fallout
Deponia

Primordia is a well-written point-and-click adventure game of a sci-fi world gone wrong. Much like Fallout or Deponia, the entire world is a post-apocalyptic mess of hostile robots, conflicting phiosophies and religious nutjobs. Many of the puzzles seem somewhat obscure as is tradition when it comes to adventure games like this, but for the most part many of them can be solved through exhausting the very few resources presented to you. Sometimes the game requires you to make a leap of logic that doesn't make sense, but other times the solution is as easy as thinking like an engineer (or a demoman).

There are some items and scenes that ultimately serve no purpose in progressing through any of the plots whatsoever, and at times it feels like the characters didn't develop all the way through, but outside of that this is a very fine adventure game. Probably one of the best you can get on Steam at the moment.


tl;dr It's a good puzzle adventure game that presents some basic concepts of social-political structures and has some of the best writing in its genre. A good game at its price and amazing on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964515286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1331, 'last_played': 1468446704}

tip:  The game uses an archaic  engine - use the included winsetup.exe and set the filter to 4x to get 1280x800 resolution.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965811997', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1468289722}
review:
Fun game if you enjoy the point and click genre.
Liked the story and the situations. Puzzles where for the most part clear, but with most of these games I get frustrated and cheat now and then. This isn't needed though, as the game has built in mechanics for you to subvert most puzzles if need be.
Really surprised by how the world draws on very similar issues we have today in creative ways. Problems we can recognise but wraped in the game lore. enjoyable and a bit thought provoking.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972359652', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1468173934}
review:
I played many, many point and click adventures during the nineties and this game was a bit of a nostalgia trip for me, particularly due to the pixel art graphic style. The artwork really is rather beautiful, with a really nice storyline.

The puzzles aren't too challenging, but give you enough to make you feel like you're achieving the objectives of the game.

The game seems to have a branching storyline - the screenshots on the shop page show scenes I didn't see during my playthrough. Perhaps it's worth playing again at a later date!

On the whole, I can heartily recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991243253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1468125536}

author: {'steamid': '76561198122646282', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1575742147}
review: This game is a masterpiece. At the time of this review, I just finished my first playthrough. I refused to use wiki, and this game made a fool out of me. All of my friends died and I ultimately was outsmarted. Going into my next playthrough, I know of several things I will do differently, hopefully to get a better outcome. I am possessed with the desire to outsmart metromind and beat the system. My advice to anyone who plays this game is to be patient and try to solve problems without looking up the walkthrough. The solutions do make sense, but sometimes it takes a while to figure it out. Don't be afraid to sleep on it and think about it. In conclusion, Primordia is a work of art that allows you to be completely lost in time. If this game had come out in the 90's, we would all be playing primordia 4 right now. If for some reason I lost my ownership of this game, I would buy it again, and pay full price for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198172921882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1467653752}
review: I loved it so much. The puzzles are challenging , the story is intriguing , the characters are great and the environment is wonderful. I can't recommend it enough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072027190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1467527611}
review:
Awesome Point&Click Adventure! The atmosphere, characters and the soundtrack, everything works so well together and create a stirring story within a melancholic, decaying, yet somehow fascinating world.

The game itself is rather short, but with some quite tricky puzzles and several interesting endings you'll enjoy it long enough. This game is simply addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048131383', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 506, 'last_played': 1467573852}
review:
If at least one of these is true:

- You like games with good writing and deep plot
- You think dystopic Machinarium would be awesome
- You loved the narrator's voice in Bastion

... then you should definitely play Primordia. It's a solid piece of point-and-click set in a post-nuclear world inhabited by sentient robots built by mythic Man, worshipped by some and hated by others. 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103507120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1467559229}
review: This game looks like something that came out of an old computer. But that retro look is kinda refreshing. As of July 2016, i had to manually turn my second screen off in windows for the game to start. Also, the windowed mode doesn't seem to be resizable. The story is compelling enough to play until the end. But, you can probably finish this game in a weekend. I would give it 3 star out of 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014174427', 'num_games_owned': 213, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1378199693}
review:
This game will make you think.
Not only is the story executed so well, it makes you think philosophically about ideas like
majority rules, utilitarinism (chosing to benefit the society over an individual who may deserve it) and moral absolutism (Abiding by the law is imperative no matter what)

author: {'steamid': '76561198160733095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1467089908}
review: I loved this game. A story that doesn't focus on humans but the things we left behind. A great story, simple but it holds your interest. The puzzles are easy for the most part a few with well hidden clues might cause a few problems. Not to hard to figure out if you think about them though. The main characters are lovable crispin is the comic relief and Horatio is the serious one but he cracks a few jokes. I can't really give it justice it's one of those games you have to play on your own to understand.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004316083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1493, 'last_played': 1660822905}
review:
This game will forever be in my list of favourite games. 
The story, the art, the voice acting, the WORLD and all of it so genuine. Even though all those aspects arn't speical to gaming, all these strengths would not be so powerful in any other medium. You live in this world, and it's just the right amount of familiar and so foreign. At least for me. 

If I ever stop recommending this game it will be too soon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966488439', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1870, 'last_played': 1467003741}
review: Wow! Just as good as any great 1991 era point and click adventure. Story, atmosphere, characters, art -- and it has like 7 different endings, and they were all great. Super recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038470822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1687065730}
review:
Primordia is by far one of the best point and click games I have ever played, I continue to play the game over and over again so I can re-experience all this world has to offer. While playing I envision what it would be like if the game had been expanded on, what the robot city would be like, what puzzles you would have had to solve, would you have ever made it back to the tower? I dream and wonder but for now, I enjoy the game <3 

Robots, dunes, exploration, mystery..... yea you need to play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066503554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1074, 'last_played': 1624994382}
review:
Almost since the decline of professional adventure games, fans have been making their own games.  These have varied wildly in quality, but in more recent years indie studios such as Wadjet Eye Games have managed to churn out charming retro games with regularity.  They generally strike the right balance in difficulty, the hand-painted art is often beautiful, and the stories are often interesting.  These games are not for everyone, of course, as games of this sort may seem "dated" or slow to modern gamers

To me, Primordia exemplifies the best aspects of most retro adventure games, with wonderful graphics (again, in a low res way that some appreciate more than others) and classic point and click exploration.  Primordia, however, distances itself from its peers through superior story, characters, and story structure.  The basic premise is an interesting one, and game designer and writer Mark Yohalem develops that premise expertly and meticulously.  The world unfolds naturally as you join Horatio and Crispin on their adventure.  The themes are more complex and nuanced than what you will see in most games.  The puzzles feel true to the world rather than thrown in just because you have to have them.

This is, in my opinion, the best game published by Wadjet Eye, and one of the best adventure games in recent memory.  If you're interested in going out on a limb and try an adventure game, consider trying this one.  If you're already a fan of retro games or thoughtful sci-fi, this is a no-brainer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089805112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 488, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1529876173}

A whimsical tale of mystery and discovery about a robot and his companion forging a path as fate would have it to uncover the blurred grey line between myth and truth through difficult choices, puzzles, and a rich and compelling story line. take a pixelated adventure into Primordia; one of the best games ive played in years.
buy it. you wont be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995684381', 'num_games_owned': 1062, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 659, 'last_played': 1465011828}
review:
It's like Beneath a Steel Sky, but with androids. It follows all the same beats. The hero and his tin can of a sidekick being attacked in the desert. A journey to the big city where things seem a bit off. And...well anything more than that would be spoilers.

The puzzles aren't too frustrating, just remember to check the sides of each screen for a transition zones. I got stuck in the first chapter just because there was a room I'd never been to and I didn't know was there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059613438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1464715091}
review:
I bought this game for $2 or something when it was on sale a long time ago, and finally got around to playing it. 

First of all: I don't typically enjoy point-and-click games. I haven't played very many of them, and I usually get frustrated with the puzzles and either look up a guide (which kind of defeats the point) or quit. 

I LOVED Primordia. Maybe it scratched the right itch at the right time, but I enjoyed every second of this game. The puzzles are challenging, but not frustrating (the only times that I had to look something up were just because I didn't realize I could scroll down on my data pack, for example, or that I could interact with an object in a certain way. For everything else, Crispin's hints were more than enough). It's gorgeous and thought-provoking. The voice acting was excellent and really brought all of the characters to life. The world is endlessly interesting. Looking at the achievements after my first playthrough, it also seems that there is a great deal to discover that I missed my first time around, which is good, because in my desire to experience more of this world I will probably play through it at least one more time. 

A lot of reviews have commented on it feeling a bit short, and I'm tempted to agree. The second half of the game in particular feels a bit rushed, but it seems to have more to do with there being lots of questions to answer, and they all get answered in a shotgun blast at once that seems to detract from the feeling of discovery that permiates the rest of the game. However, if the only bad thing I have to say about a game is "I wanted more..." is it really a bad thing after all?

Primordia is very literary. It's a game about the preservation of individuality within an increasingly communist society. It's about one's "design," and whether or not it's possible to act against it. It's about friendship, religion, creation, preservation, degeneration, and hope.

Do yourself a favor and play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976257774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 501, 'last_played': 1464642275}

author: {'steamid': '76561198060375678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 703, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1463755683}
review:
The war is lost, mankind is lost, everything is lost.
Alles was bleibt bist du, Horatio, ein Roboter der mit seinem Begleiter Crispin in der radioaktiven (Ich nehme mal an es gab da A-Waffen) W√ºste lebt. Dummerweise stellt sich heraus, dass wir zwei nicht alleine sind und etwas haben das ein schwerbewaffneter R√§uber will; Unsere Energiequellle.
Ohne diese sind wir jedoch dem Untergang geweiht. Also machen wir uns auf die Energiequelle wiederzubeschaffen. 
Was nun folgt sind 10 - 12 Stunden Adventuregaming mit gut durchdachten R√§tseln, einer wunderbaren Geschichte und herrlichen Konversationen.
√úber die Geschichte will ich nichts sagen, aber zum Spiel. Die Stimmung ist trotz des distopischen Settings nicht deprimierend, dies ist besonders Crispin geschuldet der mit seinen losen Mundwerk viel Heiterkeit verbreitet. Die R√§tsel sind logisch und lassen sich mit ein wenig Hirnschmalz gut l√∂sen. Steckt man dennoch mal fest steht einem Crispin mit Rat beiseite, wenn man ihn den fragt. Mit jedem R√§tsel erschlie√üt sich ein weiterer Teil der Geschichte und am Ende steht der gro√üe Showdown. Hier punktet Primordia mit einer Reihe alternativer Enden, f√ºr die zum Teil dann noch einmal einige Kleingkeiten zu kombinieren sind. 
F√ºr mich war das Spiel ein absoluter Gl√ºckskauf und empfehle es jedem weiter und kann nur hoffen ihr habt mit dem Spiel so viel Freude wie ich.

Nur einen Nachteil hat das Spiel, es ist so b'soding kurz ;)

PS: Auch sehr nett sind die Eastereggs. Zum Beispiel finden sich im Spiel Anspielungen auf Fallout 1 & 2. Auch denke ich habe ich den Einfluss von Stephen King und seiner Sage vom dunklen Turm (sehr gute Reihe) deutlich im Spiel wiedergefunden :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198081301506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1435226486}

author: {'steamid': '76561197966134367', 'num_games_owned': 3548, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1463511124}
review:
I judge puzzle adventure games by a single rule:

Every puzzle in the game must be solvable within the game's own universe without requiring more than a grasp of English. No trips to Google to check bible passages or pop culture references.

And that's it. That's why Primordia's difficulty is well-earned and satisfying to figure out on your own. That's all I need to know about a point-n-click, and that's what you should need as well (but okay fine, the writing is also absolutely hilarious and full of personality).

author: {'steamid': '76561198036654880', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1403480522}
review:
Un point'n'click avec une direction artistique proche des production Lucasarts √† l'ancienne, j'ai voulu tenter le coup.

Au final c'est un produit correct, mais sans plus. Il manque une musique vraiment accrocheuse, celle propos√©e fait le boulot pour l'ambiance mais impossible de s'en souvenir.

L'histoire traite d'un futur lointain dans lequel la terre devenue vaste d√©potoir, n'est plus foul√©e que par des robots d'origine diverses, pour qui l'√™tre humain n'est qu'une esp√®ce √©teinte.

L'aventure est assez laborieuse et peu passionante, j'en ai peur. Le nombre de lieu visit√© est trop l√©ger. L'empathie g√©n√©r√©e par les personnages ne suffit pas √† s'int√©resser √† cet unviers qui pourtant sur le papier me tentait.

Le seul point positif de l'histoire est la multiplicit√© de fins. Mais apr√®s en avoir vu une, je n'ai aps sp√©cialement eu envie de refaire l'histoire avec des choix diff√©rents.
En anglais seulement.

Conclusion : un point and click assez pauvre et d√©cevant. Uniquement si vous √™tes d√©sesp√©r√© d'en faire de nouveaux.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017498886', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1461600335}
review: Primordia ist ein Point&Klick Adventure der Extraklasse. Stylisch, d√ºster, zeitlos und mit kniffligen R√§tseln (Da es in dem Spiel um Robotter geht haben die meisten mit Codes zu tun) der einzige Negativpukt f√ºr mich w√§re, dass einige Bugs gegen Ende mein Spiel geschrottet haben und Objekte nicht mehr erkennbar waren und das Spiel bei einem Szenen√ºbergang immer abst√ºrtzt. Trotzdem ist es sein Geld wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062923685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1460825044}
review:
Das Leben kann unfair sein. Primordia w√§re vor einigen Jahrzehnten wie eine Bombe eingeschlagen ... da bin ich mir sicher. Ich fantasiere und male mir aus, was passiert w√§re, wenn Lucas Arts oder Sierra diesen Titel in den 80ern vom Stapel gelassen h√§tten. Ist es √ºbertrieben, wenn ich behaupte, man w√ºrde Primordia dann heutzutage in einem Atemzug mit Monkey Island, Space / King's Quest, Indiana Jones und The Day Of The Tentacle nennen? Nicht unbedingt. Wir haben es hier mit einem unfassbar hochpolierten Point and Click Adventure zu tun; ein prachtvolles Gesamtkunstwerk mit dichtem, einzigartigen Setting, tollen Grafiken, einem einmaligen Soundtrack und zwei Haupprotagonisten, die regelrecht KULT schreien: Horatio Nullbuilt und sein treuer Schweberoboter Crispin d√ºrften in jedem Retrogamer-Herz ihren Platz finden.

Das d√ºstere Szenario und die beklemmende Atmosph√§re ... die philosophischen Fragen, die das Spiel stellt ... Primordia f√ºllt damit eine weitere L√ºcke im Adventure-Bereich und d√ºrfte ohne Weiteres mit an der Spitze der Sci-Fi-Games dieses Genres stehen. Wer Lust auf einen "Blast from the (reconstructed) past" hat und geilen Retroschei√ü mag, muss hier einfach die pizzaverklebten Nerdfinger ausfahren. Bedauerlich, dass solche Titel heutzutage nicht mehr Mainstream-tauglich sind und es kaum ein Schwein interessiert. Damals ... ja, damals ... w√§re Primordia der Respekt gezollt worden, den es verdient. Ich frage mich, wo all die alten Hasen blo√ü hin sind, die damals Monkey Island und Co. abgefeiert haben!? Sind sie wirklich schon ausgestorben? 

Ja, das Leben kann unfair sein.

Mein Gott, ich h√∂re mich an wie Marvin. 

PS: Einziges Manko ist f√ºr mich das Fehlen einer deutschen Fassung. Ich verstehe Englisch gut ... doch nicht perfekt. Dadurch werden die R√§tsel nicht gerade leichter und ich musste oft in eine Komplettl√∂sung schauen (Schande √ºber mein Haupt!). Ich wusste, dass deswegen Probleme auf mich warten; den Titel musste ich als Adventure-Liebhaber trotzdem kaufen. Und das Gleiche sollten √Ñhnlichgesinnte ebenso tun! (hier bei Bedarf idiotischen Hashtag einf√ºgen) SUPPORT PRIMORDIA - es ist der unbekannte K√∂nigssohn, der sich im Wald von Wurzeln und W√ºrmern ern√§hrt (daher hei√üen die Entwickler auch Wormwood) ... und der P√∂bel vom Dorf hat keinen Schimmer, mit wem sie es zu tun haben. Sie ignorieren den Waldmensch, dabei flie√üt adeliges Blut in seinen Adern!

Ja, das Leben ist unfair.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998145359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1479492257}

author: {'steamid': '76561197976949162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1461224578}
review:
Had some problems with getting the mouse to function (at all) on my windows 10 rig but the Dev's are really nice and encouraging and was able to find a solution.  For anyone interested in order to get the game to run I simply had to alter the properties on Primordia.exe - under the compatibility tab tick the boxes 'reduced colour mode' (16bit), 'run in 640x480' and 'run as administrator'.  After doing that the game runs fine.

So the game itself

An old school style point and click adventure with some very interesting charcters, settings and concepts.  The dialogue is quite well written even if the jokes do on occasion fall a bit flat. Very much enjoyed my time exploring this little world and trying to figure out the puzzles.

Its only downfall in my opinion is that it seemed rather short - given the setting and the plot setup I was expecting more content but what is here is still very good.

8/10 - best of the genre I have played in a long time

author: {'steamid': '76561198042549377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1460669842}

author: {'steamid': '76561197983040117', 'num_games_owned': 1741, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1517, 'last_played': 1355040000}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044852726', 'num_games_owned': 453, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1460388351}
review:
Primordia is a superb game. In the far future, Man is no more and is worshiped as an ancient god that was the perfect machine that built the first robots (in the era called primodium). These manbuilt robots built more robots and they are now the only sentience that populates the post-apocalyptic world. The robots believe that Man will return once more to start a second primordium. Meanwhile, they go about "maintaining" the world and preach the gospel of man. Horatio Nullbuilt and his levitating companion Crispin Horatiobuilt are two such robots that live out in the dunes, far away from the robot city of Metropol. When a giant robot with lasers "takes" their power core, they are forced on an adventure that takes them to Metropol and uncovers everything from Horatio's past to the fate of the last humans.

The music sets the tone perfectly for this world. What struck me most was the intricacy with which this world was constructed: every little trinket of knowledge about this universe fits so seamlessly with every other tidbit. So, the writers did a fantastic job and obviously put a lot of thought into their work. The visuals, music and puzzles served to elevate that writing. If you love atmosphere and storytelling or if you loved the blackwell series or if you just enjoy wadjeteye games, this is a title that must be experienced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076066099', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 984, 'last_played': 1637940889}
review:
I won't go into too much detail because I played this game years ago, but I recently saw it in my library and thought it deserved a review. There are few negative things to say so I'll start there.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
Starting with the only downsides I can think of, it was bothersome finding the right settings so the game would scale perfectly and look sharp on an HD display, but it worked fine once that was taken care of. 
Gameplay is somewhat akin to classic point and click with character displacement handled like any old 2D RPG, but it sometimes isn't clear which items are to be interacted with, or even whether it is possible. This was sometimes annoying but can be considered inherent to the game genre.
It's too short. Don't get me wrong, the length of the game is appropriate but the mood and story are so enticing by the end you'll definitely be left wanting more.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
The art. I'll come out with a bit of an unpopular opinion by saying gameplay is not a good reason to buy this game. Its geatest asset is without a question the art. Not only is the style 100% distinctive from anything I've seen before, the devs actually pulled it off perfectly. While it resembles moody postapocalyptic or cyberpunk art commonly seen in high-res online, the low pixel count makes it particularly impressive. Combining intricate convoluted shapes with pixel-art is just something I didn't think was possible until playing Primordia. The dark and brown color tones used and occasional neon accents really set the atmosphere as a surrealist cyberpunk universe. I can't stress enough there is nothing else like this.
On top of the visual aspects, the soundtrack is just great. Maybe I wouldn't listen to the ambient sounds on their own but they really do a great job of accenting both the story and environment.
Last comes the story. Oh boy. Not only was I surprised at every turn by a creative plot, but the character development is the cherry on the cake. Whoever wrote the story really knows how to blend humor, mystery, and tragedy in a story that never left me bored (except when I got stuck desperately looking for some object to interact with).

I won't oversimplify by rating this game with a number, but I'll say this:
Since I was about eight years old not a single day has gone by without me reading a novel. I have watched thousands of movies, played literally hudreds of games, and amidst all the classics, the worldwide hits, the big budget productions, all the various forms of entertainment, this comes out easily as one of the favorite stories of my lifetime. If you can sit through a few tedious puzzles and don't mind spending half an hour looking for items in a pile of trash, then I recommend this game wholeheartedly. Hell, even if you hate the gameplay it's affordable enough that you can buy it just to appreciate the art and ambience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023066159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1364454000}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045592217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1459719577}
review:
This may just be the best freaking adventure game I have ever played in my life!
The game manages perfectly to keep you interested, but not overwhelming you.
And if you're stuck, you can always get help that REALLY HELPS from your Pal Crispin.
I HATE it when I need a strategy guide, only to get passed some roadblock of a puzzle,
like in most other adventures.
Not so here.
Multiple ways to solve puzzles.
Multiple outcomes to situations.
Multiple ENDINGS ! - I love it.

And the attention to detail is really striking, - not ONCE did I encounter a single line of dialogue that didn't fit, although that's something developers quite ALWAYS glitch up in a minor way when
allowing their game to follow multiple paths.

On top of that, FOR ONCE an adventure game orients itself in reality, in the sense that you can use the same item in different but similar situations - most other games just find one excuse after the other, why "Crowbar XY" can IN NO WAY open Door #2, when just minutes ago it was  perfectly capable of opening Door #1.
In Primordia things tend to be a little more logical, and I enjoyed every minute of it.

I played it straight through today, then immediately run through it a second time, just to collect the achievements and see all the things I could have missed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034458450', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1459486882}
review: An exceptionally well crafted adventure game with difficult puzzles and a beautifully written story.  I had thought that the intrigue and mystery of playing games like Beneath a Steel Sky and Monkey Island was lost to the dumbed down 'puzzle' games of the console era - Primordia proves that this isn't so, and I am so very grateful.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970926858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1458215916}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044490526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1360483200}
review:
This game is beauty incarnate. It uses the point-and-click adventure format masterfully, and delivers an incredible experience. Unlike some other games ([spoiler]Blackwell Epiphany,[/spoiler] cough-cough xD), you always feel like you have agency, and the number of alternate endings only add to this feel. The puzzles are fair, and the world vast and interesting.

As someone who grew up on Lem's Cyberiad, for me, robots inhabiting a post-mankind world was a must buy... but what really managed to awe me was how incredibly well they were executed. No throw-away characters and no bad cliches in this game.

If you like Asimov or Lem, robots, and adventure games, get this. It's one of the top titles of the genre at the moment, surpassing even many of the big old titles by LucasArts in the golden days.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027061958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1457773289}
review: I'm not a big fan of point of click adventures. What initially drew me to purchase this game was the art. Trust me when I say that Primordia goes far beyond just being a pretty looking game. The story is outstanding. There are a ton of endings and lots of challenging puzzles and decisions along the way. Definitely recommend picking this one up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011305508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 394, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1457478228}
review:
Primordia's robot driven post-apocalyptic setting is a great twist on your standard post-war stories. Even though the characters in the game are robots they retain many human properties that makes them quite relatable. To add to this, their human traits are merged with some very interesting quirks based on what purposes they were coded for. This makes almost every character you meet really interesting and memorable, and also drives a lot humor in the game. In particular, the bond between the playable character Horatio and his creation and best friend Crispin is consistently entertaining thoughtout the whole game. It's not just the setting that's great though, the writing and story in general is fantastic, and the voice acting is amazing.

The gameplay draws really well from the setting too. Scavenging for spare parts and pieceing machines together might feel pretty familiar to anyone who has played an adventure game before, but because of the setting and design of the game all of this feels really organic and fluid. It helps that there are core items in the game aren't simply used once and then thrown away, but instead you are gathering an array of tools (Your friend Crispin being one of them!) that you will keep reusing throughout the whole game. There is still the odd puzzle that had solutions I wouldn't have thought of and got me turning to a guide, but I would put this down to my own impatience rather than design faults of the game. I never really took the time to think things out completely as I was too compelled to move forward with the story!

Long story short, I would strongly recommend this game. The only negative thing I can think of is that I had a couple of very minor technical issues that were resolved easily. If you have any interest in point-and-click adventures or story-driven games in general I wouldn't hesitate to pick this one up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030591896', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1457642465}

review:
Una aventura de corte cl√°sico, con un gran personaje principal y un mejor personaje ‚Äòsecundario‚Äô, Crispin, de esos que no se olvidan jam√°s. Tiene la ventaja de que hay puzles que se pueden resolver de formas distintas, la atm√≥sfera postapocal√≠ptica est√° muy conseguida, los puzles tienen sentido, hay amor por la ciencia ficci√≥n y gui√±os varios desde Shakespeare hasta los juegos de consola. Tambi√©n tenemos varios finales (creo que hay diez distintos) lo cual le da un plus de rejugabilidad.

Un juego absolutamente recomendable

A classic style adventure, with a great main character and a ‚Äòsecundary‚Äô one even better, Crispin, part of the ones you‚Äôll never forget. A strong point of the game is that some puzzles can be solved in different ways, there‚Äôs love for science fiction and various winks from Shakespeare to console games. We'll find several endings as well (I think there are ten different ones) which adds a plus of replayability.

Absolutely recommendable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977878581', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1365836400}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040996114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1459385282}
review:
My god. You want to talk about fun and story-driven gameplay? This thing comes close to a masterpiece. 9/10. Details below.

Set in an extreme post-apocolyptia, our hero attempts to recover a power source he desperatly needs, stolen from him by a hulking robot. As his simple quest progresses, he finds himself drawn into the day-to-day conflicts of many men and women bots, deepening the story and lore of the world naturally. On the way you, the player, solve simple yet satisying point-and-click puzzles with elegent conectivity and solutions. The vast majority of the puzzles feel very natural, not forcibly integrated with the environment. The few esoteric ones can be figured out by paying careful attention to the dialogue of NPC bots. As you travel from your humble abode across vast wastes, to a sprawling, decrepit city, you meet incredibly interesting characters. The amount of work that went into the art design is astounding, and reflects well on the amount of work that went into the writing. The story is driven by dialogue rather than the environment, though all the scenes are breathtaking. I will say Crispin's playful banter leaves something to be desired and feels off-key, coming as it is in such a bleak game. But the story and gameplay merge so seemlessly you can forgive it. An incredible game with replay value and amazing choice endings. Highly reccomended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025028631', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1381, 'last_played': 1418542878}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065885685', 'num_games_owned': 343, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1511985224}
review:
This is a great post-apocalyptic point and click game with tons of puzzles that require your attention at all time. The story is interesting and the world is full of hidden easter eggs and clever refferences from everyday life.

At the end I found 7 different possible endings. Some of the endings had 2-3 variations. (The cutscenes were the same but the monologue and dialogue changed depending on what you did during the game.) There might be more however.

The game took me 10 hours but I spend alot of time just wandering around.

Over all I recommend it. Wish there was Primordia 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065877448', 'num_games_owned': 4139, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1455506262}
review: An incredibly charming adventure game. Puzzles have logical progression, and no solutions feel like a game of "guess what the developer was thinking". Multiple endings make for a charming and satisfying experience. Definite recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079595097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1455320762}
review:
I liked this game. I really did, which is a rare occasion for me in this genre.

I'm the kind of person who usually buys huge batches of cheap new indies and revamps of old adventure games, starts point-and-clickers excited but leaves them even before half-way, bored of the theme, disillusioned by the lack of immersion, redundant puzzles and all. Somehow it all gets diluted into a non-engaging mess. But this was not the case with Primordia; I played it through twice, once genuinely without any help, and then second time with a walkthrough / achievement guide to see what I had missed. 

I loved the dystopian atmosphere. The writing was excellent, as well as the characters. The graphics were surprisingly fitting - somehow the artists filled just the right amount of atmospheric detail in "cinematics", and the gameplay was fluent enough. Puzzles did involve every once in a while some actual thinking and not just random inventory combo-womboing, and once I even took pen and paper to solve a key puzzle. I must commend that the narration for Horatio, Crispin, as well some other key characters (without spoilers) were excellently done, which played a huge part on why the game was so immersive for me.

On the down-side, some of the puzzles were kinda redundant pixel searching, as one might expect. Luckily the hint system was just on the correct level for a guy like me, who doesn't like hunting for pixels for eternities, and might dismiss an "obvious" clue every here and then. I never felt stuck, and I always had a sense of progression in my first playthrough. Without spoiling too much, there isn't that much of difference in the endings or how your choices end up as consequences, but second playthrough (with a walkthrough) did reveal more of the lore and modest alternatives that I had missed. I must also admit that dystopia/sci-fi as a genre is probably my favorite (1984, Brave New World, Neuromancer, you name it), so I am biased to liking this game.

Overall, I can highly recommend this excellent adventure-novel to anybody that can overcome the barrier of point-and-click, and instead enjoy a ride of well fitting retro graphics, excellent narrative, good writing, and a neatly packaged ~4-6h adventure in a single playthrough - all for a very modest price. I'll fly one day, and Crispin will be laughing at me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040424144', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1455091193}
review:
This game has several memorable characters, it invokes emotion and curiosity, and has a solid plot. 

If this game were a high budget film, I'd pay triple the regular ticket price to see it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025669273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 468, 'last_played': 1375050701}
review:
The only game, so far, that I have every achievement unlocked.
It is an interesting world and a great story with multiple endings.
It has some interesting puzzles and brought me back to the early point and click style games of the 80s and 90s. Ah Nostalga, you are a funny thing.

But the game is just too short IMO.

Get it if it's on sale. Otherwise I'd say wait.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997708311', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1655227076}
review: An absolutely lovely piece. Along with the finely crafted graphics and cut-scenes, I loved the voice-over and the music. It is a game of self-exploration and finding a meaning to existence when your god is dead. There are alternative endings, which are intriguing, and there are more than one way to skin a cat for many puzzles. Choices feel real, however, you are not the only agent acting on the scene.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066892868', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 682, 'last_played': 1422955425}
review:
I love this game.  

* Engrossing story
* Unique art style, kind of like an art nouveau version of Blade Runner
* Music that totally fits the general aesthetic of the game
* Challenging puzzles
* Great voice acting

It's the sort of game that really sticks with you long after you've played through it. If you're a fan of Wadjet Eye or just point and click games in general, definitely worth picking up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074063118', 'num_games_owned': 95, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1454576177}
review: I don't usually leave game reviews, but Primodia really wowed me. It's a hauntingly beautiful game and the story is compelling. The whole concept of the universe Primordia is set in adds an intrigue to the whole thing. As a point and click game it is extremely successful. The puzzles and problems can be difficult and you may get really stuck on a few parts; this never stopped me from wanting to complete the game though. Upon completion  of Primordia I felt as if I'd read a really good book that made me think and want more. The game is interesting and mystery-filled, and I fully recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023279737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 562, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1440897817}
review:
First things first: I have only played one ending to this game, I am led to believe there are many.

Despite the above I feel I am qualified to give a review of a large portion of the content, since the core backstory is static.

This game is wonderful. It happens to be my favorite game in the world, but that is a subjective assessment and I intend for this to be an objective review so I will explain WHY my opinon has formed the way it has.

First: the world is unique.  The spectacularly different setting in which the protagonist finds himself is interesting and deeply realized. I found that as I played this game I wanted to learn more and more about the backstory, the reason things were the way they were. It is likely that not everyone will have this response but I found that the somehow quite human cyberpunk characters drew me in. The robotic population of this game have dreams, hopes, and problems which make them relatable, but also special. They are obviously not human, but the similarities between them and humanity are evident in many portions of the game. That, however, is not to say there are no differences. Indeed some of the differences are what drove me to be more industrious in my exploration of the world.

Second: the voice acting is stellar. While the voice acting is not particularly flashy, it has an underplayed value in making the protagonist and his little helper come to life. Throughout it gives simple but essential relatability with the main character, putting the player in his shoes so to speak. The voices are diverse and unique and this additionally draws the player into the world, which now not only has depth, but also seems broad.

Third: the art is dead center with the rest of the game's feel. Though robotic, many tubes and unique shapes cascade through the art design, giving the machines an organic feel (this is not the only game I've seen do this but this game does it well). Most of the tones are dead-feeling beiges and browns but there are many glowing lights throughout the game that give the overall impression of a world with a soul beneath all the lifeless metal. Again this fits perfectly with the world's history and vibe.

Fourth: the audio is wonderfully immersive. The sound is electronic with a common use of ethnic sounding pad synths. Deep, slow rhythms give the game a dark and somber feel which meshes perfectly with the mechanized art and characters. There is at least one old record you can listen to, which deepens the games portrayal of the world's past.

Fifth: the gameplay is solid. The puzzles are not hard, but they have an obvious digital slant that only increases immersion and interest. Each one is unique, although each of thier formats is fairly standard for point and click games. If this game had to have a weakness it would be the puzzles, if you don't play this game for the story and immersion, I think you're not playing to the game's amazing strengths. If you don't like stories/worlds that you can lose yourself in and just want hard puzzles, don't play this. However, if you've ever been interested in a cyberpunk world, or a fantasy story, or even basic philosophy/worldviews, let this game tell you a story. It does it well.

Sixth: no spoilers in this review but I will say the ending I found was amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144593917', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1454383610}
review:
I thought Primordia was a very good game, and I would recommend it both in terms of mechanics and story. I am a big fan of the Blackwell games, and this game has many of the same strengths.

Pros:
+ Excellent story. There's legitimately a lot to think about in this game, including political, religious, and social commentary. The game is set in a world where humans are extinct and only robots are left. We see how the society they create is a very clever mirror of our own, with plenty of parody of our own flaws along the way.
+ The point and click puzzles are solid. They are somewhat difficult, but solvable without having to consult a walkthrough because the solutions make sense once you get them. To me, this is one of the most important things about gameplay in a point and click. You have to use your brain to solve the puzzles.
+ If you do start struggling, you can get hints by talking to people (especially your sidekick Crispin), which again means you don't need to consult the internet to get a nudge in the right direction. Normally, he will give you a clue about which area you should be searching, or which object you should be fiddling with.
+ The art and aesthetics in the game are good. The characters are interesting-looking, and the world is very neat.
+ The game is paced well. It does a nice job of moving you from place to place, advancing the story and revealing the mysteries by steps.

Cons:
- Hard to think of any. I suppose the UI can be a bit clunky until you get used to it, especially how you access your inventory.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963798804', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 910, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 880, 'last_played': 1453860789}
review:
A mysterious past is slowly unveiled in a post-apocalyptic art-noveau cyberpunk world.

If you like robots, themes of AI, and/or adventure games - especially classic ones - this game is for you.  

The game follows the pretty standard adventure mechanic - click on things to make things happen - sometimes click on things with things from your inventory, or mix things in your inventory together until they become clickable on other things.  Take notes.  (Most of which actually happens for you with the in-game "data-pad".)  Solve puzzles with said notes.  

The game runs at 640x400 resolution - which can be off-putting to some, but really lends to the retro-adventure feel of the game, and I've come to love it.  (On my 1080p tv, it won't actually fill up the whole screen, but it doesn't really bother me.)  That said - I highly recommend going into the options menu and chosing the "DX" display mode as opposed to D3D if it works for you - the sprites mesh with the backgrounds much better this way in my opinion.  DOS nostalgia!

What really shines in Primordia is the story - and the art.  They come together to create a fascinating atmosphere that makes me want to revisit the game again and again - and the developer commentary is great on a second or third playthrough.  The excellent voice acting and seven or so potential endings don't hurt, either.  (The narrator from Bastion plays the main character - and the sidekick that follows you through the game is entertaining at every turn.)  The music and sound mesh well with the art to create an engrossing atmosphere - despite the retro low-res graphics.  

There aren't many puzzles in the "puzzle game" sense - but there is plenty of puzzling to be done in the game in terms of figuring out how things fit together, what things mean, and what the significance of certain items or pieces of information may be.  The story is mostly linear, but there are a few opportunities to take different approaches to solve situations - especially near the end.  Observation and careful contemplation are rewarded.

The setting is in the distant future in a post-human world - no organic life is to be found anywhere - even the bugs and little things swimming in the sewers are machines - but make no mistake, they have lives and thoughts of their own, and are no less interesting than any human character.  And for the robot fan, there are references to other robots from both popular and obscure culture everywhere - along with a videogame reference or two.  MST3K, Short Circuit, Metropolis, and Fallout - just to name a few.

I would highly recommend this game to any fan of classic graphic adventures, narrative-driven games, or robots.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009079522', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 196, 'playtime_forever': 680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1513746197}
review:
Primordia is not what it first appears. 
It's description is: "What happened to the Humans", but that isn't what the game is about. 
I thought this would be an Adeptus Mechanicus themed Adventure game with a Sam and Max buddyish element, but was actually wrong.
Instead, this is a game about logic, law, and a divide between liberty and community. 

The main characters are both charming and the other characters all have little quirks that ensures there is no "that guy" of the game. The puzzles are good without ever being too challenging and the story is tightly knit, with only about 10-11 locations and about 15 characters in the entire game. It's concise without any red herrings. Actually, because the game is so tightly knit, some important secrets are left out in plain sight, which makes it interesting to replay. 

What I also like about the puzzles in this game are that there's dialouge if the game understands what you were trying to do with a puzzle, but you were using the wrong piece and there's multiple ways to solve several of the puzzles. In fact, the biggest and longest puzzle of the game can literally be bypassed from the moment you enter the second act. 

My only complaint with the game would be the antagonist. The antagonist has a trait that they can "never lie" but then you manage to catch them in lies several times and when confronted with this, the antagonist says "no player, you must be mistaken because I am not". In a game where the entire second act is about logic, it just seems silly. Additionally, my other problem with the antagonist is that at one point the antagonist just says "I know you have a lot of questions about the world and history of this game world, so let me answer all of them for you". 

However, that small gripe aside, this game had me engaged and immersed the whole time, trying to figure out its secrets and lore (until the minute that it got bored and laid out its cards on the table).

author: {'steamid': '76561198002480220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 396, 'last_played': 1452735793}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030767212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1452194648}
review:
Primordia gleicht in Stil und Art sehr stark den Point&Klick Adventures der 90'er Jahre. In der Aufl√∂sung von pixeligen 640 x 480 bleibt somit Vieles der Fantasie des Betrachters √ºberlassen. Lediglich die Vertonung orientiert sich an modernen Ma√üst√§ben.
Die Story spielt in einer menschenlosen Postapokalypse in der die verbliebenen Maschinen nach Sinn und Zukunft suchen. Dabei werden im Verlauf des Spiels immer wieder typisch philosophische Fragen nach Existenz, Wahrheit und Logik aufgegriffen. Das Spiel bietet interessante Charaktere und erm√∂glicht h√§ufig unterschiedliche L√∂sungswege. Aber ohne hin und wieder eine Komplettl√∂sung zu Rate zu ziehen, w√§re ich weder innerhalb der Zeit noch √ºberhaupt durch das ganze Spiel gekommen.

Es ist auf jeden Fall kein Spiel f√ºr den Massenmarkt, aber wer sich f√ºr solche Spiele begeistern kann, dem kann ich es nur empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134487166', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1452215062}
review: That has to be one of the greatest game of our time. With great storyline, cute graphics and interesting characters, Primordia is more immersive than 3D games with latest graphics. The built-in hint system keeps you inside the game, instead of searching in manuals over the internet.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972054324', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 455, 'last_played': 1452087978}
review:
Point-and-click adventure games were one of the first things I ever played: When I got my first computer around 1994-‚Äô95 I played Discworld with my dad. We had a walkthrough since neither of us could understand English. Since then I have gone mostly to other genres but the adventuring spark were left in me somewhere. That‚Äôs why I have bought a great many point-and-click games but every time I play one the same thing happens: I click around for a while and get bored. They just don‚Äôt get a grip on me. That was until Primordia.

The player takes role of Horatio and his sidekick Crispin, who live in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. What seems like a peaceful existence is interrupted when a robot crashes through their wall and steals a power core that is keeping the two alive. The game is a quest to find and get back the power core. The mood is melancholic and sad but is lighten up by Crispin‚Äôs surprisingly funny dialog. Every other character was also fascinating and had some personality to them.

This was the first ever adventure game that I completed without looking at a walkthrough. Most of the puzzles are logical in a sense that if you have an item that might fit it most likely does. Every solution made sense. The puzzles are quite varied: There are use-item-on-item puzzles but also drawing, memorization, code breaking and so on. I was surprised at how many different kind of obstacles the creators had thought out. It took 7 hours to complete the game, though length varies greatly depending on how fast you solve the puzzles. There appears to be different endings and outcomes since I only got half of the achievements on single playthrough.

The graphics in this are amazing. Everything is a post-apocalyptic bleak wasteland but the world that was destroyed has this art deco kind of style (think Bioshock) that is really nice. The game actually runs at the tiniest of resolutions but is stretched to full screen. Not a lot of pixels to work with but what has been achieved is wonderful. I‚Äôd love to see full resolution images of the art since it‚Äôs so great. This is also why the game probably runs on pretty much any potato as long as there is electricity. For some strange reason in one room, after certain thing happens, my fps dropped to single digits but it was solved after I got out of the room. You cannot die and there is no rush so it doesn‚Äôt matter. Even better than the visuals is the sound and music. I think the voice acting is great but, together with the art, it‚Äôs the music that shines the most. 

If you have any interest in point-and-click Primordia is a must play, no doubt about that. For someone new to the genre it‚Äôs also a good place to start since it‚Äôs not as far-out weird with its puzzles as some games in the genre. I can only give a big recommend for this wonderful game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198107567724', 'num_games_owned': 1352, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1648352490}
review: Primordia... This game is easily the best point and click adventure game there is. The pixalated look takes a moment to get used to but it quickly makes things look like works of art. The dialogue is both very funny, witty, and sad in this dystopian society where machines rule. It gives life to and great character work to what apear to be hunks of metal. I got very attached and played it through in two sitting with it's difficult puzzles and advanced but easy to follow plots. A must to any readers and adventurers :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197967525401', 'num_games_owned': 699, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1451978713}

review: Ein feines St√ºck Software. Da f√ºhlt man sich sofort in die "gute alte Amigazeit" zur√ºckversetzt. Sehr sch√∂nes und auch witziges Retrogame, mit intilligentem Plot. Zu erw√§hnen w√§re auch der Soundtrack, athmosph√§rischer Sci-Fi Score, ein bisschen wie Blade Runner. ^^ Alles in allem ein zu empfehlendes Game wenn man auf Pixeloptik steht.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082554252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 944, 'last_played': 1452283455}
review:
Among the many things that make Primordia great are:

+ fantastic, gripping storyline, taking you on an adventure through a dying world
+ unique art style and music that will highjack your imagination
+ great voice acting - hey, Logan Cunningham and Abe Goldfarb are here!
+ humor, and lots of it 
+ characters you really care about
+ puzzles that will make you think
+ you don't have to worry that you will be stuck at some point (Crispin will give you a hint if needed)
+ commentary and blooper tracks added as an option
+ many possible endings - it's all up to you
+ developers that really care about the users and will help you out with the game if there is any issue. 
   Come on, how cool is that?

The only thing I think can be annoying is that it runs as 640x400. You can set it as a full-screen, but still - if you aren't a pixel fan, this can bug you. As for me - I hardly even noticed this, since the game itself sucked me in instantaneously. Quite frankly, I think I'm in love.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970495871', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 453, 'last_played': 1451531778}
review:
Great world, great writing, compelling characters. I really liked it but am glad that this style of game is more a part of history. It has that old school 90s sprite based vibe which is awesome if you like the old Sierra/Lucasarts point and click games. Like good science fiction Primordia created a deep world that deserved the resources of modern gaming engines.

All in all, great game and I'll be looking at this developer for more games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027611814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1418054874}
review:
Primordia is an intriguing story about a robot pushed by fate to find about his past.
Excellent pixel art, immersive soundtrack and great dialogue lines.
Puzzles are complicated but solvable.

10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993403849', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1451457407}
review:
a very solid point and click adventure that doesnt hold your hand, but also at least gives you Crispin so you arent ever lost on the way.

the music ranges from desolate to haunting and gives a full sense of a dying world and sounds like its from shortly after the 16bit era.

the visuals are very unique and asymmetrical. bringing the beauty of a more organic design to it's cast of robotic wonders.

and the cast themselves are very animated, and unique. they all gives a very distinct feeling. some come across as zealotus misionaries, others as military wardware given life, and theres even a bit of robotic love thrown in there to blur the line between emotion and robotics.

very happy with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047977341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 381, 'last_played': 1468340272}
review:
One of the best point & click games I've had the pleasure of playing. Despite the 'outdated' graphical appearance, the art was top-notch, as was the overall feel and atmosphere. But what really seperates fantastic point & click games from the mediocre ones, is the writing and the quality of the dialogue and plot in Primordia is absolutely stunning. Characters were also very likeable, in part due to the great voice acting.
 
Planescape: Torment is a major inspiration here; the initial hook of the story, Crispin/Morte, emphasis on the past, it's all here. Much like Torment, Primordia is filled with sad moments, funny moments, philosophical themes and one hell of a cathartic ending (at least the one I got).
Puzzles were decent and quite logical, although at times the game had too many red herrings going on, which made some puzzles a bit difficult for me. Still, only in one puzzle I had to go to a walkthrough and check it out. 

All in all, a very solid old school adventure game with insanely good story, one that I am unlikely to ever forget.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984348200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1663268706}
review: I thought this game started out very strong; great gameplay and an interesting story that keeps you engaged. Towards the end it becomes more text based with a lot of back tracking keeping you confined to a relatively small area. With low replayability, I would pass on this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169393936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1450878152}
review:
[h1]"Primordia" (Adventure/Point & Click) (*Spoiler-free*)[/h1]

[b]HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.[/b]

Beautiful (if grim) setting and atmosphere. Excellent dialogs.

The puzzles are quite intuitive (after thinking for a bit! =), at least some of them have multiple solutions (I finished the game without solving every puzzle), and the game has a very robust hint system which is nicely integrated into the narrative.

I enjoyed the retro/pixelated visual style, but since mileage varies greatly do check screenshots and videos and see for yourself.

Maybe a tad short, as adventure games tend to be (about 5-8 hours in this case) but you can save the game at any point (and you have as many save slots as you want), which encourages exploring alternative solutions & dialog choices.

***

[h1]In detail (*Spoiler-free*)[/h1]

Personally, I play adventure games mostly for the story, setting, and characters, with a bit of puzzle-solving to spice the mix. As noted above, in this genre I don't care much for AAA high-end graphics as long as what's on the screen is clear.

"Primordia" delivers on all counts:

> The setting is amazing: robots in a post-apocalyptic, nearly Mad-Maxian world (minus the cars), with an orwellian Big Brother on top. Although, to make it better, the mood is nostalgic and bittersweet rather than oppressive.

> The plot is itself quite good.

> I found most characters to be very well crafted. The protagonist's companion deserves a mention of his own: not only he fulfills his Sassy Sidekick role and provides the humor this otherwise grim tale needs, he's also part of a very comprehensive hint system (and seamlessly integrated into the narrative)

> The puzzles themselves are quite intuitive, and the few that may be too obscure are enlightened by the hint system. Several puzzles have multiple solutions, too (I finished the game without solving every puzzle), and at least a few of them affect the endings of the story.

"Primordia" (as other adventure games) may feel a bit too short when comparing the playtime/cost ratio with other genres, but IMHO it's the price of well crafted plot & characters... and, perhaps more important, of setting and themes you keep thinking about even after finishing the game.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014197372', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1450796740}
review:

La storia di suo ha una belle profondit√†, trama e intreccio sono ben fatti, cos√¨ come i risvolti e le possibilit√† di scelta che generano nell'avanzare del gioco.

Stile grafico coraggioso, d'impatto e di tutto rispetto sopratutto.

Insomma, davvero un bel gioco come non se ne vedevano da un po', almeno nel suo genere: la sua ambientazione e l'anima poetica vi cattureranno.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002977327', 'num_games_owned': 430, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1451101375}
review:
==New Review
I've written a new review on completing the game. First I still think the warning applies: it should be made clearer that it runs 640x400.** That's not a full screen size image in the video**. However I found it best to turn on x4 anti-aliasing, this is the best option.

This is a great story, nice main character and side kick, good voice acting, setting is interesting. I only got stuck a couple of times, and you know when you do in these games it's because you've missed something obvious or not so obvious on the screen. I'm not a fan of searching the screen for a clue and there is'nt  too much of that, but if you get stuck chances are it's that. The memorious puzzle was in fact a bit oblique to me, like I'd forgotten something in a trunk.

I'd also say this is the type of game where even though the in game data collection works fine you will need a pen and paper for a couple of the code and logic puzzles but that's it. Mostly because getting it wrong the first time locks you out of achieving some of the achievements, though this does give you incentive to play again.  

It has multiple endings so there's some replayability to it at the end. 
I'd compare the setting to Machinarium, but story style wise and feel more Beneth a steel sky. I happen to think those are two top games.

To dev: I dont think a sequel would be possible *right now* but maybe a prequel  would fit really well here. Do a Star Wars and make a trilogy and jump around the timeline.
Having read the Fallen pdf it did give me much more of a sense of story, I can see how things would be missing with out it. I'd put a link on the store page for download if it's not already there. Add the setting to right click change settings to the library entry.

Top Rating

=== old review
I bought a bunch of point and clicks at the same time, and when I got this I really didnt realise it ran this size. It's too fiddly and post stamp size. I'm aware I can scale it up x4 but then it becomes quite hard to discern things in the picture, which is annoying.
I don't have a problem with pixel art, and in some cases that's easier for finding things on screen rather than a high res style, but the art style here makes it too difficult to recognise things. I played through Techno Babylon no problem, which is at a larger resolution but something about that game has cleaner lines where as Primordia has a lot of detail. I'd compare this more to Machinarium style but pixelated.
This could really benefit the clarity it has at 640x400 at a larger frame. I know that won't be possible without remaking it, but that might actually be worth doing...
At the moment im in two minds about it and getting a refund.
Which is a pity because im pretty sure it is good. 
Depends if you can live with that size. edit: use 4x anti-aliasing, it goes a bit dream like looking but it's certainly better. cheers
===

author: {'steamid': '76561198066143262', 'num_games_owned': 277, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 512, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1450643660}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013222580', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1690520818}
review:
I have not played a point and click adventure game in a long time. 
Maybe since I was seven or ten either way I was really young.
And being much older I looked down on this games and never give them a chance.
But man do I feel stupid after playing this wonderful game.

Not only is this a great game for many reason's but its done more then just play and run wonderfully.
Its opened my eyes to what amazing storys and places are in all types of games not just your AAA titles.
This game is why I love steam their's something for almost everone to enjoy and being someone whos super into mecha,
robots, mechanical design, pixal art, and post apocalyptic setting this game hit all the right buttons.

But for the game itself I will keep this simple.
Its got amazing characters.
Great voice acting.
Amazing art and styling.
Super interesting story and lore I can't get enough of.
Gamplay is fun and inventive.
And the sound design and soundtrack is just prefect.

I really want to thank the people at Wormwood Studios and everyone who took the time, And effort to make this game.
Thank you so much for making this game its an amazing title and made me open my eyes more to other cool and interesting games and made me love the imagintion of this wonderful industry even more so thank you.

10/10 easily makes my top ten games I have ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134079987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1591806192}
review:
MULTIPLE ENDINGS.

Which also means you can "mess up." XD But it is a gorgeous masterpiece--just listen to that audio! LISTEN. It's hypnotic.

The characters have PERSONALITY, and SASS. Plenty of sass. The banter during this game... Agh, so gooooood! I melt every time I re-enter.

It makes sense. The story, I mean. There isn't much, if anything, to complain about.

The fact that I have only played 1.5 hours, and holy smecks, do I plan on playing MUCH MORE (shh, I peeked ahead), and am still hyped...  It just shows you how fantastic it is. It's already one of my favorites. 

Look, I encourage you to buy it, play it, even tell Markiplier, Cryaotic, Jacksepticeye and all your favorite YouTubers to about it. Challenge them to get all the endings and achievements on their own. It's so full and charming!

IT IS EPIC. 

IT IS WORTH IT. I want more games like this, with its enriching tale and way of storytelling, how the small puzzles urge you forward rather than hinder you... Believe me, it's more than "satisfying."

author: {'steamid': '76561198054248784', 'num_games_owned': 112, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 576, 'last_played': 1485987200}

And another thing, I actually didn't come across one single bug or glitch.

This game is beautiful, flawless, atmospheric and well fucking worth the $10 out of your bank.

Give. The. Developers. Your. Fucking. Money. NOW.
