author: {'steamid': '76561198057143937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1448558374}
review:
I give it 8.5 / 10

The puzzles provide a good challenge and the story is well written. I really enjoyed playing through this, unlike other point and click adventure games. The themes are also pretty dark, but very satisfying and aided in keeping me playing. I tend to put these kind of games down because I get bored or suck. I hated mine sweeper as a kid and randomly clicking around the screen got tiresome. Primordia even has some cheeky and cleaver dialogue incase you need to run around clicking everything. Didn't help with the frustration, but the occasional joke helped keep me from just giving up. Plus CYBERPUNK! PLUS POST APOCALYPTIC WASTELANDS!

SPOILERS!!!!--------

There are multiple endings. I assure you, saving right before the big confontation helps you experience them all! Each is pretty cool, but even some optional items can have an impact on the ending. Mainly items belonging to your companions. Also certain events may occur that have an impact on your endings. Save different files often as kind of a bookmark so you can go back and attempt for different outcomes. I had about 17 so I could see everything with three files for all the endings (confrontation save)  

For example, there's a situation where you can corner a rogue AI. Save before you attempt! Trapping him gives you an item that aids in the true ending, but killing him changes the ending of that chapter. So if you want to experience both chapter endings, you'll need 2 saves, but after that, the two paths merge and continues normally. 

ALSO! SPOILERS!

Have Crispin talk to the lanterns. He needs the practice!

review: The only thing I hate about this game is that I didn't know about it sooner.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012419488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1447612963}
review:
I can hardly remeber such an enjoyable experience for science fiction fan or anyone lusting for intellectual pleasure.

The game delivers in every single way: story, humour, drama, allusions ("this sheet really ties room together", or the robot on a bus stop and others), the setting, artitstic touch, sound, music.

It is reasonably complex. It's not an easy jorney and not a hard-core point-n-click experience, it's in a sweet spot, golden middle. I'm not a huge fan of games of such genre but I play time to time, and it is quite casual to google solution/walkthough soon enough. Not the case for Primordia. Actually I was capable of beating the game without google at all - only for achievements and some hidden story lines.

Certainly recommend! The game is rated "Overwhelmingly Positive" by community and this is really deserved.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072336177', 'num_games_owned': 225, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 425, 'last_played': 1447470201}
review: Do you like good stories? Do you like nice voice acting? Do you like some fucking awesome artwork and scenarios and ambience and whatnot? Do you like beautiful soundtracks? Do you like that kind of game where you start out laughing and having a good time and ends up becoming a crying confused mess at the end, but you still want more, so you keep asking yourself "why the hell it took me so long to start playing this game"? Then go ahead and play it. Just do it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025067795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 306, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1447265049}
review:
One of my new favorite point & click adventure games ever made, alongside [b]Chains of Satinav[/b] and its sequel [b]Memoria[/b]. 
The first act is a little slow and the third act a little straightforward, but the writing, dialogue, puzzles, theme and pretty much everything else is incredible! Well deserving of its glowing reviews on Steam and across the internet.
I also really liked the various outcomes of your choices during the game's finale, in which even some decisions early on in the game had an impact.

One of Wadjet Eye's best games, if not THE best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039908015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1389493114}
review: Beautiful pixel art is the crowning aspect of this game, just leaving it open and taking in the graphics are worth the price alone. The comedic dialogue is nicely written and acted although a bit out of place in the dismal Kinotrope-esque atmosphere of rusted machinery and manufactured wastelands. The graphics really are just stunning but as with many pointy clicky games it falls into the pitfalls of 1. having a great environment and concept but underdeveloped characters and 2. some of the puzzles just make no goddamn sense. It's one thing to have difficult puzzles, I recently played armikrog and although it took me a while I still required no walk-through because it all followed some sense,  however with this game I needed walkthroughs multiple times only to find nonsense solutions that followed no logic, when it comes to puzzle structure I expected more from the creators of Gemini Rue. BUT I still did find myself really WANTING to advance to see more of the beautiful artwork and unique world-building shown in the game and I have to commend it for that. Overall I recommend it for the graphics alone but be prepared for the game's fair share of banana fishing rods and accordion bird vacuums.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004778076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 385, 'last_played': 1378048952}

author: {'steamid': '76561198033072969', 'num_games_owned': 209, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 375, 'last_played': 1445622543}
review:
I don't write reviews often but this game warrants one.

I highly recommend this game, It is a truely amazing experiance and you can see just how much dedication to every detail was given to this game. I haven't experianced a story that moved me as much as this in a long time! The world feels so alive and the puzzles and tasks feel meaningful not thrown together. This is the first point and click I ever finished to the end without using a guide, however this does not mean its easy just that the difficult challenges are fun and worth working through on your own.

The characters, the art the atmosphere and music and the backstory just everything about this game is perfect and I am mourning its end as I could sit in front of my computer playing this forever.

If you for what ever reason are on the fence about buying this masterfully crafted game please take my advice and just buy it. I would have paid double for this without hesitation.

Thank you to the developers for this awesome game! and a round of applause to the artists and the voice actors as everything just fits perfectly!

10/10 Buy it now or miss out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044338757', 'num_games_owned': 164, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1486791381}
review: As a person who doesn't enjoy point and click games whatsoever, I have already played through the entire story three times now. This game has one of the most compelling storylines I have seen in a long time and, despite its mechanical simplicity, has easily become one of my favorite titles. The artwork is absolutely gorgeous and the voice acting is incredible. The perfect balance of humor and darkness creates an atmosphere that is not easy to replicate in a game. If you're looking for a game with an excellent story and moderately difficult puzzles to complete along the way, this game is perfect.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197992010236', 'num_games_owned': 1058, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1443988259}
review:
Primordia is a classic point and click adventure game, with gameplay reminiscent of Zork, King's Quest, or Monkey Island. You will gather, combine, and use items found throughout the world to solve problems, and you will be asked to solve the occasional riddle.

You take on the role of Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot who lives in the wasteland, salvaging parts to repair a derelict flying ship. The game begins when a strange robot cuts his way into the side of your ship, shoots you, and steals your vital power core. Without a power source to recharge your body you will surely die, so you and your companion (a floating, armless sidekick named Crispin Horatiobuilt) set out to recover your core, or at least to find a suitable replacement.

The game is divided into two major parts: first, you wander the wasteland searching for a power core, then eventually you leave the wasteland for a second location. Once you transition to the second area, you will no longer be able to access the wasteland portion of the game. Along the way, you will meet many strange robots, unravel mysteries about your world and your own past, and uncover a sinister plot.

Storytelling is Primordia's greatest strength. Once the narrative picks up (beginning about halfway through the wasteland section), the story really engages the player. The cast of characters (most of which are found in the game's second area) are surprisingly well realized. Each has a distinct personality and a clear motivation. Your relationships with each of them feel genuine, and even your enemies feel well rounded.

The game's setting and art style combine with the well realized characters to create a compelling sense of place. Despite the low resolution environments and sprites, Primordia's world feels bigger than the screen it plays out on. Stellar voice acting and a droning ambient soundtrack put the finishing touches on a beautifully desolate world.

For all its strengths, though, Primordia's downfall is the gameplay. In the 80s and early 90s, point and click adventures were among the best represented genres in PC gaming. Since the rise of 3D graphics and the emergence of new styles of adventure game, they have retreated to the niche and indie markets. My memories of those old adventure games are pleasant, and it takes a game like Primordia to clear the fogged lenses of time. Simply put, even the best made adventure games tend to have puzzles whose solution only seemed apparent to the designer. And Primordia is far from the best made adventure game.

The first issue is that puzzles in Primordia often have nonsensical solutions, or worse, do not permit you to use the most obvious solution. One puzzle early on asked me to plug a pair of ventilation ducts. The first I plugged easily with a piece of scrap cut from a nearby structure, but despite there being three more identical pieces of scrap to cut from, the game would not permit me to do so, and instead demanded I locate an unrelated item that did not seem to fit (according to the visual representations in the game). And these logical disconnects are such frequent occurrances, you will soon find yourself simply trying to use every item in your inventory on each puzzle in the hope that a solution will present itself.

The second issue is the way the game arbitrarily cuts you off from certain areas, objectives, and even major plot threads. It is even possible to lock yourself out of "winning" the game (you can still complete the game and achieve one of the "bad" endings) through a blindly made choice in the first 30 minutes of play.

Lastly (and this is a small complaint), the inclusion of achievements seems to undermine the freedom built into the game's choices. When there are three ways to resolve a puzzle, but one awards an achievement, there is a real sense that there is a "right way" to play, stifling any sense of freedom the system might have otherwise provided.

These serious and frankly unforgivable design flaws sour what might have been an excellent game. Die hard point and click adventure fans will probably push right through, but if you are an average modern gamer with fond memories of classic adventure games, prepare to be reminded of all the bad mechanics that made those games such a frustrating experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136843720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 539, 'last_played': 1441203207}
review: The moment when you get to the bus-stop robot and hear the somber "I am waiting" with Blade Runneresque music in the background is priceless. It is a rarity among video games to have such an integral world with its lore and still be digestible. To be placed in a dark bleak world, yet to have a lot to interact with. This game is a must for all who enjoy dark sceneries and deeper philosophical themes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972483399', 'num_games_owned': 1027, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1442400484}
review: If you like point-and-click adventure games, this is an AWESOME title. The atmosphere and storytelling in this game are REALLY, really good -- injecting new life into old themes (post-apoc, robot rules/society, etc.) and it has quality voice acting that really helps immersion. I truly cared about the characters in this game and there not only were multiple endings, but in many ways more than one way to solve a problem -- which is rare in games like this. I am generally NOT a fan of Point/Click adventures, but I HAPPILY made an exception to play this one. I was sad to finish it, because it meant parting ways with the world of this game, that I so enjoyed. Where many games disappoint, this unravels mysteries worth knowing... and endings worth seeking. <3 Recommended.

review: The best point and click adventure game I have personally ever played.  The story is fantastic and well executed with alot of dialog and character development that does not get overbearing.  The puzzels are sometimes a little frustrating but very satisfying once complete and it all culminates in multiple possible endings influenced by decisions made hours ago.  Machines worship Man just as humans worship gods, and this game immerses you in their world.  10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011669791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1440972911}
review:
Maybe it's a bit of a bold statement but I think Primordia is a memorable game, so much so that I'm writing this review to recommend it.

I'm a story guy and this game delivers it in spades both at a macro level (the main story arch) and micro level (the single scenes). It does suffer a bit from the puzzle adventure syndrome, that is, it's not always clear how to solve a problem with the stuff you have, even when you have everything that's needed. I know this is to be expected in a way but it still bothers me.
The old nerd in me suspected some of the details revealed in the final scenes right from the start but the game was compelling enough to just draw me in the atmospheric setting and make me concentrate on what was happening at a certain point. Hard to say the same about most games I've tried.
The music may be a bit repetitive in the long run but it really adds to the mood, it fits perfectly. So much so that I actually noticed, appreciated and left it on: in other games I usually have it on low volume or off entirely.
The graphics are retro, but in a good way. A shiny AAA engine would only marginally enhance the game. Some may even think that this old school style is actually better/more suited to this kind of game, can't say they are completely wrong.
Again, highly recommended, best game I've played in a long while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961314223', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1440882862}
review:
Really enjoyed Primordia overall. Play time 8hrs.

Things i liked:

- Good story, with cool characters.
- Excellent polylogues.
- Jokes.
- Sense of progression.
- "I am waiting", "A simple model."

Somethings i found annoying were:

- I wasn't always able to discern clickable objects (objects that had a hover-over text component) which hindered my progress. (MOST ANNOYING)
- I couldn't always tell when story paths were diverging, though this more subtle style of nuance might be a aesthetic feature.
- Some puzzles required an excessively broad associative horizon, which didn't always match real world thinking (according to me).

author: {'steamid': '76561198065854803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1439903688}
review:

Nieco gorsza jest oprawa wizualna, bardzo klimatyczna, ale momentami nieprzejrzysta. ≈öwietnego ca≈Çokszta≈Çtu dope≈ÇniajƒÖ ciekawe i r√≥≈ºnorodne zagadki oraz niezbyt wyg√≥rowana cena.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006527801', 'num_games_owned': 737, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1651281792}
review:
This game was a pleasant surprise, to be certain. I could tell just from looking at the trailer and screenshots of this game that it looked interesting, and that "Overwhelmingly Positive" next to the user reviews made it seem like a no-brainer. So, finally I picked up this game and boy, I am not disappointed.

Let's get the bad out of the way first.

This game runs in a very small resolution, at least for most modern monitors. The highest resolution possible is 1280x800, which looks best in a window. It was also a bit annoying that the only way I could find to change these settings was by a launcher in the actual folder containing the game files. I only found that much by perusing the game forum when I was disappointed with the resolution.

There isn't much replayability. I can definitely see myself trying this game again to do a few things different, but overall it is a story-driven and therefore linear experience. It has several endings, but most of those endings are decided at your own whim by how you play out the final scenes.

Now, the good.

The obvious first thing you'll notice about this game is that artwork. I found it to be very cool to look at and definitely gives you that feeling of despair - a world wasting away around you as you desperately try to rebuild what you can. You also have atmospheric music that adds to these scenes but mostly stays in the background. It adds a lot, but doesn't overtake it. Instead, it's all just working together to give you an experience.

The voice acting is likewise excellent. The main character and his sidekick both do most of the talking, so it's great to see them so well performed. It's easy to pick up on their personalities and they're both likeable.

I'm always a bit bad at puzzles in games, but I thought the ones here were challenging but always possible. Nothing ever felt frustrating or beyond my abilities to figure out. I did get "stuck" in a few places where I had no idea what to do, but it usually came down to me not thinking about the situation well enough or remembering details that I simply overlooked. It's worth saying, almost everything matters in this game. There are few things that are superfluous.

Overall it took me about six hours to complete this game. I would have liked for it to be longer, but I could say that for any good game.

If you're interested in this game at all, check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016198906', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1635913607}
review:
Good Lord please buy and play this game if you're looking at it. I liked it so much that I still think about it from time to time even though I finished my play through two and a half years ago. If you're checking out this review, then trust me you're going to love this game.

It has the absolute best, richest, and most vivid atmosphere I've ever seen in a game and the voice acting is top notch. The story is engaging and compelling. You'll be hooked.

Do yourself the favor. It's only ten bucks, and you'll thank me when you're done.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990655811', 'num_games_owned': 622, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1438385619}
review:
+++ Puzzles that make realistic sense, well-integrated into the story, and with multiple ways to solve them.
+++ Solid script, greatly blending comedy and drama.
+++ Rich and palpable world, friendly to immersion.

--- Hand-drawn vistas difficult to appreciate due to the game's old-school extra-low resolution.

Primordia is a game that almost plays itself.  The sort of puzzle-adventure where you become engrossed into the world, and lose track of time.  Its strongest point by far is how its puzzles blend in seamlessly with the world story, and thus the solutions feel natural and well thought out.  Without doubt, this is an extremely high-quality game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046897501', 'num_games_owned': 254, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1437681688}
review:
Primordia is my first "proper" Point and Click and as such I did have some trouble with some of the puzzles, but I am someone who is completly new to it with only The Walking Dead as a prior Point and Click.

Primordia is heavily story rich. There's so much in the world that I wish I could have explored more so that I might have more knowlege about it, but since it's not importaint to the plot it's touched on at most. [spoiler] There is an information kiosk that you can look at however. It'll give you information on any topic you can find. [/spoiler]

You follow Horatio and Crispin, two robots living out in the dunes, until their power core was stolen by a bigger robot. They embark on a mission to get it back. I don't want to go too deep into story but the ending was one I was very satisfied with. I'm so used to games having a truely happy ending but the endings in Primordia were none of that. [spoiler] The endings were that of weariness, telling the player that in this world there is no such thing as a happy ending.  The world has died and there doesn't seem to be a way to get a kind of renewable resource, and if there is it's just not known. [/spoiler]

Primordia was an amazing game, it wasn't too long nor too short. It was just right.

review: This is one of my favorite games, I played through it twice, the second time having the game developers commentary on. It was a great experience, and the emotional times can really dig into your heart of the games story. It's a great story, solid puzzles, amazing character designs, and I love the envirnoments. 10/10 would play through a third time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066983814', 'num_games_owned': 483, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 320, 'last_played': 1506980278}
review:
A hidden gem on the Steam store, Primordia is a game that is about robots in a world where their creators have long since been gone. You are a robot named Horatio Nullbuilt with his best friend Crispin Harotiobuilt, and you two are living in a wasteland. This game is great at charather development and world building.
Man is a god among robots and some say Man never existed. Some robots are barely surviving in the dying world they find themselves in. Others live together in Metro city, a strange place that seems like the last civil place on earth. When Horatio and Crispin's power core (the thing that keeps them alive and running) is stolen, they must embark on a journey using only stuff they can salvage in classic point and click style to find whats rightfully theirs. The gameplay is simple, but like most point and clicks it's about the world and the story is tells. And it tells a good story. Without wanting to spoil anything, trust me and get this.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999334943', 'num_games_owned': 844, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 504, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 504, 'last_played': 1383421826}
review: Damn good post-apocalyptic robot noir.  Reminded me of Alphaville and other bleak black-and-white post-war counter-modernist films.  I can't comment on the voice acting, because I play adventure games with voices turned off whenever possible (and so should you), but competent writing.  Varied locations and characters.  Multiple satisfying endings, and even the "happiest" is pleasantly bleak.  One of the best of the modern small-team adventure games (definitely better than Gemini Rue, which also was going for sci-fi noir).

author: {'steamid': '76561198044784523', 'num_games_owned': 808, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1437123728}
review:
I've always been a fan of the adventure games Myst and Riven. My favorite part about these games, as a kid, was that they whisked you away to a completely different, and foreign place. Though many adventure games seek to do this, few fall short, and end up feeling like "just another point and click" derived of any rich narrative. Primordia is not one of those games that falls short at all.

I should admit before I go any further that I've only played the opening sequence of this game thus far, and am extremely excited to get back to it after this review, but this particular summary will be noting the aesthetic, and initial response of Primordia.

I absolutely love post-apocalypse. It's not an uncommon scenario, thankfully, so there's lots of material to dig through on the subject. Unfortunately, there's quite a lot of BAD post-apocalypse games out there, and so with some hesitation, I bought this game, and sat down with some skepticism. For ten bucks, I was hoping it was going to deliver, and the reviews spoke for themselves.

Primordia does something a lot of post-apocalyptic stories don't, and removes humans altogether from the character roster. You begin the game as Horatio Nullbuilt (the surname meaning some dude presumeably named 'Null' built him, which is a common theme throughout the game), the 5th version to be precise, and are accompanied by Crispin Horatiobuilt, your custom companion and comic relief. The world around you is an age-old Earth, looking very barren and very post-war. A strange robot cuts down your door one day and steals your power core, without which you can not charge your own batteries (nor Crispin's). Since that simply won't do, you venture out into the world in order to find the strange robot and reclaim your power core. 

Easier said than done. What follows are scenes common to Adventure/Point+Click games: You meet hosts of interesting robots, travel to new and exciting places, and spend a good deal of time trying to combine every single item in your inventory to see if it does something cool. Excellent (okay... MOSTLY excellent) voice acting, a (so far) riveting and comedic script, beautiful artwork, and intriguing characters make this one of my favorite Adventure games to date, and I've barely even started it.

Should you get it? I mean, it's a point and click. You know what you're getting. The deciding factor, in most cases, is the story and artwork, and both deliver wholeheartedly. Even this early, the story is already showing to be incredibly promising, with twists and turns, and dark comedy as only robots can deliver. The script, as mentioned, is really quite good, and I don't find myself simply reading through the subtitles and clicking through in order to progress, but rather relishing the lines and the delivery. The art, while simple and "retro" in style, does not detract at all from the story, but actually enhances it with far-off vistas, incredible robot designs, and teeming robot cities, both very alive, and strangely dead. 

Fans of point and clicks, this is another excellent addition to your collection, reminding me of titles like Deponia, Riven, and (of course) Monkey Island. Fans of sci-fi, post apocalyptic fiction will also love this game. All in all, I think it's one of those rare games on Steam where I feel like I absolutely got what I paid for, and then some.

And I haven't even finished it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068649736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 763, 'last_played': 1436731838}
review: I couldnt pull myself away from this game! It was a real peice of nostalgia playing a 90s DOS-style point and click game. The graphics were very impressive, and keeping loyal to the distinct low-res 16-bit feel. The storyline is engaging with some interesting sub-text about human society. The puzzles are challenging enough to keep you wanting more, but never too challenging. The music was beautiful and really added to the sence of desolation. The only think i didnt like was some of the voice acting was a bit hammy. Other than that its a brilliant game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122656243', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1464987305}
review:
When I first saw this game, I was looking for something similar to machinarium (another point-and-click adventure game) and what I was met with while playing Primordia was not at all disappointing. There are some very unique things that set this game apart from other point-and-click adventure games.
     One element that is so different about Primordia is the surprisingly large amount of dialogue that is incorporated into it, unlike most other games of the genre.
     Another characteristic that adds to the game is Crispin, the protagonist's "sidekick" if you would call him that. He adds a sense of humour to the game (although sometimes rather corny) and can offer hints to the player that are valuable, but not always completely revealing of the next course of action that must be taken. Crispin is an often uplifting character in this post-apocalytic setting.
     Another trait that won me over is the atmosphere in the game. It seems realistic in the post-apocalyptic setting, and it is one of my favorite things about this game. The backrounds always seem beautifully made.
     The puzzles in this game are very engaging and are not always clear-cut which may seem like a bad thing, but I personally enjoy the extra challenge. Not every puzzle is as simple as clicking on one thing and then another. They often include various items and/or certain actions to be taken. This is a huge difference between Primordia and other point-and-click adventure games.
     The only complaint I really have about this game is that it seems to include a few creationist concepts that I personally do not agree with. It is brought up through the concept of humanism in the game which is symbolic of today's major religions that believe that a god created humans.
     Another piece of this game that I am not fully content with is the way the protagonist moves. It can sometimes seem somewhat clumsy, but I won't be critical about it seeing as how that is how it is with most other point-and-click adventure games.
     Overall, I would give this game an 8.5/10. It is definitely a worthwhile play for those who like games such as machinarium or other big point-and-click adventure games because of the unique elements it includes.
     One last thing I would like to address is that it sometimes has multiple choices that can be made, leading to different outcomes. They do not alwyas have a huge effect on the story, but it adds a sense of independence in the game.
I highly recommend that you all look into playing this game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198039580049', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 400, 'playtime_forever': 1080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 673, 'last_played': 1707697453}
review:
I haven't played a point & click adventure game for a long time now (my last game was the second "Broken Sword" game, which came out in 1997). I wanted to remember my childhood experience with such games, so I chose this game to do it with. It's a good game for its genre. 
I enjoyed the world, characters and story the game offered. It was quite entertaining. Solving the puzzles felt good and the story (though not character driven) evolved in a way that made sense. 
There was only one major flaw in the game - a puzzle that required the player to know a different language! If you don't know that language, then be prepared to look it up ... so if you plan to play this game without cheating (like my plan was), then be prepared to be disappointed (or as in my case outraged) with this puzzle. Good luck with trying to have a good time with the game after that puzzle ... http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=474516938 http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=470028951 Unlocked all achievements!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044539233', 'num_games_owned': 1235, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 653, 'last_played': 1450525195}
review:
Point and click adventure with a dark sci-fi setting.  The graphics are low-res, but everything is super polished.  The voice acting is also extremely good.

It's LucasArts style (no unwinnable situations), but there are multiple possible endings you may have access to based on your actions.

Good story and fun puzzles.  Worth a playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126903460', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 519, 'last_played': 1436115888}
review: A fantastic sci-fi point an click, brilliant Gieger-esque Art Novau style and a sense of humour that worked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025460617', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 426, 'last_played': 1435765005}
review:
Great game. The grungy cyber-punk story is right up my alley. It's cryptic and a bit hard some times, as point and click adventures should be, but I only got stuck once and you can't run into dead ends where you cant finish the game.

Only issue I had was with the resolution, but with a quick google search on the issue all my problems were solved.

Would recomend for any point and click adventure fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047003592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1435789659}
review:
The game is good. Beautiful art, decent story, most puzzles are logical.
Worth buying, specially when in sales.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068637953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1435369545}
review: There's a Fallout Easter Egg in this game and that itself is awesome, the story is very nice and the dialogues between the robot bros is amazing as well as with the other bots, some puzzles are sooo cryptic that can definately lose my will to keep going on. Specially in the city part. I played it for more than 5 hours but due to technical difficulties i played the rest offline. Good game I really loved it, i got it on sale and think that i should have gotten it full priced honestly. GG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002354450', 'num_games_owned': 1067, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1435237753}
review: Wonderful world building, engaging story, very simple and elegant interface, terrific voice acting. Highly recommended and well worth the time playing and the money to purchase. Definitely take the time to click anything and everything you can find. Also there are multiple endings and some quests it's easily possible to lock yourself out of if you're not careful (though the reasons you get locked out make sense to the storyline). Play through at least once and then check out a guide so you can make sure to see everything. I got every achievement and had a blast doing so.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995790140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1435397296}
review:
97% d'avis positifs sur Steam, des critiques dithyrambiques, en plus j'adore les jeux Wadjet Eye Games, notamment la s√©rie des Blackwell que je consid√®re comme passionnante et originale √† beaucoup de niveaux. Et pour couronner le tout, les univers post-apocalyptiques sont plut√¥t ma tasse de th√©. Pour moi, il √©tait √©vident que j'allais passer un bon moment avec Primordia !

Il y a beaucoup d'√©l√©ments pour faire un bon jeu dans Primordia !
H√©las, malgr√© tous mes bons √†-prioris et ma volont√© de m'amuser, je n'ai jamais r√©ussi.

Histoire en r√©sum√©:
L'humanit√© a disparu compl√®tement depuis des lustres et ses seuls h√©ritiers peuplant la Terre sont les robots, qui ont reconstruit une soci√©t√© bien √† eux, h√©ritant toutes les tares de leurs cr√©ateurs. L'Homme n'est aujourd'hui plus qu'une l√©gende, certains robots y croient, et d'autres non. Horatio, le h√©ros, vit en ermite dans le d√©sert et se fait voler la pi√®ce ma√Ætresse de son vaisseau par un robot mena√ßant. Aid√© par son petit assistant Crispin, il se lance √† la poursuite du voleur, ce qui l'entra√Ænera dans diverses p√©rip√©ties...

Premi√®res constatations : les graphismes sont d√©licieusement mornes et d√©primants, et la musique est du plus bel effet.
Les doublages sont pas mal, m√™me si l'intonation des personnages (robots) est constamment monocorde, et que leur voix est souvent distordue, ce qui se r√©v√®le un peu fatiguant √† la longue. On retrouve l'ami Abe Goldfarb, qui doublait Joey dans les Blackwell, et qui se cantonne ici encore au r√¥le de l'assistant du h√©ros, Crispin. Mais √ßa fait toujours plaisir de le retrouver !

Plus on avance, plus on se rend compte que l'histoire et l'ambiance sont tr√®s s√©rieuses. Les quelques traits d'humour sont surtout des r√©f√©rences de geek (jeux vid√©o comme half life, fallout, etc) et des blagues d'informaticien, bref, tout ce que je d√©teste. Dommage !
Le rythme est lent et je me suis demand√© de nombreuses fois quand l'intrigue allait finir par d√©coller, ou quand les choses allaient vraiment bouger. Ca vient peut-√™tre aussi de l'ambiance pesante ou simplement de l'univers assez fig√© et monotone. C'est s√ªrement voulu, mais du coup, √† aucun moment je ne me suis amus√© sur ce jeu. Je ne me suis jamais senti non plus emport√© par l'intrigue, qui passe rapidement de retrouver la pi√®ce du vaisseau √† sauver une ville enti√®re. Un rebondissement un peu trop classique dans le genre.
Difficile de se sentir impliqu√© lorsque cette ville est peupl√©e de seulement quelques robots. En effet, avec le recul, vous n'int√©ragirez pas avec beaucoup de personnages : ceux avec lesquels le h√©ros peut vraiment dialoguer de fa√ßon √©labor√©e (hormis son compagnon) ne sont pas nombreux.
Les dialogues montrent √† quel point les robots du coin sont compl√®tement tordus / bugg√©s, ce qui peut √™tre amusant. Vers la fin, le h√©ros affirme qu'il en consid√®re certains comme ses amis alors qu'au bout du compte, ils se sont crois√©s dans la journ√©e et n'ont eu que des √©changes assez limit√©s (hormis avec Crispin, encore une fois). C'est assez bizarrement amen√©. Mis √† part Horatio, les personnages ont un background assez peu d√©velopp√©, ce qui ne permet pas de s'y attacher vraiment. Leur (non) charisme n'aide pas beaucoup non plus, mis √† part Crispin, qui fait de son mieux pour caser des blagues et des remarques cyniques quand il peut.

Reste alors les √©nigmes. 
Certaines sont plut√¥t originales (le branchement des c√¢bles par exemple), certaines sont juste usantes. Avec le recul, encore une fois, je me rends compte que j'ai pass√© une bonne partie de mon temps √† trouver des codes et √† jongler avec pour ouvrir des portes / r√©parer des trucs. Le reste du temps, je l'ai pass√© √† trouver des objets pour les donner √† un gus X ou Y qui m'en refile un autre en √©change, et ainsi de suite. La forme est parfois vari√©e mais le fond ne l'est pas du tout. Le peu qu'il reste se compose d'√©nigmes de r√©paration et de dialogues de type questions-r√©ponses - vrai/faux selon ce que vous avez retenu du dialogue.

L'outil qui r√©cup√®re les donn√©es part d'une bonne intention puisqu'il vous permet de stocker les infos et de les garder sous la main √† tout moment pour r√©soudre les √©nigmes, comme une sorte de calepin. Le probl√®me, c'est qu'il stocke √† la fois des informations cruciales et des trucs compl√®tement inutiles ou dont vous ne vous servirez plus jamais (il n'efface pas automatiquement les infos qui correspondent √† des √©nigmes r√©solues depuis belle lurette), ce qui vous oblige √† faire d√©filer tout un tas de pages sans int√©r√™t avant de retrouver celle qui vous int√©resse. A quoi √ßa sert ?

Point appr√©ciable cela dit : aucune erreur / mauvais choix n'est consid√©r√© comme un √©chec dans le jeu. Vous pouvez tout √† fait foirer une sc√®ne, le jeu consid√®rera toujours qu'il s'agit de votre mani√®re √† vous de faire avancer l'histoire. Ca vous laisse donc de nombreuses possibilit√©s de d√©bloquer des situations. Autre point positif qui en d√©coule directement : de nombreuses fins sont disponibles !

Au bout du compte, le jeu est plut√¥t court (entre 4 et 6h), sauf si vous comptez le recommencer pour tester toutes les solutions et les fins. L'histoire est assez t√©l√©phon√©e, et plut√¥t basique sur le sujet Science-fiction / robots.

En r√©sum√© :
Si vous aimez beaucoup les point and click, les ambiances post-apocalyptiques, la science fiction, les r√©f√©rences geek, les robots, et surtout, si vous √™tes un grand nostalgique, vous appr√©cierez sans doute ce jeu, en plus le prix est plut√¥t correct.
Seulement voil√†, ces crit√®res sont g√©n√©raux, et cette critique refl√®te uniquement mon avis personnel. Oui, il est possible d'√™tre d√©√ßu par ce jeu, il s'agit plus d'une mise en garde. Si les points n√©gatifs que j'ai mentionn√©s sont importants pour vous, donc si vous avez plus ou moins les m√™mes exigences que moi, r√©fl√©chissez bien.

J'esp√®re que ceux qui se laisseront tenter l'appr√©cieront, car j'adore ce studio et j'ai beaucoup de respect pour le travail qu'ils accomplissent habituellement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998136902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1435380658}

Fallout+Machinarium+Awesome Companion=Primordia

author: {'steamid': '76561198028911545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 595, 'last_played': 1435049134}
review:
Silly humour and neat story, really enjoyed it.

I'm not sure on their decision to making a game in this day and age for a 320x200 CRT screen though, and have to upscale it on you screen. Is it just trying to capture the look of old games for old times sake?
I assume the art would have been drawn at higher resolution to start with, why not keep it like that instead of downgrading it into pixels? The only reason games use to look like that was because that's all they were capable of.
Would have been nice to have the option to choose the original art of the downsampled pixel art.
Or is it some twisted joke +_+ since the game talks about the future and technology?

author: {'steamid': '76561197970398622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1435123094}
review:
Primordia doesn‚Äôt have the best start. During the first 20 minutes I was pushing myself to continue based only on the positive reputation of the title. I‚Äôm glad I stuck with it, because when it gets going it‚Äôs an admirable game. The world and the story has as much rigorous thought and attention put to it as you could ever demand of a title. 

My only problem with the game (apart from the slow start) is the puzzles. I don‚Äôt mind slow paced games, or solving puzzles. But there‚Äôs something with the point-and-click form that makes me lose patience faster than 3d puzzle games like Portal or Antichamber. There‚Äôs always walkthroughs to help out players like me, but I don‚Äôt like going that route. There‚Äôs puzzles in Primordia where I have no idea how I would have ever solved them, like in my entire life, without looking up the solution. I want to see what happens next in the story, that‚Äôs my primary interest in these titles. But the designers thought otherwise, and because they thought this was a good idea, I‚Äôm not going to think ill of anyone who likes the puzzles. It‚Äôs just not for me. And I guess it‚Äôs ‚Äúnot really a problem‚Äù because faqs exist. But I wish there was something else that could be done with this type of game. Of all the point-and-click games I‚Äôve played there‚Äôs only a couple where I haven‚Äôt hit a wall because of pixel hunting. Those moments always make me wonder what the point is.

Despite that rambling second paragraph I would absolutely recommend Primordia to anyone who likes the look of it. It‚Äôs superb sci-fi, of the kind that‚Äôs not just rare in games, but rare anywhere. It treats its characters and the world with intelligence and respect. What made the first 20 minutes a bit dull was that I couldn't tell how ambitious it was going to be with the setting. I mean I've seen a ton of stories start out like this with lonely scavengers in the desert. But when it started dropping hints about what the game would really be about it made me increasingly excited. It takes a serious stab at exploring what life as a machine in a world run by machines would be like. What their religions and laws could be. Echoes of their human ancestors, now adapted for their style of thinking. And it does this without any attempt at dumbing it down for a wide audience. A gutsy thing to do, and it works.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094432643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 1439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 989, 'last_played': 1441665800}
review:
Gorgeous post-apocalyptic p&c adventure with an interesting take on religion from the perspective of robots. A bit rough in places where the audio goes in and out, and a few odd glitches here and there (I unlocked the "end the game with every robot possible" achievement at the same time I got the "kill EVERYTHING" achievement??), but otherwise near perfect. I still can't get over the animation of the melting door!

A++ would play again, if just for Logan Cunningham =3

author: {'steamid': '76561198012002337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1370400738}
review: Fun old school point & click adventure. Definitely worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049283080', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1434998563}
review:
This is a very interesting and strange game.

The graphic style is ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù kind of haunting and wistful, unique and beautiful.
Play is somewhat frustrating because you have to find items then combine them while in your inventory for use on items in the environment.
Some of the combinations that need to be used are just not intuitive or easily figured out.
Also if you combine two items by putting one on the other it may not combine until you put the other thing on the one thing. 
(In example, maybe you put water on dirt it doesn‚Äôt make mud but if you put dirt on water it DOES make mud)

Personally I have enjoyed the walkthrough so far, I say walkthrough because to make any real progress in the game I just keep the gamezibo.com walkthrough open on my tablet.

So, I can‚Äôt really say that I am playing the game, perhaps you are more clever than I am, but, I need a step by step guide.

Graphic style and clever banter are the strong points of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134678166', 'num_games_owned': 551, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1438974788}
review: At times, the puzzles can be very frustrating, but not beyond what's to be expected in a point-and-click. This robot-centric game is atmospheric and at times funny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008668180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 723, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1434942027}
review: The game has story richness and suspense oozes out at you at every turn. Every detail beckons you to imagine beyond what is presented on screen, and wonder at the depth of the story and the background. This game needs to be scaled up and expanded to compete against AAA titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153068062', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1434907277}
review:
I absolutely adored this game. The story was compelling enough for me to feel invested without becoming so complicated that I lost interest. The visuals and sound track are stunning. The dialogue is well written. Crispin is a little talkative but I grew to enjoy his company. The puzzles have a range of difficulties. 

My only issue with the game was it crashed on my a few times. I was able to fix the crashing but there was still a glitch were the images of my inventory looked like colored blocks. It did not really effect the game play though.

Would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027295819', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 428, 'last_played': 1456177013}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089501075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 553, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1420960307}
review:
I do not like point and clicks.

I love this point and click.

Characters you actually care about. Very interesting story told mostly through implication rather than blatant exposition. At least as many allusions as any Fallout game. Despite the fact that the game is fairly small and your ability to explore and interact with the world are necessarily limited it still manages to create the impression of a much larger world. My only complaint, and it's a small one in this internet world, is that some of the bread crumbs are so far off the path that after you look up a walkthrough to get you unstuck you're left wondering how the first guy ever managed to figure it out in the first place.

I have more money. If they ever add to this world I will have a little less.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963813187', 'num_games_owned': 1356, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 88, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 88, 'last_played': 1375304877}
review:
At first the game is all like "HAVE SOME MORE FRAMES!"

And I'm like "No, that's okay, I still haven't totally explored these, and found all the objects"

And then the game is like "HAVE SOME MORE FRAMES!"

And I'm like "Really, no, it's alright. I'm still completely dumbfounded by the frames I already have"

To which the game is like "HAVE SOME MORE FRAMES!"

And at that point I realize I'm totally fucked. I'm back to being 7 years old and trying to figure out The Secret of goddamn Monkey Island.

Primordia doesn't want to be your friend as much as Wadjet Eyes own productions, and I don't think that's a good thing.. But it's still mostly worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101454381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1486743858}

author: {'steamid': '76561198197569186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 437, 'last_played': 1433136793}
review: I LOVE post-apocalyptic dystopian stories like this!  The puzzles were challenging but fun, the dialogue was great (I never got tired of Crispin's quips), and the art was so cool!  I loved the style so much, it really suited the theme of the narrative perfectly.  I'm really glad I played this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045739251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1427741014}
review: I really enjoyed playing this point and click game about a robot who is learning about himself while working to figure out what happened to mankind who made him.  It is a bit of a sad tale with various endings but overall a really neat story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153154083', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1475992401}
review: This game is incredibly engrossing. I simply could not stop playing once I started it. The artwork is beautiful and nostalgic, the story is darkly satisfying, and the post-apocalyptic world is phenomenal. It's so rewarding to solve all of the little puzzles and find funny little hints (the Fallout one made my day). I would HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone with the need for a good, profound story and a great brain teaser. Buy this game now!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972487188', 'num_games_owned': 855, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 443, 'last_played': 1434281040}
review: A few puzzle actions defy logic, as in any point and click, but no more than a few. Crispin is a genuinely helpful companion whose advice stays the urge to glance a guide when at a dead end. The somber color pallet holds a mood that Full Throttle had merely aspired to. Voice acting is rigid but professional, each sentence unnaturally delivered one line at a time as would be expected of a classic in the genre. Story is vague but sufficient in depth, it is delivered with subtlety and no facet is ever put forth like a child's bedtime story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040573839', 'num_games_owned': 2228, 'num_reviews': 298, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1434307543}
review: Very interesting adventure game. Make sure you look up the alternate endings after you finish it. They're all really good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995217572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1434287545}
review:
A refreshing original adventure game with strangely charming retro-graphics despite the desolate environments devoid of living things. You play as a robot in a post-apocalyptic world, where robots of varying degrees of sentience, function and design remain after humanity become extinct. Exploring and learning more about the world is compelling, the puzzles are well enough designed, you have a companion that is both useful and funny and the game is just long enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome. 
A small gem of an adventure game. Much recommended - don't let the seemingly crude and perhaps initially offputting graphics deter you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971653267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1355644800}

author: {'steamid': '76561198063377908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1596833866}

author: {'steamid': '76561198104181925', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1502832519}
review:
I am a huge fan of Point and Click games, from the DOTT and Monkey Island games. I am a huge fan of Wadjet Eye games and I usually buy all of their creations. So like all of the games I played through I'm going to review it in PROs and CONs. Or you can of course read the Verdict at the end.

[b]PROs:[/b]
[list]
[*] Beautiful pixel art graphics
[*] Incredibly immersive 
[*] Awesome storyline
[*] Really good and unique Jokes especially if you're a computer geek
[*] You have a floating companion
[*] A lot of content to explore and scenes to unlock
[*] Multiple choices to solve puzzles
[*] Multiple endings (you should play all of them)
[*] Really really awesome ambient and music
[/list]

b]CONs:[/b]
[list]
[*] Too short
[*] Should be longer 
[*] Really too short
[*] Some parts of the game should be more explorable
[*] WE NEED MORE BACKSTORY


[/list]

[b]Verdict[/b]

It's an incredibly beautiful game, with beautiful music and funny jokes. I really hope for a sequel or anything happening in the future. It has multiple choices of how to solve a puzzle, which is somewhat revolutionizing, since in the early games there was only one way to finish the game. Now I really want to replay some of the scenes because of different interactions. The one and only CON that I could think of is, that it's simply too short. I finished it in less than 20 hrs and after it I felt sad that it already ended. It had a lot of fun and interesting characters. Another awesome job you did there Wadjet Eye!

author: {'steamid': '76561198040788270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1434031781}

author: {'steamid': '76561197992662345', 'num_games_owned': 598, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1433827870}
review: One of the most enjoyable adventure games I've played. It doesn't treat you like a child and assumes you're up for the challenge but is never too frustrating. Great atmosphere and great story, all around very good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006944655', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1362384000}
review: Great puzzler with loveable characters. If you like machinarium and similar games this ones right up your alley!

author: {'steamid': '76561197971878112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1433540239}
review:
Ok so let me start off by saying even at full price this game is worth buying.It's goregous in a rusty-noir (that's mine) kind of way that, I honestly didn't think was possible with this type of rendering. This game has made me an instand wadjet eye fanboy.

I experienced absolutely no bugs in my playthrough,
 I thoroughly enjoyed the voice acting, and the writing is excellent. 
I was able to play this game with my 3 year old in the room (you don't generally find such a dark story free of offensive language or innapropriate visual content so it's a huge plus for me.)
Easily the best point and click game I have ever played (I've been gaming for 27 years now I like to think of myself as a connoisseur).
If you like the point and click genre you NEED to play this.
If you don't, but like a good story then I'd say you wont be dissapointed.
You can read more about the story and setting in other reviews so I wont go into it. I'd just say that it was enthralling start to finish and the puzzles aren't brainwracking but you need to use your head throughout the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000824354', 'num_games_owned': 1300, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1418481843}
review:
A downbeat trod through a world where robots scramble to survive amongst the ruins of decaying, forgotten human world. Primordia has all the charm, class and witt of old point-and-click games and none of their problems and is a delightful story in a game that doesn't hold your hand. All in all, a short point-and-click adventure game with puzzle elements and some philosophical nods.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

* Some very cool little puzzles add a little bit of depth and side objective. One puzzle, for example, has you exploring an encyclopaedia style database of information via an information kiosk to try and unlock information pertaining to the current objective, and is a nice side-step distraction
* Incredibly good game design, nothing is over or under designed and it takes all the good elements of old point-and-click games and none of the problems
* Fantastic sound assets, voice acting and soundtrack

[h1]Mistakes[/h1]

Finding mistakes and problems with this game is difficult, though there are some minor and non specific design mistakes.

* It can be finicky trying to find solutions to progress at times which can impact the pace of the story
* The graphics are arguably too low-res or dark. For me, that adds to the appeal

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

Primordia is listed at ¬£6.99/9,99‚Ç¨/$9.99 which is fair for it's 6 hour+ story. There's also a [url=http://www.wormwoodstudios.com/p/primordia.html]short demo available for free[/url].

GOG offers a copy of the soundtrack, a MAC version and some other small extras at a cheaper price and may be a better choice for some.

* There are a number of interesting cutscenes and small story elements to discover, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=152701150]most of which are married with Achievements[/url]
* Everyone who enjoys Primordia should take a few minutes to check out Wormwood Studios' other IP which includes 3 games; Like a Raisin in the Sun, Salt and Beacon, and a number of short stories, all of which are [url=http://www.wormwoodstudios.com/p/small-games.html]available for free from Wormwood Studios, hosted on The Escapist[/url].
* [spoiler][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T7HPWpjCesQ]Primordia has several possible endings[/url][/spoiler]

http://store.steampowered.com/app/227000

author: {'steamid': '76561197989896260', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1432748901}
review:
[b]General Overview[/b]: Primordia, a point and click adventure, takes place in the unique timeline of post-apocalyptia where humans are no longer present. The only thing left is their own invention: machine. Machine that prospered and slowly became just like human, with their own ideas and vices. Even if they're limited by their programming, they could still interact with others like normal folk. Taking the reigns of Horatio Nullbuilt and Crispin, what starts as a simple retrieval turns into a full blown adventure, albeit a somewhat short trip.

[b]Gameplay[/b]: The game itself follows the point and click style of gameplay, so its hard to screw that part up. That said, it does a good enough job being difficult and leaving you wondering "what the hell do I do now?" Thankfully, Crispin has a built in hint-o-tron to give you tips on what you could do or should do if you're ever stumped. The puzzles themselves are, in my opinion, pretty darn easy. The only difficult ones would be where you meet your unfriendly thief again or when you need access to a certain place with a long string of code. Other than that, it's pretty straight forward. Then again, I play puzzles for kicks so take that with a grain of salt. 

There [i]are[/i] some puzzles with different methods of completion, usually a good and bad way. Sometimes the bad way is the only obvious way, where the good way will require a save here and there to help you out should you pull an oopsie. By the way, you'll probably be doing this often. Puzzles do have "soft-fail" states, which can be pretty infuriating, so save often! The actual game itself is, unfortunately, pretty damn short. You could probably finish the entire game within 5 hours or so (after knowing everything and everyone and all the choices). There is [i]A TON[/i] of going back and forth. No joke, you'll probably find yourself going back and forth between robots, trying everything, for a good 10 minutes until something works. It can get annoying fast. There are also a few references sprinkled here and there to earn a few chuckles. Some more obvious than others.

[b]Art[/b]: Holy hell, this art style. While a mess of browns, it works so damn well together. Not to mention Horatio and Crispin always seem to stand out from the environment whenever possible, so that's also a plus. Unfortunately, the overwhelming abundance of browns makes finding some robots or items kinda difficult. Had to pull the hover method to find a few things sometimes. I understand its supposed to be post-apocalyptia, but sometimes you have to look away and rub your eyes.

[b]Music[/b]: It's amazing. Done.

[b]Acting[/b]: The VA in this game are beautiful and, at the same time, somewhat phoned in. Sometimes you can tell the lines are being read from the script. Other times you feel it from the heart. It is, overall, a very good experience to feel the voices actually try when they do. Funnily enough, it was the side characters that, in my opinion, had the best acting compared to our main characters.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone that loves a good point and click adventure with a fanfuckingtastic sound track.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961367991', 'num_games_owned': 457, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1580874592}

author: {'steamid': '76561197960539015', 'num_games_owned': 771, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 715, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 715, 'last_played': 1431474643}
review: What a great goddamn game.  So well done, so deep.  The only thing I felt lacking was the ending, but then I discovered that I had only experienced 2 possible endings out of SEVEN.  Top notch artwork.  Outstanding voice acting.  A gripping story in a world that could be our own.  I have never consumed ANY form of media that made me feel sympathy for a robot (except Marvin from Hitchhiker's, perhaps...)  I really can't wait for Wormwood Studios' next project.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966004131', 'num_games_owned': 1107, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1430952436}

author: {'steamid': '76561198071422698', 'num_games_owned': 326, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1430928749}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970687509', 'num_games_owned': 1185, 'num_reviews': 283, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 298, 'last_played': 1430862787}
review: Usually I do not have the patience to play retro (i.e. pixelated) point-and-click adventures anymore, nevermind finish them. This one kept me going though and I played it all in one sitting. What kept me going? The setting and the story were original (at least they were to me) and engaging. The gameplay and puzzles were simple enough to not get tedious without being pure pushovers. Most importantly, though, the characters were interesting and absolutely beautifully voiced -- far superior to a recent so-called "AAA game" that I played where I grew to hate the characters. Not in Primordia: every character was great and the voice actors and sound design was perfect: Horatio, Crispin, Clarity, Ever-Faithful, Gimbal,  Goliath, Oswald, Primer, 187th, Memento Moribuilt -- so many awesome voices and dialogues that I enjoyed immensely.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969634400', 'num_games_owned': 592, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1429265232}
review:
Wow, another great entry into this new golden age of adventure games. Primordia does so many things right, stuff that should be common in every game of this genre, like multiple solutions to puzzles, branching paths and multiple endings.

Both the story and atmosphere are great, and Crispin, the sidekick, serves not only as a great jokester, but also as a nice hint system that ensures that we are not left wandering aimlessly, like in many old adventure games. 

The game is quite short, but it‚Äôs better for it, as it doesn‚Äôt suffer from overreach, and it achieves the goal of telling a good story and exploring interesting themes.

There‚Äôs not many downsides to this game, but one particular puzzle, near the end of the game (involving a kiosk), annoyed me, and didn‚Äôt played by the same rules as the rest of the game. I also thought that the voice of Horatio never felt appropriate for a robot (it‚Äôs the same actor as the main character of Gemini Rue, but in that case it fit great) , but it‚Äôs just a minor quibble. The rest of the cast and characters are great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034255356', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 247, 'last_played': 1429141515}
review: Very depressing and bitter sweet but very hauntingly beautiful. Highly recommended for sci-fi story fans in particular robot-AI story lovers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013115338', 'num_games_owned': 7447, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1433, 'last_played': 1428962050}
review:
A fun point & click adventure developed by Wormwood Studios. This is their only commercial release to date but they did do two games for Indie Speed Run 2013 called Like a Raisin in the Sun and Salt. It takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where all the humans are gone and you play a robot named Horatio Nullbuilt.  You have a broken down ship that you live in and another robot breaks in shoots you and steals your power core. Now you are on a mission to get it back.

Gameplay:
	It plays just like a typical point & click adventure game. Finding objects to use and figure out puzzles to progress further in the game. Puzzles were a little challenging for me but were fun to figure out. They require some logic and can have multiple ways to figure them out. Choices you make in the game can change things later in the game. If you‚Äôve played other adventure games then you‚Äôll have no trouble playing this.

Story:
	It kept me interested and curious to dig deeper. It all starts out over a power core but there‚Äôs a deeper secret you can uncover if you make the right choices in the game. Great supporting cast which brought some comedy to the game. I really enjoyed the banter from Crispin your little sidekick throughout the game. There‚Äôs also seven different endings to the story if you care to see them all.

Visuals & Sound:
	It has retro style graphics with some great looking hand drawn rooms. They did a great job of showing you a dark and grim world. An easy to use interface, and great voice acting. You can also change it to text only if you are one who just wants to read it all.

Overall:
	Primordia was a fun and enjoyable game. The story was a little slow in the beginning but picks up a little ways in. I laughed at times and even felt a little sad at times. It‚Äôs well worth playing if you enjoy point & click adventure games or a good story and it won‚Äôt take you to long to beat.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969331425', 'num_games_owned': 1305, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1428801760}
review: Fantastic story and puzzles. I am a huge fan of all of WadjetEye's adventure games and this one does not disappoint.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970680531', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1650237014}
review:
Truly a master piece point click adventure game which has learned and adapted from all it's former predecessors. If you're interested in an old styled point click adventure which preserves the "vintage" feel of the genre, while making mile stone improvements to its execution -- then this is for you. 

Everything in this game made sense, I only used the walkthrough a small amount of times. The side kick is actually useful, he even hints you if you get stuck. The characters felt real and alive, things were not too 'grindy' and the story was very captivating... I can't say enough good things. If you're thinking about buying this game then don't think twice, buy it.
