author: {'steamid': '76561198010212548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1355126400}
review: Yes! I haven't played all the games published from Wadjet Eye Games but I would recommend this and also Resonance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999192541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 583, 'last_played': 1411363908}
review:
I would really like to recommend this game but I simply can't.  Despite the unique story, amazing voice acting, and fun universe it all took a back seat to the puzzle aspect of the game.

I'm no stranger to adventure games.  I've always been a fan of these types of games but Primordia simply doesn't do it for me.  I found the puzzles to be frustrating and counter intuitive.

Part way through the game I ran into a game breaking bug that caused it to be impossible to continue without a guide.  After an hour of rubbing things on other things and clicking on every pixel I did the unthinkable and went to a guide only to find out I've run into a somewhat common glitch.  On this Steam forum I see a post from one of the writers/designers for the game say "Sigh. If we ever do another patch, I'll make sure it gets fixed."  This is my ulitmate woe with the indy developer.  I pay for the game and I would hope that known bugs would be fixed.  I don't like to hear "IF we ever do another patch."  A bug in an adventure game isn't like most other games.  You don't always know there is a problem.  You just keep trying to solve the puzzle till you give up or turn to a guide.  For me that ruined half the experience.  Now every time I get stuck I wonder if I'm wasting my time because of another bug or did I forget to pick up a cup of coffee three screens back.

TLDR:  If you want the game then get it for the story and the art and not the puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010369064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 579, 'last_played': 1411264259}
review: I really loved Primordia it took me back to the days when Sierra, Revolution and Lucas Arts created some truly unique games and Primordia stands perfectly in their company. The voice acting is very good and there is a lot of humorous references to pop, computing and gaming culture. Primordia gives the player many choices for a game in this genre with various ways to solve puzzles and multiple endings that have very different outcomes. A few puzzles might be considered difficult, but most will keep you entertained without causing frustration. It took me about 8 hours to finish before going back to try different solutions to see the all the endings. I think Primordia is well worth the asking price and I found it more enjoyable than some newer click adventures 2-3 times more expensive. If you enjoyed games like Beneath A Steel Sky, The Dig or Ring World you won't be disappointed in Primordia.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076365408', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 722, 'last_played': 1458446953}
review: One of the best adventure games I have ever played.  Solid dialogue, wonderful plot and characters.  Multiple endings, about 12 hours of gameplay, and a sassy robot sidekick that provides amusing commentary.  The voice acting and music are top notch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042281910', 'num_games_owned': 351, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1404014273}
review: Kind of a strange steampunk point-and-click adventure. The main character has the same voice as the narrator in Bastion, adding some nostalgia in there. The story is amazing, as should be in any point and click. It's a fairly quick game, but it's certainly not easy to figure out. Reminded me a little of Zork. I loved the game, and it's worth your time and money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984093030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1423879385}
review: This game is ONLY $9.99. ONLY. I would (and have) pay much, much more for a game of this caliber. I've gifted it to several friends, because it is easily the best game I have played in the past five years.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027737162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 331, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1410399372}
review:
This game has an excellent story and a unique and interesting setting filled with charmingly colorful characters.  It is thoughtful and meaningful, and addresses some serious theological and philosophical points, while remaining mysterious and exciting (most of the time).  However, I found the gameplay to be very lacking, in a number of ways.  I'm now going to complain about all the things I need to complain about, but do please recall that I actually enjoyed this game :)

The puzzles in this game were difficult, and not in a good way.  While many of them had "cool" solutions - which would be awesome in a movie, for example - they were often not cleanly solvable, in the sense that they were the only plausible solution and made everything "make sense" when you figured it out.  For me, a lot of the reason I want to play a puzzle game is for that awesome feeling of everything coming together when I figure it out.  This is not the sort of game that does that for me.  Here's a few of the problems that I saw:

1. Trying to create a clever solution rather than a good puzzle.  The solutions to puzzles are often the sort of zany solutions that are fun to watch heroes think of in movies, but not reasonable to force the player to think of.  In other words, they don't feel like THE solution, just A solution (and yet in the confines of the game, they are THE solution).
2. Tooooo many items.  Unlike a lot of games, in Primordia you almost never get an item taken out of your inventory when you are done using it.  By the end of the game, I have so much stuff in my inventory that the task of getting through a locked door has dozens of reasonable-sounding solutions - crowbar, plasma torch, signal transmitter to pick the lock, etc, etc - but only one of them is right (and it's probably none of the standard things I've learned how to do throughout the game, because that would be to easy).
3. Generic, reusable items.  This is one of my pet peeves in puzzle games.  When you have a generic item like a hammer, there's a trillion and five ways that the player can think of to use this item.  Even if the game designer could think of all of those, allowing those solutions would make many of their puzzles too easy.  Anyway, this game is full of generic items that you use again and again throughout the game (but are never allowed to use when you think of it).
4. Confusing items.  I had a whole bunch of electronic gadgets and doodads that it took me a long time to figure out how they worked - a signal transmitter, a decryption device, a memory reader, etc.  All of these could be used only in very specific circumstances (i.e. as far as I can tell, the memory reader can only be used to access memories from a severed robot head - which you encounter in this game a lot more than you would think!), but this information is never explicitly told to you (I never really figured out what the rules for the decryption device were).
5. Just too much going on at once.  The game is basically divided into two parts.  During each part, you slowly unlock more areas, and then can travel freely between all areas that you have unlocked during that part, which by the end of each part results in a huge environment in which to look for a small number of remains tasks.

The end result of all of this was that I played the game with a walkthrough constantly ready.  And I do not regret it :)  Most of the things I had to get help on ("most" because I started getting lazy near the end), I think I would have felt frustrated rather than satisfied if I took the time to solve myself.

The interface is unfathomably archaic and unintuitive.  For example, the process of using an item - one of the most base necessities of a point and click game - requires (1) hovering near the top of the screen to open the tool bar, (2) selecting the inventory button to open your inventory, (3) selecting the item from the inventory, (4) clicking outside the inventory to close it, then finally (5) clicking on the thing in the world that you want to use the item on.  On all the interfaces mentioned, there are also many confusing and sometimes unnecessary/duplicate buttons.  The datachron (which automatically takes notes on things you have learned) has a horrific interface that looks something like an old school gameboy, with giant text on a tiny screen, and buttons (that you have to click with your mouse) for scolling up and down.  Similarly, the signal transmitter - on which you frequently need to set a 4-digit number to transmit - is pretty obnoxious, requiring you to click on the left and right sides of two dials (not even buttons that you can see, so it's hard to find the sweet spot to actually click on) - one to cycle through numbers, and one to cycle through DIGITS.  DIGITS.

All that being said, however, I think this game is definitely worth playing for the story alone, which like I said is fantastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010334329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1410309420}

author: {'steamid': '76561197999470590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 938, 'last_played': 1410006808}
review:
Overall this is a sad case of a game with brilliant elements but too many faults to make it an enjoyable experience. It has the best sense of humour of just about any game I have played. The story is good, though some of the elements don't fit together.

The problems are:  

1/ the graphics are terrible. Yes, they have a cute, arty style but they are ridiculously low resolution. 

2/ The mechanics are clunky, with slow menus and too much time watching pixellated figures crossing the screen painfully slowly. 

3/ Some of the puzzles are good, but a lot of the time I had to use a walkthrough not because a puzzle was difficult but because the game is inconsistent. Most exits are identified by mousing over, but some are only identified if you move the character to the edge of the screen. There is a system of storing info useful for solving puzzles but some of the info stored is irrelevant and some vital info is not stored. To combine items in inventory you pick up A and mouse it over B. You get a message telling you that's a dumb idea, but it turns out you need to pick up B and mouse it over A.

Cleverly written, and chock full of enjoyable characters. The puzzles followed a logic that was immediately understandable, but still required creativity to solve. In short, I loved it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018526506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1404123674}
review:
If you like point and click adventure games this is for you.
Well developed characters, mysterious and intriguing story boasting multiple choices and endings.
Set in a gritty, grimy sci-fi post-apocalyptic diesel punk world.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989378273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 457, 'last_played': 1407316571}
review:
First the good: Nice world, nice graphics, reasonable story, adequate voice acting.

Now the bad: Arbitrary puzzles, extemely linear, except for the magic points you should save to redo different "paths" for the achievements, terrible obvious boring ending, unskippable credit sequence that doesn't even respect alt-F4, and worst of all it just not fun.

Constructive advice to the devs: Don't make your hint bot refuse to give hints, especially in a snarky tone. Make your puzzles actually make sense. Tell the player when the path of a mostly linear game is going to diverge. Better yet, auto-save right before that divergence. Allow the player to be the hero at the end. Choosing "I'll never join you!" should not end with a crap series of still screens and the player losing to the big bad.

Constructive advice to people who play it: Use a walkthrough. The first part is pretty decent but the city is just silly and arbitrary. And you'll never get the achievements without a walkthrough, unless you click everything always forever in the right order (including not talking to someone when you first meet them!).

author: {'steamid': '76561198062269122', 'num_games_owned': 1154, 'num_reviews': 290, 'playtime_forever': 603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 603, 'last_played': 1406886519}
review:
Si eres de los que vivi√≥ la √©poca dorada de las aventuras gr√°ficas, deja de quejarte por los rincones como un viejo cascarrabias y juega a "Primordia", una aventura gr√°fica con p√≠xeles como pu√±os que te devolver√° a los 90.
La historia se centra en un mundo postapocal√≠ptico plagado de robots donde t√∫ eres Horatio. S√≠, eres un robot, no el flipado de CSI. El caso es que un robot con apariencia de caja de zapatos voladora te roba el n√∫cleo de energ√≠a de tu nave, as√≠ que ya sabes, ¬°a buscar!
Durante la aventura ir√°s acompa√±ado de un cacharro volador llamado Crispin, que har√° las funciones del t√≠pico escudero dando pie a conversaciones graciosas o bien facilitarte pistas.
El juego no es de humor. Tiene un tono serio-decadente, pero apto para todos los p√∫blicos.
Los gr√°ficos son calcados a los de los 90. Pixelacos de los buenos. La m√∫sica tambi√©n est√° genial. Vamos, que de poco salgo a comprarme una mano-loca al kiosko del rev√≠val noventero que me ha dado.
El juego en s√≠ es corto, pero como la dificultad en algunos puntos es jodidilla, pues seguro que se te hace algo m√°s largo.
Probablemente, tal y como est√°n las aventuras gr√°ficas actualmente, "Primordia" no ocupe el lugar que merece. Ahora, mientras me invento un futuro ut√≥pico donde este juego ocupa un lugar especial en el mundo del videojuego, aprovechad para sacar vuestra tarjeta bancaria y comprar el juego, ¬øo vais a compraros un en√©simo FIFA?

[b]La historia parece demasiado simple. ¬øDe verdad es bueno?[/b] En ese caso, lo siento, oh gran cerebro, siento comunicarte que este juego no tiene la cantidad de millones de giros de guion como para que te guste. No lo juegues.
[b]Me refiero a que va de unos robot buscando un "n√∫cleo de energ√≠a". ¬øNo es demasiado t√≠pico?[/b] No te quedes con eso. Lo bueno del juego se saborea jugando, no leyendo la cr√≠tica de un t√≠o que no conoces de nada.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046487935', 'num_games_owned': 414, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 597, 'last_played': 1527538805}
review:
[h1]The greatest point'n click for all cyberpunk lovers[/h1]

I've played a lot of point'n click, and besides the fact that some others as Machinarium and Botanicula are pretty amazing, this one was for me, by far, the best one I've ever done. Everything is perfectly designed to take you in the game, the characters are very well made, and the story will make you think and ask yourself about things you didn't even expect.   

It is of course my personnal feeling, as I love cyberpunk, but I think this game is worth playing. You will have some great time, I guarantee it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066339830', 'num_games_owned': 4106, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 3323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2225, 'last_played': 1421453543}
review:
Primordia, a point and click adventure game that has quite good story with challenging puzzles. More or less like The Cat Lady... the good and the bad. To sum it up:

Pros:
- Great/Mature story
- Multiple endings
- Challenging puzzles... to the point I required help from walkthrough *ahem*
- Funny dialogues
- Great voice actors
- Decent price point

Bad:
- Weak graphic engine, seriously. I even had a Developer helped me to get the game up and running.
- Art isn't up to my standard.
- A bit short game (approx 5 hours), but for 2.5 USD when discounted/on sale (or bundled), well... I guess  can't be helped.

The gameplay is just another point and click adventure. You pick up one object, deliver it to one character, get another item to unlock another area... rinse and repeat. You also are required to pay attention to hints collected. Not so much new invention in this aspect.

Story, well, I can't say much without spoiling anything, but the story is interesting enough. In fact, I wouldn't have completed the game had the story been bad. It's like, again, The Cat Lady - light story in the beginning and developing slowly until the finale.

Soundtrack is so-so, not that good but not that bad. Voice actors, however, are top notch. They really portray the characters well. Oh yes, don't forget about hilarious exchanges between Horatio and Chrispin throughout the game. More often than not I laughed on many occasions thanks to that funny Chrispin. 

Overall, Wormwood Studios, I think, have a success creating a good game for us all. Moreover, they are willing to interact and listen to their playerbase as well: see  [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/227000/discussions/0/38596748079663186/]here[/url]. I wish them luck with their future projects, too bad it won't be Primordia 2 (as has been said by the Developer himself).

Recommended game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052714314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 698, 'last_played': 1388213291}
review: This is an absolutely fantastic point and click adventure. I am so happy to find a great little treasure such as this. Genuine storytelling is hard to find it seems like, and this has that dusty wasteland / rusty robot feeling to it that our post-modern imaginatinos crave.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068919027', 'num_games_owned': 219, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1396488613}
review:
So first things first, i did not finish this game. I liked it, but there came a time when i said enough was enough. I gave up on the game not because it's broken, no because the stories bad, and not because it's a bad game. I stopped because i couldn't stand some design choices made by the developer. If you don't have a problem with some of the issues i have with this game, then it might be a better game then i let on.

This game is good, the stories a bit so-so (i am not a sci-fi fan, so this may not be the case for you), but there is a depth to the world that makes exploration satisfying. For an adventure game (and a sci-fi), it's not bad. Adventure games are usually sold based on their stroy, or their atmosphere and world; this one falls squarely with the interesting world brand of adventure games. It takes a serious stance to its story, so if you wanted another monkey island-ish adventure game, keep looking. The visuals are solid, and what humor there is (mainly in the form of referenceses, such as the crowbar) isn't very satisfying, but it's harmless. 

Where the game lost me is its choice on puzzle design. There comes a time when you have to do some tasks, like convince 2 robots to stop arguing. The problem i have with it is they don't give you the information for long, so you either have to write it down or memorize it. Only after writing it down can you try to solve the riddle. It's a bit backwards, where you have to work around outdated, missing, or omited mechanics to get to the puzzle before you've even had a chance to ponder it. There is a device that records important pieces of information, but what it deems as important can be hit or miss sometimes (such as the robot diologue riddles, where the riddles aren't written down). 

The game also does a very poor job of giving hints if your stuck. This problem, and a few others, are indicitive of the genre. One such problem is having puzzles where you have to guess at what the developer wanted you to use to progress. An example would be ruining soup in some adventure game, where you have mud, shoe polish, and a rat. Only one will ruin the soup, despite all of them being viable in a realist sense. 

In the end, this is an adventure game, so replayability is already low. I'd rather not waste my time reruning the same diologue trees over and over, which is what i found i had to do for the robot riddle puzzles. If I couldn't write fast enough (cus memorizing the jargen and name drops was not easy), i would have to guess and restart. There are i believe 5 riddles or so, so having to restart from the 4th on can be annoying to say the least. At this point, the game felt more like work then fun, so i gave up on it. I didn't want to put in that much effort for what i felt was not enough in return. 

You are expected to bring a lot to the table to get through the game. Good memory, write stuff down, and replay the same section over if you experiment. You will find that trying to force your way through diologue puzzles is very time consuming. If you get stuck and fall back on this, you might feel inticed to cheat (as i was). When i feel like i have to resort to a walkthrough to make progress, the game begins to feels like a chore. It's not fun when you have to use a walkthrough for an adventure game, because relying on it really takes you out of the world. Personally, i call it quits at that point, as i did here

To reiterate, this is not a bad game. It's a game with a vision that i fell outside of. If you played a lot of old-school adventure games, or you're a sci-fi fan, you might find a lot to like. If you find you didn't like older adventure games (or Daedelic's brand of adventure games, like The Dark Eye or Memoria), or you gravitate towards newer games like the Telltale brand of adventure games, this game may not be to you're liking.

If an old-school sci-fi adventure game with some of the problems of older games, as well a bit unforgiving approach to game design (in that you will solve problems for yourself, without more help then the developer deems nessassary) sound good to you, then this might be a game you will enjoy.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If anyone should wonder why the developer of the game commented on this review (i was very suprised about it, personally), it's because he questioned some of my reasons for quiting, as well as questioning why i would post a review of a game i played so little of. After being initially pissed, i thought a lot about the review and realized how many assuptions i had taken as fact. I heavily edited the review after i thought about it, namely because the initial review didn't convey what i wanted it to; this game was not for me, for the reasons listed above, but it might be the game for you depending on your tastes. 

The developer didn't harrass me (though initially i thought he had), and i am changing this review because i feel like it. Mark was a decent guy, and he responded more calmly and professionally then i thought he would. I made the changes i did because i was initially wrong, the developer earned my respect, and i had gone back over the review and found it unsatisfactory. If you think this makes my review less reliable, then so be it. You have been informed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045081106', 'num_games_owned': 1181, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1591496919}
review: For those who grew up on the point and click adventure games of old (Monkey Island, Full Throttle, et cetera), they aren't dead - you just need to know where to look. To those who haven't, point and clicks are largely narrative-driven games based upon exploration and puzzles - and this game has all three in spades. Intriuging setting? Done. Tough, but (almost always) fair, puzzles? Done. A compelling narrative? Oh yeah. This game has all of two downsides - first, that clues are sprinkled into the dialogue, but there isn't a way to reexamine or replay it, so sometimes you're left guessing. Second, the game is short - but this is more of a nitpick than anything, because its actual length belies the completeness which the game concludes with. Ultimately, this is a great work by a talented team, and the only real reason you wouldn't like it is because you don't like point and click adventures.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059125167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1414369868}
review:
I revived a giant war robot by sticking its finger up its nose 11/10.

In all seriousness though, this game is beautiful. The story is wonderful and moving, the characters are well-written and fleshed out, and the humor is surprisingly funny despite the game's bleak dystopian setting. The art and backgrounds, though they look somewhat dated and old-fashioned, are still detailed and do a very good job building the world and creating the atmosphere. The puzzles were a little hard to figure out at times, but always had a logical solution. I strongly recommend this game to everyone, unless you're not much of a point-and-click fan or can't stand dystopian settings I guess. Seriously though, this game is amazing. You won't be disappointed.

This game also happened to introduce me to Wadjet Eye Games and has sort of been a gateway drug into their other games. Which are also really good. I am ok with that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991394989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1412214954}
review: Great little game.  Some easy puzzles, but many that make you think.  Several different ending options (though they don't vary TOO terribly much), decent graphics & decent story and some good humor make this make a lot of fun to play.  It's easy to pick up and easy to get hooked on playing.  This was definitely one of my better P&C purchases :)  If you aren't too concerned with achievements it is likely a quick playthrough, but the achievements make it a bit more fun.  They aren't overly tedious and add some fun and humor to the game.  Well worth the time to get them!

author: {'steamid': '76561197982374070', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1461, 'last_played': 1418315372}
review: Love the art style and music in this game! It sets the mood beautifully for a captivating storyline filled with humour and compelling characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981064656', 'num_games_owned': 1060, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1537295195}
review:
The story is about a neutral bot which don't give a shit about anything except himself. The player choose himself of whom Horatio would be by doing the thing around the game.
One of these "old-school" adventure games, when you solve "a puzzle" or to move on next by the multiple ways.
The consequence is just a different ending to the game. Oh boy, and it has a lot of the endings.

Pro: story, music, dialogues, art.

Cons: game is very easy and logic if you want to get to the end, but some moments are really screwed up, it took 20 days to think for a 5-6h game; also there is nothing new if you played the "Planescape: Torment".

P.S. Look for Horus

author: {'steamid': '76561198012670485', 'num_games_owned': 345, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1405972895}
review:
I'm not giving a thumbs down because I out and out dislike the game - I'm not not entirely sure if it's worth the trailer hype and full price purchase given the shortcomings. Feels like a spiritual successor of sorts to Beneath A Steel Sky, something I'm surprised more people didn't pick up on. Visually it all works and the music pleasantly chugs along - Along with some humour from Horatio and Crispin.

Here's the problem though; Just as the game allows you to get more comfortable and eager to explore the story more, it stops becoming fun. The middle section of the game has some painful 'swap this for that' puzzle sequences that become a chore, and you are only driven to continue because of the story, and trust me, you will be looking at a walkthrough at some point, some of the puzzles are too obtuse.

It also ends far too soon - overall only having 2 main environments in the whole game is not that satisfying at all, and what could have been quite atmospheric starts to feel a little brownwashed. The character development was never built up long enough for me to feel any emotional connections with the characters, and there were some uninspired and cliched plot turns. Beneath A Steel Sky never varied too much in environment either but at least it stayed enjoyable right to the end. There are multiple paths in the game to take which will lead to different endings - but it really depends on whether you enjoyed the first run to want to do this, and I'm not entirely sure if I want to play this game again for a while. Shame there's no windowed mode either, can appreciate the Lucasarts style resolution/graphics decision but couldn't easily leave the window or tweak anything.

I'm not saying it's a bad game, trust me, it isn't - I would just suggest you wait for it to go on sale, as there's a chance you could be disappointed like I was.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990944536', 'num_games_owned': 245, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1405931068}
review:
Overall satisfying adventure game with only a few caveats.  Most of all I recommend this game.  

Pros: 
‚Ä¢ Thought-provoking story full of moral ambiguities and juxtaposed viewpoints making you question your own judgments of the characters and their actions.
‚Ä¢ Good interface with a minimum of unnecessary clicking and waiting.
‚Ä¢ Varied endings dependant on choices made by the player.
‚Ä¢ Interesting scenery, good voice acting, and excellent atmosphereic soundtrack.

Cons: 
‚Ä¢ Completely unnecessary gender references at various points.  It's a world full of robots... Why does there need to be a "female" robot with boob-curves, or gender binary relationship references between androgynous mechanoids?
‚Ä¢ Serious tone somewhat undermined by numerous 4th-wall jokes by  a main character.
‚Ä¢ Lots of back-tracking and occasionally preposterous leaps in logic were needed to solve puzzles.  Several times I found myself resorting to "randomly combine junk until something happens" or having to look up walkthroughs, and being utterly baffled how someone would arrive at that solution.

As stated above, I do highly recommend this game, and I enjoyed the story.  You should check it out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049680527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1542885823}
review: Definitely recommend to fans of this genre. Beautiful artwork, great sound and atmosphere with interesting characters and an engaging story in a world that made me think of the Matrix more than once. Which is a good thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001834986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1405698474}
review:
This game surprised me. I went in expecting another tedious point-n-click, but was quickly sucked into the world that is Primoridia. You play a robot named Horatio that is on a quest for the rather simple goal of finding his home's battery. What ensues is a storyline that unveils a history and lore rooted in a mixture of "God and his creation", aiming forward with questions of freewill and the role of the State within a society. All the while, Horatio simply wants his power core. 

A brilliant, rich and enticing game. It asks more questions that it answers, while playing with your imagination and leaves you wanting more from this universe. All in all, if you're looking for a game that challenges your logic and problem-solving skills, while experiencing a well-developed world and excellent cast of characters, look no further.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028159127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1374562732}
review: Great game, beautiful art style. Somewhat difficult at times but that only adds to the gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041106486', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1418493417}
review:
7/10
(I recommend this game ONLY if it is on sale)

Backgrounds full of rich details, as a subtle score carries you from scene to scene, each character I met was -interesting- and -entertaining-...ohh Primordia... you welcomed me kindly and at times I was deeply impressed with you. However, your on point dialogue and voice acting is what really convinced of the adventure.  If only other dynamics of the game followed suit.  

The story is very engaging but the ending left me a bit bored with it all.  The "action" scenes are almost comical and felt clumsy.  There were a few too many puzzles that demanded too much or required pixel hunting.  Also, there were too many key moments, the moments of the adventure that I was most excited for, that fell flat.  There were blemishes in the walking animation that I think could be easily fixed.  In the end it leaves me disappointed but memories of conversations between the lead characters, Horatio and Crispin, make me smile and feel it was all worth while.  I can easily imagine myself listening to the two of their voices participating in a radio show adventure.

I salute Wormwood Studios in their first creation and have high hopes for their next.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004766184', 'num_games_owned': 1169, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 390, 'last_played': 1403651660}
review:
This game is underrated in my opinion. If you like Point&Click Adventure games and haven't played this yet, definitely do. It has hard puzzles (sure - I might have taken a look in a walkthrough once or twice), great general geeky humor, robots, amazing voice acting (Logan Cunningham of Bastion!), beautiful pixely art style (try 640x480 on a 27" monitor, it's great). Oh and did I mention robots?
Once I started I couldn't stop playing until the early morning. But even once you're done, you're not done. There's replay value due to different ways to do the same puzzles, multiple endings and achievements you won't unlock on your first playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972146100', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 202, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1374931982}
review: This is one of the coolest games I've played. Great atmosphere, provacative story, and clever interactions with the game world, which completely immersed me. I highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035048248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1497577009}
review: A really interesting point and click adventure game that deserves a sequel. It doesnt seem to be very well known in the gaming community but its definitely worth looking in to. I love the atmosphere and the world its based in. Truely a unique sci fi game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000094900', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1486878002}
review: One of the best and most polished independent adventure games around.  If you'd told me it was an early Lucasarts game I probably would have believed you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084291565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1530943405}
review: This is probably the best point and click adventure game I have played. If you enjoy sci-fi story based games - you will love this one. The music, voice acting, puzzles, challenges were all very unique and a blast to play through. It's definitely unforgettable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996354180', 'num_games_owned': 947, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 1651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1070, 'last_played': 1491611127}
review: Primordia is quite good overall. Among its best assets are its strong sense of style and its audio.  Both the music and the voice acting are excellent.  The graphics are on the pixelated side, but totally serviceable. In fact, they, along with the overall feel of the game, harken back strongly to the old classic Beneath a Steel Sky.  The puzzles are pretty well done, with most in the mid-range of difficulty. There's really not much to complain about, and this game is an easy buy for any adventure gamer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968565253', 'num_games_owned': 1111, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 2095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2095, 'last_played': 1381277336}
review:
I liked it a lot. It's dark and grim. It's about "Horatio Nullbuilt", a somewhat stoic and secretive humanoid robot living alone in some long-stranded organic-looking airship in the middle of some barren brown desert. Humans are long gone, only machines remain, some worship them - or their legacy - in a secluded and lonesome manner as Horatio does. He has a self-built low-grade flying companion robot, "Crispin Horatiobuilt", who is an obvious sidekick, who keeps refering to himself as that and who is supposed to be a constant contrast to his builder for he is not as nearly withdrawn as him but more humorous, even on a meta-like level for example when he comments your futile efforts to do the same thing over and over and expecting different results.

There are more interesting characters to see. All kinds of machines who inhabit the few remaining places in the world. Be it a bomb from some long-past war that never detonated and which is worshipped for it is a creation of man, the remains of colossal titan robots buried deep within the desert or old human cities maintained by robots just enough not to collapse totally.

Primorida is a middle-scaled adventure for what I can tell. It has an interesting story, great characters, powerful voice acting (every character is voiced - and those robots who cannot talk bleep around in their own manner) and a significant amount of puzzling too. If I remember right I had to look up a walkthrough a few times, though I guess I was just blind on one eye for the solutions seemed reasonable afterwards. There are several endings, they all seem fitting and interesting in their way, and while the decision which you will see is made very lately in the game it is still somewhat relevant what you do mid-game. 

There is a significant amount of lore background. You will meet characters who share their stories and views on the world. You will learn more about them, their motivations and failures. There is a robot society that kinda imitates human society. It has it's own leadership and entities. However barely anything about is perfect. It is in demise, and Horatio is trying to find his way through. He is connected to the world around him more than he admits, and getting to know him better was done very well I think, from robots remembering him to data logs hidden within the places he visits. The art is nice, there are some great dark or soothing music tunes, everything seemed crafted together well and I thought I was satisfied with all aspects of the game even though it has been a long while since I've played it. Definitely the best adventure from Wadjet Eye Games I've played thus far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037559916', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1422127938}
review:
It's a cool story, It's a really cool story. Also, the difficulty is just right. Idk. I just really like games that are story-focused but aren't a B-type action movie. This one is really good if you like thinking! Like, the riddles and puzzles were interesting to solve, but not impossible to find. The main character is voiced by Bastion's narrator, Logan Cunningham, which is definitely something to look foward to. I like the fact that you don't get unnecessarily killed too, unlike Another World. Also, the pixel art is BEAUTIFUL.

Bad things? Well, it's just a story. Point and click away, nothing more. And a terminal input riddle near the end, which I liked very very much, I guess if you really like action in a videogame this isn't for you. Still gives you a thrill during the climax. This story is GOOD I tell you. Totally worth your every penny. Well, if you like the genre. Also, it's cyberpunk! How can you NOT like cyberpunk????

author: {'steamid': '76561197971078768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1608676525}
review:
A lot of things make this game brilliant. Besides being REALLY challenging and seemingly have multiple ways to solve a puzzle, it's story makes it an adventure, that is a joy to follow. The best part about it is the voice-acting and dialouge. The game is so well-written and so well told that when I started playing it, the only interruption that I allowed myself, was sleep.

The game is an exciting tale about two robots and their powercore. I would recommend it to everyone who likes point-n-click games (and even if you don't, this game might be a refreshing change of pace). It took me 10 hours to complete it, and I do not regret it!

EDIT: After having played other PnC games, I returned to this a second time. It is now my definite favorite adventure game. The atmosphere, the simplicity, the characters, and the story just makes for a grand experience, and I would recommend this for everyone who wants a good introduction for the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965689444', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 572, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 572, 'last_played': 1404265003}
review: You can beat it in a day but you'll wish you couldn't.  This takes everything that was great from the glory days of adventure games, including some stunning pixel art, and refines it to perfection.  The story is excellent, the puzzles actually make sense and are quite fun, and the characters and dialogue are wonderful.  No adventure game fan should miss this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045176730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 473, 'last_played': 1418667475}
review:
I am in love with Primordia! I found this game randomly and I am soo glad I did! Beautiful environment/sprites, engaging story, and classic point-and-click gameplay done right. This game is truly a work of art! 
I think this game gets the point-and-click puzzle/adventure aspect right in a way that many of these types of games fall short - the puzzle solving logic is straight forward and makes sense. You won't get left scratching your head, unable to move forward because of a vague goal or illogical item use to solve puzzles. Very enjoyable to play through and though I haven't finished the game just yet I can see the replay value being high considering there are multiple endings.
BONUS - The Primordia world is enhanced through the game's website: http://www.primordiagame.com/
A prequel story: http://www.primordiagame.com/fallen_complete.pdf
And an audiobook version can be listened to here: https://www.youtube.com/user/WormwoodStudiosInc/videos

I honestly don't have anything bad to say about this game. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys post-apocalyptic or dystopian tales set in a futuristic/sci-fi world with themes focusing on Robots, and retro style point-and-click puzzle games where story is the highlight of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060703168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1404958202}
review:
Is this game perfect? No. But it is one of the best games I have ever played, and definitely one of the most memorable.

The art is beautiful, voice acting is fantastic, writing is quality. I didn't skip any dialogue, this in a game with lots of dialogue! The puzzles are mostly good and some are compelling.

The only real problem with this game is the nature of a few puzzles, which stray into pixel-hunting territory or have completely non-intuitive answers of the 'click everything until something works' type.

My advice? definitely buy it, especially if it's on sale, and maybe play with a walkthrough open in another tab to avoid pixel-hunt rage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056294387', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1620059832}
review:
This was my first point and click game, and really it made me like the genre.

The story is very interesting from start to finish.  You play as Horatio Nullbuilt version 5.  A robot sort of obsessed with fixing things, building things and correcting problems.  He lives aboard his ship with his creation Crispin Horatiobuilt version 1.  They live in the middle of a wasteland aboard the UNNIIC, a crashed ship with a long lasting power source.  That and the nearby scrap gives them all they need to survive.  A problem arises when that power source is stolen from them though and they have to find a way to get it back before they run out of juice and are shut down forever.  

The story just gets more interesting from there as you meet more and more interesting, very well written I should add, characters and solve some very interesting puzzles and problems.

None of the puzzles are overly difficult, with each having a sensible solution.  Nothing like I had always heard point and click games can be, with solutions that are so removed from reality you pretty much have to have a walkthrough to beat it unless you are supremely patient.

the fact that there is several endings as well as a way to alter the best ending slightly by how you play is quite wonderful.

All told the game shouldnt take you very long.   4-5 hours give or take allowing for some time to get stuck on what to do next I think.  Shorter if you are really fast, with some replayability in terms of endings and getting the achievements.  

If you like well written stories give it a go.

Personally this rates very high with me and I look forward to whatever this dev puts out in future.  

Well worth full price in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988038335', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1601146972}
review: The interplay between Horatio and Crispin as they push deeper into this pixelated robotic realm to recover their stolen goods is a high point in an adventure that feels like a bit of a slog despite its relatively short length. Primordia never quite sold me on its experience like other some of Wadget Eye Games' more impressive releases have in the past. It's certainly worth digging into for the beautiful settings and interesting characters, but the puzzles and story don't have that satisfying hook that makes you feel like it was worth all the effort.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073967940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1497123350}
review:
UPDATE (June 2017): 
After replaying Primordia again, I have decided to keep my review as a negative one. I was simply more frustrated than I was intrigued and I found the puzzles to be exceedingly obtuse. I consider myself to be a very patient person, especially when it comes to video games and puzzles. However, I really could not get through this game. Some problems' solutions were just nonsensical and when I finally figured them out (a few took over 30 minutes of me just randomly clicking and searching), I was even more frustrated by the fact that they were supposed to be solved in that manner.

To give specific examples, [spoiler] the oil on the table that Oswald is drinking was extremely misleading. Crispin tells you that he saw oil in that area to clean the gears and that's the only oil you can actually interact with. Horatio says that Oswald won't let you take it, so it leads you to believe that you must do something to obtain it. However, you are supposed to give the gears to the shopkeeper, even though Horatio says something along the lines of, "There's no point in talking to him." It took me about half an hour to finally stumble upon the idea of giving it to the shopkeeper arm, because I had done just about everything else possible. Additionally, the floating pile of junk in the underworks that contains Oswald's chain and the Gospel of Man is hardly distinguishable from the gunk around it. It would be nice if the pile shined every few seconds or something to indicate that it's not just another collection of useless garbage in the Underworks. Or you could even have Crispin say something like "I thought I saw something shiny by the bridge where Clarity shot that husk." Also, the transmission code that you have to send to Factor "0518" was quite confusing considering you were given the code "518" and you only have a 4-digit transmitter. Of course, "0518" seems like the sensible first thing to do, but previously in the game when you were given a 3-digit code, you had to find the prefix number for it; "0XXX" would not work. My final gripe, where I stopped in this most recent playthrough, is the "Redlien" haiku in the kiosk terminal. Not only is it obscure and seemingly meaningless, Crispin's 'advice' is something similar to [i] it seemed like you could read that Redline poem in two different ways [/i], as if that helps at all. It didn't. I think I spent another 30 minutes on the "Redlien" puzzle, just rereading it and clicking on Crispin a bunch of times to no avail. [/spoiler] I eventually decided I wasn't having any fun and I should just stop. I should mention that I really enjoy the story as well as the writing. Horatio and Crispin are extremely likeable when they aren't repeating 'clues' that don't help with the puzzles. I [i] really [/i] wanted to enjoy this game; if I didn't I wouldn't have replayed it. I simply couldn't get over the confusing puzzles. Maybe I would recommend this for someone who doesn't mind reading a walkthrough every step of the way, but I just didn't have much fun playing this.

 

Original Review (June 2014):
Primordia is a point and click game that has beautiful artwork and immersive music. The story is enjoyable and I encountered zero bugs. The characters are well-developed and the occasional humor is pretty funny. Sounds awesome, right? Well, there's just one problem: I didn't have fun. As I played I felt more annoyed by the puzzles than I felt happy that I completed them. Because as soon as you fix a problem, PLOP new thing for you to fix! At first, Crispin's (your comedic companion) hints helped but when you get farther he seems to just tell you what you already know. The items you must obtain are typically in places that you wouldn't expect, and the hitboxes for them are typically small. This game just drives you to the point where you try to use every item on every object, even if it doesn't make sense, to see if that will work. I found myself sitting there trying to combine my crowbar with my memory pouch. What will that do? Nothing. But I HAD to try it because I've done everything else. And then it turns out all you had to do was something simple but there was no way you could have known about it. This game has so many amazing qualities; I wanted to like it so bad. But I just couldn't. It's just not fun. Overall, I just found this game more frustrating than satisfying. If you've got the ten bucks and you LOVE point and click puzzle adventures, go for it. You might like it. But for the average gamer, I cannot recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050219817', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 669, 'last_played': 1402807369}
review:
Muy buen juego. Es una aventura grafica al mejor estilo del Monkey Island 2, pero con varias cosas que la destaca.
Tiene varios puzzles que te hacen usar los sesos, y no son cuestion de probar todo tu inventario con todo. Ademas tiene multiples finales y, en ocaciones, se pueden seguir distintos caminos para resolver el mismo problema.
La historia me gusto mucho y los personajes en general son muy interesantes, tu compa√±ero le da un toque humoristico aunque el tono en general es bastante serio.
Lo compre bastante barato, por lo que fue una agradable sorpresa ver que tenia dialogos totalmente hablados, lo cual es raro en aventuras de este precio. Adem√°s de los dialogos, el sonido y la ambientacion son bastante buenas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998343422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1419884096}
review:
I've been playing a lot of indie point-and-clicks lately; Primordia stands out because of its writing and setting. It has a LucasArts Loom vibe to it, with the protagonist Horation NullBuilt conjuring up an idea of what Bobin Threadbare would be if he was competent and decided to use his amnesia to his advantage. Yes, both characters have amnesia, have lost their home communities, and the fabric of society quite literally rests on their creations. Elements of the story definitely seem similar. The setting of Primordia is more exciting. It's a colorful combination of dystopia, cyberpunk, and steampunk. While that mix is becoming more and more common these days, finding 'good' games in that genre is still rare.

I mentioned the writing: the story is captivating if only to explore the lore, and the main plot-arc is mediocre. The dialog writing is where the game shines; Horatio's sidekick levitating robot Crispin is a very well written NPC that integrates into the game nicely. The character is used to solve some puzzles, though not too much, and offers rather direct walkthrough-type tips if the protagonist is stuck.

With it's marvelous writing, I wanted Primordia to feature more NPCs and dialog quests. A particular stand-out quest involves a logic puzzle attempting to legally assign the surname of a pet robot. While the logic is difficult to follow without pen and paper handy, the writing and voice-acting attempts to seduce the player away from choosing the logical option and I was tempted to go down a logically-flawed path (which the game teased would result in different endings and impact late-game quests). Rarely does game-dialog inspire this anymore, and it is where indie games such as Primordia stand a cut above the rest.

The game has a relatively short playthrough and the puzzles become more difficult, sometimes to the level of ridiculousness, later in the game. This is caused by the game too early allowing me to use multiple items for different quests, and in the late game suffering through trying every permutation of item combination to solve the puzzles. Nonetheless, I would recommend this game to a casual or hardcore adventure gamer, as it is both enjoyable and tells a well-written, albeit cliche story.
