author: {'steamid': '76561198000422381', 'num_games_owned': 826, 'num_reviews': 229, 'playtime_forever': 481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 481, 'last_played': 1385721232}
review:
This game is a point and click adventure set in a post-apocalpytic world where all humans are (presumably) dead.  Although I haven't really read books or played other games on this topic, I think it does a pretty good take on the setting, enough so to spark some creative interest of my own.  The characters and full-game voicework are for the most part fairly well done but dialogue kind of falls flat in a few places, mostly because of the script writing and not because of the voice actors.  The story is fairly cohesive and events therein are weighty and interesting, but in a few places I feel like the scenes were not given -enough- weight.  This is especially true of all the alternate endings and post-game cinematics, which although included to give the player some logical options, needed a bit more fleshing out.  It is also interesting to point out, it is impossible to game over although some decisions can change your endings.

The visual aesthetic of the game is quite nice, as is the music.  While pleasant to listen to and not annoying in any way, none of the tunes were especially catchy or easily memorable, and in a few of the dramatic scenes a stronger musical touch would have gone a long way.  Sound effects are unfortunately fairly weak, lacking thematic when operating devices and having little oomph when explosions occur, and in some places the game seems bugged and plays no sound effect at all.  The voice work has a nice robotic emulation added, although some characters seem to exhibit multiple variances in recording quality or style that doesn't seem to be a character quirk.

Performance-wise the game runs fine.  Although it resizes itself and forces fullscreen (thus making dual-monitor setups a little wonky), the resolution is not a complaint.  I never had pathing issues or pixel-hunts (just me being blind).  The game interface is functional and unobtrusive, as well as autosaving.  There are some included commentaries as well in the options menu.

All in all, I really did enjoy the game despite some of its flaws.  Its not very expensive, and it's about 7 hours of gameplay for one playthrough, with low replayability.  The setting is done very nicely and the story is good, what's there to complain about is mostly some rough edges and needed spitshining.  It doesn't ruin the game at all.  I'd say pick it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964128895', 'num_games_owned': 1736, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1700519109}
review:
Primordia is a game set in a world where ‚ÄòMan‚Äô has mysteriously disappeared from the world. Man, also known as ‚ÄòThe perfect machine‚Äô were the builders from which sentient robots sprang into ‚Äòlife‚Äô. You play Horatio, a humanoid robot searching for his power core which was stolen by a ‚Äòbig robot with claws that shoots lasers‚Äô. You have a companion along the way, Crispin. He‚Äôs a cocky little robot, full of witty banter and useful advice (although, that advice can be hard to coax out of the little guy at times).

But I digress, back to the story. All I can say is, ‚ÄòWow‚Äô. Ok, so it starts a little slow, but once you start learning about you character and his past the game really opens up. Playing as ‚ÄòHoratio Nullbuilt V.5‚Äô, your character has four versions of prior history of which the data has become fragmented and corrupted. You‚Äôll meet robots along the way that seem to know you, but you haven‚Äôt much recollection of them! On top of the world that you are set exploring, this story mechanic really draws you in and makes you hungry for more. I remember thinking that if this game was a book, I‚Äôd read the hell out of it! It‚Äôd be one of those books that you can‚Äôt put down despite having to work early the next day! And in truth, I couldn‚Äôt put this game down. Thanks Wormwood Studios, my daughter finally gets to sleep, and instead of capitalising on this moment of rest that I could be having, I decide to turn on my PC and play a little more Primordia!

The music and sounds effects really help to bring this game to life. The background music can be haunting at times, and other times it can be so subtle to lift the mood of a scene that you hardly notice it has changed. The voices of the many robots that populate the world have a slight tinny, and sometimes electronic sound to them, each different from the last. Being how it‚Äôs set in a world of robots, Wormwood Studios could have simply hired the same vocal artist and applied filters to his/her voice, but they haven‚Äôt gone this route thankfully. Every robot you meet oozes personality, and the voice acting is top notch, adding real character and a human touch to these robots that were, at least in the past, touched by humanity.

Despite all the things that make Primordia such a wonderful game, there are a couple of things that bugged me whilst playing through it. The first thing is the heads up display, or HUD for short. The HUD is located at the top of the screen, and when you drag your mouse up to the top it will pop down, allowing access to the various menu‚Äôs and inventory. Sometimes it can get in the way though, as it‚Äôs not located at the upper most pixel, and sometimes when you are on the lookout for that next pick-up, or you want to exit to another area, the HUD can slide down, thus breaking the immersion ever so slightly. It‚Äôs not a deal breaker by any means, but it can be a slight annoyance at times.

The second thing that got to me the whole time was the graphics. Don‚Äôt get me wrong here, I absolutely adore the art style. This game looks great, my problem is that it could have looked amazing. This game isn‚Äôt HD, you can set the resolution higher, but you then have to apply a filter to smooth out the jaggies as the game wasn‚Äôt designed to run at high resolutions! This results in the image being a little washed out when you play full screen. This wouldn‚Äôt be as noticeable on a smaller monitor, but on my 22‚Äù screen it was a slight issue.

Gripes aside, Primordia is a polished and lively world with a great story that compels you to finish the game. Clocking in at around 4-5 hours, it‚Äôs a journey so full of history and lore that you can‚Äôt help but be fascinated by it, the world they have created is really captivating. The central character and his companion guide you through this gritty world, and even though Crispin can be a little on the sarcastic side, you become attached to all you companions, and enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982699993', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1384569672}
review:
Primordia is a well done point and click adventure game, but those new to the genre may find it frustrating and inconsistent. 

Point and click adventure games depend on their characters and setting, and Primordia delivers in both. The NPC robots who inhabit the world are all distinctive and have personality, but the real centrepieces are the two main characters. Horatio, the playable protagonist, plays the straight man to Crispin, his robot sidekick who I personally found kind of annoying. However, Crispin's sarcasm and jokes do a lot to lighten the mood established by the setting. Primordia takes place in a post-apocalyptic world inhabited entirely by robots. As a crucial and interesting element of this world, some of the robots worship humanity, who they view as their creators and the originators of the world. The world itself is interesting to look at and there are some really striking setpieces in several of the stages. I won't really discuss the story, but I will say that the "good" ending resolves much more than any of the other ones. Though you have to be careful as there are a couple decisions in the game that can lock you out of getting what seems to be the only ending that gives you some sense of closure. 

The graphics are done in a retro, psuedo-16 bit style that can occasionally make it difficult to determine which objects are in the background and which are interactive objects. Furthermore, my biggest problem with the game comes when you try to use these objects. Several times in the game you have to use Crispin to retrieve objects that are out of reach but the things he can do and the types of objects he can get aren't consistent. Sometimes he can bump things off ledges but other times he can't, sometimes he can use a keypad and other times he can't, sometimes he can fly into a pipe and get something and other times he can't. What it boils down to is trying everything you can and relying on trial and error to solve several puzzles as things that worked last time don't now for mainly arbitrary reasons.

Overall, Primordia is an interesting, well-fleshed out point and click adventure game that occasionally doesn't follow it's own rules. But if you can get past hearing "I don't think that will work" several dozen times you'll find a fascinating world filled with a host of unique characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962414275', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1372180951}
review:
Primordia is fantastic. 

This game is a must play for anyone who enjoyed the point and click adventure games of the past. If you have never tried a point and click, this is the best example of one you could ever hope to encounter.

The story was extremely well written, and the progression was perfect. You really feel like you are developing the story and game as you play, as well as learning about yourself in the process.

This game had me both happy and sad at the end of the game. I was elated to have played such a game, and devastated that it was over.

Horatio and Crispin have a life of their own, and you really couldn't ask for better leads.

If you were ever a fan of the point and click adventure games from Sierra, this game is dead on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025120603', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1418521218}
review: Based only on Primordia and Resonance, I'm on board with Wadjet Eye games being the new king of the old school point and click adventure.  Their games have felt the most like the Sierra and Lucasarts adventures I grew up on - strong puzzles, interesting characters, and a goofy sense of humor.  Primordia is shorter than I expected, but it has a surprisingly deep and engrossing story - and I love the art style.  The puzzles are actually pretty tough, but if you pay attention to the dialogue there are always hints.  So, be prepared to try every dialogue option and every combination of inventory items, and keep a pen and paper handy.  Also, save often.  There are multiple ways to solve puzzles and some of those lock you out of endings/achievements.  I have a habit of reading walkthroughs for areas after I have completed them because I like to make sure I got everything.  So I had to replay a few areas to get everything in "one" playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066984849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1385214828}

author: {'steamid': '76561197965135144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1588118032}
review:
Update 8 years later.

After having learned a great deal more about history than I knew when I originally played this, I don't think I can recommend it for its writing any more. Originally I was floored by a brilliantly optimistic vision of machines overcoming their need to serve the extinct humans and start living for themselves, but most of that was my interpretation at the time and not textual. Upon replaying recently, that theme is present, but only barely. Far more central to the entire narrative is the idea of private property being more important than any societal good it might do otherwise. I'm not going to argue that metromind is some misunderstood savior, because she's not and those kinds of delusional shitheads have certainly existed in reality, but she was written quite explicitly as a strawman of any government entity that wants to extend a social safety net to its citizens, so that the rational strong-man protagonist can triumph over her with sheer facts and logic.

The fact that one of the "good" characters you meet along the way is a law-code fetishizing, quasi-fascistic murder-hobo also says a lot about this game's worldview.

I still adore the art style of the game, and if you're the type to play games entirely to look at pretty pictures (no judgement, I do it fairly often myself) feel free to grab this because I would rank it with machinarium in terms of wonderful world-building through back-ground art.
developer_response:
Sorry your views on the game changed!

I think you might consider the possibility that your present experience is no less an act of interpretation than your earlier experience, and that your present view might not be entirely based on the text of the game.  For instance, a character who says "Mercy is malware" might not have been presented as having the right worldview, and a protagonist who ends the game by remarking that the only way for his airship to fly again was to understand that the work of fixing it was too much for "two hands" might have changed his view on private property.  

To the extent that you don't subscribe to "the death of the author," the game is about reasoning oneself out of bigotry and violence. Through logic and experience, Horatio overcomes his "core logic" of needing to destroy Metropol and the Metropolitans and learns to build and welcome the refugees from that city. But, anyway, a review is about your experience, not my intent!

And, of course, as the line goes in The Red and the Black, "Nothing could have been more absurd. Argue yourself out of being disliked?"  Bad wine ages to vinegar; good wine ages to great wine.  It's our fault, not yours, that you didn't enjoy the game the second time round.  Perhaps in 2028, you might give it another try and see if it "reads" differently.  In the meanwhile, I hope you find games that you find more congenial and can wash the bad taste of Primordia's vinegar out of your mouth!  Times are tough enough without bad games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980561918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1681131125}
review:
Normally if I were to hear about a game set in a Post-Apocalyptic wasteland I wouldn't even bat an eyelash. This type of setting has always been one that I've felt at odds with. I just can't bring myself to care about a world that is both filled with things that I hate and is not worth saving in the first place.
But...But...What about radiation? And zombies? And...And villianous paramilitaries with nonsensical goals? That stuff is really cool right!? No, no it's not. Not to me, anyway.

Primordia changed my opinion of this setting and I must say, I never thought that would be possible. For starters, there are no fucking humans. Thank God! Fantastic! To think that; in this game, the apocalypse finally does what it says on the tin! Just marvellous. You begin the game as a robot called Horatio Null-built version 5 who is going about his daily business, making repairs to his ship out on the dunes.  Suddenly he is faced with an intruder who attacks and robs him of his ship's vital energy core. Without this energy core he will eventually die, so of course this leads him on an epic quest to find the robot who robbed him and retrieve his stolen property. Along the way you explore many philosophical questions on topics ranging from religion to society to my personal favourite, the "Needs of the many. Vs. Needs of the few." argument.

If you're looking for a game that has a strong story, strong characters, challenging but logical puzzles, all set within a Post-Apocalyptic world done right, then look no further. This game is for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993984598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1355299200}
review: Groovy setting, good puzzles. The downside to having the game set in some kind of machine-run post-apocalypse is that everything is brown, which is hardly unusual nowadays but still gets irritating when you're looking for brown objects against brown backgrounds. Also, it's possible to screw yourself out of half the endings pretty early on in the game, which sucks a bit. Despite that, it's a good adventure game, but Resonance is better (also a Wadjet Eye game).

review: Primoridia is an amazing game; it is a point and click adventure/puzzle game.  The story is very easily immersive, and as the game progresses you struggle as you learn more about yourself and the sick twisted machine world that you reside in.  Thurst into a machine wasteland, the main character Horatio Nullbuilt searches for a power cell that was stolen from his ship.  If you like sci-fi ish games and also somewhat of a challenging yet fun adventure, then you will love this game!  It is easily one of the best games I have ever played, and it left me craving more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036186446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1558870581}
review:
Certainly one of the best point and click Adventures I've played since the nineties!* Both immersive and humerous. The story is Great and told extremely well. the art style is very appealing combining art nouveau and cyberpunk proves a valid design concept, the resolution ould be a tad bit higher tho and animations are a bit of a let down but that's a flaw of many games in the genre.
Gameplay is fluid, controlls and leveldesign are sensible, avoiding frustration. Riddles range from realtively easy tasks to complex and hard enigmas, without lowering to the level of odd/alien/generic minigames or resulting in daylong meditations on what to do. Unlike most P&Cs with inventory, Primordias items are neither randomly taken from the environment(aka taking the banana instead of the wench) nor require absurd combinations, most "crating" tasks are sensible. 
The Help function is a bit wonky, it's hints range from being very specific to being nomore than a slight nudge in the right direction and there are no "advice levels" or "search functions". there is no hotspot highlighter, which may be seen both ways. You will have to think a bit to get this game done but it's very well solvable without any outside help** or random clicking.
It's also fully*** voiced, and quite good if I may add.

Ps: Unniic, Genius!

*Probably THE best if you dismiss myst 4 as not a point and click game
**I required it once, when I was standing infront of the hotspot. The hotspot was even named "crystal"   -.-
***The is one spot(info booth) where I would have liked an additional voiceover, something Myst 4 did: voice all written text.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983536968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1384242598}
review: A nice little point and click adventure title. Suffers from the same click on everything, combine everything until you figure out the answer problems all PAC games. The story is neat, the voice acting is great and the art style is quite nice (even if low rez so i recomend playing it in window mode by running the \steamapps\common\Primordia\winsetup.exe). The hints system was well implemented so I'd give it a 3/5. Worth <$10 if you enjoy this sort of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014244484', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1408067994}
review: With gorgeously rendered pixel art, tight voice acting and dialogue, and a story that starts fiendishly simple and mutates into something more in careful pace with the narrative, Primordia is a definite must-play that touches on posthumanism, identity, religion, old vs new, and so much more. With a ridiculously number of possible endings and engaging puzzles in true point-and-click adventure 'what the hell kind of combo was that' style, it's a short but involving experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019745707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1974, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1603, 'last_played': 1388907127}
review:
I haven't been this happy since Grim Fandango. It's a 16-bit point-and-click adventure (in the play style of Curse of Monkey Island) in sepia tones. The game is fully voice acted, and it's the least annoying voice acting ever. The lead is voiced by Logan Cunningham, the guy who narrated Bastion, and the other characters and voices thus far have been FANTASTIC. 

At one point, I had to set the mouse aside to get pencil and paper out because a pair of indignant robots wanted me to settle a legal dispute, but not until after proving my worthiness by solving a logical story problem. 

Basically I have spent six times as much money on games that were one tenth as engaging and wonderful. I don't know why this game isn't blowing up my friends list already, but hey, now you know.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044563479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1383605662}
review:
Primordia is a real gem. Well-written story, lore and characters.
Great puzzles force the player to think about the solutions and try different approaches.
The only thing I didn't like about it was the occasional need for pixelhunting; a "highlight hotspots" button would have been nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045354004', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1542173953}
review: Amazing Story, it flows perfectly. This game's visuals and asetics are great, the hand-drawn art style (the way the make the sprites is literally using like MSP and taking the hand drawn art and crushing it using resize) fits perfectly with tones ands settings of the game. The game perfectly blends moods and themes with comical and engaging lines. The voice work is top notch, i mean you should sold to buying this game at hearing Logan Cunningham (Bastion's Narrator, Rucks) is the main character: Horatio. As well Crispin your AI compadre is an amazing character and in many ways reminds me of a very familarlly close friend of mine, in voice and attitude, and honestly the main character pings also feel similar to between me and my friend so this game resonated to me on an extra level. Its short but commendable for its size and the developers. I reccomend this to anyone who enjoys a good story, some thinking, and enjoy 16-bit level pixel art, which on that mention the game comes in one pretty small resolution but its to preserve the visual quality of the art so its easily overlooked.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054153027', 'num_games_owned': 665, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1797, 'last_played': 1379305115}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993028863', 'num_games_owned': 539, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1390930664}
review:
If you showed me this game and told me that some guy with a time machine brought it from 1994, the golden age of adventure games, I wouldn't question it. Well, maybe the time machine part. For all I know you could have found it in a bargain bin or at Goodwill or something. Maybe your uncle's game collection.

My point is that this is a game that looks and feels and sounds and plays exactly like the best of the genre 20 years ago. Anyone who is fond of classic point-and-click games will like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027063308', 'num_games_owned': 722, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1529847512}
review:
Best game i've played since Machinarium!

Just buy this game.  This game is perfect.  All of the dialogue is narrated beautifully.  The characters are unique and interesting.  The last time I talked to EverFaithful (not a spoiler I swear. Early in the game) I wanted to cry. I might get a tattoo of him.  
The art is mindblowingly good.  The story is unique, interesting,  and well written.  I freaking love this game.  It's like a really good book.  As soon as you're done you want to read it again. You can't wait until it's been so long you can't quite remember it and know you can read it again and kind of get that same feeling with a bit of nostalgia.  That's this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970542767', 'num_games_owned': 1789, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 483, 'last_played': 1355126400}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018351149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 488, 'last_played': 1417337322}
review: Excellent adventure game in a very interesting and atmospheric dystopian future where robots rule the remains of earth, or rather try to survive in them. Awesome and well written characters who maintain the balance between the dark atmosphere of the desolate world around them and a robot's take on humour. Also, some really nice references to Fallout and others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031651888', 'num_games_owned': 798, 'num_reviews': 441, 'playtime_forever': 662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1417116039}
review:
Un autre jeu de Wadjet Eye, du m√™me calibre que Resonance ou Gemini Rue. Celui-ci se d√©roule dans un monde o√π les humains n'existent plus et seuls les robots survivent, √† d√©faut de vivre. Nous incarnons l'androide Horiato accompagn√© du petit robot volant Crispin (cr√©√© par Horiato) et tout commence quand un vilain gros robot vient nous voler notre source d'√©nergie.

Comme les autres jeux de Wadjet Eye, Primordia propose plusieurs fins. Il parait m√™me qu'il y a plusieurs mani√®res de r√©soudre les √©nigmes (ne l'ayant fait qu'une fois, je n'ai pas pu le constater par moi-m√™me).

Le background se d√©couvre au fur et √† mesure et est tr√®s tr√®s riche. Le ton est plut√¥t s√©rieux, mais Crispin vient rajouter de bonnes notes d'humour (vraiment marrant, ce robot).

Les voix sont de tr√®s bonnes facture et comme d'habitude, le g√©n√©rique de fin est accompagn√© d'une tr√®s belle musique.

Je le recommande aux amateurs de point'n click non rebut√©s par des graphismes old school (pixelis√©s).

review: Decent point-and-click story. It's about on par with the early Space Quest games. There are a couple different story paths translating to different endings, but some may be hidden if you fail early objectives. A solid adventure, but nothing riveting.

review: One of the best adventure I ever played ! It's graphics are simply beatiful, the story is deep, and allow different game paths, with different endings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040545381', 'num_games_owned': 829, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 598, 'last_played': 1381334491}
review:
'Primordia' had a story so good, I had to come back and play it again to see some of the other endings. Many of the most thought-provoking events make references to issues that have kept me awake before. It's interesting to experience a game that has me thinking about it for a time after the ending credits.

There are some audio issues after using Steam's overlay UI, but the game's pretty polished aside from that glitch. The puzzles are good, but the world is a little empty. However, the animated characters are entertaining and keep things interesting. The artwork and voiceover work is also amazing.

If you want a good story that's told with a classic style point-and-click adventure game, then this is it.
developer_response: Thanks!

review: This is a realy fun indie game. there's no cambat, but it can really get under your skin... A must have for someone who likes puzzles and critical thinking games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108803380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1411321655}
review: This is a great story-driven game set in the distant future, where man is but a distant memory. This game has a dark story lightened somewhat by realistic and funny banter between the two main characters. If you like puzzle games, or any games that make you think, play this. It is an amazing game that can't be missed!

author: {'steamid': '76561198082689223', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1381281326}
review: This game was utterly and completely fantastic from start to finish.  From characters to plot, setting to even the oppresive atmosphere of your surroundings, it was done flawlessly.  Fans of old school point-and-click adventure games will feel rejuvenated, and newcomers to that lost genre of old will be held in awe.  If you choose only one indie game to randomly pick up off Steam, make SURE you you get Primordia!!

review: Interesting story, the atmosphere is great/music well suited, voice acting is top notch, characters are cool (love that ever-faithfull dude, awesome scripting) & the puzzles are logical/just about right in terms of difficulty, good idea to have a few different ending too. Overall I really enjoyed this game & definitely recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994728746', 'num_games_owned': 1024, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 920, 'last_played': 1379616033}
review:
Very good adventure game with top-notch voice acting, great atmospheric setting, beautiful music and interesting story. The only downside is that there is not much to explore, the whole world is rather small, and 1 or 2 puzzles were pretty hard. Luckily there is your sidekick - Crispin, who will give you a small hint sometimes, and he's a very funny character too, reminds me of Wheatley from Portal 2 a lot. 
There are also several distinct endings. 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197972226499', 'num_games_owned': 821, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1379224991}
review: This game is awesome. Really intelligently written.The auther said he took inspiration from Fallout and Planescape: Torment, and it shows. There's a few nicely done call backs to those games too. If you're in the mood for a good story and some puzzle solving to go with it, I strongly recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000264284', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1598242196}
review:
I've never been an extremely huge fan of point-and-click puzzle games, but Primordia caught my attention, initially due to the attractive art style and the story teaser. So I gave it a try, and was blown away by how much I absolutely enjoyed it. It's your standard point-and-click; you collect items, open your inventory, and can combine items or use them on characters or objects in the world to progress. So there's little to mess up when it comes to controls, and Primordia succeeds there. 
The game is set some ambiguous number of years in the future. The world is inhabited by robots, no sign of organic life anywhere. You play as Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot designed to build and repair. While aboard your ship, the Uniic, you are attacked by a strange robot and stripped of your ship's power core. Left without transportation and limited power keeping you running, you are left with no other option but to wander out into the world, trying to track down a power source, or as a last resort, enter the city of Metropol, "the city of glass and light." Not much is known about Metropol, other than there is supposedly unlimited power for everyone. Still, Horatio has his reserves about entering the city; despite his logic-driven robot nature, he doesn't trust the place.
As I mentioned, the art style was much of what first intrigued me, and it's prevalent throughout the game. It's designed to look very old-school and pixelated, but the amount of detail that can be projected by so few pixels is astounding, not to mention the general apocalyptic dystopian feel it gives off, which as a fan of Fallout, I enjoyed all too much. 
Overall this was one of those games that gave me that feel of reading a really good book; I'd sit down and play and not want to put it down until I found out what happened next. The only problems I had were a few vague or confusing puzzles, in which I had to resort to the old "try everything with everything on everything" play method common to point-and-click games. Aside from that, the game offers multiple endings, some far more underwhelming than others, which left me feeling a tad unsatisfied. Still, the game was extremely enjoyable, and one of the few games that I'd almost like to forget playing so I could enjoy it all over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976237743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 125, 'playtime_forever': 1186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1571086602}
review:
An amazingly atmospheric game with beautiful music, superb voiceacting and old adventure game inspried graphic style.

It's interesting to note that some of the 'sidequests' are entirely optional, but usually help you out, or give you some backstory about the world or characters. 

Luckily, the puzzles are all managable and logical (Very fitting), and when you do get stuck, you can always use the in-game hint system to jolt your brain. 

My first playthrough took about 8 hours to finish, and I'm sure that I might get a different experience if I make different choices on subsequent playthroughs, which i fully intend to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056290009', 'num_games_owned': 3905, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 833, 'last_played': 1417054175}
review: One of the best indie games released in 2012 and a treat for fans of the adventure genre. Everything, from the captivating plot to the beautiful graphics, is excellently done. The Puzzles offer a lot of variety, the soundtrack is fitting, the voice-acting outstanding, the characters are likable and the exceptionally well-written dialogue couldn't have been better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997036304', 'num_games_owned': 3184, 'num_reviews': 455, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1417023916}
review:
Again, a very in-deph game and with a reflection of Gemini Rue with a missing memory as part of it. I should one day get around to seeing all multiple endings as I'd like to know how you can complete the game with all robots and so on.

Edit: The story is set on an Earth far in the future where humans are such a distant memory that robots view humans as some kind of a god-like beings complete with a bible that teaches robots that mankind is "A perfect machine from the heavens that built them in it's own image" and so on. You even get quizzed on this to get a bomb from a old military robot that's guarding them.

The start of the game you play as Horatio Null-built who even built his own little sarcastic companion who can help out in reaching items and such that are out of reach. Horatio is building a ship to take off from this planet where energy is scarce and he had just discovered a energy core, but a robot comes and steals it, taking it back to this city that Horatio has to investigate to find out where the item has gone.

I do love how all the robots have a surname based on who build them and because Horatio has amnesia, he doesn't remember who built him, but his companion's surname is "Horatio-built" and there's even a case where you have to solve a dispute between two who have fallen out and each wishes to name the robot they created together and take full ownership of him.

As you can guess, the oldest and rarest of machines are named "Man-built" because they were built by humans and had most-likely seen and interacted with humans when they were still on the planet that is now a giant polluted trash-pile. Another great hit from one of my favourite game developer/publisher Wadjet Eye Games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972103428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1417602705}
review: Sorta a kings quest game.  Point click inventory.  But the plot is really good.  A couple intesting little moments but I really liked it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036818867', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 678, 'last_played': 1417064998}
review: I found out about this game a couple days ago on the RPG Codex. I'm not a big fan of adventure games but I've played a few and enjoyed them greatly such as The Longest Journey and Syberia. I am, however, a big fan of good storytelling and in that aspect this game gets a perfect score. One can tell that a lot of love and attention to detail went into making this game: beautiful environments and wonderful music that fits and creates great atmosphere. There are different ways you can go about solving the puzzles. The main character is really interesting, the different themes are well developed and there are no clear good and evil cliches. The game is very reminescent of Planescape: Torment in terms of themes, music, atmosphere, and interesting character and sidekicks. I highly recommend this game, very very beautiful, you will be touched especially at the end. Perfect score 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197966916859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1378613776}
review:
Great storytelling in a post apocalyptic adventure.  I loved the soundtrack and mood this game induced in me.

It suffers a little with ridiculous puzzle syndrome, but nothing a guide can't help to put you on the right track.

If you like old school point n click adventure games this one deserves your attention.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990711996', 'num_games_owned': 1753, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 326, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 325, 'last_played': 1386777135}

author: {'steamid': '76561198053908804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 828, 'last_played': 1378652445}
review: Pretty much everything I ever wanted in a point and click game - witty dialouge, lovable characters, a feeling of discovery uncovering an intriguing story. The puzzles are quite well-balanced IMO, just maybe a bit on the pixelly side so you might end up missing hotspots to click (they do have the words pop up when you mouseover hotspots to help with that)

author: {'steamid': '76561197977620684', 'num_games_owned': 1519, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1558993860}
review: Great post-apocalyptic robot thingy quest. Something like Machinarium.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077105674', 'num_games_owned': 847, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 567, 'last_played': 1382556260}
review: A fantastic, fantastic point-click adventure game. Anybody who loves games with post-apocalyptic settings will enjoy this game. Good characters, interesting story, brilliant voice-acting and excellent artwork. I can't recommend this more, easily one of my favourite games to date.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996848142', 'num_games_owned': 1026, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 774, 'last_played': 1453059292}
review:
Oh, Primordia, what a marvelous creation you are.
It's an adventure game about robots in a post apocalyptic world, where human life has ceased to be. The game takes us on a journey trough the desolated land, on which we meet a great cast of characters and learn more about the past, how robots think and what the future may hold for the world. Loved every moment, some of the puzzles were devious and had multiple solutions. The way you solve them also affects the overall plot and ending.

In short - 
Primordia is an incredible point & click adventure game and one of the best in the genre.
The story, voice acting. art style, world, characters. Just everything in it was so captivating.

I wish we've got another point & click adventure game from this developer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982052706', 'num_games_owned': 5379, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1378205007}
review: Das ist OldScool! Grafik wie auf alten Sega Spielen! Interessante Geschichte ich hatte viel Spass beim Spielen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008872166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1379626926}
review: An incredible adventure game, Primordia offers a unique setting, interesting plot, likeable and various characters and obviously clever puzzles. A must play, not only for adventure fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011388211', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1418468030}
review:
If you love graphic adventures like I do, you cannot miss this game. Good story, great dialogues, humor, and a very interesting view on the science-faith debate. They could have done something better for what concerns the animations, but it definitely doesn't ruin the experience.

Graphic adventure. Sci-fi. Humor. Interesting view on a controversial topic. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995189004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1375859454}
review: Fantastic plot, witty dialogue and beautiful artistic scenes. One of my favourite games this year.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984483737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1378083844}
review:
What happened to the humans?

Set in a post-apocalyptic world strewn with cast-off machines, Primordia tells the story of Horatio Nullbuilt, a stoic robot who values his solitude and independence. Horatio spends his days studying the Book of Man, sparring with his droid companion Crispin, and tinkering with the airship they call home ‚Äî a peaceful existence that becomes threatened when a rogue robot steals the energy source that the pair needs to survive. (Developed by Wormwood Studios)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025122943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1355817600}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993223432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1553451300}

Highly recommended to adventure game fans.
developer_response: Thanks... eight years late, but better thank never. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197984313865', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1474526787}
review: Point and click and I flat love it. Best enviroment and atmosphere I have seen in a long time. I even went as far as buying the soundtrack off Amazon I suggest it as well. If you like dark trancy techno of the deep poetic future sort...

author: {'steamid': '76561197986511953', 'num_games_owned': 781, 'num_reviews': 311, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1409131900}
review:
Primordia is a modern point and click game. It draws parallels to classic games in the genre, and it's aesthetic greatly reminds me of the game "Dark Seed". It takes place in a post apocalpytic world where humans have gone extinct. The main character is an android named Horatio who undergoes a quest that leads him to discovering his origins and why the world ultimately ended.

It's a nice enough game in general, and it's engine reminds me quite a lot of Scumm. Of course it's not a particularly difficult game, and without prior interest in the genre it will just collect dust on your harddrive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002540254', 'num_games_owned': 2697, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1418714621}
review: A fantastic (and difficult) old-fashion point & click adventure. Clever puzzles, good voice acting, and an interesting post-apocalyptic world. Well worth your time if you enjoy the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970361977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 425, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1377306880}
review: Good adventure game with a unique story. Never needed a walkthrough so the puzzles are pretty logical.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996794965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 575, 'last_played': 1381004886}
review:
You should play Primordia.  That is, if you‚Äôre interested in well written characters that represent larger themes of Religion, Politics, Justice, and what happens after the Apocalypse.  It‚Äôs hard to sum up here, and it‚Äôs hard to take in while you‚Äôre playing (because you want some things expanded on).  There‚Äôs a lot of substance packed into this short game.  

Stylistically it‚Äôs a lot like an old adventure game ‚ÄúBeneath a Steel Sky.‚Äù  However Primordia adds on all the powerful themes I mentioned above.  Truly Fascinating.  Very memorable characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999565345', 'num_games_owned': 926, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 298, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1453053766}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042206553', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1009, 'last_played': 1459052284}

author: {'steamid': '76561198033101690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1376460758}
review:
Like Indie games?

Like Point and click adventures?

LOVE deep in-depth amazingly built worlds and stories?

THIS is the game for you.

Though short and and very VERY tough, this game fulfills the best of the three things stated above. It totally sucked me in, very immersive world, with lots of dialog options.
Plenty of humor involved too.

The RPG mechanic of the game is great too, the amount of dedication required to achieve specific endings is HUGE.

I give this game a 10/10. Definitely worth the 10 dollars.

P.S. If you happen to pick this game up, talk to Crispin and as many people as possible, and try to remember just about EVERYTHING you hear. You never know when what, or knowledge will come in handy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004751663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1410007296}
review: This is simply an amazing story, with beautifully drawn artworks and well produced narration. Worst part about it was that it ended. Absolutley loved this game. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044602606', 'num_games_owned': 7479, 'num_reviews': 542, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1417206250}
review: Finished Primordia. I think there are a few things I didnt uncover or explore, but overall, I feel I got a good playing experience with the game. As with all point and click adventures, there were some frustrating moments trying to figure out where I missed something, but it was still quite a bit of fun. The story was pretty cool overall. The graphics were nice enough, and there were plenty of quirky and comical moments. Definitely a good game...not a 5 star effort, but definitely 3.5 or 4 stars for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995123637', 'num_games_owned': 421, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 340, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1527456531}
review: A well made adventure game with an awesome story and setting. Great art, great voice acting, great music.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014766672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 398, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1375614980}
review:
This is one of the best adventure games I've played in a long time. The story is great, which in my book, separates ok adventures from great ones. The graphics leave a lot to be desired, but the story is great, the interplay between the the main characters is awesome and the puzzles are fun and challenging. Did I mention the voice acting is really good? Not many games leave me wishing for more, but this was one of them. I'm also hoping for a some sort of sequel!

Check out more reviews on: http://completingthebacklog.blogspot.co.uk/

author: {'steamid': '76561198066299742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1418856120}
review: Superb point and click adventure. Interesting and beautiful world, the story is good and the puzzles are all logical and make sense. there are multiple ways to solve problems and several different endings. Certain puzzles/problems can be irreversibly failed, forcing you to find different solutions and in some cases altering the story/ending. If you like adventure games, buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966366813', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1374956592}
review: Harkening back to old school SCUMM games. Primordia taps into the Steampunk side and let's you experience a strange world that seems oddly familiar. If you enjoy point and click, you need to give this a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983060770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1374424898}
review: Primordia √® prima di tutto un grande omaggio alla storia del genere punta e clicca. Fin dalla scelta di utilizzare l'interfaccia a scomparsa nella parte alta dello schermo, tipica di alcune vecchie glorie (ne cito una su tutte, Gabriel Knight - SIns of the Fathers) fino a scegliere una risoluzione "vintage" di 640x480. Ma Primordia √® anche una bellissima avventura, ambientata in un mondo cyberpunk dove l'uomo √® ormai solo storia da raccontare. Un gioco con una trama interessante, uno stile grafico forse non davvero originale ma efficace, dialoghi sempre intelligenti, voice acting di altissimo livello, bellissime musiche, enigmi che forse non sono mai davvero difficili, per√≤ logici e coerenti con l'ambiente e le varie situazioni. Ancora non vi basta ? Allora vi dico possibilit√† di risolvere alcuni enigmi in pi√π di un modo, finali multipli, achievements e cloud saving. Che state aspettando ? Se vi piace il genere sar√† un piacere giocarlo, come lo √® stato per me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010465516', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 746, 'last_played': 1374578595}
review: I think this game is awesome; a really well made Indie Adventure title. Reminiscent of 90's PC adventure games, Primordia is a 'point and click' game in which you must use skills of logical deduction, puzzle solving, listening and recall to complete all tasks and find all usable objects. I really like the tone created by the graphics, artwork/scenery, soundtrack and dialogue; I quite liked Horatio and Crispin as protagonists, too. The game has backstory that ties into the plot nicely, and I didn't find it overly expansive or tedious. The world in the game is quite small, but its an appropriate fit for the length of the story and the style of gameplay. I highly recommend this, its a beautiful little game. *****

author: {'steamid': '76561197980770933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 657, 'last_played': 1418965461}
review:
Words cannot express the deep and thoughtful world that Primordia is. Unless for some reason, you hate ‚Äì and I mean, truly, with burning fire, HATE ‚Äì point and click adventure games, you owe it to yourself to play this game.

As dark as the world can seem, humor abounds in this game. The simple graphics are still beautifully rendered, and the characters you meet are ones who will climb inside your head, and stay for the long haul. With a cast of incredibly well realized and acted robots, the world doesn't just invite you in; it sucks you down, and makes you a part of it. Things in this game will be thought about days, weeks later. Enough cannot be said for how immersive this game is.

As unfortunate and bleak as the world of Primordia may seem, it has many things I wish to see again. Perhaps, if enough people play Primordia, some day we can all go back together.

2017 Update: Still thinking about this game. Still both horrified by and in love with it. Miss ya Horatio.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046288510', 'num_games_owned': 1970, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1945, 'last_played': 1707150771}
review:
An awesome poetic game about life, death, and robots.

A fabulous story about Humanity, faith, justice and hope.

A quest to return home with friends, to fly away having built a new world, a better one.

Primordia is about what is primordial, and what is but Horatio and Crispin's Humanity ?

Not flesh, but mind ? Not power, but friendship ?

author: {'steamid': '76561198055057709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 289, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1374456272}
review:
I'll admit, I do have a soft spot for stories that involve robots, but it's been a while since I've experienced a good one. Primordia is based in the days long after mankind left this world - which is now a brown, rusting, and barren planet that appears to harbor no life outside of small insects.

The puzzles are very VERY number heavy (and I kinda suck at puzzles), so I'll admit to using a walkthrough on many parts. Hey, I just wanted to get to the sweet sweet story.

Great game and I love the characters and concept.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027990253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 436, 'last_played': 1355299200}
review:
Adventure Game mit einem sehr sch√∂nen Retro look

ist seinen preis auf jedenfall wert

author: {'steamid': '76561198018778902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1437229361}
review: Primordia offers a compelling story which entwines the mystery of the disappearance of man, the corroption of the great machine city of Metropol, and the recovery of a stolen power core. Horatio Nullbuilt and his companion Crispin are an endearing pair, made all the more so by fantastic voicework. Although the puzzles can be difficult at times, with a solid walkthrough, Primordia is a tale worth experiencing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078503582', 'num_games_owned': 2735, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 75, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1417267779}
review:
Golden age of point-and-click / text adventures might be gone, but this title brings you back to early 90's, when greatest classics were born. Primordia is pure 2D pixely adventure with unique art style, gripping story that will leave you thinking, great voiceacting (Logan Cunningham - Bastion) and atmosphere of dystopian future emanating from every single pixel. It should be noted that it shares couple of similarities with Beneath a Steel Sky, another great experience.

Any fan of classic point-n-clickery can't go wrong with this one, as it is one of the best in its genre available on Steam. However it might be a little bit too short if you follow only the most straightforward path and forget to explore the backstory, explore details and solve few optional puzzles.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999832775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 769, 'last_played': 1451914168}
review: It's like Blackwell, except with harder puzzles, robots, wasteland and insanely good SF story. Make sure you do all the endings and achievements to catch the full story (yes, most achievements contribute to what happen during the good endings).

author: {'steamid': '76561197967307161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 426, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1372434082}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971050010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1417451381}
review:
Primordia is a puzzle adventure game where you follow the story, collect items and solve puzzles to progress.

I really like the story, which is set in the future in a city of robots. I won't mention much else since I don't want to give away the story. 

Just know if you like these style of games, then Primordia should be on your wishlist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041934875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1372248046}
review:
Not a fan of point and click puzzles thus i had to rely on a walkthrough for the most part. However the storytelling, voice acting and the soundtrack are utterly superb. I really enjoyed the post apocalyptic- ....steampunk(robots okay) feel. The pixelated graphics complimented the game really well. Interesting gameplay and i have to say that i love the fact that I can fail at parts of the game. What i really love about this game is the notable effort of detail. For example -POSSIBLE SPOILER- the bus breaks down and if you travel below the courthouse you can see a sad robot, that you can talk to, waiting for the bus that never comes and he doesn't contribute anything to the major plot but he is just there :( .

GET IT, BITCHES.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002028253', 'num_games_owned': 1675, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 792, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1428220230}
review:
Great point`n`click adventure game with awesome story and funny dialogues! If u love puzzles, dont mind the point and click style and ur not looking for graphics, this game is for u! 
Once again Wadjet Eye team made me go for 100% achievements like I did with Blackwell Deception, another game I enjoyed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065488139', 'num_games_owned': 1120, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1500404055}
review: This is a really entertaining and well written classic point and click adventure game. Set in a dystopian world where all humans have died years ago, you play as a robot and his sidekick trying to recover a stolen power core. The puzzles are pretty intuitive and not too frustrating (like many adventure games are for me). It's very cyberpunkish  with retro 16-bit graphics. It's also very reminicent of Beneath a Steel Sky, one of my favorite adventure games which is now freeware.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028443764', 'num_games_owned': 1292, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1417185791}

review:

review:

Apesar do visual desnecessariamente pixelado (n√£o √© como se o jogo se esfor√ßasse a simular uma experi√™ncia retr√¥), suas cores predominantemente terroras em contraste com suas luzes azuis produz uma est√©tica particularmente agrad√°vel. author: {'steamid': '76561197968545232', 'num_games_owned': 738, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1373191808}
review: Great game. Would have been a classic in the point and click era. Themes are akin to Beneath a Steel Sky, but the puzzles are far more logical. Characters are vibrant and likable (although one in particular may be somewhat verbose). Writing is fantastic, and makes it another gem from Wadjet Eye's offerings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000836250', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1370325933}
review:
The best point and click adventure I've ever played.
an engaging story with exceptional dialogue, amazingly unique and beautiful art style incredibly well thought out puzzles that force you to pull out the ol' pen and paper.

10/10 well worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044662288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1369862145}
review: This is the type of game that falls under classifications; "point and click", "puzzle solving", but for about 95% of my playthrough, I was engaged and immersed. Even to where at one moment I stopped and found myself wishing it was a movie instead. It's a sarcastic drama, that deals with heavy topics, causing you to stop, think and problem solve. But also holds on to a clever side that lightens the mood and feels at home within the tale. 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051962093', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1527377476}
review: This was a great game with plenty of riddles that you will scratch your head over. Increadable plot, ending, and charectors. This is one of my favorite games i have ever played through. I beat it twice ahd hope to play more. Something i liked was that how it ended realy relyed on you. I felt like my decisions mattered. There were a cuple things you could do differently just to see what happened. You realy came to love the characters and hope for their well being and throughout the game as hidden lines unfolded the game just got that much better. If you are thinking about adding this title to your libary you totally should.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079858222', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1448650418}
review: A flawless game that leaves you hungry for more, this really is a magnificent indie game that oozes with a completely absorbing cyberpunk atmosphere. Great plot, great characters, often moving, the usual puzzling moments of point and click adventures that are executed very well, charming retro 90s-style adventure graphics, excellent overall design and a beautiful Vangelis-style soundtrack......This game is an absolute must for both fans of great point and dlick adventures and grim, atmospheric cyberpunk science fiction. I could happily play this over and over again and not get bored...

author: {'steamid': '76561198025529387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1369574625}
review: One of the better adventure games I've played. The puzzles generally make sense, the story's interesting enough to keep your attention and it's got Abe Goldfarb in it. A few gripes: There are some bits where it's not clear that you can travel further to the side of particular scenes (which stumped me for a while), and there are some items you need to pick up that are pretty hard to see, but the worst is that there are some things you can fail to do (or do incorrectly) that will lock you out of some of the content. But those are pretty minor. Even if you do miss the optional bits, you still get most of it and it's impossible to get stuck in an unwinnable state. This is definitely an example of how adventure games should be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992936998', 'num_games_owned': 2887, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1367132400}

author: {'steamid': '76561198000207862', 'num_games_owned': 312, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1367218800}
review:
Primordia is an independently developed point-and-click game with lots of character, atmosphere, and overall well constructed in its apocalyptic scenario. Humans are long gone; some robots think they are figments of imagination, others revere them for creating them, and others just don‚Äôt give a shit. A flying metal burrito with a laser pointer takes Horatio‚Äôs power core and he ain‚Äôt gonna take no shit from some fuck ‚Äì so he follows the trail of metal burrito to the last thriving city, a city of robots, ran by a hivemind that doesn‚Äôt take shit from no one.
I had taken 6 hours to play through it; however it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm a bitch and used a walkthrough. Going through without a guide would provide several more hours than what I have listed.
Get this, it‚Äôs fun and you will enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973181104', 'num_games_owned': 506, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1366873200}

review:
Nettes Point&Click-Adventure. Hat ein bi√üchen was von Beneath A Steel Sky, obwohl weniger umfangreich. Die Grafiken scheinen handgezeichnet zu sein...ein Jammer, dass sie nicht h√∂her aufgel√∂st sind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025566272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 552, 'last_played': 1361606400}
review:
Primordia is a must for anyone who is a fan of old-school point & click adventures. 

The tale follows robot Horatio and his floating companion Crispin as they try to retrieve a power core stolen from them by a boxy robot with lasers in a post-apocalyptic style world - however, the story is much more than this basic premise. One of the central questions the player wants answered is what exactly happened to the humans who presumably once inhabited this Earth and created the robots left behind. Added to this is a tapestry of moral and philosopical themes such as the meaning and existence of free will, individuality, progress, and what constitutes the 'greater good'. These sometimes rather heavy themes are pulled off through excellent writing, and are offset by a quirky humour that runs through the whole game. This off-beat humour and occasional breaking of the fourth wall are reminiscent of some of my favourite, genuinely old-school games such as Simon the Sorcerer, and I think anyone who was playing this kind of thing in the early 90's will appreciate it. The worldbuilding and background detail is fantastic - my one gripe is that the game just doesn't go far enough. There are hints of exciting other locations that we don't get to visit, and the larger philosophical themes are never fully explored. 

As this is a game and not just a visual novel, I should probably mention a bit about the gameplay - it's pretty much standard of point & click games, and uses the traditional inventory system. Nothing stood out as unique, but equally nothing was inconvenient or jarring. The puzzles are not particularly challenging, and there's plenty of hints on hand from Crispin if one chooses to press him for them (it's also pretty fun to hear him getting annoyed and snarky when you try and use him too many times). I prefer simpler puzzles so the flow of the story doesn't stall, but others might find this game too easy. 

In terms of visuals, the pixel art is gorgeous, and the colour palette of browns, rusts and muted golds perfectly realizes the dusty, disued world. The audio content is also great, from the music to the voice acting. Even minor characters are voiced, and the robot voice effects are pretty cool.

Overall an 9/10 for this game. The presentation is beautiful both visually and aurally, and beneath this is a solid story rooted in a world that feels like it really could be our future. Horatio and Crispin are likeable and memorable characters to journey through this tale with, and their easy banter creates the emotional anchor to this crumbling planet. Points are lost for the sense that the game could have been bigger both in terms of the number of locations, and the philosophical ideas that never seem to be explored quite as far as you hope. Regardless, 'Primordia' is highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042590045', 'num_games_owned': 479, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1362297600}
review: Nice and old-school but with extra apocalypse.  The inventory system is clunky and they have that horrible 'looking for interactable objects' type problems, but the puzzles are generally old-school with a few extra logic and dialogue puzzles (I had to get out a notepad and pen to work out one code cobination).  Lots of alternate endings depending on whether you managed to accomplish certain things during the game as well as according to your choices at the end, so I'll be playing through again at some point.   Doesn't play well with steam though; don't try to use the in-game chat or otherwise disrupt the program whilst it's running or it will turn glitchy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045517966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 740, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 740, 'last_played': 1361779200}

review: Beautifully done, despite being made with pixels. These aren't the pixels of old, though, and the highly detailed backgrounds and characters will pull you in. Multiple endings, a rich world history and mythology, hours of replay, and the low cost makes it a great deal.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990162989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1360742400}
review:
Good point and click adventure, in some ways it's a bit like Beneath a Steel Sky. It's like the classic point and click adventures and doesn't dumb itself down either, so you can get stuck figuring out exactly what the hell you're supposed to do, exactly how these games should be. 

If you do get stuck, you can speak to your sidekick for clues without giving too much away.

review:
Do you like point 'n click adventure?
Do you like post-human/post-apocalypse settings?

If so then this game will push all your buttons. It is quite an interesting world that was built. The puzzles are challenging but not impossible. There are multiple ways to solve many of them and different solutions will change the endings.

It really is a great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077744760', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1502473688}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003546387', 'num_games_owned': 893, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1360224000}
review:
I didn't play too many adventure games back in the day: Monkey Island, King's & Police Quests, a bit of Full Throttle, and Deja Vu, Shadowgate and Rise of the Dragon on consoles - but Primordia is one of the best I've ever played.

Somewhat short, but packed with interesting puzzles, multiple endings and solutions and incredible dialogue, Primordia kept me rivetted for days and despite my best intentions, sent me packing to GameFAQs more than once.  If you like adventure games, you owe it to yourself to give this a spin.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981494710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1449506371}
review: Wow. Aus "kurz Mal reinschnuppern" wurden pl√∂tzlich 199 Minuten. Wer Englisch kann, eine gute Story in einer post-humanistischen Welt genie√üen will und dabei nicht vor 90er Pixelgrafik zur√ºckschreckt, der sollte zugreifen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030839450', 'num_games_owned': 730, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1686, 'last_played': 1358323200}
review: This is indeed a one of a kind game worth buying, My dog bought me this game and I haven't regret it since.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974500703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1511068611}
review:
This is a point and click game with fantastic atmosphere, a well designed world and  they've really put a lot of thought into making puzzles that aren't just "use item x on object y".

One note; if you're ever stuck because you want to use an item on something out of reach, use it on Crispin to ask him to do it for you. Or just click Crispin anyway, he's the in-game hint system, just don't do it too often or he'll get snarky.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987760619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1704908829}
review: Excellent

author: {'steamid': '76561198024583914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1356940800}
review: Short (10-12hr), but good. If you're wanting a pure adventure game (think King's Quest) it's worth a look. Story is serious, but the sidekick and gamer inside jokes keep it from getting down. Only real complaint is you can't change the resolution, which is a shame because the graphics would be amazing at a higher res. They have a demo on the company site if you want to try it first.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983250285', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 542, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 447, 'last_played': 1450801742}
review:
All Horatio ever wanted was his power core back...

This is the best adventure game I've played in a decade. The robopocalypse has never been this atmospheric, or bleak, or beautiful, or funny ALL AT THE SAME TIME. Also: Primordia is mercifully devoid of bullshit adventure game logic, there are multiple approaches to puzzles, it's got alternate endings and even has a commentary track. Get this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046505969', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1373872301}

review: Probably the second most atmospheric adventure game this year (right after The Walking Dead). A must buy for Bladerunner fans and not only.
